This game feels like its from a bygone age, one where Microsoft and Xbox were putting up a fight (and maybe even winning) against Sony in the Console Wars. Its great.

An entertaining linear story mode at around 5-6 hours (on Normal mode), though for maximum enjoyment you should have played or at least seen a recap of Space Marine 1. (And/or understanding Warhammer 40K lore)

A 3 man Co-op "Operations" mode that sees you play as your own different Marines that you can customize head to toe (from 6 different classes) and go on missions with other aspiring recruits/players trying to level up and score better gear.

Though at the moment there are only 6 missions to complete. They mostly feel good to play through, and multiple runs are needed to upgrade and level up your Space Marine.

(This is also the live-service, seasonal part of the game so expect content updates unless something completely unexpected happens).

There is also a very fun but very dry no nonsense PVP akin to old COD lobbies but without the vulgarities, racism, and probably no no-scopes (yet).

Hope the devs update this "Eternal War" mode as well cause there is some good building blocks to work with.

Combat is very fun, consisting of dodges and parries to outmaneuver and counterattack the enemy respectively.

Not too much to learn other than the timings of parries/dodges and melee combos of each weapon but the chaotic horde-style gameplay will still sometimes give you problems even if you have mastered the intricate art of murdering other Alien lifeforms.

8.5/10 or 9/10 if you are already a fan of 40K.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine II, is an alien murder machine simulator developed by Saber Interactive and published by those guys that made their fortune making cycling simulators.

On the planet Kedaku, a Deathwatch Killteam is sent in to deploy a virus bomb to, at the very least, slow down the Tyranid hordes ravaging the planet. Demetrian Titus, former Ultramarine and current Ordos Xenos clean up crew member, is heavily injured after a battle with a Carnifex. He is saved, however, by his former Chapter, and Titus is reinstated as Lieutenant of the Ultramarine’s 2nd Company.
Also, his Killteam all died. They seemed nice.

Now, having undergone the Rubicon procedure, Titus is now one of those Space Marines that are taller than normal Space Marines, but their armor isn’t as cool so it always kind of feels wrong. He, along with squad members Chairon and Gadriel (not to be confused with that elf lady from The Lord of the Rings: Galadriel), Titus does battle with the Tyranid swarms as he and his men discover now and terrible secrets in a star system at war.

Some people waited thirteen years for this game, I was one of them. Space Marine II is practically a continuation of the first game with some new and cool features added on. No longer being restrained on the 360 and PS3, Space Marine II does a great job actually capturing the scale and numbers of a Tyranid invasion of a planet.

Space Marine II, like the first one, is a third person shooter revolving around shooting aliens in the face and then tearing them apart with whatever beating stick you have on hand. There are a variety of weapons to choose from such as, the Bolt rifle, the other Bolt Rifle, the longer bolt rifle, the bolt rifle but with a better scope, the one that shoots plasma, the melta gun that feels like you’re pushing your hand through a ball of wet socks when you use it. And also a bunch of melee weapons like: The knife the side of my entire body, a chainsword so I can stab you while I’m stabbing you, the power sword which is like a regular sword but also cuts thing gooder, and the big hammer you use because your message wasn’t clear enough when the chainsword was being used.

Its a neat mix of Gears of War shooting and hack and slash action. Dumping an entire magazine of bolt rounds into a swarm of Tyranids and then laying into them with whatever melee weapon you have on hand is the bread and butter of the game play, and its a pretty good bread and butter. Its like the first game where you turn grots and Orks into Swiss cheese, but now theres a ♥♥♥♥ ton more Tyranids than there were Orks in the first game, and slicing through them in swathes is basically dopamine injected straight into my brain.

There are also larger, angrier, hornier Tyranids that accompany the swarms. Warriors are the most common, but you do occasionally have to deal with other variants like the Lictor, a stealthy bastard, and the Carniex, a big bastard.
Zoanthropes are there too, but who cares.

Mission variety is mostly just trying to stem the tide of alien bugs, either by blowing them up good or deploying something that upsets them. But there’s some intrigue in the story, enough to keep you hooked with the plot, like a big reveal that I can’t mention.

Chaos is there, Tzeentch flavored this time. That’s not a spoiler, they’re in the promotional material. That’s not the big reveal, though.

Outside of the story mode, you also have two multiplayer modes to keep you coming back. Operations is a 3 player Co-Op mode where you and two of your Space Marine pals do stuff that helps Titus and the 2nd Company, as well as the Cadian 8th and any other Imperial butt hole in the system, deal with the invaders and send them packing. Its an interesting mode, almost reminds me of Left 4 Dead sometimes, its really fun to play, just make sure you have 2 other pals to play with or else an NPC follows you around and that’s lame.

The OTHER other mode is PVP, the Eternal War is an 8 vs 8 man murder mode where the Primaris Astartes do battle with the Heretic Astartes, the Chaos Space Marines, the LEGIONES TRAITORIS.
You have several classes to pick from, the same ones you pick in Operations, and then go to town on one another, either trying to kill 50 of them before they kill 50 of you or holding objectives until the timer runs out or the meter fills up.

Its a goofy, fun, chaotic time, but its also frustrating at points. It feels like kind of an after thought in a way. And the name of the game seems to be grouping up and melting the other guys via focused fire before they can melt you. You can do some clever things every now and then with your class abilities, but it mostly comes down to who sees who first and who pulls the trigger faster.

I like the game a lot, solid 8/10 for me, there’s just some things that irk me the wrong way. A lot of the weapons feel undertuned. I feel like when a weapon is basically “The one you start with, but bigger.” it should feel like it. I think a Tyranid Warrior, the ranged ones, once took 20 some rounds of bolter to the face before even being stunned.
The Boltguns in general also feel weak, I mean that in a game feel kind of way, not in a balance way, it does have problems balance wise, but. The way it sounds just sounds weak to me.

The Bolter in the first game was mean, it sounded like someone was punching the side of a car door really hard. The Bolt Rifle however may as well be making a “pew pew” sound.

Also, please put more attention into the PVP. I don’t know exactly how to fix it, maybe new maps and random spawns or fine tune the weapon a bit better? It feels like an afterthought since it was in the first game, which it might have been.

Yeah I like it a lot.

Space Marine II does a good job in capturing that fantasy of being a giant, 8ft tall meat mountain murder machine in a messed up super future. Your steps are big and stompy, and everything you hit with any kind of weapon just turns into a fountain of blood. Tyranids coming at you in the hundreds and literally climbing over one another like a tidal wave to get up a wall is amazing to see.

Warhammer 40,000 is such a weird franchise to me, mostly just because of where it stands as a series. Its a tabletop War game with a lot of extended universe material like books, comics, and y’know, video games.

Having been a Necron Player for the last 20 years or so, because I like winning and Terminator kicks ass, I got to see the war game I love fluctuate and change, introducing new people, sometimes for the better, sometimes for the worse.

40K is the only War Game I know where a good chunk of the fanbase actively refuses to play it. Even a lot of the other material is -mostly- ignored in favor of just reading summaries on wikis around the internet. Warpath and Mutant Chronicles probably don’t have this problem, and you probably don’t even know what those are.
And if you do, hey! We should play sometime.

Its a series that people want to change, mostly for the worse. Its also a series that people are way too invested in, and not even from a financial point of view. This endless war on the internet about what 40k should and shouldn’t be is, hilariously enough, sort of indicative of the franchise as a whole. An endless battle between people that don’t actually want a common ground, they just want to be in charge.

Its still very near and dear to my heart, but there’s probably going to come a time in the future where I might just have to move on. Mostly because of corporate ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but if my friends are all gone, I may as well go too.

Game's very good, not sure why people are complaining about some epic thing needed for crossplay. Performance can be iffy at times and some people can't even play, so there's definitely issues with it so far, but otherwise I have no complaints!

I really like the game. I do wish the campaign offered more of a sense of progression and customization and rewards for completing missions in it other than just knowing you did so plus the accompanying achievement on whatever platform you might be playing the game. That aside, the first couple missions of the campaign I did were pretty fun and then I started doing Operations and never really felt a desire to go back to campaign.

In Operations, you get 6 different classes to play as and level up, with their own perks and 3 loadouts for each class to choose what weapons you want to bring into a mission. You'll be able to swap to any of those loadouts during various predetermined points in the mission and even if you don't want to change loadouts, you can at least use it to reload your ammo. Even if you fail an Operation, you get credit for each part of it you completed, and awarded some xp based on how far into it you got before you all died. If you win, obviously you get the normal amount awarded for completing that tier of difficulty and even more if you find a Gene Seed on the map during your run and whoever is carrying it doesn't die before the end of the Op. If you find a Gene Seed, be warned that you can't also carry a Guardian Relic-the item you can find on maps that can be used to revive yourself if you get downed. Scattered around the maps can be crates that can be smashed and often hold anything from ammo packs to med kits to the different types of grenades: shock, frag, krak (sticky), and melta bombs.

The xp you get for completing the Operation goes not just to your class of Space Marine, but your weapons used as well. Any class able to use the same weapons as another will benefit from that weapon xp and unlocks as well, meaning you can spend all your time with a chainsword on one class and switch to another at level 1, but still use the higher tier chainsword you unlocked with the higher level class. Once you level up a weapon, you get a Mastery Point to use to unlock a perk on the weapon. The more versions of that weapon you master, the more points you get to spend on perks that further upgrade any version of that weapon you use. Ranged weapons and melee weapons can each have at least 1 other version you can craft that works a little bit differently in combat once you unlock the 2nd tier of weapons. Melee weapons can often also have a different version that offers a block instead of a parry (at least judging by the description in game and how it's seemed to function so far). For example, I just got to the 3rd tier of weapons and made a force sword that hits nearly twice as hard as the one I was using before, but it's speed is at least 3 times slower according to the stats, and you can definitely feel it in combat. Even if it looks like there's only about a dozen or so different weapons in the game, you will be able to make a decent amount of different kinds that play quite differently from each other to keep the combat feeling fresh even beyond having 6 different classes and therefore 6 abilities to choose from.

I've mainly been playing the Bulwark class cause I liked the sword and shield combo it offered at first, but over time have really grown to love not only how powerful it's shield is (can block sniper fire-sure it staggers me, but i don't take any damage) but how good it's ability it. It can be upgraded to not only revive downed allies, but fully restore Contested Health of any allies within it's radius when used, plus deal damage over time to enemies within it's area of effect. Contested Health is HP you can recover if you deal damage within a short amount of time (or get a finisher) and it quickly fades over time, but again, the Bulwark can get a perk that slows that rate by 50%. There's currently no medic or dedicated healer class in the game, but the Bulwark is the next best thing for now and it's honestly not a bad substitute. My main gripe with it is there's a perk it can get that drops a shock grenade when it's armor pops, but that shock grenade also damages me when it drops. Not my allies-just me, it seems. I hope/assume it's a bug and not the intended design, because it can really get you into trouble at low health.

The Operations themselves are supposed to be unlocked alongside the main story as you play thru it, but I chose to just play my way thru the first 4 before I stopped and definitely not because I lost that one. Each one I played was not only pretty different from the others in terms of what was being done during the mission, but a decent 20-40 minutes in length depending on how things play out and how mean it wants to be to you. It can get pretty difficult at times, especially going from tier 2 to tier 3 in the levels of difficulty. I haven't tried the final tier/level of difficulty yet, but I can only imagine how much more difficult it gets. Just going to tier 2 "average" difficulty, there was a noticeable spike in how hard it was, plus how much less stuff there was and how much less the health kits restored-speaking of, you no longer dropped in with a free med kit from average difficulty on up. The higher difficulties are definitely more rewarding to play, though. Not just in terms of xp and extra coins, but how fun and brutally hard they can be and how satisfying it can be to survive waves and encounters in it.

The coins you get from completing Operations successfully and from playing pvp matches can be spent on unlocking new cosmetics for your Space Marines as well as new weapons for them to use to gain more mastery points for weapon perks. They're also used for unlocking perks on each of your 6 classes, so you'll probably be going thru a lot of them. Fortunately you can also get up to 75 coins per class if you complete each of their trials-they're little tutorials on how to better play as each class since each class plays so differently from each other.

I tried a couple matches of the pvp with a friend and while I thoroughly lost both of them-especially the first one-I had a lot of fun and want to play more of it. It feels kind of like third person Halo Reach multiplayer with more melee focused combat. You definitely have more of a chance to tank some shots than something like Call of Duty, but you and enemies aren't bullet sponges. It feels very fair in how they approached it as well. From what little I saw, it seems like you have your own progression system for pvp and you unlock more weapons to use in it. Even if you lose, you get xp based on what you do and if you do well, you're still rewarded for it. How do you "do well" things as simple as healing a teammate with the Bulwark's ability, assists, and of course kills, but also objectives, avenging allies-basically all the things that would get you those medals in Halo multiplayer would go towards giving you xp.

With only 6 Operations and 3 pvp modes, I was worried the game wouldn't have enough content to keep me interested for a while because I was expecting something more like their WWZ game where the main story missions basically were the main operations you did and then they had horde mode as another mode you could play-but I really think they structured things in such a way that it will offer a decent amount of replayability and keep enough people interested for long enough to feel like it was worth their money even if they decide to not finish the main campaign.

That said, I think starting things off with a forced campaign tutorial and then wanting you to play the first campaign mission before unlocking the first Operation was a bad decision. They should have dumped you straight onto the battle barge and let you at least do the first Operation and saved the whole forced tutorial and "play a mission to unlock an Operation" mechanic for after your first Operation rather than doing it the other way around. ---

An excellent game with some performance issues on lower-end pc's (I'm still rocking a 1080Ti because GPUs are stupid expensive still).

Pros:
- This game *nails* the 40k aesthetic and environment better than any game before it - even Darktide.
- 3 game modes on launch. Even if Eternal War has some server issues, having more options on launch is good. Operations will get fleshed out further based on roadmap being posted by devs, so there'll be even more content to dig through later.
- Combat feels pretty good! The default control scheme on mouse and keyboard is a little whack, but you get used to it (or you can change it). Only thing is you *will* get animation trapped sometimes. It just happens.
- Visceral executions are a delight to watch

Cons:
- Story is fine I guess, any complaints I have are spoilers.
- Enemy variety is a little low.
- The AI for your two squadmates in solo-Campaign are *not* okay. They suck ass. Will frequently not target enemies, not execute stunned enemies, will not target enemies attacking objectives, sometimes won't even res you if you go down. Play with friends, or play on Easy (game doesn't have achievements for beating campaign on set difficulties, just for beating campaign at all) because playing on the hardest difficulty without friends has a few very acute pain points in the story. Otherwise, game isn't actually that hard.
- Eternal War (PvP) mode is total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Time to kill is way too short, and there seems to be no rails on who you can get match-making into. So if you're a new guy into the PvP mode, you can get matched with people with all - and I mean *all* - the unlocked gear and get totally ♥♥♥♥ on until you catch up. Which can take a while, given you're getting ♥♥♥♥ on. This mode needs a rework, ASAP.
- The pay to get early access was scummy. Wish companies would stop this ♥♥♥♥.
- Performance issues; I've got an AMD Ryzen 7 3700X, 16GB of RAM, and a 1080Ti. Game runs well enough but has some serious hangups once in a while even on Low settings. Possibly just lag from people joining/leaving sessions, but it's hard to tell if it's my hardware or the network. I'm overdue for an upgrade, so this might be an entirely *me* problem.
- Solo queueing into Operations is a similar annoyance in lack of team cohesion that solo-ing into LFD2 or *any* co-op PvE will bring you. People will run ahead, ignoring enemies, letting teammates die, just to try and run the level as fast as possible. Annoying as ♥♥♥♥, as it always is.


Looking forward to more content down the road!

The campaign of Space Marine 2 is pure cinema, peak masculinity, but in the raw, honorable sense, not the forced "feelings" of modern (S o n y) entertainment. It is a worthy successor to the original Space Marine staying true to the true Warhammer 40k spirit, from the grimdark aesthetics and sharp dialogue to the visceral combat and unforgettable catchphrases, this game is steeped in the essence of the 40k universe. It definitively passes the vibe check.

There is no weakness here, no false sentiment, only the unyielding strength of the Adeptus Astartes. This is no charade of emotion from the weakling masses of modern Terra.

This sequel does honor to its predecessor, as any true son of Guilliman honors the gene-seed of his primarch. The game is the very essence of the 40k made manifest.

While fighting through Tyranid swarms, you witness Cadian squadrons holding the line against an unending tide of enemies. These moments offer a powerful sense of scale, while you may be the protagonist, you're just one cog in the massive war machine of the Imperium. The game does an excellent job showcasing the Imperium’s many parts, from the Astra Militarum and their discipline shouting Cadia stands while being charge by a swarm of gaunts, the Admech with their arrogance, disdain for the flesh and their many rituals to please the Machine Spirit to the zealous and fanatic Ecclesiarchy and, of course, the ever-present bureaucratic nightmare of the Administratum.

On the performance side, Space Marine 2 handles remarkably well, even when the screen is full with enemies and chaos. The fluidity helps maintain immersion, ensuring that you never lose sight of the epic scale and intensity of the battles and the scale of the conflict.

The companion AI, while functional, can be a bit off sometimes, often leaving enemies stunned without finishing them off. If you're not there to clean up after them, those enemies will recover and come back into the fight.

The co-op features are well-implemented, allowing you to seamlessly join your friends sessions via Steam or using an invite code. While playing with random players works fine, there are occasional slowdowns due to the lengthy loading screens when joining or leaving sessions. This could definitely be better as it can get a bit annoying.

Writing a review for non-Warhammer fans, so if you're into Warhammer, I'll just say that this game will probably scratch whatever itch you've got. Go for it. The game was literally made for you.

If, however, you're not somebody who's into playing as a tacky-looking action figure, fighting against barely-legally-distinct xenomorphs, then I'd like to give an honest review after my short time with the game to help you get a bit more of an idea.

Ranged weapon variety? Forget it. You, at time of writing, basically have four major options - some form of 'bolter' (every gun that fires bullets is a bolter, I guess?) that are all more or less very same-feeling, a 'melta' (fire shotgun), some plasma weapons that all differ very slightly from one another, and then sniper rifles. They all get the job done, but none of them feel particularly satisfying. Animation-wise, a lot of the larger enemies don't react to shots whatsoever, so these weapons don't feel particularly 'punchy.' I'd give the actual shooting experience in the game something like a 4/10 - clunky controls, weird aiming system (which is justified by the hybrid ranged/melee control scheme, but that doesn't make it any less weird and clunky) and a lack of visual feedback often just makes you feel like your guns aren't doing much, even if they are.

Melee weapons? That's the good part of this game. Many melee weapons, all with unique combos to learn and enjoy, and individualized strengths even though they, theoretically, should all pretty much do the same thing. They cooked here. 9/10 melee system, very good. Lots of focus on countering and dodges, or knowing how to pull off combos without getting your health bar torn apart.

General aesthetics? Look, I get it, some people adore Warhammer and Space Marines, but like... they're ugly. Horribly ugly. Like something a middle schooler would draw in the back of a notebook while they're not paying attention in math class. To make things worse, the game has you earn cosmetics - perfectly fine on its own! - and the cosmetics will be... a laughably tiny change. "Congratulations, your reward for completing 40 different 30 minute long missions is - we put a strip of paper on your pauldron!" Again, I'm sure this is something meaningful for the crowd that happily throws away thousands of dollars and hundreds of hours on figures of these guys, but for somebody who isn't all that into it... it's just a strip of paper with a seal. Not a very good reward. Your best aesthetic customization is going to be in colors, and there you have more room to work with, but at the heart of your look you'll always be the same, really ugly action figure.

TL:DR - if you have friends who are obsessed with Warhammer, this is a pretty decent game to play with them even if you have no interest in the setting. Puts Darktide to shame, but that's not exactly hard to do.

The games very good, especially the campaign. It is masterfully crafted with well written characters where every single NPC feels alive and have a personality (their little conversations are quite interesting) and the environment is extremely immersive as well, with very detailed structures and biomes.

PvE and PvP are quite fun as well.

Overall its a great game!
(If you enjoy Warhammer 40,000, then you'll probably enjoy the campaign as well)

Campaign:
Great Cinematic experience, better with friends, very cool.
Only low point I can think of are the "Rats" section of the 2nd mission and some downtime sections from the "Cave" mission.

PvP:
It's ok, a bit death-bally and significantly less emphasis on Melee in my short experience with it.
I didn't have much interest in it before and quickly lost interest in it, so I haven't played a lot of rounds nor grind each classes to unlock their other, more interesting weapons.

(Co-)Operations:
Only having 6 missions on launch is terrible, -Tide games and World War Z had more on launch in the past and needed more content.

It is early, but the balance seemed all over the place.
At the higher difficulties, there are fewer resources and sometimes placement of Ammo Crates, it felt similar to the tactical survival experience of Back 4 Blood, World War Z, and maybe like playing Remnant 2 with a non-S/ A-Tier build but instead using a sub-optimal life-leech build.

Regardless of the difficulty, missions have RNG aspects to it such as the mid-level events requiring 1-6 sub-objectives to complete.

You have to ration your ammo in specific parts of certain missions and try to use the environment and equipment you find as optimally as possible (explosive barrels, explosive flowers, and level gimmicks such as the fire wall at the end of the first mission).

Enemies becomes bullet spongy at higher difficulties and are more numerous, with less resources spawning, and Medicae Stims healing less HP. Different weapon types seem to have different effectiveness vs specific enemies. Running away to the next airlock/ elevator to despawn enemies behind you is cheesy but effective.

Perk and class balance seemed to be all over the place, but I need to play more to be sure, and there seems to be some bugs or hidden effects (Bulwark fully-healing after using Loadout change pods and their banner phasing through the lift in a mission).
Examples for balance stuff:
- Certain classes have ammo generation perks later on in their class (or weapon perk line) which seems to be a mandatory pick compared to the other options;
- Bulwark's Level 8 perk restores max contested health for squadmates in the AoE, allowing you to partially/ fully heal when combined with an enemy execution/ finisher, and the level 23 perk shares this with squadmates anywhere, which substantially reduces the need for healing items (and again, seems like a mandatory pick compared to the other options);
- Weapons with high damage per shot that can hit multiple enemies can heal past contested health (e.g. Melta Rifle, Las Fusil, etc).

Also you use the same currency to buy weapons, class perks, and Space Marine Chapter Customization and you always feel poor while progressing initially, with some classes having more expensive weapons (e.g. Assault). You also need to grind each class and weapons types.

Additionally, trying to get an Armory Data to unlock the next tier of weapons for the first time will be tougher than usual as you need to play the higher tier with previous tier weapons.

Basing this off of the singleplayer campaign, I'd give this game a neutral review if I could, I enjoyed some parts of it and some parts not so much. First off the game does look and sound amazing and does Warhammer 40,000 every bit of justice it possibly can, there's tons of detail everywhere and the environments and scale of the enemy hordes are seriously impressive. And it's not just a cosmetics thing, you can see the swarms climbing walls and such and you can destroy them. The basic combat once you get used to the parry and dodge system works pretty well and the weapons feel like they all have a use; I tried to use most of the weapons I picked up during my playthrough and there were few straight up upgrades, more like sidegrades.

The structure of the missions is very linear and there's generally very few things to find apart from audio logs. At the start of the game it felt like you got obstructed very often, I kept walking into invisible walls, but I think the game opens up later on more and the midway part of the campaign had the best mission variety. Sadly I think the campaign falls off towards the end, but other than that, I mostly had a good time. I wish the jetpacks would have been used more in missions.

Now onto the things I didn't like; the whole campaign seems designed more for co-op play than singleplayer. The AI teammates are generally very bad at covering you while doing objectives (+ they cannot do objectives themselves), and you'll regularily get pinned down by ranged enemies all the time, so in every encounter you have to hyperfocus the ranged enemies down first because the AI won't be doing that. At first I started the campaign on Veteran difficulty and I found it to be too annoying to complete with the AI so I switched to Normal after a couple missions and had a much better time. But still the squad AI could really be better, the game should offer a more balanced singleplayer experience.

Also (potential spoilers warning), the campaign isn't very long, I finished it in just about 11 hours, while generally taking my sweet time to explore as well. Towards the end it's like they forgot the beginning of the invasion (Tyranids) completely and the ending felt very cliche and Disney like. I did like that they introduced more enemies later on and I'm a fan of different than usual Chaos factions being represented but it felt like there should have been more story missions across all the planets. I know there's the Operations mode and Eternal War, and I expect that'll add a lot more playtime, but the main campaign felt quite short.

The game ran well on my laptop with an i9 13980 HX, 32 GB RAM and Nvidia 4090 RTX 16 GB; on 2560x1600 resolution I could play it on high settings with ultra textures (without any upscaling), getting between 60-80 FPS. Some of the larger fights dipped as low as 50 but not below that. I'll probably test how it runs at 4K later on but I'd expect it to require some DLSS at least.

I didn't like that the game has no support for aspect ratios other than 16:9, so at 16:10 I had constant black bars on my screen all the time and it should really be fixed as it's a standard feature in PC games. Also, there was no support for inverted horizontal camera controls for gamepad, so I couldn't play it on gamepad since I use fully inverted controls (both vertical + horizontal) in all games I play; another thing that should be fixed and added to options. Had to learn to play on keyboard & mouse instead :p

TL;DR:
Solid gameplay; nice WH40K aesthetic; poor AI and mission design more for co-op; short campaign that falls off towards the end; some annoying missing technical features

The game is tough, brutal and has some really visceral combat. If you love Warhammer 40k and enjoyed the first you will absolutely love the second game. The scale has been impressive it feels like fighting huge zergs of enemies and if you play as Co-op you will have a blast with friends.

Having just finished the game i am of two minds about it:

The Good: It builds on the first game and does a great job of making you feel like a space marine. Your powerful and hit like a truck, it is friendly to the lore and brings the world of 40k to life. I have seen some reviews talking about the first half of the game being the worst part and i have to disagree. The first half of the game defending worlds from tyranids is amazing and exciting. And now here is where the bad comes in:

The second half of the game feels like a rehash of the first game. It feels like they just wanted to have you fight chaos for pretty much no reason other than you did it in the first game. This is a issue as it left me wanting more, you just seemingly wipe the nids and chase chaos and to me this was boring. When they showed there would be three worlds to fight on i was expecting a long story where i am jumping from world to world dealing with its attackers and i feel this is what saber should have done. It should have been you fighting the nids on one world whilst chaos attacks another and a 3rd faction the other and then have them merge. But instead its simply hey you seemingly dealt with the nids now go fight chaos for the last act.

Overall i recommend it if you are a fan of 40k or the first game as it does fill the need of 40k fun and that fun from the first game. Just dont expect it to fill you at the current moment roughly 2 days of playing and i have finished the story on veteran i expected more saber. Hopefully a DLC will come out with more missions

The latest 40k game that got tons of positive reviews before it was even released. It tells the story of how three and a half ultramarines defeated just a few million tyrranids and chaos followers. Again attached lobotomized psyker, chaos-thermo-lord-wizard, references to Lord of the Rings and, unlike the first part, not fapable IG girl.
This game, apparently, enough money, so we have:
The scenery in the game is exactly three kinds again: ruins in swamps, city, cemetery in the ruins. The only glimmer of light at the very end: the ruins of cemetery in a warp anomaly.
Enemies are also of three types: tyranids, chaosites, and demon. Though for each type are drawn special, pathos-busting animations of knocking out heresy.
Weapons compared to the tabletop redesigned just to the point of impossibility: from melta made shotgun, from laska sniper, from stormbolter dull machine gun, and from the jumping satchel evil machine unstoppable imba. And they didn't let me dabble in heavy weapons

1)The game presents genetically enhanced superhuman warriors as ordinary overgrown men in sealed lats.
2)Almost the entire game, while in the combat zone, the protagonists walk around without helmets (Strictly forbidden by the Codex Astartes). The phrase of the captain (!) of the Ultramarines (!!!) addressed to the sergeant “Why do you take the Codex Astartes so seriously?” is tantamount to breaking the oath of some Creed regiment.
3)The aforementioned captain, fighting with weapons the average SM would be ashamed of, in armor less flashy than the sergeant next to him.
4)Royals in bushes the size of a necron tomb.

However, in general, game came out not bad and even much more lore-friendly than 3rd DoW

Упомянутый капитан, воюющий с оружием, которого постыдился бы и обычный десантник, в доспехе менее пафосном чем у сержанта рядом.
Рояли в кустах размером с упомянутый титан.
Впрочем, в целом игрушка вышла неплохая и даже куда более бэковая, чем ДоВ 3.

I played through it solo on Veteran, my initial experience was a bit Luke-warm with the first few missions but it didn't take long for me to get more into it, especially since the campaign gets better as you progress it, early missions have this more frequent re-occurring issue that is present when you're playing solo, where certain segments feel like they're not meant for you to be on your own with the two AI partners that share a singular brain cell, such as for an example having to use a flame thrower to push back a swarm of tiny lil' insects whilst dealing with lots of ranged enemies and having to complete some objectives, problem is, the flamer takes you primary weapon away so all you're down to is your pistol for ranged enemies plus enemies in solo mode tend to focus more on the solo player than the two AI partners, so these situations can feel a bit bad . However , this starts becoming less so of a problem at the mid point of the campaign where it starts feeling like they put some more thought into making it more enjoyable when playing solo. The campaign as a whole is really damn good by the end, apart from some stumbles in design where it can very much feel like it's a Co-Op campaign with an optional solo mode from time to time, it's epic, doesn't over stay its welcome , ends on a pretty satisfying note with a spectacular final act fight that was incredibly kick a**.




Just like in SM1's it's just 6v6 across 3 maps and 3 game modes, Annihilation (TDM), Seize Ground(Domination) and a KOTH-like mode with 6 classes . So it's light on the map variety but offers more variety than SM1 in terms of game play styles with more classes of which each one now has a unique ability to use, a frontal shield for the devastator heavy, a AoE chapter banner that heal's people armour from the Bulwark class or brief invisibility for the sniper and so forth.

So far have dug into it a fair bit, melee is a notibly weaker compared to SM1's PvP, this is potentially partially due to the lag problems of SM1's not offering extra protection for lag-teleporting assault marines who due to SM1's bad netcode would often just ignore half of the damage you threw at em'.
The game is also more team depended now, certain classes work together really well, the Bulwark is a shield guy with a power sword, his shield can absorb all ranged damage and surprisingly he can do it forever basically unless he gets hit from behind and then to boot he can deploy an AoE armor regen for everyone , so when you combine him with the heavy devastator class you got a combo that can deal with ranged and CQC targets very well , covering each others weaknesses and offering an armor heal from the bulwark and a frontal shield from the heavy devastator to keep each other in the fight.

It's not that bad at all , matter of fact i am oddly addicted to the PvP, there are some balancing quirks such as the Bulwark turtle players but nothing too extreme to ruin it fully.

However i do wish they did more with it, i wish it was 12v12 perhaps instead of 6v6, i wish the Chaos Marines could be properly customised, unlike loyalists the chaos boys just get preset colours and armor and that's it, the in-deph customization is completely lacking and missing for them.

Also levelling in it works in a way that you just get a higher number on your report card, you also unlock new weapons and winning X amount of matches gets you new armour cosmetics, which also can be earned in Co-Op mode. There are no perks, no means to change attachment or flat out upgrade your weapons in PvP, those things exist in co-op but are absent here and that's honestly for the better, it means there's no perks one can unlock to give unfair advantages over others as in SM1 and since gear is equal there's no max level guy who has a bolter that does 6x more damage than yours, those all exists still but are just for the co-op strike missions where you have light rpg elements in which you get to further fine tune,upgrade and buff up your class and weapons.




Think of it like doing Left 4 Dead campaigns that you just keep replaying for fun but also in this case to level up, earn new gear or get your current gear to become stronger, because it's not just your class that levels up and unlocks various perks and nodes you can purchase to upgrade your character but also your weapons get stronger too, unlocking stronger versions with even new cosmetics to boot to showcase that they are better.

You play as one of the two other squads in the game that under-take missions whilst TITUs and his team are doing their own thing. Though here the game does become gear n level depended, going to the hardest setting early on will just get you destroyed, since you're expected to play the lower difficulties first to get better gear and more upgrades for your class. It's an enjoyable chaotic romp, thought progress for gear can be a bit slow and higher difficulties above average tends to yield somewhat too spongy enemies even with high-end gear.

The core game here is great. The enemy variety leaves a little to be desired, interface slightly clunky, and the side missions are (so far) inconsistent.

I am starting to hate the way they've tied health and armor systems into melee. Especially on higher difficulties it's just not feasible to regain health in certain fights.

Additionally the TE-style red/blue rings for dodges and parrys ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ suck. It feels like a duck tape solution to their wanting to implement dark souls-esque timing requiments while filling the screen with swarms of enemies. It becomes and annoying indecipherable mess.

Oh and the ammo replenishment mechanics do not work in boss fights that physically yank your camera away to LOOK AT BIRD when your trying to replenish ammo.

Good 40k game, but there's a lot of jank getting in the way of a great overall experience.

7/10

Astounding game with an amazingly enjoyable and very well put together campaign. I don't often write reviews but this one definitely deserves every single thumbs up it can get. Thank you Saber Interactive & Focus Entertainment, you did good.

Solid enough game - it does what it says on the tin - be a giant super human and smack bugs around. Story seems fun so far, operations are good (but with a caveat) and I like the melee and gunplay. After some more time in the game (both story and operation) I can delve a bit deeper into things.

Story - 7/10. It's pretty straight forward, though there might be a twist or turn in there (that I'm sure you have already gotten spoiled through various news media anyway). Not much to say. Simple, but cool.

World building - 10/10. Top marks. The maps, the battlefields, the chaos, the swarms, the absolute gore - it's just fantastic. It's beautiful and disturbing and just beyond anything I expected. Game teaches you about the 40k world and the immersion it provides gets you really stuck into it making you want to know more.

Gameplay - 9/10. Gameplay is marvelous. Though I'm still struggling with the timing of dodges and parries I've occasionally gotten in a flow where I just become a blender, chopping xeno scum to the left, doding xeno scum to the right, and firing of headshots as quick reaction. I for sure need to get better at the combat flow, but I can easily see how good it can be if you get good at it and once you do it's going to be euphoric.

Operations - 8/10, but with a caveat. The mainstay of the game in my opinion. It has huge potential and even the little I've played is so much fun. It reminds me of the golden days of Mass Effect 3 multiplayer (if you know, you know). However the biggest issue is playing without a full team - because you are stuck trying to connect with random players and that is it's own bag of worm. From people with bad connection, to people who won't go to the mission area, to people who just afk. I honestly prefer having bots over the random players, but unfortunately you can't choose to add bots - you have to hope nobody tries to join. The fact that we can't add bots makes me want to subtract 2 points from the score on it's own because the issues with random players can be very aggravating. They need to add an option to add bots..

Endless War - haven't played =p Might try it some day, but not a big PvP so - check others opinion on this game mode.

Would I recommend? I think, yes. If you enjoy the concept of loop gameplay from operations, and you have a full team (or the devs add option to add bots) I think you will have a blast. I know I will once I'm done with the random player issues.

Oh, and a final note. Stay away from the ultimate edition and cosmetic DLC's and all that. Even if you pay for it you still have to unlock it. This is a rather difficult game to review as a non-Warhammer fan. Because from my perspective it is a competent hack-and-slash-shooter devoid of personable characters or any intriguing plot-elements. But to a Warhammer fan it is grimdark-personified; each human a cog in the Emperor's ever-marching war machine which renders every man and women as barren of life as the land itself.

Thus, this is less of a review of the story, and more so the game itself. Graphically, it looks rather stunning--with majestic vistas of the skull-regaled factories of the city worlds to the gruesome, steaming swamps of the backwater worlds. And while some people have reported issues of high-temps and crashes--issues that should be looked into and addressed--for the most part, and across a variety of systems, the game seems to run rather well. That shouldn't be a pro for any game, it should just be the standard. But it's 2024, so... bar's been pretty low for a while now.

The overall gameplay loop consists of running down un-inspired corridors to face random-sized groups of enemies. And while the campaign is mercifully and justifiably short, devoid of any diversity of gameplay or objectives, what you're then left with is the Operations Mode. Best described as a Raid Mode of sorts. You're expected to run through these over and over to level up your character(s) and your equipment to then run these maps on a higher difficulty. And therein shines both the game's main strength and its main flaw. In the grim darkness of the far future, there is only war. And that motto does a lot to encapsulate the gameplay loop. There is only combat, and random objectives that rely on more combat. So it's a damn good thing then that the combat feels so damn good. Taking a chainsaw sword to a group of alien-baddies twice as short and thrice as frail as you will have you feeling like the Emperor's Chosen; pistols sound like a cannon and kick just as hard, and destroy just as much. Sniper Rifles are downright busted in the right hands. And I'll never, ever tire of grappling toward an enemy to deliver a skull-crushing dropkick. It speaks volumes that in a game with such limited enemy-variety and such non-existent diversity of gameplay I never got bored of the combat. It is fun, fluid and epic. It rewards aggression by granting you shields for each enemy killed through executions or perfect parries, and the ability to regen a bit of health lost to attacks if you're quick enough to retaliate. What isn't epic however is the un-inspired level-design, the lackluster repetition, and the horrid war of attrition that each mission eventually boils down to.
Each mission has a fixed layout and main objective, they don't change from match to match; instead, what does change is the placement of enemies, the number of them, and the amount required of each objective. Sometimes you'll be forced to place two bombs, another time you'll be forced to place five. And while this doesn't do a whole lot to shake the tedium of repetition, what it does do--however--is change the difficulty rather drastically. You can run into a couple of tiny one-shot guys one run, and a horde of huge, melee-focused guys another. And that would be fine if it wasn't for the limitations of their combat system. Because while it is fun, it is also rather limited in your ability to utilize it for your own survival. Like I said above, you can regen a bit of health lost if you're quick enough with a melee attack, and you can regain shields through executions or a shot to the head through the use of a perfect parry. What this does is promote an aggressive playstyle that rewards parries of the smaller enemies, and the executions of the larger ones. However, larger, melee-based elites don't give shields for perfect parries. And so, with the random spawns of enemies, you could find yourself surrounded by ten melee-based enemies and be unable to regain shields--meaning you'll watch your health dwindle and be unable to do anything about it. Worse, if you're then at the same time getting pummelled at range, which completely removes the ability to act quick enough that you regain a bit of lost health. Well, you can get better perks, of course. But that doesn't change that fact that random spikes in difficulty that skill cannot compensate for aren't fun; difficulty doesn't mean tediousness. And with a failed run meaning the potential loss of gathered upgrade materials, it being up to chance rather than skill is frustrating at best, and infuriating at worst. I'm not max level yet, and so maybe there are more perks to counteract such things, but it doesn't make the grind to get to max level any less annoying.

Class Progression is rather limited. You've no choice in what perk to begin with, meaning there's not really any build-variety. Weapon Progression offers a bit more variety, allowing you to choose whether you favour less speed and more damage, or vice versa.

Multiplayer is fine. It's a nice little relic of the early 2000s obsession with tacked-on versus modes. Little unbalanced, perhaps. But all the more nostalgic for it. It has a rather limited customisation-system. Grapple-hook dudes can use a Knife and a Sword but cannot use a power-fist. Shield-Bros can use a power-fist but cannot use a hammer, etc, etc. Fans might blame that on lore--but if that's the case, I don't really see why you'd offer customization at all. Better then to do perks, rather than equipment.

I do find it rather strange how unwelcoming the game is of newcomers. It doesn't go out of its way to ever explain any role, word or lore-based concept. And while one could argue that it is a game for fans, thinking that a Triple-A publisher would ever make a game of this size and not want to attract newcomers is downright naive. If you're not already a fan you'll either be real confused about a lot of what they're talking about, or you'll be spending half your playtime on the wiki. Overall it's a decent hack-and-slash-shooter that won't ever impress any non-Warhammer fan or person who enjoys a greater diversity of gameplay; it's all corridors and button-presses and horde-styled defence finales. But on the flip-side, it seems to be a delight for Warhammer fans; a crunchy, blood-soaked romp through a world of stainless steel and great, towering cathedrals, filled with horrid tech bonded with flesh, robot-skulls, and weapons galore, all of it in the Glorious name of the Emperor!

Battle Report: Space Marines 2

From the Desk of Brother-Sergeant Gabriel, 3rd Company, Ultramarines Chapter

Mission Log: 15 Hours In, Campaign Complete

Hail, Brothers and Sisters of the Imperium,

The long-awaited call to arms has been answered. Space Marines 2 has descended upon us like a righteous storm, and after dedicating a solid 15 hours to its campaign and accessories, it is time to deliver our verdict.

Space Marines 2 has risen to meet the high expectations set by its predecessor and then some. The narrative, steeped in the grimdark lore of the 40K universe, unfolds with the gravitas expected of our sacred battlefields. Each mission is a crucible of intensity, keeping the Emperor’s light blazing as you face the myriad horrors that plague the galaxy. The campaign's storyline is robust, providing a compelling blend of heroism and tragedy that befits the grand saga of the Space Marines.

Combat is a symphony of visceral destruction, every engagement a testament to the might of the Adeptus Astartes. The bolter’s roar and the chain sword's hum are rendered with such fidelity that it feels as though you’re wielding these sacred relics yourself. The enemies are varied and formidable, challenging even the most seasoned warriors among us. The improved AI ensures that no battle is ever truly predictable, demanding tactical acumen and reflexes as sharp as a power sword.

Graphically, the game captures the dark majesty of the 40K universe with hauntingly beautiful environments and detailed character models. The ambiance is as oppressive as a Space Hulk, with every setting dripping in the atmosphere of an Imperium on the brink.

In terms of gameplay, the enhancements to combat mechanics and the new abilities granted to our esteemed warriors are noteworthy. The balance between raw power and strategic depth has been finely tuned, allowing us to crush the xenos and heretics with righteous fury.

However, the path of the righteous is not without its trials. There are moments when the mission design feels somewhat formulaic, and a few technical hiccups mar the otherwise flawless execution of this grand endeavor. Yet, these are but minor blemishes on an otherwise gleaming armor of excellence.

In conclusion, Space Marines 2 stands as a proud addition to the legacy of the Warhammer 40K series. It honors our tradition of battle while forging a new path with unwavering zeal. For those who walk the line of the Emperor’s light, this is a battle worth engaging in.

The style of the game is on point with satisfying gameplay, but it has some GLARING issues. I'd recommend it, but I hope it gets some polish soon!

Pros:
Style: The feel of the 40k universe is really hit on the head. This alone has probably gotten me through the game. I just really adore it.
Audio: Crunchy sound design is very satisfying.
Weapons: The gear you use feels pretty good, the design is limited, but it's loyal to the universe.
Gameplay: Fairly rhythmic fighting with parries, counters & dodges.
Big enemies: Boss fights can be tough ( Angel of Death difficulty ), but typically manageable ( caveat below ).
Story: The story is a bit shallow, but good enough.

Cons:
The most glaring issue is ally AI. It's horrendous, pathetically bad. This can make some boss fights an absolute slog when you're trying to balance yourself to proceed through the fight. It also destroys immersion seeing an Astartes knuckle f***ing himself in the corner while you're fighting for your life.
Hit boxes: The hit boxes are bad. You'll get hit at bizarre ranges & you'll often shoot invisible walls when attacking enemies. I've also been struck countless times through cover from ranged attacks.
Homing Melee Attacks: One the most annoying things in this game is enemies leaping at you ( not talking about parry counters ) & having them turn in the air or have them YA YEET themselves after you when you dodge.
Stun Lock: Though I understand it's a swarm hitting you & that's sort of the point, getting stun locked is just a poor choice. No one likes stun lock. No one likes losing control of their character. No one wants to have 2/3 of their health gone from 3 gaunts.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is nothing short of a triumph, seamlessly merging intense combat with a gripping narrative in a way that will captivate both long-time fans and newcomers alike. This latest installment in the Warhammer 40K universe sets a new standard for action-packed shooters with its impeccable blend of brutal melee combat, strategic gunplay, and stunning visuals. Saber Interactive really came through with this installment. It is a game that long time fans of Warhammer 40k truly have been asking for.

From the moment you step into the power armor of a Space Marine, the game impresses with its attention to detail. The graphics are absolutely breathtaking paired with a bombastic audio design, Space Marine 2 showcases the grimdark universe with a level of realism that immerses you completely. The environments are richly detailed, from the war-torn landscapes to the imposing architecture of the Imperium’s strongholds.

The combat is where Space Marine 2 truly shines. The gameplay feels both fluid and weighty, with a seamless transition between hand-to-hand combat and ranged weaponry. The abilities and upgrades add depth and variety, ensuring that each encounter remains fresh and exhilarating. The game’s AI is notably sharp, presenting a formidable challenge that keeps you on your toes without ever feeling unfair.

Narratively, the game excels in delivering a compelling story set against the backdrop of a galaxy in turmoil. The voice acting and script are top-notch, with a storyline that feels both epic and personal. The character development is rich, and the dialogue manages to balance gravitas with moments of dark humor, adding layers to the experience.

Multiplayer has a offering of diverse modes and a progression system that keeps the action engaging and competitive. Whether you’re battling in co-op missions or competing in PvP, the multiplayer experience is both rewarding and addictive. Looking forward to see what Saber Interactive does with future content.

In summary, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a masterclass in combining thrilling gameplay with a deep, immersive world. It’s a must-play for fans of the franchise and a standout entry for those new to the universe. This game not only meets but exceeds expectations, proving itself as a benchmark in the genre. Prepare for a relentless, adrenaline-pumping adventure that you won’t soon forget.

Space Marine 2 is a long-awaited, much-hoped-for sequel to the first Space Marine game. You play as <REDACTED> (jk it's freaking Titus like that wasn't obvious enough) who starts off using Primaris-styled equipment as a regular first-born marine. Hmm. Can't say that's particularly lore accurate, but whatever, it's Titus so that's cool. Unfortunately he's no Mark Strong this time, can't blame him after everything that happened. Be aware.

I tried playing the campaign missions on Angel of Death difficulty. This will color my breakdown below.

The 'nids are, as expected, annoying ass space bugs that swarm you faster than skaven do at a Warpstone rave party, and they're fairly dangerous. In fact, each of them individually might not seem like a problem but start throwing in 3 or so hormagaunts and you'll start having more stab wounds than a mugging victim in London. The termagaunts, those little annoying freaking shooty bugs, appear to not wield regular fleshborers, since the damn things flash green like miniature rapid-fire venom cannons. If you don't know what a venom cannon is, I'll explain it further down below in the Warrior section.

All of these swarm mechanics overwhelming you through sheer numbers is really pronounced. I started having to take engagements carefully and seriously right from the get-go. You can't regenerate any health from simple executions this time either, you need to have taken damage recently (a la Bloodborne) and this makes Titus not only feel like tissue paper, but unable to recover easily. You need to use the medical stims and those are far and few in between, so they definitely took the 'its too easy' critique about the first game too much to heart. Titus will find these enemies dangerous and annoying in equal measure as a result, so don't go thinking you can charge into the jaws of hell and not get tarpitted harder than Abbadon facing a 50 block of guardsmen backed up by a Commissar Lord. They are just as fearless as said guardsmen and unlike Abbadon, Titus can't ♥♥♥♥ out like 10 attacks in a single round of combat, so you better hope you're good at parrying.

Note that while parrying or dodging or attacking, you are more or less animation locked. You can't cancel easily, and this honestly makes you feel a lot more sluggish than Captain Titus, who is now obviously the best version of Titus there was. This means you have to thin their numbers at range, hopefully reducing the 'gaunt variants down to less than 3 by the time the Warrior rushes you down.

Let's talk about Warriors. Warriors are the big 'nids that have that annoying ass whip, that annoying ass paired boneswords, that really annoying ass devourer, or that annoying ass venom cannon (that long snout thing).
The Whip is not too bad in a 1 on 1, just make sure to either stay clear of it while wiping out the small forms or...dunno, charge in and beat it to death before it can get really annoying. When it does that lash combo attack, it's very hard to parry so you're better off just trying to keep your distance and shooting it down.
The twin boneswords is just tanky. That's it.
The devourer is basically a rapid-fire fleshborer, and the Warrior who uses it is the most irritating PoS you will ever encounter. It will constantly skate away to the backline to pepper you with clusters of projectiles and it adds up a lot of damage very fast. Snipe this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as soon as possible. If you try to close in melee, it will sometimes unload every shot into you at point-blank range and you can die from this.
The last one, the venom cannon wielder, is the sniper variant. A venom cannon is like a biological railgun except instead of shooting a metal projectile it shoots this venomous acidic crystal that is superheated by the electrical discharge (yes, this is how it works in lore) and is launched at high speed to penetrate vehicles...or something. It didn't really work against real vehicles, but it definitely works against MEQ (shorthand for 'marine equivalent') like Titus. You will get a warning in the form of a sickly green laser tracking you and you can dodge the shot quite easily with good timing. The real problem is when one of them shows up and you are fighting a swarm or two and their Warrior melee cousins all at the same time, which is when things get nasty. Even then, its particular attacks are not hard to avoid, so either trust in your mobility or kill them off first, your choice.

There's more bug variants and their stupid tactics but I'm tired of talking about bugs so let's talk about weapons.

Gunplay and melee aren't mutually exclusive, it retains the general fluidity of the first game and you can swap between the two styles of combat very fast. Pistols are actually useful, they take their own slot and can help offset some disadvantages of your primary, while also serving as a way to perform kill shots on parried enemies.

Bolters. Holy Emperor the bolters. There are so many bolter variants, and some of them being very cross purposes with their actual function to the point it makes you wonder who needs this many variants. They are all lifted from the Primaris arsenal, and you get the whole freaking line of them (except Assault Bolters). Bolt carbines, heavy bolt pistols, auto bolt rifles, you name it they have it. In fact, I would argue that there are simply too many bolters. In the first game most of the same roles were replicated by unique weapons, such as the plasma gun, the lascannon, the vengeance launcher, and so on. Now you get...bolters.

Some of them are effective and some are not, but all of them are only average on Angel of Death difficulty so I didn't really find them to be that unique. What stood out were the non-bolter weapons, the Plasma Incinerator and the Melta Rifle.
The Plasma Incinerator is like a cross between the regular plasma gun and a very small plasma cannon, and it performs well enough in that role. It's plasma and it hurts.
The Melta Rifle is basically just like the melta gun from the first game. Tight AOE cone that does more damage the closer to the center of the aiming circle you get, huge shotgun blast that can melt anything.
There's some other stuff like the Las Fusil, which is basically just a lascannon if they scaled it down and in-game it's basically a Charge Rifle from Titanfall. It's still a good weapon, but they clearly learned their lesson from the first game where the lascannon's instant shot could utterly destroy an unfortunate enemy's face at close range.

Melee weapons unfortunately all feel a little samey. The chainsword is effective but it only swings in tight arcs and relies on a charge attack combo to stun enemies, which is extremely awkward compared to the first game where your stun/charge attack was another key altogether. This means it is very easy to start a chainsword combo then get hit for your trouble because you have no way of interrupting your enemy.
The power sword is a little more forgiving as it has actual stances that emphasize AOE or single target combat. It still has the issue of not being able to stagger big creatures reliably, or having a charge attack combo that matters, but it is reliable enough with its large sweeping attacks to actually outperform the chainsword on a regular basis.
The thunder hammer took a big hit from last game. It is just as sluggish and slow despite Titus' better augmentations, but is weaker. You can put a lot of hurt on enemies, but you have too many gaps open that leave you unable to defend yourself properly. Compare that to the first game, where the hammer's instant-kill damage and reliable stun combo can AOE wipe out hordes of daemons or whatever. It's very weak in this game.
The power fist staggers most enemies. Good enough.

I have been hoping for a sequel for space marine for 11 years, I have been waiting for this to release for 2 years. Does it deliver? I will explain below, starting with the campaign, then the MP modes ending on the technical details and overall thoughts.

Campaign


Space Marine 2 puts you into the armour of a Space Marine 40.000 years into the future. A genetically engineered super soldier that is 3 metres tall, a space marine is almost indestructible, they are faster and stronger than any normal human and some of them can be hundreds of years old. They are wrapped in myth and legend and are skilled warriors beyond measure. They are a bulwark against terror in a universe that has known only war for centuries.

Humanity is fighting against horrors beyond their comprehension and while there are several factions of said horrors, the main one we're dealing with here, is a Tyranid Hive fleet.
Tyranids are a bug/lizard like faction that swarm the universe to consume biomass, they evolve at an incredibly fast rate and can counter almost any known weapon or biological agent known to mankind and speed is of the essence when dealing with them. A planet attacked by them never truly recovers and there are millions and millions gunning for you.

The story picks up quite some time after Space Marine 1, and you are Titus. While I won't go into much story detail. The tutorial and thus the introduction to Space Marine 2, immediately shows what stakes you're up against and sets the tone for the entire campaign.

The campaign is a great introduction to some of the scale that Warhammer 40K offers and its bleak hopeless setting, there is only war and it shows. The campaign is filled with gigantic set pieces, wild lush alien forests and jungles, gigantic cities with massive cathedrals or abandoned bunkers and dark secrets. Everywhere you see signs of the carnage that happens all around you and the grimdark setting that 40K invented really shines here.

Gameplay wise the game is reminiscent of Space Marine 1, just improved upon. combat is fast and diverse and the game expects you to switch tactics on the fly.

As a space marine you have a great arsenal of weapons to use, from the infamous Bolt weapons, massive assault weapons that fire a bolt, a massive rocket propelled round that embeds itself in the target and detonates, to melta guns, plasma guns, heavy bolters. But you also have several melee weapons, from the Chainsword, to the Thunderhammer. Why? because the combat in this games switches between thinning out hordes and hordes of enemies before they reach you and then turns into a hack and slash brawler fest.

The combat is incredibly dynamic and it keeps you on your toes especially on higher difficulties. Luckily you are not alone in this rigorous slaughter fest. Titus has two other space marines with him, which can either be controlled by your friends or the computer. While the bots lack some finesse and tend to focus on direct threats, they are a welcome addition. Just don't expect too much of them, they are bots. they beeline for you to get you up if you're down but not out and they can distract some enemies.

The campaign will take you around 10 to 12 hours to complete and my time with it was enjoyed very much, I had several "Holy sh!t" moments and I felt like a space marine, the story is all I hoped for after 13 years and I loved it.


The multiplayer is the other part of Space Marine 2. It can be separated in two parts: PVE and PVP.


PVE is one of the parts that shines here, during the campaign several squads often help Titus with secondary objectives, the PVE or Operations gives you control of these squads. You can run this with up to two of your friends or bots, but trust me, play with friends.

You have six classes with each of them having a distinct role, weapon set and main ability.
From the standard space marine with bolter and chainsword, to the bulwark with shield and sword to a stealthy sniper

Each class has weapon upgrades, perks for the weapons and the class itself and customisation to unlock.
Yes you can create your very own space marine or unlock several other space marine chapters and customise those and while the customisation needs some polish, it's incredibly varied.

There are currently six operations most of which coincide with the campaign, they can take 30 to 45 minutes to complete and on higher difficulties they require coordination, tactics and sharing of resources.

They often feel like mini raids and they are incredibly fun to do, however in contrast to games such as Darktide I wonder how fun these missions stay, they feel less like a horde shooter and more like a mini campaign, while enemy variety and objectives can switch around in an operation, I feel it might get repetitive. Yet they are like I said incredibly fun and I will probably keep coming back to them, just because of the gameplay loop.


The second MP mode is Eternal War, a 6v6 PVP mode with the same classes as the Operations mode, just different progression. There three modes, King of the Hill, Seize ground (several points to capture) and Annihilation (team death match) and as of writing 3 maps.

The gameplay in pvp is great, classes are diverse and while some balancing might be happening it is incredibly fun to play despite it's lack of maps and modes. I spend several hours playing this and the tactical aspect in it is really fun, it isn't just run and gun, you have to counter other classes, bullwarks can block damage, snipers sneak around, assault's jump in to cut you down. There are tons of cool skirmishes to be found and it's an absolute blast.

However it's also the most bare bones part of the game. While the customisation for space marines is great, the chaos marines lack customisation, every class is attached to a traitor legion and is thus bound to it. You cannot play an iron warrior vanguard for instance and the armor itself is barely customisable, sometimes even not. For some of the more chaos minded players this can be quite a big letdown.

The other issue is that while it is 6v6 I can only make a lobby with three people, not six or four, locking out some of my friends to play with, I get it for PVE, I don't for PVP.

PVP feels like something added later in development and I hope that the devs do expand upon it with some much needed Quality of Life changes.


The game is quite CPU heavy, I have a i9-10850k CPU and a RTX4070 TI SUPER, the game runs like a charm in 90% of the game, but some areas and missions are incredible heavy on the CPU so much I wonder if it's a bit of optimalisation. Some area's that are small tank my frames, while some large open areas I run at a solid 80 FPS on ultra settings.

Besides that though, the game is beautiful to look at and effects, lighting, textures are all incredibly impressive, from the sparks of a broken cable to the blood that flies around.

The sound design is really well done and weapon sounds pack the punch you expect them to, every bolt fired, every enemy screech, every punch thrown is of high quality and this combined with the graphical design makes this a very immersive 40K game.


Despite some personal gripes and an in my opinion a bare bones PVP, this game has been worth the wait, it build upon the foundation of Space Marine 1 and improved it immensely. It offers something for older fans and something for newer fans of 40K and it is an incredible home-coming or introduction to the Space Marine franchise and thus Warhammer 40.000. It's an incredibly brutal, fun third person action game and the gameplay loop is quite addicting.

Sabre shows it understands 40K and this game is an ode to it.

Overall the combat and general gameplay is some of the most satisfying I've seen since something like Gears but without all the cover nonsense and the first run of the campaign has some real jaw dropping moments in both visuals and reveals.

However, if you're looking for more than the campaign, this is hard to recommend. Much like Left 4 Dead, Back 4 Blood, World War Z, Darktide, etc, there's just nothing to do in the PvE Operations mode except grind out cosmetics and passives. That might be enough for some, but it lacks any of the systems that make something like Destiny, Warframe, Deep Rock Galactic, Remnant, or the plethora of other rougelikes out there that do so much with mapgen and other secondary systems that make each run feel like a run, not just going through the same motions again. I'm never excited by anything that's gonna drop from a mission, it's just "cross the finish line this many times" for your next passive/cosmetic.

Cosmetics are awesome, classes are fine, progression kinda sucks since you only unlock one row at a time. Not sure I'll be playing long enough to max a single class despite only playing two of them. Passives are... there? They all feel like relatively minor gameplay bonuses that help steer your playstyle, but not one so far has made me excited to unlock or feel it was worth working towards. They feel more like bypasses to some inconvenince rather than some Astartes-level power. I don't think I'd be able to tell an endgame level build from an early game one from gameplay alone.

Would be awesome if in new game + you could play the campaign with your custom marine so 60% of the PvE missions were playable with the PvE classes. I think that's my biggest issue, the best PvE content isn't what you get to replay for progression and what's there to replay gets stale fast. Really hope to see some updates to the operations modes that make them more fun to replay. Modifiers, loot drops that persist after a play session, consumable buffs, unique mission rewards, map variants, mapgen, really anything except playing the same mission over and over with some different combat pacing each time.

If campaigns are your jam, pick it up on sale. If you wanted something more replayable, wait.
