In all seriousness yeah its an alright enough game with a short but decent campaign (albeit some aforementioned cutscene errors or bugs such as where they either freeze but the audio continues or its the opposite of the audio lagging behind the visuals of a cutscene).

Combats fun allowing you to pull off some cool as finishers to enemies to regain health and shields (finishing moves in action games is always a win) but some of the controls can feel quite janky with awkward keybinds set by the game for pc.

The operations co-op mode currently has an error where you can get stuck in the hub after readying up for a level and would certainly benefit from some variety, otherwise the same 6 levels could get repetitive for some people, I like to think of it like its Left 4 Dead where you can play through the same levels countless times but the game play is what keeps it fun, but some more random/less linear objectives if possible could probably help make the levels feel less repetitive.
With hopefully some more content and additions operations mode can hopefully reach just a bit more of the potential that it does offer, but still simply just co-op romping with some friends or random allies and curb stomping aliens together are fun solid foundations, hopefully it can just be improved upon.

There's a PVP multiplayer mode where you play as the space marines faction or the Chaos marine (evil hellish marines) faction and fight each other. I haven't played much of it myself but yeah its alright, its there for those who want it.
You can't unfortunately customise the Chaos faction characters, you get premade models for each of the classes on that side, which while they do look cool themselves, does seam like some people are still let down that you can't customise them as well like you can with the space marines.
As far as I've seen theres not many like cool takedowns or anything you can do to enemy players, its just clunky space marines on both sides blasting or thwacking each other clumsily like its a call of duty game and using their ultimate abilities non-stop with no cohesion to see who dies first, then respawning with your abilities charged again to rush back into the fight and repeat the process. Yeah its alright for those who may like the PVP stuff but personally I think the PVE stuff's more the games strong point.

Both the Co-op mode and PVP mode have separate level progressions though so don't think you can level up a class in co-op mode then pop into PVP with a skilled up PVE dude and stomp fools, which is fair BUT however, while class level progression is separate for each mode. You can still unlock cosmetics currency and armour pieces for your characters just by completing matches in both modes as each character. So you can still play both modes and they still count for cosmetic progress at least for each class you beat a match as, so thats nice.

Yeah look, TLDR: Its a decent co-op game and being able to run around and stomp out enemies with allies while playing as giant f*ck off power armoured boys is still awesome. Heck I'm not a big Warhammer series fan myself meaning I knew bugger all about the lore, but I am starting to learn some things about the universe by playing this game and its encouraged me to look a bit more into it.

And you don't need to be a fan of the franchise or know everything to enjoy the game, I'm a simple fella, I saw big mech suits, chainsaws and brutally ripping alien scum to shreads... and thats all I wanted from it.

So its still a solid cool game to play and have fun wreaking havoc on enemies with your big space marine ruthlessness and brutality. But I think it would benefit from some more additions and content, the foundation is there, just build on it and add more levels, and maybe some variety in objectives to keep the co-op mode from becoming stale.

P.S The Season Pass content cosmetics have been a bit disappointing so far, Its just more colours and decals really, I was hoping for more unique/cool and actual standout armour pieces or such to justify its content but so far it leaves alot to be desired IMO.

My Dearest Martha,

I write this letter having been beset by Tyranid scum and Chaos villainy. I have finished the main campaign with my AI brothers and there is much to say.

They say war is hell and while that is true here it is a very pretty hell. The sights and sounds of battle are massive in scale and in quality. Watching enemies explode into bloody bits or some magical dust ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ was always satisfying. While most of my time was spent with two other squad mates there was always a feeling of a larger campaign at play. Sometimes from background battles raging, but also in those moments when you are charging forward alongside a massive army.

The spectacle is really incredible and I found, in general, the combat to be fun. Guns felt like that had impact and "oomph" melee weapons had weight. It felt good to run around, see the sights, and fight. All the pieces make for an extremely compelling experience that I couldn't walk away from, even if occasional issues would cause the odd rage-quit.

So let's talk about the bad stuff, because this has not been all roses. For every time you get a jump pack and the game gets 100x more fun there are a few things and missions that bring the overall experience down.

First off - this game is clearly a multiplayer/COOP game first. The AI squad is awful. They get the most important part right, which is trying to revive you if you go down, but beyond that they are poor in combat, and almost non-existent when it comes to objectives or tactics. Now it's okay to make a game where you want COOP as a focus, but if you are going to advertise and push that it's a solo game too you do need to properly support that experience and I think the game falls incredibly short in this key area.

In fact I think that if you had a better, more effective, and/or commandable squad the other issues I have might not matter. I also felt that for a giant armored Space Marine I felt like dolled up tissue paper. The game asks a lot in terms of special blocks, regular blocks, special dodges, regular dodges, pistol counters, executions, ranged fighting, and melee swarms all at once, but gives very little health and armor to support all of that even on the baseline difficulties. It doesn't make the game impossible by any means, but it does make it a little less fun.

Still I can't help but think that much of this is less of an issue if my squad was doing a better job of not making me fight everything mostly alone possibly while juggling objectives and in one really bad stage while also using a flamethrower to keep swarms at bay.

While I've focused on issues a bit I think overall my net experience with the game is far more better moments than troubled ones. There was only one stage I hated (the swarm bunker thing) and a few objectives that made me long for less brain-dead brothers at my side. It didn't prevent me from completing the campaign over a few days because I couldn't stop playing. They are also all issues that can be fixed.

So often we see games come out with problems way beyond the scope of a patch, but in the case of Space Marine 2 I don't think there is anything that couldn't be improved down the line. Hopefully they actually make some of these improvements, because I think this game could be damn-near perfect if they did.

Also as these issues are almost all tied to the single player experience, if you are playing online or with friends I think realistically you are just going to have a much better time. So it's an easy recommend to online/COOP players and while I still recommend it to solo player I do warn that there are some pain points, especially on higher difficulties from your AI companions.

At a time where my gaming has been an hour here, an hour there, try this, try that, Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 became my world for a few days. Despite the blood and carnage of it all it was a glorious focus and a stellar time.

Fantastic. It’s exactly what you'd expect from a sequel to 2011’s Space Marine and a Warhammer 40K action game. It takes everything that made the first game fun and cranks it up, refining pretty much everything that you remember about that original game.

I never followed the details about the story prior to the release so I wasn't sure if it's gonna pick up from where the last game left off. But I was pleased to see that not only does it still feature Captain Titus as the main character, but also manages to be an overall much better story with a couple of fun memberberries thrown in for fans of the original.

And if you're really invested in the lore, you'll be pleased to know that the developers poured a lot of heart and attention into making this an accurate 40K experience. It's probably the most authentic "play as a Space Marine" experience to date, because you truly feel like an eight-foot-tall truck on legs, towering over regular humans and barreling through everything like an elephant in a china shop. Including any living thing that isn't at least as big, because it's going to end up getting stomped like a grape. Everything about this game's design is just as over-the-top, excessive, and ludicrous as you'd expect, and it's glorious.

After finishing the campaign I just had to write a review to get my thoughts down on paper, this review will contain no spoilers for the story, but will talk about themes, gameplay and performance. Together of course with an overall impression, to start things off.

Space Marine 2 exceeded my expectations by a significant margin, this game is fun to play. I've seen some other reviews talking about how the combat system is "unforgiving", but I can only say that I disagree. The fast paces melee / ranged blend is really satisfying once you figure out what works for you. I played the game on the second to highest difficulty for my first run so far, I had to adjust in the beginning but once I got over the hurdle, quite frankly I just saw myself improving and getting better at managing the fights. To an extent fights in this game feel reminiscent of those from DOOM, specifically Eternal. Every fight is a puzzle that you need to think creatively to solve together with staying on top of incoming attacks and positioning.

Complaints about the AI are valid, but I didn't notice much in terms of them getting in the way of me having fun.

Performance wise, I'm running on a fairly old rig, 1080 and an i7-4790k, and I got stable performance albeit not exceptional on the high preset. For me I am fine if a game runs at 30 as long as it is stable, and Space Marine 2 was, depending on level, either running at stable 30, stable 45, stable 60 or unstable 20-30. The 20-30 range being in some of the later where the game is flexing it's muscle in terms of scale and the number of effects on screen.

As for all the stuff with the Epic integration? Quite literally you accept the EULA and that's it. It has no other impact on your gameplay. I find complaints around this sort of stuff to be valid, if exaggerated. It is okay to be upset that this is "forced" upon you, but I do not think it warrants leaving a negative review for the game, personally.

Story? This feels like it could've been a 40k novel. I say that with significant praise, compared to the first game the stakes are higher, the characters are better, and it just feels like a part of actual canon now.

I am incredibly satisfied, and depending on how the game develops in the next few years, it might take the spot for "My personal favorite 40k game", as it is now, however? Firmly top 3.

Suffice to say, I strongly recommend this game, I will be diving into the multiplayer and co-op components in the next few days, and if there is anything to add or detract from this review, expect addenda :)

If no addenda are found on this review, my stance holds firm.

Short Version:
Visually beautiful game, fun gameplay, good amount of variety in classes, few bugs, lots of re-playability, Co-Op PvP and PvE, beloved lore and well loved franchise.


Long Version:

Space Marines 2 is a sci-fi and gothic dark fantasy with biblical motifs that make Warhammer 40k awesome. The sheer and immense sense of scale, both indoors and outdoors perfectly capture the depth of the world that is Warhammer.

You can feel the immense love for the lore and source material, it's definitely made by fans who genuinely care about this world that is imbued through the visuals and attention to detail in every facet and asset.

This is every Warhammer 40k fan's wet dream.


Pros:
• Impressive visuals with lore-accurate art direction. The brutality and bleakness of the 40K universe are masterfully conveyed
• Superb combat system that equally rewards skill, resource conservation and a tactical, team-oriented approach. Very easy to pick up and get better. Pacing is done very well
• Solid variety of enemies, all of which have unique behaviors, movesets and abilities
• Bosses that evolve their movesets dynamically, and are highly challenging on the harder settings
• The 40K lore is accurately transposed and faithful to the series canon
• Enjoyable, well-written storyline, compounded by plausible characters and interesting events
• Exploration and Customization are rewarded
• DLC's are purely cosmetic, all future content is already planned ahead of time and content is free


Cons:
• AI companions aren’t smart enough for complex objectives, and can’t be ordered around or customized
• Balancing issues make some weapons redundant or useless
• Tabbing out of the game at any point causes the game to freeze, and I'm rocking a pretty solid set up



Writing/Lore/Worldbuilding

“In the grim darkness of the far future, there is only war”. A historical quote that single-handedly resumes the bleak, brutal universe of 40K; Humanity spans the stars, its society on the verge of collapse and only carried by a fanatically-rooted war economy. SM1’s protagonist, Titus, returns as the main character and is sent on a mission to defend the Imperium; this time around, insect-like Tyranids and the Ruinous Powers of Chaos.

The tale of Titus and his two Ultramarine companions is lore-accurate and engaging — 40K fans will catch many references and bits a newcomer wouldn’t, but that doesn’t make it un-enjoyable if you’re new to the franchise. Characters aren’t one-sided and have solid narrative depth; the feeling of being an important cog of the Imperial war machine — but a cog nonetheless — is conveyed perfectly, as it should be.

Visually and artistically, few games can equal the desolate beauty the game has to offer. From the enormous Tyranid swarms laying waste to all, to the iridescent distortions of Warp powers and the blasts of Cadian artillery, everything looks and sounds amazingly crisp. Settings are varied and rich in detail, with more than a few impressive landscapes. Weapon sounds, dense effects and excellent voice acting only give further emphasis to the action-packed battles you’ll engage in. The gory finisher animations, different based on the enemy faced and weapon used, add great emphasis to the destruction of tougher foes.


Exploration & Secrets

Maps are linear, with one path to follow once either all foes are slain, or certain objectives are completed. Still, exploring the few side-areas, nothing more than crevices or branching dead-ended paths, is worth your time. There, you’ll find precious supplies and uncommon weapons that will improve your survival chances: medkits, Relics allowing you to revive once, heavy weapons and ammunition caches. Lore-related Dataslates also can be listened to in order to better understand the events that transpired. There are no collectibles or proper secrets to mention, nor a map, which you won’t need given the fairly-simple layouts and on-demand objective markers.


Operations (PVE) and Endless War (PVP)

After the Campaign, you’ll unlock several Operations: PvE missions parallel to the main story that depict critical events and feature another Ultramarine team that helped Titus in the main story. Contrary to the campaign, here you'll have access to six customizable classes, each with unique loadout capabilities and Ultimate skills, other than different passive perks and weapons to unlock as you gain XP after an Operation is cleared. Experimenting with different playstyles and combinations, and upgrading your class, adds solid replay value and good progression feeling. These Operations also have progressively increasing difficulty, with better rewards, such as cosmetics, XP bonuses and so forth, proportional to the difficulty you’ll engage into — however, you won't go far in the harder difficulties without better gear and advanced perks, despite all of the settings being available from the start regardless of level.


Content & Replay Value

Average playtime is around 16 hours to complete the game on Angel of Death (hardest) difficulty with two AI teammates, taking extra time to explore all locations thoroughly. After that, Operations and PvP modes greatly extend the content with their high replay value. The story is instead linear, and there’s no reason to replay it except achievements.

The PvP mode, Endless War, has Chaos forces face the Space Marines in a variety of objective-based modes, ranging from the classic Deathmatch and CTF to more nuanced ones. It allows full loadout customizations just as in the PvE mode, and is a nice addition for those interested in competing against other players to test their skills.



Conclusion:

Do I recommend it? Absolutely. Even if you’re not a 40K fan and just enjoy action games, this is a solid pick. Even better if you have two friends to tag along; the best experience is in co-op.

We have arrived, and it is now that we perform our charge. In fealty to the God-Emperor, our undying Lord, and by the grace of the Golden Throne, I declare Exterminatus upon the Imperial world of Space Marine 2. I hereby sign the death warrant of an entire world and consign a million Tyranid souls to oblivion. May Imperial Justice account in all balance. The Emperor Protects.

Now that I have finished the Campaign fully I feel I can give a fair review.

But for those who TLDR: The Positives of Space Marine 2 massively outweigh the negatives. It is the sequel that Space Marine deserved and more.

Pros:
- The large set pieces and open battlefields are fantastic, you truly feel as if you are in an unwinable battle against overwhelming odds.
- The actual fighting gameplay is great. You feel heavy and powerful as a Space Marine should
- Story is overall very good, fair amount of fanservice especially as you get towards the late game.
- Environments do the Warhammer 40k universe justice especially the hive cities.
- Gun play is fantastic, this is what shooting a bolter should feel like
- Characters are fantastic, my the end of the game you truly feel a real connection to your squad.
- The ending boss fight is one of my favourite boss fights I have EVER played its truly breathtaking, the perfect blend of challenge, counters and length


Cons:
- Veteran difficulty is quite frankly far too punishing to play solo, the tyranid portion (specifically that damned antena mission, if you know you know) Is near impossible with the amount of damage the shooting tyranids do all while you get stunlocked by the smaller enemies
- Health is far too rare a resource. In Space Marine 1 you could refill health via executions while in Space Marine 2 it only refills shield which on Veteran difficulty only has too charges.
- Upon early release there are audio bugs thankfully never during cutscenes but it does pull you out of immersion when suddenly the game goes silent.

Ending thoughts:

I played through the entire campaign in one sitting, I had to change to Normal difficulty after the antena mission because Veteran was simply too unforgiving. However once I switched to normal and was no longer dying so quickly the game was a blast to play. Space Marine is to this day my favourite childhood game bar maybe Battlefront 2, its what got me into Warhammer 40k and is a very special piece of media to me.

Space Marine 2 is a worthy sequel, expands the scale, the carnage and everything else that made Space Marine 1 so special. This game was clearly made with love and care. Its absolutely worth a buy.

As a T'au player it pains me to recommend this game with all the Xenophobia but I did it for the greater good.

A masterpiece that is so rare in today's gaming landscape - reminiscent of a time we called the "golden age of gaming" with absolute Warhammer 40K brutality that we all love.

Graphics
• Incredible model detail everywhere
• High fidelity and dense environments
• Loincloth physics is 👌
• World just looks amazingly beautiful - sheer scale 'shock and awe' at every horizon

Gameplay
• Simple but satisfying, much polished from Space Marine I
• Movement feels super satisfying and heavy as an Astartes should
• Gunplay is impactful and smooth, though aiming feels a bit clunky at times due to the way it's configured
• Melee is a transcendent experience, as the Emperor intended, with all the right splashes of red
• Old school gaming feel, this plays like a true Space Marine successor/sequel should

Story
• Well-paced, Titus, Chairon, and Chadriel have some amazing moments in this campaign to save the Recidious System from annihilation by xenos and Choas scum alike
• Background characters like Major Sarkaana, Cpt. Sevastus Acheran and others aboard the battle barge were all memorable in their own rights - though many Ultramarines don the same Primaris power armour their dialogues and faces behind the suit intrigued me enough to warrant their own spin-off campaigns if possible
• World-building elements in the story campaign created a larger-than-life immersive experience, thanks to the attention-to-detail when designing the objects in the game - everything feels so authentic to the 41st millennium time period
• Epic, grand, dazzling - are all words that are too small to describe the awe I felt when finishing the campaign, it was a religious experience to say the least
• Too short, would have loved a longer campaign - easily finish-able in a day. Hopefully future expansions could be added that bring fourth more stories in this game/engine.

Overall, this was the successor to Space Marine that was worth waiting 13 years for - in fact there was a time when this game would not have been possible and to see it and play it is a blessing and a great privilege. For anyone who is a fan of the 40K universe I say this is a must buy - my only complaint is that it will leave you wanting more.

Space Marine 2 is exactly what you would want/expect for a Warhammer 40K game. The story is solid with some good callbacks to the first game. The game runs well and movement and shooting feel fluid and weighty. Overall a 9/10.

I'll start off with setting the gameplay expectations.
Mechanically, it's a third person action game with an emphasis on melee. Missions broadly involve progressing through a level while completing set objectives and fighting a variety of enemy types. Whether you enjoy the gameplay is very subjective, but in my personal opinion it is a challenging, yet fun experience that effectively mixes ranged and melee combat while staying engaging. Coop and PvP modes are available, with the former definitely being worth your time if you enjoy the campaign.
It is not an open world game with 50-100 hours of campaign. It is not an RPG, nor is it MMO-like.
Primarily what this game aims to be is a sequel to the first game. Don't expect a different game.
Now that that's out of the way;

Space Marine 2 is set amongst the Warhammer 40k setting, and it is abundantly clear that it has been developed with care and dedication. From the detailed, living environments to the story awareness, it is a game that has been sorely missing from the 40k franchise for some time.
I am not high brow with the stories I enjoy, but I highly enjoyed the characters and scope of the story. 14 years since we last saw Titus, it's a fitting continuation that includes additions since made to the setting. Cadia's fate, the Primaris and more are involved in an unforced and appropriate way.
There are many moments where I have to stop and look at the scenery to take it all in, and game details down to each color being matched with their actual miniature equivalent are great to see.

I would definitely consider if you have the necessary PC specifications before purchasing, as it is a hefty game. Beyond that, I haven't experienced any technical issues, and have heard of very few people experiencing them. Parts of the gameplay can feel frustrating, but I think it really is a skill situation. My only complaint is that there's not more of it.

Depending on what you want from the game it's either for you or not.
If you are looking for a game with the elements of a Mass Effect or maybe Rogue Trader in it's story then this ain't for you, it's a game for the people who want the old games from 2010 back, the action based third person shooter with blood and gore.
People who enjoyed the first game or even GOW, you will have a blast with the different executions, the gunplay and the overall presentation of Space Marine 2.
It feels really good to just sit down, join some friends and blast your way through a tyranid horde and watching your custom made Space Marine cutting a Warrior in halve.
The campaign itself was for my taste long enough, it had it's amazing moments with certain twists and expecially the presentation of the battlefield, how the skybox looks and the complete level design is something from another world.
You get sucked into the world of 40k in a blink of an eye, even the intro video was the sweetest eye candy I had this year but it doesn't just end there, it goes on with massive scaled battles taking place in the background and the ambiente just fits so well into this setting, so fluent and yet so sharp.

The Operations are not exactly what I expected, I do love the different perspective on the levels with the view of the other teams and what they did, it gives another nice inside on how the war against the xenos is fought.
But I would have loved a similiar kind of PVE gameplay like in Darktide, might just be me but it would suit the game more if they'd add something like that, not as repetitive like Darktide but inspired by it to say the least.
The classes all feel unique in their own way with how they play and feel like.
Customisation on the other hand is done right with the player having to play the game and not just buying in on it, I get that people like to get the easy way sometimes but honestly, that's the way I like it with Space Marine 2.
Don't get me wrong, I really love the fan service of most Warhammer games and I believe this game will do just as good as a Halo Reach in terms of said Fan Service.

The multiplayer although needs a lot of work, unfortunately there is no true customisation for the Chaos Marines which makes me quite sad, I'd love to have a full World Eater set with all the different parts of armour and insignias there are but we just have to wait for that.
Balance so far is ok-ish if you know how to counter f.e. a heavy, you won't have a big of a problem dealing with them but classes like the Assault who are just a flying target with no really prowess to themself or the Vanguard who has no real chance on surviving a encounter with a tactical is something they need to work on.
Especially the Vanguard would benefit from one armour slot more or maybe a better evasion during fights, I know it's a light class but having a sniper ripping you apart with his pistol because your hook is taking a bit to long to shoot you towards him is frustrating, might just be me but that's my opinion on it.

The game shows great promise in becoming a true sucessor to the first part and as of now it is a really good, if not even the best Warhammer game out there at this very moment, maybe Darktide is a bit better but that's just me, I love both of the games.
Space Marine 2 is a game which gives the players what they want, it's really refreshing to have a game like this combating modern gaming and showing us that there are still people out there who care about a franchise this big.

There are some technical issues I don't like that much like latency and the game not closing right, or just randomly closing the lobby in PVE and refusing to start a mission even tho everybody is present in the ready zone but honestly, it's not even fully released yet and we all payed to get our hands earlier on the game so I think it's something you can excuse as of now.
If the stability of the game will be improved or not is up to the Devs and I hope they will take their time with the new DLCs, they already did really good on WWZ but they can do even better with this one.
Can't wait to see this game becoming GOTY.

That's all from me, if there is anything you dislike or think I missed please just leave a comment on this review.

I've found this game to be a really good sequel to the old Space Marine game, continuing the story of the protagonist from the previous game as they face new threats.

Pros:

- The production value is great. In my very first mission, I spent my game time in between gawking at the scenery, and dying to enemies (skill issue). The environs iconic to the Warhammer 40k franchise are beautifully rendered, and the dev team has had tremendous attention to detail.
- VO and story are solid so far. As of this writing, I haven't delved too much into it, as I'm eager to play this in co-op
- Combat feels representative of Space Marines: while at time clunky, there's a definite feel of momentum behind it, and both melee and ranged combat feels satisfying.

Cons:
- Performance is currently unreliable at best. Loading time on an SSD is much higher than I expect it to be. The game will try to load cutscenes, and while still loading them and stuttering, it will play the audio track, desyncing the audio track from the cutscene video completely.
- Graphical performance also heavily depends how much of the game resources you've managed to buffer. You can have a combat area with 10-20 enemies maximum, and turning too fast might cause stuttering or a slight freeze, but at the same time, if the game just throws hordes of Tyranids charging your emplacement, the game performance might be completely fine and not miss a beat. YMMV.

Not tried:
- Server / Co-op: I have yet to try the co-op functionality, so I can't give any advice on its performance.

Verdict:

Despite performance issues, I've found it a well-done game, and would definitely recommend it. Since this review was written during the pre-release time, I don't doubt that down the line the devs will release further patches to address what myself and others have seen so far when it comes to performance issues.

Yes the spooky SBI did consulted on this game, but honestly I don't really see any detrimental influence so far. As for Ultramarines not looking 100% like a wet dream of an Austrian painter, lets be real. Anyone worth their Warhammer 30/40k salt knows that there is no canonical establishment of Ultramarines all needing to look like they came from the Austrian alps singing Sound of Music. Yes, all space marine take on features after their gene father (Rowboat Girlyman in this case), but Roboute's gene has far as lore goes is pretty stable and has few if any mutations.

All Salamanders look like Pele from SMT because Vulkan gene had a flaw that made everyone black with red eyes. Same goes for some others like Night Lords (scary emo goths) and probably Luna Wolves (bald and angry). Some, like the Raven Guard (sad emo goths) are as a result of their planet's environment (Kiavahr being terrible and Deliverance being a literal ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a moon) or like White Scars (Mongolians) who not only Oct 7 his entire planet in about 20 solar years, but also recruited people exclusively from the tribe who took him in.

Some Legions (and by extension first founding chapters) like Iron Hands, Luna Wolves, Dark Angels, Emperor's Children, Imperial Fist and famously Ultramarines recruit anyone from anywhere so long as they are worthy. And because their genes are relatively stable, they do not completely inherent ALL of their Primarch's physical traits. Though you'd obviously find more blonde in say, Emperor's Children and Dark Angels than you would any hair on Luna Wolves.

Not exactly, but you racist AND stupid especially if you didn't know the lore, because from your perspective, why would there be an ethnic limitation in that regard? Get out of here with that you donkey.

Now with that out of the way, some thoughts about the game:

1. If you're a 40k buff, the design, scenery, voice-acting, atmosphere, weapons etc are all exactly what you'd expect Warhammer 40k to feel like.

2. Audio design for the most of it is impeccable.

3. Combat is fluid and mostly satisfying with one caveat (will elaborate in negative).

4. Beautiful graphics, even on my 3070ti at high mids it still looks fantastic.

5. Runs very great on my 3070ti, Ryzen 9 and 32gb DDR5. Though would recommend installing it on a nvme ssd to increase loading speed.

6. Only played about 1.5 hours of the campaign, but the lore so far is fantastic. How they speak, the mannerism of the Astartes, the imperials, the mechanicus etc are all as they should be.

1. ESG. This is the biggest middle finger and a complete deal breaker. Nevermind being forced a stealth installation of ESG onto your system, it ironically PREVENTS you from booting the game unless you go into task manager and DELETE ESG PROCESS. How stupid is that?

2. Second deal breaker for many, the FOV is horrible and there is no way to extend it. The space marine model eats 1/3 of your entire view, which severely reduces your peripheral awareness unless you are constantly looking around.

3. The weapons feel less impactful and heavy than they did in SM1. This wouldn't be so much of an issue if some of the weapon didn't feel so floaty/light (but then again, they are being welded by not just space marines, but Primaris so maybe it gets a pass).

4. Some weapons don't sound as punchy as it should be. The heavy bolter for example was defeaning in SM1 and especially in the Dawn of War games. Other weapons like the bolter pistol needs sound louder and more punchy (you are literally shooting a miniature rocket after all, and a normal unaugmented human can barely fire it without breaking their shoulders. Unless you're a Catachan, then you can fire anything).

5. Titus's first voice actor, Mark Strong, was way better than Clive Standen. Don't get me wrong, Clive does try hard and delivers as best he could, but there's something about Mark's voice that really suits a gruff veteran space marine.


Despite my grievance with some of the more creative decisions like the changing of Titus's voice actor and weapons sound/feel not as heavy as the first game, I understand why they did it. SM2 gameplay and combat is much more fast paced and fluid than SM1 ever was. It might be a solid reason, from a technical perspective to not have everything sounding like Ferrus Manus clapping Fulgrim's cheeks on Istvaan V or having the screen shake like it's Armageddon on a Tuesday. I can live with those decisions, not a deal breaker.

What is and WILL be a serious issue, is the presence of and the poor FOV (which can be easily fixed with an update to allow adjustments).

Space Marine 2 is an exhilarating, action-packed sequel that takes everything great from the first game and cranks it up. The intense combat feels fluid and satisfying, with epic battles against swarms of enemies that really capture the scale and ferocity of the Warhammer 40k universe. On top of that, the game runs smoothly with excellent performance, even during the most chaotic fights.

I'm having fun so far, but this is not the GOTY, Helldivers 2 Killer super game people were hoping it would be before release. combat is clunky and over-complicated, but serviceable. Gunplay is fine but there are too many bolters with too few differences to make them feel like unique weapons. Reload times are universally atrocious, it should not take a space marine 3 entire seconds to reload a bolter. Melee as actually noticeable a step back from the first game, every weapon feels too slow to tackle the absolute mosh pits each combat arena descends into. The game seems to want you to square up with the elite units and take your time dodging and parrying specific attacks but you'll never be in a position to do that with all the smaller nids chewing at your ankles at all times. Execution animations are overlong and lacking in variety. I haven't even played for very long and I'm already sick of the "stab the warrior with his own sword" animation.

The visuals and art direction are where this game succeeds the most. every little detail oozes 40k and it really feels like the most complete rendition of the setting we've ever gotten in a game. The sheer size of some of the enemy hordes you'll see and fight are hugely impressive. If you see a wave of tyranids cresting a hill, they aren't just set dressing, they're coming for you and they're hungry. However, despite the quality of most visuals in the game, I must say that the flamethrower might just be the single worst video-game flamethrower I've ever seen. It was so bad that it actually made me stop playing so I could write this. It's frankly baffling how terrible it looks and feels to use, you'd think that the game about fighting hordes of alien bugs would have put some effort into making the ideal anti-horde weapon look and feel good, but nope. It doesn't set enemies on fire, doesn't light up the environment and doesn't leave any lingering flames behind. It's pathetic, frankly.

Overall my first impressions are mixed. More positive than negative, but if you aren't a 40k fan, I'd say you're safe skipping this one. I'd give this game a low 7/10, closer to a 6 than an 8.

I've had this game on my radar for almost 3 years, was somewhat concerned when it got delayed a year but man am I incredibly happy they decided to because this game feels insanely polished. I played this game solely in low graphics for the entire main campaign and it still is one of the most atmospheric and gorgeous games I've ever played.

If you're familiar with Warhammer 40k in any capacity (or are somewhat of a tourist that knows some lore tidbits like myself) and you love the aesthetic and have wished for so long for a sort of immersive experience that takes place in the franchise's world in a form that ISN'T a turn based game; this is a must buy, instantly.

The campaign was amazing, around 8-9 hours of content but it felt perfect for me, not too short, not too bloated. And the finale just drove me over the edge, genuinely such an incredible high note to add on with plenty of fan-service that satisfied me and will surely make a bunch of loreheads incredibly excited and happy to see through.

Very small complaints, it would seem the game is generally scaled for 3 individual players given that the bot companions are actually not very useful at all! My recommendation if you're getting into the game with your friends is to go into veteran difficulty and experience the game that way, but I'd advise against higher difficulties solo. It's not impossible, just feels overwhelming when the enemies don't ever focus anyone but you and you're tasked with just using the best gear, leaving no real room for customization or experimentation (when it's your first time playing through the game).

Aside from that, not much else that I care about, oh aside from the final boss seemingly not letting you go in with your preferred loadout in the main campaign? Seemingly the only place that happens and I'm not sure if it's intentional. Granted I played this over the course of the first day for ultra and gold edition owners so this will surely get patched out in a week or less.

Oh and operations are incredibly cool and will be a lot of the replayability for many players with how you can customize your own class specific space marine in SO MANY LEVELS of fashion. I'm still waiting on my friends to get on since they only got the base game without the headstart, but I'm excited to play through these missions with them.

Last notes, I do wish you had some kinds of Chaos customization but I'm not damaged in any way that it isn't there. Also there is going to be a lot more content coming out in at least the next year and a half, the developers have actively released a roadmap explaning the addition of full on enemy classes and operation missions ENTIRELY FREE, with the only paid DLC coming in the form cosmetics, plus talks of adding full on playable classes in the future? We'll see if that talk actually goes anywhere but I can't say the idea of it doesn't have me thrilled.

As it stands now, I've yet to 100% the game and excited that I have plenty to experience and unlock. I'm extremely grateful for everyone involved in creating this product (that was clearly made for me since it comes out officially on the day I was born!), and I'm excited to see what comes in the future of this great game!

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 - A Review

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 delivers an exhilarating experience that both fans of the franchise and newcomers will find impressive. Developed by Saber Interactive and published by Focus Entertainment, this sequel successfully builds on the foundation laid by the original game while introducing fresh elements to keep the gameplay engaging and exciting.


Set in the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40,000, the game immerses players in a desperate battle for survival. As a Space Marine, you are thrust into the chaotic struggle against the Tyranids, a relentless alien species. The narrative does an excellent job of capturing the essence of the Warhammer 40K lore, with its dark and brooding atmosphere perfectly complementing the intense action. The storyline is well-crafted, offering a gripping and emotionally charged experience that keeps players invested in the fate of the characters and the broader conflict.


The gameplay in Space Marine 2 is a standout feature. The game combines fast-paced action with deep combat mechanics, allowing players to engage in brutal, visceral battles. The combat system is robust, offering a satisfying mix of shooting and melee combat that feels both powerful and precise. The variety of weapons and abilities at your disposal ensures that combat never feels repetitive, and the ability to customize your loadout adds a strategic layer to the gameplay.

The game also introduces new mechanics and refinements from its predecessor. The improved AI and enhanced enemy variety make each encounter feel unique and challenging. The level design is top-notch, featuring intricate environments that offer tactical opportunities and add to the immersion. The seamless transition between ranged and melee combat is particularly noteworthy, allowing players to fluidly switch between different combat styles depending on the situation.


Visually, Space Marine 2 is a treat. The game boasts impressive graphics that bring the Warhammer 40K universe to life with stunning detail. The character models, environments, and special effects all contribute to a visually striking experience. The dark, gritty aesthetic of the Warhammer universe is captured beautifully, enhancing the overall atmosphere of the game.

The audio design is equally impressive. The sound effects are impactful, from the satisfying crunch of melee attacks to the deafening blasts of gunfire. The voice acting and soundtrack further immerse players in the game, with the voice work adding depth to the characters and the soundtrack heightening the tension and excitement of the battles.


The multiplayer component of Space Marine 2 is a welcome addition, offering various modes that extend the game's longevity. Whether you’re teaming up with friends or competing against other players, the multiplayer matches are well-designed and provide a fun and competitive experience. The replayability is enhanced by the variety of weapons, skills, and loadouts available, allowing players to experiment with different strategies and playstyles.


Overall, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a standout title in the Warhammer 40K series. It successfully builds on the strengths of its predecessor while introducing new elements that enhance the overall experience. With its engaging storyline, refined combat mechanics, impressive visuals, and immersive audio, it’s a must-play for fans of the franchise and a compelling entry point for newcomers. The game delivers a memorable and action-packed experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

As a die-hard Warhammer fan, I approached Warhammer: Space Marine with cautious optimism, trying to set my biases aside. So, what's my verdict? It’s… just okay. But let’s dive deeper into that.

First off, it was undeniably fun to role-play as a badass Space Marine. Mowing down hordes of Xenos was incredibly satisfying, and every execution felt intensely gratifying. The PvP mode brought a wave of nostalgia, reminding me of the old-school shooters from the 2010s. Simple, but effective—and despite being a bit undercooked, it was highly enjoyable. Admittedly, I spent most of my time in PvP after finishing the campaign. The different classes felt distinct, and each had its own utility without any glaring balance issues.

On the PvE side, it’s a solid option for some casual co-op fun with friends—perfect for those laid-back Friday nights. If you're a Warhammer fan, especially one who loves Space Marines, there’s a lot to appreciate here. The customization options for your Space Marine are extensive, letting you personalize your character as much or as little as you want, which is a nice touch.

Visually, the game is impressive, though the controls can feel a bit clunky at first. Thankfully, customizable keybindings help smooth out the experience. However, some of the animations feel stiff, and the AI companions can be frustratingly inept, especially during defense missions on higher difficulties.

The real highlight is PvP combat. While the mechanics are simple, the execution is satisfying, and the customization options, especially for loyalist Space Marines, are deep—giving off a “dress to impress” vibe reminiscent of classic games. The Heretical Astartes, though, don’t get the same love in terms of customization, which is a missed opportunity.

But this is where the praise tapers off. The story? Basic, with a straightforward premise that doesn’t leave much to chew on once you’ve put the controller down. PvP, while fun, is limited to just three game modes and a handful of maps. And, despite the engaging core gameplay, the lack of meaningful progression holds it back from being something truly special. I also encountered a few bugs that don’t seem to have been widely discussed yet. For instance, my character would sometimes randomly fly across the map, or worse, every character—including mine—would start clipping through the floors. Fortunately, reloading from the last checkpoint or restarting the game usually fixed these issues, but it was still a frustrating experience.The final boss, especially on higher difficulties, dragged on far too long, making it feel like it overstayed its welcome and left a bit of a sour taste by the end.
In the end, Warhammer: Space Marine is a decent experience, but it falls short in key areas that could have made it great.

It's an excellent game. The campaign has non stop moments of epic and memorable scenes that are packed so densely with laconian style blunt conversations and phrases that you can smell the sweat through the screen as your character regains his faith in brotherhood. There wasn't a moment where I was bored and thought to myself that the game was being padded out, I just had fun all the way through the campaign. This all is enhanced by the badass combat, where it looks like you're effortlessly cutting down the craziest monsters in rapid succession if you're playing well, while getting your face kicked in if you don't. Parrying, doging, gunstriking, armor and your melee movesets provides so much avenue to swing your big ♥♥♥♥ around, without it feeling like you're getting everything for free, because even a few little enemies can destroy you if you go afk. You're basically forced to regain health through hits, then line up gunstrikes or executions to regain armor, which protects your health against ranged. It feels so good to do because EVERYTHING can be parried and stomped into the ground, you're like a tank inching forward through the masses of enemies, without it feeling too easy. It's like Sekiro or Elden Ring, you can parry/deflect everyone's moveset with a very generous window if you make the right choices. I hope they DON'T add health regain on executions because it would make the game feel like ♥♥♥♥, because then you turn into a brain dead execution drone who doesn't even understand gunstrikes, which ruins the skill ceiling and what makes this gameplay feel so good.

Operations is a PvE Coop mode alá Darktide that adds a whole bunch of RPG mechanics as you play through missions from the view point of another squad. You get a dozen classes to level up with, with passive skill trees, a lot of weapon variants that don't even exist in the campaign, getting full access to customize your armor and even having skill trees on weapons. These skill trees have just enough impact to make you feel like a god once you're progressing through them (ie. regenerating health on kill perks). It provides enough complexity and enjoyment that it feels like a fresh experience right after the campaign, which doesn't have much RPG elements at all.

Seriously though, the skill ceiling of the gameplay is so rewarding that this could easily be a not recommeded if they make it easier.

For almost a decade, I wished for a sequel to Space Marine.

I was afraid it would never happen. THQ crashing and burning had left the possibility of a true sequel in limbo. In spite of Overwhelmingly Positive reviews on Steam, and a fairly large cult following, I had doubt that anyone would pick up the ball, and finish what Relic started.

Then, to my shock, a couple years ago, a trailer drops.

I wanted to shout for joy, but almost instantly, I became skeptical.

Worried that my beloved game could never have the sequel it deserved in our current development culture. The new studio would gut it of what made it's soul, insert contrived modern tropes and disrespect the source and setting.

I have NEVER been so happy to be wrong.

Space Marine 2 is Marvelous. Jaw-Dropping.

Saber has taken Relics Masterpiece to new heights, added new mechanics that enhance the experience and expanded the multiplayer, seamlessly weaving it into the campaign, making it far more interesting and addictive that it's predecessor.

Bravo, Saber, Focus, GW and Everyone who made this happen.

Wow, where to begin, I'm only 6 hours deep into the game so far, and every expectation I've had has been shattered. When they said that hundreds if not thousands of enemy units will be on screen, they meant it. The battles are massive, the enemies unending and unrelenting, but they captured the feel of an Astartes (space marine) perfectly. The gunplay and swordplay feel terrific, the special kill animations are gory and glorious, all of the melee weapons feel like they have weight and even with the hordes of enemies, you feel powerful.

I especially enjoy seeing the imperial guard regiments in the campaign. Youll run into them regularly and they always say something about the Astartes showing up to save the day. Fighting alongside Leman Russ's and Chimeras while wielding a heavy bolter and a company of cadian troopers charging in with battle cries is exactly the experiences I was looking for in this game. Every expectation I've had so far has been exceeded bar 1.

So far my only complaints is that it takes sooooooooooo long to load into an operation mission, and it seems that others are experiencing this issue as well as I waited for 30 minutes and no one was able to connect. My other complaint is I highly recommend making some friends or convincing some to buy to play with. The AI comrades are almost useless in some fights, and on hard difficulty it really makes it tough to advance.

TLDR: Definitely worth the money so far IMO. Absolutely shattered every expectation I had going into it. I'll update my review once I finish the campaign.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A brutal and thrilling adventure.
As a huge fan of the Warhammer IP, from the grim darkness of 40k to the rich tales of the Old World, Horus Heresy, and Age of Sigmar, I love it all. I played the first Space Marine game and enjoyed it, so I had high hopes for the sequel. And let me tell you, this game is fantastic.

Space Marine 2 captures the essence of 40k perfectly, immersing players in a beautifully detailed universe. The graphics are stunning, with every level well designed to showcase the dark, gothic beauty of the 40k world. From the imposing statue of Sanguinius to the intricate banners and relics, it’s clear that this game was made by fans, for fans.

The sound design is top-notch, too, with every bolter shot and chainsword swing feeling powerful and satisfying. The soundtrack and ambient noises perfectly set the mood, making every battle feel epic and intense.

One of the standout features is the use of the World War Z engine, which brings the Tyranid swarms to life in a terrifyingly perfect way. The engine handles the massive hordes seamlessly, creating a sense of terror and chaos that fits the Warhammer universe like a gauntlet. Charging into a sea of Tyranids, cutting them down by the dozens, feels exactly how a Space Marine game should.

Gameplay is smooth and responsive, with a perfect balance between melee and ranged combat. It’s fast-paced and brutal, just like the lore demands. The controls are awesome.

Overall, Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike. It captures the heart of the 40k universe with fantastic graphics, solid gameplay, and a deep appreciation for the lore. It’s a brutal, beautiful experience that delivers on every front.

Prepare your bolter, and dive into the fray.
Space Marine 2 is a glorious addition to the Warhammer legacy.

Space Marine 2 is the first game I've giddily anticipated like a child before Christmas in about 10 years. The game itself is wonderful, but the content is condensed, so outside of replaying on harder difficulties, you can knock out the entire story in a day or two.

Space Marine 2 yearns for content patches and expansion packs. The story of the Operations mode is so neatly interwoven with the Campaign experience, that it's hard to believe there will be many new levels introduced outside of a full blown expansion pack that adds levels to both experiences.

Are there glaring balance issues? Yes. Are there bugs? Yes, Do I have friends who meet the minimum requirements, but still have rendering issues on some levels? Yes. All of these things are subject to improve. I am eagerly awaiting the next major content update and further optimizations.

Space Marine 2 is shaping up to be an engaging action-packed experience for both seasoned fans of Warhammer 40k and newcomers to the franchise. Here's an all-encompassing review of the game based on your observations:

Pros:
- Phenomenal Graphics: Space Marine 2 delivers visually stunning landscapes, character models, and enemies. The graphics bring the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40k to life in a way that feels rich, immersive, and true to the source material. The environments and combat animations elevate the sense of scale and brutality in each battle.

- Great Gameplay & Simple Mechanics: The game offers smooth and straightforward gameplay, making it accessible even to newer players. The controls are intuitive, and while the combat feels deep enough to satisfy experienced players, it’s simple enough to pick up and enjoy without a steep learning curve.

- Variety of Difficulty Levels: For players looking for a tailored experience, the game features multiple difficulty settings. Whether you’re looking for a challenge or just a casual playthrough, you can adjust the game to your preferred level of intensity.

- Progression System: Space Marine 2 features a well-thought-out progression system, with plenty of upgrades and customization options for your character. Though the progression can feel grindy at times, especially if you're short on gaming time, it provides a sense of accomplishment as you develop your character and abilities. It encourages replayability.

- Straightforward, Action-Packed Story: The game delivers exactly what you’d expect from a Warhammer 40k title. The story is clear-cut, action-heavy, and reminiscent of video game narratives from the 2010s. For those tired of overly complicated, meandering plots, this is a refreshing return to straightforward, cinematic storytelling. The cutscenes are well-executed and add to the overall immersion.

- Perfect for Co-op Play: The game allows for co-op multiplayer, which can make the experience even more enjoyable. Playing with friends adds another layer of strategy and fun, and can greatly affect the difficulty and pacing of the game.

Cons:
- Grindiness for Some Players: While the progression system is rewarding, the grind required to unlock certain abilities and gear can be a turnoff for players who don’t have a lot of time. Depending on how long you can dedicate to playing, this might feel tedious, though it’s a staple of games with RPG elements.

- Occasional Bugs: Like many new releases, Space Marine 2 has a few technical issues. Players have reported performance drops, occasional crashes, and trouble joining co-op/multiplayer modes. However, these bugs appear to be situational, and your experience may vary. Fortunately, you haven’t encountered many problems yourself as of September 5th, but it’s something to be aware of, especially for others who might experience these issues.

- Limited Story Length: While the story itself is enjoyable, it’s on the shorter side. Depending on the difficulty you choose and whether you’re playing alone or with friends, the campaign can be completed in roughly 6-10 hours. For players who prefer longer single-player experiences, this could feel brief.

Conclusion:
- Overall, Space Marine 2 is a fantastic game for anyone looking for a visually stunning, action-packed, and accessible Warhammer 40k experience. Its simple yet satisfying mechanics, impressive graphics, and straightforward story make it a great title to dive into, especially for those who enjoy co-op play. While some may find the grind a bit much or experience technical hiccups, the overall experience is engaging and reminiscent of classic action games from the 2010s—refreshing in a world full of grind-heavy titles.

Let's get the obvious out of the way. The operations, just like with the PvP mode, is bolted on with little design beyond "getting it working" mechanically. Let's not pretend otherwise. It's great that it's there, don't get me wrong, but loading into it feels like the game was going to be something else other than Space Marine 2, like a third person Darktide. They even have the same briefing screen when joining a mission.

The six marines that play the classes are effectively walking one tone characters that are designed to be replaceable easily, and it's very telling that the game has a "default" selection of who actually goes on them to the point that the lines rarely match up. Not very jarring, given as it's effectively only two or so lines per instance it happens, but it's very clear that it's a case of "Meanwhile, this is happening", and that leads to thinking if it was just cut out to be replaced as just co-op optional mode rather than the mandatory sections it is now. Which likely means I can probably guess where at least one of the upcoming new missions is going to be, but I could be wrong.

Sticking to the mechanical details, both the main campaign and these side operations have no lobby options. The main campaign is mercifully friends only, but the operations are match made, meaning that frequently I found myself joining one in progress, and often a significant chuck into it. This, with other games that have done multiplayer story lobbies, is jarring when you're coming out of a briefing only to find yourself in the final section of the mission with no details between. Add to that needing to effectively pull the networking offline if you wanted to play it solo without worrying if you're slowing someone down with looking around or paying attention to the map, and it feels very cheaply thrown in to pad out an already lacking story.
This IS something that is going to change "sometime soon" given the season pass, however it's rather telling that it was pushed out the door a touch too soon. The PvP modes are more evident of this, given at the time of making this review, Quick match straight up doesn't work and there's barely a handful of maps. And even then, they feel almost identical, besides setting changes and the layout of the central area.

I've played a few hours of it, and frankly while it is serviceable, it is VERY clear where the main draw of the game is, even when reading the roadmap and season pass. And it's not in PvP.

So why am I recommending it? After all, that was a sizeable rant for a blue thumbs up. The short version?

Because it's more Space Marine.

The operations themselves might just be shorter sections, but they still have the same polish with the map design that the main game has. Especially with the Tyranids. Yes, they may not have the same character or different mob types than DEM KRAZY GITZ the Orks have, but then you have the numbers. Yes, technically there's less variety with them, but given the nature of the race, it makes sense. They are a hivemind that are literal billions in number, and the game loves to remind you of that in set pieces that throw massive hordes at you.

This gets shifted a bit when inevitably the spoilers start coming into effect, but there's enough going on to stop things from getting too samely. I mean, it's a game with the imperium of Man in it, but I won't ruin which flavour of inevitable.

The setting once again is nailed out of the park. Everything is exactly as you'd expect from a top flight Warhammer game, and is only improved in the sequel over the original game. What setbacks, however, are in the game's health mechanic and the melee.

The healing from aggression is still there, but now it's closer to how Bloodborne manages it. You take a hit, and you can restore back to full if you are quick and aggressive enough to deal damage, with finishers restoring any white health, plus armour, back. However, the nerf is that the recoverable section ticks down, and once lost, you only have very limited stims or your special to get it back.
This certainly is more challenging, but at the higher difficulty levels it feels almost too much of a step back. But then, that's going to differ player to player, depending if you're into the power fantasy of being a post humanoid, cybernetic master of murder or one (very powerful) person against forces too numerous to count.

The melee, on the other hand is not as fluid as it once was. This comes from the addition of a "parry" mechanic, and I should quickly mention it is not as "twitchy" as something like the Souls games have it. The game doesn't explain it well enough, beyond the "Hit button to counter blue, dodge orange" tells. You can literally parry any standard melee in the game, however doing so locks you in place for a moment. I think this is where the "clunky" comments come in, as nothing else is different than the previous game, but it gets to a point where you're not certain if blocking strikes is worth it outside of the blue tells you're "supposed" to be countering.
It also doesn't seem to work in PvP. You can still block melee strikes, yes, but then you're stuck in place, and the opponent can just keep swinging and swinging until they can inevitably chip you out, heavy attack to break it, or you try to roll out of it. Granted, this is likely more signs of the multiplayer modes just being bolted onto the game and the feature was more for the AI targets, or that there's little way of explaining how it works in PvP.
Outside of that, it's effectively the same as with the first game. Which, given it was perfectly serviceable there, is just as good now beyond the parry system being a touch unreliable.

But again, this count be the fact my first time through was on Veteran, and a lack of understanding on how it works. But it's still minor gripes.

Overall, I'm still going to carry on playing it. At time of this meme, I've cleared the single and co-op content at about twelvish hours. Not that I'm a believer in "hours played = cost" crowd, but given the launch at £55, going to £80 or £90 after the season pass and more Smurf focused DLC, I'd certainly would say slap it into a wishlist and watch what happens in a few months’ time. I'm not regretting it, but if you're just in it to follow on the adventures of Titus, new voice artist and all, I'd poke around a bit before diving in. As to if the season pass is worth it, I'd absolutely avoid pulling the trigger until there's more details.

But, nagging matters aside, it's more Space Marine. Which is absolutely fine by me, even if it is more bloody Ultramarines...

Сюжет
Начнем с того, что со времен Space Marine прошёл целый век. Капитан Деметриан Тит, по причине обвинения в ереси со стороны своего собрата Леандора, был отправлен на допрос к Инквизиции. Хотя, в будущем, обвинения были впоследствии сняты,Титу, пришлось вступить в Караул Смерти, где ему пришлось отслужить пол века. В конечном итоге, в результате попытке остановить вторжение Тиранидов - расы жукоподобных существ, основная цель которых пожирать систему за системой, в системе Рекидиус на планете Кадаку, Тит был смертельно ранен, но его быстро спасают новоприбывшие Ультрамарины. После пробуждения, Тит встречает капеллана Квинта, которые рассказывает о прохождении Рубикона Примариса по приказу магистра Марнеуса Калгара. Тит хочет вернуться в Дозор Смерти, но Квинт напоминает ему, что он был освобожден от влияния Хаоса и что если он действительно хочет искупить свои грехи, то он должен помочь своим братьям. Титус принимает доспехи Примариса и Квинт советует ему сохранять своё прошлое в тайне и докладывать капитану Акерану о своих делах. Акеран назначает Титуса командиром отряда, в состав которого входят братья Кайрон и Гадриэль. В целом, весь сюжет будет вертеться вокруг попытки Империума человечества остановить Тиранидов, а в последствии столкнуться с силами Хаоса.

В целом, Space Marine 2 продолжает идеи своей предшественницы: это шутер от третьего лица, совмещённый с жанром hack and slash. Игроку придётся использовать как дальнобойное оружие для сражения со слабыми врагами, так и холодное оружие для борьбы с более сильными врагами, так как пули на них не действуют. Здоровье восстанавливается, если добить врага или использовать лечебный стимулятор. Броня восстанавливается сама по себе со временем. В сюжетную кампанию можно играть как одному, так и втроём. Также, в игре имеются и полностью сетевые режимы, например, битвы в формате 6-на-6.
EN:
The continuation, probably not one of the many successful games in the universe of the world of Warhammer 40,000, many have been waiting for too long. Everyone who played, at one time, the first part of Space Marin, was clearly impressed by all the brutal trailers, starting in 2021.
So the developers from Saber Interactive, who were given a very important mission, namely not to fall into the dirt when creating a video game based on this iconic franchise, on a par with "World of Warcraft".
And, thank God, the creators of another numbered part did their best to please the fans of this universe, as well as attract new people.
The sequel has become noticeably bigger, better and grander. Although it is based on a familiar foundation laid by the authors of the original.

Let's start with the fact that a whole century has passed since the time of Space Marine. Captain Demetrian Titus, because of the accusation of heresy by his brother Leandor, was sent for interrogation to the Inquisition. Although, in the future, the charges were subsequently dropped, Titus had to join the Death Guard, where he had to serve for half a century. Eventually, as a result of an attempt to stop the invasion of the Tyranids, a race of beetle-like creatures whose main purpose is to devour system after system, into the Rekidius system on the planet Kadaku, Titus was mortally wounded, but he was quickly rescued by the newly arrived Ultramarines. After waking up, Titus meets Chaplain Quintus, who tells him about the passage of the Rubicon Primaris on the orders of Magister Marneus Kalgar. Titus wants to return to the Deathwatch, but Quintus reminds him that he has been freed from the influence of Chaos and that if he really wants to atone for his sins, then he must help his brothers. Titus accepts Primaris' armor and Quintus advises him to keep his past a secret and report to Captain Akeran about his affairs. Akeran appoints Titus as the commander of the squad, which includes the brothers Kiron and Gadriel. In general, the whole plot will revolve around the attempt of the Imperium of mankind to stop the Tyranids, and subsequently face the forces of Chaos.
In general, Space Marine 2 continues the ideas of its predecessor: it is a third-person shooter combined with the hack and slash genre. The player will have to use both long-range weapons to fight weak enemies, and cold steel weapons to fight stronger enemies, since bullets do not work on them. Health is restored if you finish off an enemy or use a therapeutic stimulant. The armor regenerates on its own over time. The storyline campaign can be played either alone or as a threesome. The game also has fully online modes, such as 6-on-6 battles.

This game came as a bit of a surprise, since the first instalment of the series was a moderately successful title that left fans wanting more. Now, 13 entire years later, we get a sequel that turbo boosts the concept of the original in every way imaginable.
You still play as Titus, but now you have a squad that follows you in every mission, and the main enemy for the first half of the game are Tyranids.
Said Tyranids have some of the best dynamic swarm movement I've ever seen in a videogame thanks to the dev's experience with similar mechanics on games like World War Z.
They can break off into clusters, pile on top of walls and generally act like a real horde, not a pre-scripted bot puppet.
Graphically, the game is truly impressive, perhaps one of the best I've ever seen. I never tire of looking at the vast, grandiose cities going down in flames as battles rage on in the distance, with swarms of aliens descending from the skies while battleships fire at them. The design of the marines and maps is also spot-on, Warhammer fans (myself included) will rejoice at the small details on every character and building model.
Of course, such heavy graphical fidelity comes at the price of performance, and the game does need a beast of a PC to run: with an RTX4070 ti, I could only manage 60-90 FPS at 1440p with everything maxed, with dips below 60 in extremely messy scenes. Still, DLSS did its job (I'm sure that without it, performance would be even worse) and the game hasn't crashed in over 12 hours of play so far.
Sound design is also good, with special mention going to the weapon effects: one can only describe them as...meaty.
Now, to the main point: the gameplay is limited, but enjoyable. What I mean by this is that you won't get any complex plots, open maps and huge skill trees here: story mode is almost completely linear, point A to point B, kill enemies, cutscene, repeat. You have some loadout options, but overall it's really not worth playing more than once.
However, it is very fun, and it doesn't overstay its welcome at an average duration of 8-10 hours (side missions excluded).
The melee combat didn't click much for me personally, with an awkward parry system and combos that can be performed with only one button. The ranged, third-person shooting is very satisfying though.
After you're done with the story, you have two main modes to discover: the side missions that are heavily coop-focused and have their own class and progression system, and the PvP multiplayer.
Said missions are much more challenging than the main story and require you to use your combined abilities and weapons to succeed, while offering weapon leveling, special abilities, small skill trees and marine customization options.
The PvP is serviceable, offering the usual modes ones would expect (capture point, team death match etc.) while including a modified version of the skill trees used in the other mode. It runs much better performance-wise (120 FPS) and it feels alright, not exactly an afterthought but certainly not the mode the devs have put the most work on. For example, they could have added extra features like vehicles, turrets, abilities unique to each faction or even the ability to control Tyranids ala Left 4 Dead to make it more exciting.
Most of the criticism I can throw at this game is simply my wish for more of it: more missions, more weapons, more classes and definitely more factions. Happily, the devs have promised exactly that with the roadmap: we'll get further updates along the way, for free (with a paid cosmetic option) and a very likely expansion in the future, as the ending of the main story hints at more adventures.
Given the commercial success of the title, I'm sure we'll get all of that and more.

30 hours in and I'm going to iterate on what I find nice:

Melee - It's a LITTLE wonky with some animations taking longer or being shorter depending on weapon, though some feel a bit clunky with how they lock you. However parrying and dodging are mixed well into it, gunstrike's making melee a little forgiving but you are sadly unable to get into the thick of it like Space Marine 1.

Ranged - Guns feel punchy, they are satisfying to use, some perhaps taking more of a learning curve but they're all very much viable. The Heavy Weapons especially. There isn't much else to say other than some ranged weapons can fulfill a role much better than others and some can be jack of all trades.

Enemies - Ehhh...some of them feel okay to fight but are a little overtuned. My gripe is with the Termgant and Tzangor. Why these two? Because the Termagant is a swarm based ranged unit that can come in a dozen per wave doing way too much damage for how accurate they can be and how numerous they can be. A lot of people go 'skill issue' well how is it a skill issue when the enemy has a nigh 100% accuracy with every shot they make, and each shot chips away your armor like it is a literal piece of air, Termagants feel overtuned.

Why are Tzangor's mentioned? They're a melee swarm unit with SHIELDS, why is that bad? Unless you use MELTA you are not getting through the shield. I can see WHY they gave SOME shields and not all, but the shields feel like they're a bit much, because they don't take damage until they either lower the shield or you manage to get around them. Not to mention on higher difficulties, a single Tzangor can take down 1 to 2 Armor bars, and a good chunk of HP. These little guys, come in packs of 20 or more in the waves.

Story - If you've played Space Marine 1 you are in the right ball-park of how this goes, but there is a decent bit of twist to it. I will say that of all things, the story felt good. It felt like a proper Warhammer 40k story rather than just something tacked on as a second thought.

Overall? Yes I do recommend it, but I would also recommend tempering expectation. Some enemies feel overtuned, dodge timing is a little wonky and I'm STILL trying to get it down after finishing campaign and playing on Substantial threat level in Operations.

The game is wonderful, but there are some parts that need more time in the oven to be considered a full part of the meal. Some enemies that need more tuning to be considered a challenge fully, rather than just a bit of an unpredictable mess.

For those who say Skill Issue, I'd like actual REASONS as to why you're going to say that rather than just you saying it and moving on without properly elaborating, because all that tells me is that you haven't actually played the game that long, and/or you don't care about others in the game than yourself.

At the time of writing, yes the game is playable albeit with some significant performance modifications. On my OLED I’ve managed to squeeze out 30FPS with occasional drops to ~24, 65-70deg temperature, and around ~3hrs from a full charge,

I’ll share mine here, gained from tinkering and looking at other user’s solutions…

Starting with Deck settings, I’ll go with my usual:

- FPS 30
- TDP 12
- GPU Clock 1200
- Scaling Mode: Stretch
- Scaling Filter: FSR

And game settings:

- Display Mode: Windowed
- Resolution: anything below 1280x800
- Render Resolution: Performance
- Resolution Upscaling: FSR 2
- Motion blur: Off
- Quality Preset: Low (for all)

Brightness calibration- tailored to individual taste.

And back to the game - so far it’s hugely refreshing for a new release AAA game. Great combat, great story, great fun.
