This is a good game, a game with alot of issues but I do recommend it if you are even slightly interested in WH40K

Combat is pretty good, the parry system can sometimes have issues if multiple parries come up. If you time one right but then another pops up it seems to cancel it sometimes and you get hit when you were not even trying to parry the 2nd attack. The dodge always seems to work, but the problem is this game has some really wonky hitboxes so you will get hit dodging and wonder what even hit you (espicaly with bosses oh god its bad with bosses) where they have invisible hitboxes that will hit you even if you arn't even close. The Carnifex was the worst for this but its manageable.

The healing system is awful on Angel of Death, the melee to restore health becomes pointless because you take so much damage you never get any back with all the enemies jumping at you. And health injectors are so rare, for many sections of the game its laughable. Your fury mode becomes the main option for healing, where you want to avoid combat and stand there and recharge but it feels counter intuitive to what it was actually meant for

The guns feel great but they sound really, really weak. I don't know if its a mixing issue or something but they lack any real oomph to them and bolters sound more like you are firing a semi automatic pistol or something and it kinda sucks, but gameplay wise I found myself using almost all the weapons at one point or another and getting results with them. Which leads to alot of experimentation and exploring the systems which is really good.

There are some major bugs, some levels glitch out and you cant pickup guns or items(looking at you cargo elevator) and also sometimes the AI totally bugs out and will just refuse to rez you, they will walk towards you then get distracted and run back and forth while your meter ticks down and its infuriating. Sometimes the AI just totally loses it and will just stand still and do nothing for large periods of time. Also randomly when Acheran was giving his speech in the hanger I walked up to watch it and a space marine came up behind me and trapped me and I had to reload the entire game because I got stuck which was really random.

The game falls into the trap difficulty wise what alot of games do, which is just turning things into bullet sponges that do alot of damage as opposed to real difficulty. Ghost of Tsushima mastered this, and honestly on Angel of Death if they just lowered the health pools on some enemies and kept literally everything else the same it would be way more tolerable and actually fun. Having to put 4 clips from a bolter run to get a full reload and then another couple clips into a Zoanthrope to just get it to go down becomes a point of hilarity. Although this is remedied by just having Krak grenades(which the game seems to keep forgetting you have because grenade pickups basically become extinct in the certain parts of the game)

The campaign at times becomes kind of a slog when many of the major set pieces s just stand here, and do the thing that prevents meter in the top corner from going down/up. Its distracting having to watch the meter while you want to actually look at whats going on, on the screen and annoying because it feels uninspired after you do it for like the 6th time.

Now all my complaints I had though, are entirely remedied with the sections of the game with the jetpacks. I honestly think they should of just built the entire game as Assault Troops because it feels amazing. The quick movement to escape hordes, jumping in and out of melee, picking off enemies in the air. It feels like thats how the game should be played. It almost turns into a doom-esque with how fast paced it becomes and its glorious.

The pvp is also fantastic and I think if they keep updating with maps and unlockables it has a real leg to stand on.

Pros:
- You feel the weight, strength, and agility of an armored space marine.
- You'll shout "For the Emperor!" and "Death to xenos!" while crushing endless hordes (characters in-game shout it too).
- Storyline, characters, lore, atmosphere, and animations: excellent.
- Gameplay and mechanics: decent.
- Visuals: stunning.
- Audio: good music but lacks a better sound stage during action, cutscenes, and events. Battle sounds are often muffled and generic.
- Technical/optimization: okay for 2024. Runs smoothly at 4K@60 fps on a 5800X3D with a 3080Ti on ultra settings with DLSS in performance mode.

Cons:
- Connection issues affect single-player: Requires an internet connection and can lose connectivity, forcing mission restarts from the last checkpoint. Allows continuing offline, but this problem recurred even during the end credits, interrupting them.
- Co-op campaign is essential; solo doesn't work well. Bot companions are primitive, forcing the player to handle all tasks and boss attacks. Because of that most missions are less fun, some much harder and veteran difficulty is nearly impossible solo; had to complete it on normal.

Offering unmatched quality from game-play to graphics, performance, and overall package, there's no better game so far. It is a terrific third-person shooter with a compelling story, loads of weapons that are a blast to use. This game raises the bar for all Warhammer adaptations.

Multiple missions into the campaign so far, and a couple matches into multiplayer and think it's a solid time to write a review. Further disclosure for future context, this is written during the early launch so some of it might change in day 1 patches or later updates.

COMBAT
The game feels pretty good in general, like an update to Space Marine 1, exactly like it should. Control scheme is a little different but the features and feel are basically all still intact, there are minor differences in it that prevent things like the old short hops/instant slam combos that I do miss, however that may just be rose tinted goggles for classic jankiness. My only real gripes so far are two things:

For starters, health and defenses feel so much lower across the board than the first game, there are times I honestly feel like swiss cheese the moment I get touched by anything whether it's PvP or PvE and it doesn't seem to matter the class either as armor disappears if something looks at you wrong let alone attacks you, and it takes much longer to regen too.

Secondly executions. I have no idea what possessed them to change executions to only restoring armor, but it does not feel as remotely rewarding as SM1, this also exacerbates the other issue, because what good does regaining my armor do when the moment the execution finishes and I'm being swarmed again it instantly gets knocked off. It honestly feels like someone on the dev team looked at potions and medkits from Vermintide and thought "let's just do that" without considering the impact it'd have to shoehorn those into a game not originally designed for them, at the cost of the original healing mechanics.

That aside the new parry and Gun Strike both feel pretty fantastic and definitely add some to very basic and stripped down hack n' slash of the original game, especially when you can chain them on some of the meatier enemies. First getting a well timed parry, leaving them vulnerable to the gun strike for critical damage, which stuns them for an execution. This creates a pretty great flow and definitely rewarding when you quickly burst down some otherwise bullet sponge like enemies.

VISUALS
Looks wise, the game so far has been very vibrant and detailed with some set pieces/moments that visually tie in greatly with the gameplay, such as seeing large hordes in the distance that would in almost any other game be just background visuals while you fight waves off, but here they actually are the wave you're fighting and I think it ties in amazingly with the theme of having to deal with a flood of Nids. There are some other great visual/gameplay tie in set pieces but I don't want to mention too much.

STORY
I won't touch on too much on story due to not having finished it, but it makes some rather predictable turns so far, as well as some contrived convenience for plot. But it's 40k, I didn't come here looking for Shakespeare or the pinnacle of realistic storytelling, rule of cool is king in 40k, and so far it's been delivering on that.

MULTIPLAYER
It is looking pretty good in general so far, the addition of co-op to the campaign is a big win for sure and feels great to grab some friends and play through, the PvP is pretty much the same as SM1 with the exception of the issue I mentioned previously, and the larger variety of classes is nice. Having a more objective/goal focused mode with Operations as opposed to the old Exterminatus wave survival is interesting, but I do hope to see the wave survival return.

CUSTOMIZATION
Now here is something that I do have some annoyances with. First off, every color should be available for any slot with primary, secondary, and tertiary. If they want to make them unlockables for more of a gameplay loop and reward system(especially considering the lack of distinct armor marks like 1 had) then fine. But there is absolutely no reason to have colors restricted to slot, like why is it that I can ONLY color trim gold but not use it as a primary if I want? Between that and the lack of patterns for more detailed color schemes like different colored thigh armor to boots, and individual hands(noticed Crimson Fists absent as a pre-set this time, the Iron Fists also lack their single metallic colored glove) it really feels like just an objective step back with the feature this time around. I really hope in the future they make it so that you can choose unlocked colors in any slot, and that they make colorations like the Crimson Fists possible.

SUMMARY
The game is a perfectly serviceable and generally improved game over the first, other than the couple minor issues I ranted about, I've not had any real issues with the game other than a couple bugs/connectivity issues which I'm sure will be worked out shortly, likely before it's scheduled launch date or as a Day1 patch. So all in all if you liked the first game, or just a pretty big Warhammer fan in general, I see this as a must have right along with Space Marine 1.

Brothers, Space Marine 2 is a triumph of the Emperor’s will, a beacon of His light in this grimdark galaxy. From the moment the ceramite-clad boots of our revered Captain Titus hit the battlefield, you will feel the weight of your duty to the Imperium. Every bolt round fired, every xenos butchered, and every battle cry echoes with the glorious might of the Adeptus Astartes, as it should, brothers.

The game captures the brutal, unyielding reality of the 41st millennium. The combat is visceral, raw, and unforgiving—just as we expect from the eternal war that is our existence. Every swing of your chainsword bites deep, every shot from your bolter obliterates the heretic, the mutant, the alien filth. There is no mercy, no hesitation—only righteous fury.

But beyond the combat, Space Marine 2 immerses you in the brotherhood of the Astartes. You can almost feel the ancient machine spirit of your armor as you stand shoulder to shoulder with your battle-brothers, unbreakable in your resolve. The atmosphere drips with the decay of a dying galaxy, where hope is but a flicker, and the only truth is war.

The visuals, brothers, are nothing short of awe-inspiring. The gothic architecture of the Imperium looms large, casting deep shadows over blood-soaked battlefields. The enemy is legion, and each one more vile than the last, but you—an angel of death—stand above them all, delivering judgment in the Emperor's name.

In truth, Space Marine 2 is not just a game, it is a holy crusade. It reminds us why we fight, why we bleed, why we die. For the Emperor. For humanity. For our brothers.

Praise be to the God-Emperor, brothers. This is war as it was meant to be. And we shall be victorious.

If you are trying to measure this as strictly a standalone video game, and aren't buying this for the IP, it delivers on an 7-8 out of 10 experience fairly well. Nothing too crazy, no standout feature, no unique mechanics.

It's a really polished and good looking 3rd person shooter which reminds you of what the bar once was for that genre. Think a 2010s game with 2024 graphics. Move from one area to the next shooting all enemies, rinse repeat. There is no progression of any kind barring the story. There is also no mid-game ability unlocks unlike games. What you see is what you get from mission 1 to the end minus some set piece levels with a flamethrower and a jetpack.

For 40k fans though, which I am, this delivers on every promise as a space marine simulator. You now get to BE the little model you spent hours painting (with even the option to customize using actual games workshop paints in multiplayer), and allow yourself to be immersed in the frontline of those epic battles you imagine when you play tabletop. The voice acting is everything you expected. From over the top macho yelling, to fervent screams, and all in the name of the holy emperor.

Folks may complain about the simplicity of the game, which is why I started with that point. Still, if you know your 40k lore, and know what to expect of space marines as a whole without dumb expectations (such as characterization from beings who only exist for war), this is all you you would ever need in a space marine game. It doesn't exceed expectations, but it does deliver on its promises.

The only downside is that there are a few bugs that need fixing, however the game is young and the developers plan to keep posting fixes and new content, (for which I am excited). -Animations are brutal and beautiful (think of the og 'For Honor' executions), though a few more execution animations could be nice just since they happen so often.
-The weight and feel of the gameplay makes you really feel like a Space Marine
-Story is top tier, I won't spoil it but I reccomend playing the first game or watching a story summary before playing the story for this game.
-PVE is fun and replayable, even tho there are a limited number of missions, there are some randomized bits that can happen during them and it feels special when they occur
-Customization is fun and 90% are only earnable through gameplay
-The exception to the point i just made above are cosmetics from the seasonal passes, but I am perfectly fine with this because the roadmap shows that all content additions and non-cosmetics from the seasonal releases are completely free.
-There were some crashing issues on the 4 day early access, but within the first day all of the crashes I experienced were patched. The devs QUICKLY address stuff and that gives me hope that the following cons will be remedied soon

Cons:
-In the PVE mode you cannot play the same class as another player. Personally I think that it wouldn't hurt the balance too much to allow this, and it should be allowed so players can play the way they would like. The main issue with this, however, is that matchmaking doesn't match you based on your class and you will often run into lobbies with players all wanting to play the same class. They should take a note from how DRG handles classes and overlap.
-Similarly, in PVP only two players can be the same class. While this at least allows some overlap, it forces some players to play as melee focused classes, which is problematic due to the next issue
-The PVP mode has some balance issues with melee classes being almost entirely useless, but to be fair I'm not too sure how it could be fixed. Also armor customization for the chaos marines in pvp is really limited.
-Controls are a bit weird to get used to, and rebinding is limited (specifically i wanted to change the interact button and execution button, which were both E, to both be F but it would only let me have one be F because they "conflict" even though the default controls "conflict" on E).
-No FOV slider, which when your character takes up half the screen can be a bit of a pain


Overall, despite a few issues, I highly recommend SM2 and I'm looking forward to the future of the game!

New York styled Pizza:
Pizza dough:
14 g instant yeast
617g water - 95F
950g all-purpose flour
19g fine sea salt
25g granulated sugar
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
1 tablespoon (14g) butter
1 tablespoon (9g) extra virgin olive oil
6 cloves garlic, rough chopped
2 teaspoons (4g) red pepper flakes
28 oz (794g) can of crushed tomato
2 teaspoons (2g) dried oregano
1.5 tablespoons (21g) granulated sugar
salt and pepper to taste
Splash of olive oil
2 cups (227g) low moisture mozzarella, fresh grated
2 cups (200g) Monterey jack cheese, fresh grated
1/2 cup (26g) parmigiano reggiano, fresh grated
American Pizza Dough:
Preheat the oven and a baking steel or pizza stone at 500F for 45 minutes before utilizing it.
Whisk yeast and sugar into your water, and allow it to sit for 5 minutes. In a separate bowl, add flour and salt and mix by hand to combine. Pour your water mixture into your flour and mix by hand until you get a rough dough, then transfer to a work surface and knead until it starts to pull away from the work surface and is relatively smooth.
Place your dough in a greased bowl, then cover with plastic wrap and let rise for 1 - 2 hours at room temperature or until double in size.
Punch down your dough and dive into 300g pieces. Form those pieces into balls and place them in a floured proofing pizza box, cover with a lid, and proof at room temperature for 3 - 4 hours. (If you do not have a proofing pizza box, you can use a floured baking sheet, cover it with an inverted baking sheet and wrap it in plastic wrap.)
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
In a medium sauce pot, add butter and olive oil. Set that over medium-high heat; once the butter melts add garlic, cook until fragrant, add pepper flakes, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic begins to brown on the edges.
Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and a splotch of olive oil, boil over medium-high, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 12 minutes, stirring occasionally or until thickened and viscous—season with salt to taste and let it cool down.
Assembly.- Place one of your pizza doughs onto a floured pizza peel, and flour your dough generously.
Punch your dough down in the center, working your way out to create a ¼” wide. Pick up your dough, place it over your closed fists, and rotate it around, gently stretching to 13” to 14”.
Place a couple of spoons of your sauce, starting in the center, spreading in little circles, and working your way to the edge until it gets evenly spread out.
In a medium-size mixing bowl, place mozzarella cheese, Monterey Jack, and Parmigiano; mix until combined. Sprinkle your cheese mixture to your desire and place in the oven onto your baking steel and bake for 5 - 7 minutes or until the edge gets golden brown and the cheese melts.
Enjoy.

Fantastic game, with a bombastic campaign that has entertaining coop.
Weapons, sounds, locations all looked and sounded amazing.
The only con is: I want more.

So far 8 hours in, played a good chunk of co-op with friends, public co-op, a few public pvp matches and roughly 90 minutes of singleplayer. Didn't personally have any performance issues aside some minor screen tearing in cutscenes that I choose to suffer as vsync gives me a surprising amount of input lag right now. Had gotten it as a gift but I'm trying my best to treat it with the same scrutiny of a $90 price tag they took on for me to play.

Gameplay's really good, solid blend between melee and gunplay, you can't hard tunnel into one or the other, especially not gunplay, melee rewards you for being aggressive through armor and health regen (Rallying from bloodborne, you can't infinitely keep healed in most cases but you won't hurt for HP when you learn your best and worst gear) and with the relatively decent roster of weapons you won't feel like one part is too stale to try to master - though the ranged enemies in this can be overbearing at times when the full roster of enemies starts to come into play.

Can't speak much of the story yet, as of writing this I'm not horribly far in as I went into the co-op specific mode to grind so I can join sept9 marines and help them get into the fray quicker, as well as spoil myself with the cosmetic system.

The soundscape's close to perfect but there's small things that don't sound quite as satisfying as they should (Stalker Bolt Rifle and Bolt Sniper Rifle having roughly the same impact per trigger pull despite one being much more higher impact and slower gunplay being an example).

Controls in this are a lot to manage and frankly having sprint tied to two separate buttons; one overlapping with your dodge button with no way to disable the overlap also causes it to not function as consistently as it should which leads to some frustration in the more hectic gameplay. It's mostly a skill issue, but I still feel like this isn't a good design choice all the same and there's other minor control hiccups.

There's a fair few bugs and performance issues that should be researched before making the purchase, but between several friends of varying mid range spec computers, nobody has had more than some heating issues that were within safe playable standards for any length of game sessions aside the marathon length time.

All in all so far an easy 8.5/10 or maybe even 9/10, if you're new to WH40k like I am then it's a little weird as an entry point, but still a massive blast as far as an entertaining videogame goes.

Graphics
Scale
Gore
Models
Music
Atmosphere
Campaign although short its terrific.

The bad:

Weapons feel weak

Combat - as above, the weapons feel to weak, there's no real way to parry and the one in place for combos doesnt work on it's own. Enemies always target only you hitting your teammates only some times.
AI - Team Squad NPCs feel terrible, they suffer uselesness, I don't know why we have them in the first place?

Overall 4/10 Cause I can't stand that after what happened to Helldivers - Developers still think that making big guns weak is fun, no it's not fun. Guns are GUNS, and BIG GUNS NEED TO DO BIG DAMAGE. If Space Marine needs to put 30 mags into one big enemy what use are the Cadians anyway?

Im really dissapointed and Ill wait for a balance.

After some time the game grew up on me, I still hate low ammo counts, still hate low variety of missions but ultimately I loved it enough so that I continue playing it, therefore it is a matter of honor to change review to recommended.

First ever review because this game is just that good. Aside from DLSS and FSR seeming to be bugged as well as having some performance issues in terms of temperatures and frames rates, which will hopefully be fixed with DLSS3 and patches, the game is a solid 9/10.

So, I am going to give this a pretty early review.

Its pretty good. There are a few issues, such as long loading times or issues with joining servers as of launch. But, that could be due to the overall stress of numbers trying to play right now. Much is lieu of what Helldivers dealt with early on.

The game itself just BLEEDs 40k. This is a MUST for any Warhammer 40k fan if only for the sight of a Dark Angel Bladeguard and a Space Wolf Hound of Morkai not killing each other because there are Thousand Sons to dust.

Gameplay is solid. All personal opinion, but the Melee is satisfying and the counters and dodging feel rewarding. The melee really rewards a more methodical and dueling flow to the fight and actually punishes random spamming. Gun play feels just as good, my two main classes being Vanguard and Heavy, both play different and just feel amazing.

Overall, in its current state (9/05/2024) game is a solid 8/10. Has issues with connectivity and long load times (which I think are helped by turning crossplay off) and I believe the Anti-Cheat can cause some temp spiking if that matters to you. But game is enjoyable and worth it for those who are into the fandom.

Ryzen 7 3700X and a 2070 Super ran everything on high and DLSS on Quality at a smooth 1080p 60fps no problem. The only bug we have encountered so far have been infinite load times but that only happened twice in the entire play through. This game is also FILLED with cosmetics for customizing your online character for Ops/PvP which is a huge bonus for 40k fans if you have a favorite chapter. 8.75/10 so far!

Edit: After a few more hours with the current PvP mode I'm def chalking this game up to a solid 9. Excited to see the next mode they add in!

I have to say, I've never looked into Warhammer, it's just never hooked me, especially the tabletop stuff. But I thought I'd give this game a try as my first time experiencing anything Warhammer, and I can tell you, with the PS5 controller and good optimization in 4K, this game feels and plays stunningly. The set dressing and attention to detail in the environments alone make this something truly special, and every level improves upon the last in this regard. It hearkens back to the glory days of 360-era games in the best way possible.

If you're a fan of Warhammer 40k, play this game. If you're not? Play this game.

It really looks amazing and the big battle scenes feel cool but there is a lot of little gameplay things that bother me. No hp regen, I spent the whole game on like 10% hp. You can recover little pips of armor but they go away so fast and sometimes you can't even avoid some damage. On higher difficulties the big enemies become damage sponges and it isn't fun hitting them 100 times before you can execute them.
The weapon balancing also feels off, it seems in campaign and pve everything is about the same strength so that no weapon is better, but that just feels bad because I can't one shot enemies with melta weapons or thunder hammer...

Anyways, this might seem like a negative review, but overall it's still a very cool looking game and we finally get a continuation of Titus story!

The campaign is amazing. It captures the 40k universe amazingly well and really feels like you could be in the boots of an space marine. It feels good and has good weight to each action. The grittiness and darkness of this universe is shown so well.

The online is where the game falls off a lot. If you're hoping for some super engrossing PvP combat, look somewhere else:

There are two versions of online. Co-Op PvE, and PvP.

The co-op PvE is pretty good. I like how it's integrated with the main campaign, so that was a smart decision and feels like you're still seeing parts of the campaign even after you've finished it. Very cool way to do that. Unfortunately there are only 6 missions, but more are promised to be added via the season pass.

The PvP though, is where things start to get bad. It's obviously not a focus of the game, and feels very tacked on, but it's still a thing. If you're going into this game wanting to focus on PvP, I feel like you're going to be disappointed.

- Lack of maps. I think there are 3? 4? Hopefully more to come with the season pass.
- Lack of game modes. Standard team deathmatch, a mode with three points you try to control to earn points, and another mode with one point that rotates you have to control for points. That's it. Again, hopefully more to come with the season pass?
- Lack of balance. I'm not even sure how to approach this. Between bulwark's that are invincible due to their shield (there are ways around it, but come on, it's massively OP), and a class that stunlocks by grappling you, it gets frustrating fairly quickly.
- Corner-advantage. Look, I get it it's a 3rd person game, but it's really annoying to be killed around a corner by someone that I can't even see even though I'm looking in their direction. They can see me, but I can't see them.

All in all, definitely get the game for the campaign and play through that. It has a decent length, and each mission is pretty long. The PvE portions of this game are great. the PvP portions are not. For the PvE alone I'd say it's recommended, but maybe when it's on sale.

In the Name of the Emperor: A Review of Warhammer 40k: Space Marines 2

Brothers in arms, heed my words. I, Brother Sergeant of the Valorous Chapter, bring you tidings of our latest endeavor in the grim darkness of the far future. The Imperium has forged a new instrument of war—Warhammer 40k: Space Marines 2. Prepare yourselves for a review worthy of the Emperor's finest.

Forge of Battle

The battlefield calls, and Space Marines 2 answers with unyielding strength. This game is no mere simulation; it is a crucible where your mettle as a Space Marine is tested against the unrelenting tides of xenos and heretic alike. The graphics are a testament to the Emperor’s glory, with visuals that render our power armor and wargear with such detail that even the most stoic of Techmarines would salute the developers.

Tactical Mastery

Strategic minds will find much to praise. The tactical depth of Space Marines 2 is unparalleled. Every engagement demands precision and cunning. The tactical pause feature allows you to command your squad with the foresight of a Chapter Master. Positioning, cover, and the use of terrain are critical. This is not a battlefield for the faint-hearted. Your decisions will echo through the annals of war, shaping the fate of your squad and the outcome of every skirmish.

The Armory Unleashed

Brothers, the arsenal at your disposal is both formidable and expansive. From the thunderous roar of the Lascannon to the cleansing flame of the Heavy Bolter, the weaponry is as varied as it is devastating. Each weapon feels unique, imbued with the power to smite the enemies of the Imperium. The customization options allow you to fine-tune your loadout, ensuring that your squad is ready to face any foe with the Emperor’s righteous fury.

The Enemy’s Onslaught

The xenos and heretics you face are not to be underestimated. The AI has been honed to present a challenging adversary, capable of adapting to your strategies. It is a worthy foe, ensuring that every battle remains hard-fought and demanding. Whether facing the ravenous Orks or the insidious Chaos forces, you will find that the enemies you encounter are as relentless as the darkness itself.

The Emperor’s Blessing

Warhammer 40k: Space Marines 2 is not without its flaws. There are moments when the game’s relentless pace can become overwhelming, and the need for a stable connection for certain features can be a hindrance. However, these are but minor blemishes on an otherwise exemplary testament to the Emperor’s glory.

In Conclusion

Space Marines 2 stands as a shining example of what it means to wage war in the 41st Millennium. It is a game that captures the spirit of the Adeptus Astartes—unyielding, valiant, and ever-ready to confront the darkness. For those who seek to prove their worth in the Emperor’s name, this game is a worthy trial by fire.

Prepare your bolters, steel your resolve, and march forth, Brothers. The Imperium needs you, and Space Marines 2 stands ready to test your valor in the fires of battle. For the Emperor!

End of Transmission.

Do you remember when early CoD (MW, MW2, I think maybe the first Black Ops) and Gears of War and Battlefield were games where everything was just 10/10 epic all the time? That's back now. You can have that feeling again, and oh, by the way, all of the single-player content can be played co-op.

Success in combat hinges on balancing offence and defence. Parries and dodges are important for self-preservation, but doing them well opens the enemy up to a high-damage counterattack. Non-boss enemies have a drone/master relationship, with the drones trying to swarm you. It's difficult to attack the swarm directly, but killing the elite that controls them will cause them to either die or turn on each other, so target selection matters. There are no cover mechanics to speak of. You have to charge in and get your hands dirty.

The weaponry selection allows for a lot of flexibility. Chainswords, power swords, combat knives, and thunderhammers all have different combos, and different trade-offs for high single-target damage vs area damage. Ranged weapons aren't really the focus, but they also balance range against power and area, with analogs to sniper rifles (Stalker bolter), machine guns (heavy boltgun), shotguns (melta rifle) and sometimes flamethrowers.

Space Marine 2 is one of those games where you can die embarrassingly, think this might be beyond your abilities, and then come right back and blaze through it like an invincible avenging angel. It'll punish mistakes quickly and harshly, but when you're in that flow state, catching leaping minoris by the tail and smashing them into the ground, parrying three Lictor attacks, and following up with a headshot and gory chainsword fatality, it's just the absolute pinnacle of the 3PS experience.

Imagine you threw together gears of war and helldivers.

Space marine 2 evokes a lot of xbox 360 era shooters in control scheme and moment to moment gameplay. The campaign, while only 6 missions, spans about 12 hours on easiest difficulty, assuming you never die. My single player run took around 15-17 hours on 3rd hardest difficulty.

The co-op campaign really shines with a lot of customization options, progression for your chosen marine build, and fun ways to mix and match squad perks and specializations. You really have to think about your team composition on hardest i.e. "We need a tank" "we need someone with heavy single-target weaponry." "We need a horde clearer.".

PVP is pretty bog standard. There's king of the hill mode, a king of the hill-adjacent mode, and deathmatch. That's it. The classes and variety make up for the shortage of modes but if you bring to mind gears of war's pvp mode, it's exactly the same. The camera and physics and deathcam even make it feel like gears of war.

There's a roadmap out including a ton of cosmetic options, a drip of new enemies and weapons and gamemodes, which are great.

The campaign story is also some excellent sci-fi fare that really ramped up around halfway through, and some very badass cinematics and set pieces. The final mission on demerium especially stands out with some "didn't expect that." moments.

So, firstly this game is a breath of fresh air, 13 years was worth the wait since the first game. The world-building and lore is on point, the mechanics are familiar yet improved and this game really puts you in the world of the grim dark future and the dev's really did their homework.

Further in a world (our world) where every game needs a unicorn character, the game drips with masculinity and is a reminder of what we've lost in gaming over the last decade or so. (Interestingly none of the developer staff are from the western world) so maybe thats something? But yeah a breath of fresh air when every game recently feels the need to make political points about the real world rather than just focusing on the game.

The graphics are amazing, the storyline is really good and a nice development on the first one. No spoilers but it skips 100 years and with the 13 year gap we kinda feel like we've been serving penance with Titus so that fits nicely.

The 'endgame' multiplayer system works kinda similar to WWZ on the PVE side, and the same as the first SM on pvp side. Sadly there is no endless defence/holdout (yet) like there was in the first game.

This brings me to the only negative thing I can say about SM2, and that is that the endgame content is very limited... 6 co-op missions and 4/5 PvP maps is going to feel stale very quickly, and I worry if they dont add content quite quickly, that this game will dry up much like SM1 did once everyone had the skins they wanted.

I give it a 7/10 for now, well worth buying and playing, especially if you're a 40k fan. However the endgame content does drag this score down form a 9/10.

The Story is honestly really fun and probably the best part about the game currently. It has Co-op for 2 more players and is overall written well and feels good to play. Even playing alone is fun because the squad AI is surprisingly good.

Combat feels really good if not a little clunky at times. You feel powerful in the campaign and in PvE on recommended difficulties. Combat in PvP is a mixed bag due to class counters and some imbalance.

PvE classes are unique and very flexible in terms of skills and is very fun with friends and even randoms. Right now you can only play Loyalist PvE which is somewhat disappointing since they have the Chaos models and voice lines in PvP.

PvP needs some serious balancing since right now it feels like you either get stomped or you do the stomping with no in between.

Customization is fun as long as you are a loyalist Space Marine even though it could use a few more chapter emblems (please give me Son's of the Phoenix emblems I am begging you). Chaos needs its own major update for cosmetics because right now its just color swaps.

Only major deal breaker is that the servers these guys use to host online games are the literally the worst. Space Marine 2... it’s everything and nothing, a swirling mess of blood, steel, and madness! You are Titus, but who’s Titus, really? A hero? A pawn? A construct of war?! Doesn’t matter—the moment you grip that chainsword, the galaxy whispers, then screams.

The Tyranids crawl—oh god, they crawl! Everywhere, like ants in your brain, gnawing at sanity. I swear, I heard one in my room last night. The combat’s so real it reaches out, grabs you by the throat—are you playing the game or is the game playing you? Endless slashes, endless roars, and then the bolter, the gunfire in rhythm with your heartbeat. BOOM BOOM BOOM! It's not just the controller vibrating, it's your soul shaking apart.

The world is too large, but too small. Why does it feel so big, but I can’t move far? Walls, invisible, but I know they're there, I can feel them breathing down my neck. Titus talks, but did I hear him say something else just now? “For the Emperor,” he says, but sometimes I hear “Run.”

There’s beauty in it too, in the destruction, in the chaos... but that beauty is suffocating, it traps you, makes you want more. One more Tyranid. One more battle. Just one more... Until you forget how long you’ve been in the war. Hours? Days? Did I sleep last night?

Space Marine 2 is loud, violent, a fever dream of warhammer glory... or maybe it's just a trap, pulling us deeper into the madness, into the abyss. Are we Titus? Are we lost? I don’t know. I don’t want to know. I just want to keep playing... 10/10

9/10 game for sure.

This review is based solely on the PvE mode since I haven't played campaign or PvP yet.

Super crisp gameplay, haven't experienced any bugs so far. Joining issues and one crash but it's to be expected with a huge playercount.
Gameplay is top-notch and very skill-based. The difference between a bad player and a very good player is incredibly noticable even at the lowest difficulty and personally I think that's exactly how it should be.
Customization is awesome. Diverse classes. Progression is really good. You're able to level weapons that are shared between classes so you can bring your endgame weapon that you leveled on one class onto another completely fresh level 1 class.
Heavy focus on teamplay both in gameplay and in spirit, having to share resources with your team instead of being greedy.
Transparent devs with an established roadmap and an open forum for suggestions that, given enough upvotes, the devs actually look at and consider. Plenty of stabilization updates now in the first week of launch. It bodes well for the future of the game..

Downsides - Not a lot tbh. Server issues, having to migrate host completely at random while in the middle of a match which takes up to a minute or two, the guns not being as impactful as they would be in established lore like having to empty an entire Bolter magazine into a Tyranid Warrior even to just get him into execution state. Most of the complaints I have are about the customization.
Very limited customization for the chaos space marines in PvP mode. Although I don't share this opinion, I've heard it from multiple sources that the core gameplay of both campaign and PvE is kind of one-dimensional.
Customization for loyalist Marines leaves a lot to be desired if you're coming from the tabletop or if you're a real lore-enthusiast. Left and right pauldron have different specific emblems, knee pad emblems are very limited, colors are very restricted and designated between primary, secondary and tertiary colors so you can't have any color you want on any part of your gear. You're restricted to certain colors on primary gear, certain colors as secondary and certain colors (mostly metal) as tertiary colors. You cannot have a head with a green wreath and a golden skull, for example. They're both gonna be one color. You cannot have a white shoulder trim with golden adornments, they're both one color. Small things like this is really important when it comes to chapter heraldry and Space Marine identity, but in the grand scale of things it doesn't diminish the quality of the game. It's simply an issue for people who want to follow the established Space Marine lore.

All in all; If you're a Warhammer 40k (and specifically Space Marine) fan then this game is DEFINITELY for you.
This game lives and dies on it's PvE mode. The devs have promised to expand on this through adding more missions (there are currently 6), a horde mode and more to come. I feel hopeful about the future of this game.
If you're just looking to turn your brain off and play some campaign for 10-12 hours then the price tag is probably not worth it. The fact you can play campaign in 3 player co-op is great though, and the campaign will surely leave you wanting for more, causing you to jump into the PvE mode with your own customized Space Marine.

From the very first mission, Space Marine 2 does an excellent job of capturing the essence of 40k. You instantly feel like a powerful Space Marine, battling through waves of Tyranids with a mix of heavy weaponry and brutal melee attacks. The controls feel responsive and tight, whether you’re unleashing bolter rounds into enemies or slicing through them with a chainsword. The combat is fluid and satisfying, and the game is well optimised, considering the chaos that can be going on at once.

Campaign Highlights

The campaign offers about 7-8 hours of intense, action-packed gameplay. The story keeps you engaged without feeling too long or repetitive. If you're new to the 40k universe, the game does a good job explaining the basics of the lore, so you don’t need to be intimidated. For longtime fans, the game remains faithful to the lore, providing a deeper connection to the characters and setting. It’s a story that’s easy to follow but engaging enough to keep you invested throughout.

Multiplayer Potential (PvP)

As for multiplayer, if you're coming in expecting loads of content right away, you might be a little underwhelmed. Currently, there are only three game modes and three maps, which doesn’t offer a huge amount of variety. However, what is there is extremely fun and addictive. The gameplay feels fast-paced and dynamic. Although the content is limited, the core mechanics are solid, and there’s a lot of potential for future updates and expansions. If the developers build on this strong foundation, multiplayer could really shine in the long term.

Multiplayer Potential (PvE) (Limited playtime personally)

PvE is just as limited, offering as of time of writing only 6 operations but it too stands as a solid foundation for the devs to build off and has so much potential to but one of the games defining reasons for people to want to buy the game.

Final Recommendation

Space Marine 2 is an easy recommendation if you're looking for a game that balances action and accessibility. Whether you’re a seasoned 40k fan or completely new to the series, the game offers something for everyone. The campaign is entertaining and well-paced, while the multiplayer, though currently light on content, is fun and addicting with room for growth. If you're considering picking it up, I'd say go for it it’s a blast to play.

TLDR

Space Marine 2 is a fast-paced, fun game that nails the feeling of being a Space Marine in the 40k universe. The campaign is engaging and runs about 7-8 hours, with great combat mechanics. Multiplayer is limited in content right now, but what’s there is a lot of fun. Whether you’re new to 40k or a veteran, it’s worth picking up!

There's a lot of good here, but there are a couple of major flaws that really sour much of the experience on higher difficulties. Some of these on their own are not terrible, but the combination of them can cause some serious frustration.

TLDR: Play the Campaign on Normal, with other humans, for the best experience. The current state of AI teammates is abysmal, and balance scaling on Veteran+ is difficult, but not in a fun way.


Long version:

First of all, do not make the mistake of starting the campaign on Veteran. Your AI Teammates in the Campaign are absolutely useless for anything other than reviving you. For some reason on difficulties higher than Normal they rarely use their abilities, and would rather spend several minutes shooting at one termagaunt while you juggle multiple warriors.

That doesnt sound too bad until you start hitting campaign missions that REALLY feel like they were designed for human players - where one person has to activate an objective and the rest covers. Only the AI will never do these objectives, and they certainly won't cover you. Gotta shoot enemies off of an objective, well they don't do that either.

This would also not be a huge problem if some enemies focusing you basically reduce your own DPS to zero if you want to not die - Zoanthropes for example shoot series of balls/beams that will either hurt you a lot, or knock you down over and over, unless you dodge constantly and hope your teammates are shooting the Z (spoiler; if they're AI: they're not.).
On top of this, ranged enemies will target the player almost exclusively. 2 of your AI Bros can be punching a ranged Warrior in the face but it will still spend every chance it can trying to snipe you across the yard.

Once you play with other human players it all comes together much better, but bumping difficulty up starts showing some other flaws. Enemies become bullet sponges, where even chaff enemies like gaunts take multiple combos from heavy weapons and Majoris enemies take multiple stalker mags to the face.

On higher difficulties it quickly becomes a game of dodge back and heavy forward as you very conservatively take on enemies in what feels more like you're playin Dark Souls 40K rather than a Space Marine game, as even chaff enemies' ranged fire wil quickly strip your armor to nothing as soon as you get it back from an execution. Unlike SM1 where chaff enemies are health bags, this is not the case in SM2 as melee kills don't restore (non-white) health unless you have specific abilities going.

I Like it but thats not the whole story..
Space Marine 2 is well set in the grimdark universe of Warhammer 40K. As a continuation of the OG Space Marine Game from 2011, it attempts to bring the one-decade old formula of bolter shooting and chainsawsword slashing to 2024. However, it struggles to do so and is very expensive on top. I really enjoy playing the game and will most likely cotinue to play it. But it has some notable flaws and if you are thinking about buying the game you should consider the following.


Pro: A Treat for Warhammer 40k Nerds
If you're a fan of Warhammer 40k and a sucker for the (totally not overrepresented) Ultra Marines, its a awesome implementation in the Universe.
The game is a well representation (even if a little generalized) of the lore and atmosphere that makes up the core of 40k for me. It allows you to stomp Tyranids and match yourself with . In the Coop PVE and the PVP mode, the Customization System allows you to tailor your Character into your favorite Space Marine Chapter or Chaos Legion. The Lovecraftian horrors of the 40k universe are well-represented, making the story engaging despite its somewhat bleak plot and dialogue.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Cons: Not Worth the Price if You're Not a 40k Geek
However, if you're not deeply invested in the 40k Universe, Space Marine 2 falls short. The gameplay feels outdated, with clunky mechanics that haven't evolved much since the original game . Combat can be fun, but it's often repetitive and lacks the refinement seen in other smilar modern titles. The writing is another weak point, with dialogue that ranges from uninspired to outright poor. Online multiplayer is plagued by long wait times, frequent connection errors, and bugs that, for example, can make enemies invisible (very fun), breaking immersion and gameplay. The game has a very hard time to offer anything beyond its niche appeal, making its steep tag hard to justify for newcomers to the world of 40K aswell as casual players.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------


Space Marine 2 delivers exactly what I want out of a Warhammer 40k game: a grimdark experience in a universe that lacks hope with the permanent thread of extinction for a human race lost in endless external and internal conflict. However, it struggles to appeal beyond its core audience due to outdated gameplay, technical issues, and blunt writing. If you're a diehard fan of 40k, you'll find enjoyment in this game despite its flaws. For everyone else, who just want to stomp some Aliens and blow up stuff, there are better and less expensive options.

If you are a 40k fan and even if you are not this is an amazing game to jump into the series with. It really fulfills the space marine power fantasy as you cut and tear through hordes of Tyranids using all of the different weapons available. The game gets even more fun when playing with friends or matchmaking with randoms. The game is very well made apart from a few mechanics that need some tweaking but I am sure that will be fixed in due time. Cant wait to see what they have in store for this game in terms of new enemies and missions.

Got a rig that barely meets the minimum requirements, but it still runs pretty smooth and well on custom settings between low and medium. The optimalization is really good, didn't expect this in early access.

The campaign is shorter, but intense, action packed and full of action, lore and many nods and easter eggs. It is clear that the devs made it with lot of love and passion for the Warhammer, with every single detail. The combat is simmilar to first game, but improved and more smooth, while giving you the amazing feel of what it is to be an Astartes, without making it weird or unbalanced.

Co-op operations are interesting and sometimes even more intense. And nicely tied to the main storyline. With more to come in the future, I am curious as how will the devs approach it, but after what I had the chance to see and play, I have full faith in them.

Didn't play much of PvP yet, so can't talk about the balance, but I feel like the customization of marine is lacking (which applies also for the operations).

For Adeptus Astartes, the customization options of armor and weapons is incredible. But each class has predefined look of the marine's face. Meaning that if you want to play without helmet or play class where skin is visible and you make for example a Salamander or White Scar, you don't play ashen skinned or Mongol marine, but still the default one. I really hope this will be changed in the future and more options will be offered. Same for Chaos Marines where the customization options are even more limited.

But this is the only criticism I can offer for this game. Other then that, it is worthy successor to the first game and amazing gift and love letter to Warhammer 40k fans.

I've been waiting for this game for 10 years and it has largely delivered, but I do have a few gripes.

Gripe 1: Annoying bugs (not the enemies in game). In a 4 hour session, my friends and I managed to bug an encounter that would force us to reload last checkpoint at least 5 times. Luckily the checkpoints are rather frequent so we didn't get set far back, but still annoying.

Gripe 2: No camera position or FOV controls. I just wish I could pan the camera back even just a little bit. Titus is a massive space marine and takes up a rather significant portion of the screen. I get the armor is detailed and all, but I want to see the enemies coming at me before they're in my teeth. Being able to back the camera up would be so nice. Also don't remember seeing a setting to change the position of the camera from right shoulder to left or in my preference, middle.

Gripe 3: The bolter's sound design is lackluster. They sound like they pack a punch, don't get me wrong. But it does not sound like I'm firing a gun that's launching .998 caliber mass reactive shells. Darktide did the bolter's chunky sound far better justice.

Other than that, the game is great. Let's be honest, the campaign missions are dull just like the story, they really only serve as a frame to get you from one encounter to another, but oh boy, did it ever feel so good to crush and stomp Tyranid hordes as a Space Marine? I did miss Mark Strong as the voice of the main character though. The new VA is also doing a good job, Emperor be praised..

Oh, and ♥♥♥♥ Leandros. ♥♥♥♥ that guy.

It's hard for me to put into words how faithful this game is to the source material. Every inch of it is straight out of 40k novels and codexes. The dialogue, the various groups you encounter, the aesthetic, the sound design, the tone, everything. It absolutely blew me away the level of detail that went into this game to faithfully recreate the world of Warhammer 40k. It was everything I could have asked for after waiting 13 years for the sequel, and more.

The only things I think could be improved upon was the combat when it comes to fighting swarms of enemies and some of the mission designs were clearly made with co-op in mind. Melee combat works well when you're fighting up to small groups of enemies, but when there's 15 or 20, or more, you're quickly surrounded and your armor and health drop fast. At least it did on the 3rd hardest difficulty, which the game advertises as the intended experience. The original Space Marine got around this by allowing you to replenish all your health using executes, but in Space Marine 2 it's merely one bar of armor; and that lasts about half a second when you're in the thick of it. I'm by no means the best player, but I'm good enough to recognize how punishing this new system is. Combine that with some missions clearly meant for you to perform objectives while a friend or two covers your back, and it can get a little difficult.

All in all, though, this game is an absolute love letter to every fan out there and was well worth the wait. I just hope it doesn't take more than a decade for the next one.

As a fan of the 40k universe and Table top game since early 2000 this was Literally everything I had hoped it would be. The campaign was EPIC on the scale that you always imagined it would be like if you were a part of the action while shuffling you carefully painted and assembled minis around your home made terrain peices.

I don't know how to adequately express that the authenticy and care taken to make this game really represent in a well played out narrative the immensity of the lore, scale of the structures, Massiveness of the armies and forces, the unique technologies and everything that makes 40k a masterwork of world building, really shines through even just playing through campaign. The battles feel intense, the sound design is amazing, graphically it is stunning from character and creature models to terrain, vehicles, architecture, and setpeices.

I entirely get it there are some graphical glitches now and again and if i had a gamplay gripe it would be that the combat is a little clunky especially melee (but honestly the marines are pretty clunky....), although the Satisfying feel of firing the bolters and other weapons really covered for a lot. I'm sure as I continue to grind levels on Operations I'll be more upset about some of the technicals...but just purely as a 40K Space Marine fan I couldn't have enjoyed the campaign much more than I did.

PvP is challenging and fun the Level grind Is going to be my next goal I'm not that big of a PvP player so I'm less concerned about it but it would be neat if that ended up being a strong feature too.

Highly recommended in general, Must have if you love the 40K Universe.

By no means is it perfect, but compared to some of the other 40k and Warhammer Fantasy games, this game is amazing. So much attention to detail and love given to this game and setting. First thoughts as someone who's never really played any Warhammer or 40K games (other than Vermintide 2).

This game really takes me back to the feeling of the Xbox 360 era of gaming. Good, simple fun. For $60, this game doesn't just focus on one aspect to perfection but does multiple things very well. Kind of like Halo and Gears of War vibes.

Campaign: You get a solid campaign that can be played co-op or solo. The voice acting and characters are very interesting. The atmosphere and world are a lot to take in and can be breathtaking at some moments. They put a lot of polish in the design. 

PVE: Missions mode, where you can team up and play different classes to further unlock new weapons, armor, and mastery/bonuses for the weapons. 

PVP: I haven't played enough to think it could get in depth enough to be someone's main staple for a shooter, but it is a fun addition to the game that doesn't seem to take itself too seriously but knows what it wants to be at the same time. 

I was worried when I saw a season pass that had a lot of cosmetics at first, but I don't mind paid content being cosmetic only; that is fine; I just don't like when those are the ONLY cosmetics in this game. I can safely say though that this game once again goes back to the Xbox 360 era, where there are a lot of different customization options that you can grind for and earn in the game that aren't locked behind a season/battle pass. That was one of my favorite things about Halo 3: earning your armor. 

Overall, I would give this game an 8.5 out of 10 so far. Once the road map and content become more fleshed out over time, it will have a lot to offer. I think it is a good complete $60 game, though. And for all the Helldivers 2 comparisons or people wondering if it's similar, I wouldn't say too much. It is 3rd person and lots of gunfights/hordes of enemies, but that's about where it ends. The game is a lot more serious and not goofy at all. So don't come into this game thinking it's a better Helldivers 2 or replacement for you if you are upset about Helldivers recent changes. Both games do things differently and have two different vibes.

What is there is truely excellent and if you're looking for a satisfying feeling, power fantasy that offers up a surprising amount of difficulty, this is exactly for you.
The only disappointment so far (27 hours in) has been how the content does seem to run a bit dry sooner than expected. I expected the game to have a similar lasting power as Left 4 Dead games, that offered short "Campaigns", yet it was just fun even repeating the same levels.
The problem the "Operations" PvE missions seem to face, is that there is no real reason to scour through the corners of the map very well in hopes for something cool or different. Yes, health pickups and the like are valuable, but they don't change the game in ways that different weapon pickups, adrenaline shots, chainsaws, gas canisters, defibrillators etc. seemed to change things up in L4D.

The different grenades offer a tiny bit of variation and so do the somewhat randomized enemy encounters, but that's about it in terms of variety. Even the most valuable things, the Armory Data is always(?) in the same spots.

With that said, the gameplay loop itself is ridiculously fun and trying to tackle new difficulty levels has been exciting and I don't see myself dropping the game any time soon. But it has left me wishing there was more to discover, rare armor piece finds or.. just a little bit more intrique to level exploration itself.

Right now it seems there's a "meta" building up that some players only dodgeroll through the level to the objective areas, skipping fighting anything that isn't necessary and I'd say that's a big indication of the levels not being interesting.

I don't regret a fully priced purchase however (bought the standard edition, with no season pass and other stuff) and have had a truely fun time with an action game that has me admittedly a little bit addicted.

Glad that the devs will be adding things in gradually. :) Hopefully it's concrete enough to offer variety once things start getting too repetitive.

I had a lot of fun with Space Marine 2. The visuals are phenomenal, and it's clear that much effort went into making all models, from the space marines to Tyranids to Thousand Sons, look like animated versions of their tabletop models. The gameplay loop of transitioning between ranged and melee combat takes some getting used to if you, like me, haven't played many other third person shooters. I played the prequel many years ago, but don't remember much. If you're a big fan of games like Gears of War, perhaps the gameplay loop will feel more familiar. The combat is solid - when it works, it feels outstanding. This is especially true in the boss fights, which generally feel fluid and dynamic. When it doesn't work, however, gameplay can feel very frustrating. You might lose your entire health bar very quickly to ranged enemies or get swamped by a horde of hormagaunts or tzaangors, and it won't feel like there was much counterplay. This game is best experienced in a squad with other human players. The AI squadmates are... ok, but it feels like the developers gave them a large heathbar to compensate for the fact that they're really sluggish and don't really do much. When playing solo, you might get swamped by enemies that your squadmates should have easily dealt with, and from my experience this doesn't happen anywhere near as often when playing with human teammates. The story is quite short but it's tight. The missions feel well-structured, and if you want more there's a plethora of activities to do once you finish the main campaign. Overall, this game is quality over quantity. I hope the season pass DLC brings more PVE missions that include other factions from the Warhammer 40,000 universe, such as other xenos races and other chaos gods.

Honestly fantastic game that was worth the wait.

The game is visually fantastic and the level design is breath taking. Massive backgrounds while going through a linear level with huge battles going on. Genuinely amazing.

Story was great with quite a twist at the end that feels like it's going to lead into some DLC.

The customization is pretty great! Being able to customize your Space Marine while being in a known chapter or/also creating your very own chapter makes it incredibly solid.

Now for the only negativity I have for this game. The Operations. They're alright, it's simply another campaign that goes along with the main campaign and adds some context here and there and it's pretty fun. If you're into immersion though and think you're your own space marine, tough luck. You're still seen as an Ultramarine. The actual main downside with Operations in my opinion is locking classes if a player has chosen it first. I see no reason to do this when other games like Darktide allow it. I get that these classes are apparently actual characters in the Ultramarine chapter, but it's such an irritating block. You'll have two brothers who want to be the same class and neither of them wish to change, forcing a third player to just stand and wait until one decides to finally leave the lobby. It's infuriating.

It's an amazing game that brings a huge win for the Warhammer 40,000 franchise and I really hope it has a good life with future content. I'm incredibly looking forward to the horde mode.

This IS Warhammer

Warhammer Space Marine 2 nails the fundamentals. It does not need bloated systems to confuse or give an illusion of depth. The depth is in the combat. Learning and mastering the flow of combat as you slowly upgrade and perfect your Space Marine. This game perfected skyboxes. If you enjoy Grim dark, Futuristic settings or even ripping through hordes of enemies this game is for you.

After 13 long years we finally got a sequel to the ultimate Space Marine experience and boy oh boooy it was worth the wait! Space Marine 2 is a solid, no-nonsense, old school TPS / hack'n'slash action game. It just simply feels good.

The good:

+ Gorgeous graphics. Character/creature models look great, levels look astoundingly well made (especially the skyboxes and backdrops). They have truly nailed the Warhammer aesthetic.
+ Fantastic sound design. You can feel the weight of a Space Marine on the move, the kick of a heavy bolter, the crunchy and gruesome sounds when you're ripping a Tyranid apart. Eargasm stuff.
+ Combat feels tight and flows really well. Seamlessly switching between shooting and melee, simple and easy to execute combos (Take notes Game Science!). Doom Eternal style executions. Nothing groundbreaking or innovative about the combat, nevertheless it's still pretty satisfying.

The bad:
To be honest I don't have anything bad to say about the game, only some nitpicks.

- As of right now the Operations mode (PvE co-op) is pretty barebones and doesn't have a lot of replay value besides small stat upgrades and skins.
- Multiplayer feels super unbalanced. Matchmaking throws you in with players that are already max level so you just get steamrolled.
- Minor bugs during the campaign.

Technically these are cons yes, but I'm writing this review based on my experience during early access, and the game officially released just a few hours ago. All of the issues I wrote above will be fixed and more content will be added (hopefully enough to flesh out the Operations even further) in the coming months.

Final score: For The Emperor / 10

This review is coming from a perspective of a 40k fan. I am relatively new though, only 5 years ago did I discover this universe, which is quite recent for a universe thats been around since 1987. Since my intoduction I have several painted armies (a space marine one among them) alongside having played some games and listened to a lot of Warhammer books and lore over the years.

Warhammer 40K : Space Marine 2 is a game that absolutely delivers on the experience it was aiming to create while going above and beyond for some aspects while fumbling tiny things along the way. I am pointing this out because this is getting increasingly unusual in the game industry nowadays. Most games coming out trying to sell you a live service while the game is not finished enough to be able to do so. Meanwhile this dev team seems to have taken their time to release a complete product that gives a solid foundation to making a live service work. 3 separate modes, all with a different focus and gameplay experience. Its quite refreshing, but that does not make the game automatically perfect. Lets talk about all of these modes and my thoughts on them.

Campaign: (no spoilers)

This mode continues the story of Demitrian Titus, the protagonist of the first game, with a fancy new narrative 13 years after the games release. Just like the other modes, you can play this mode cooperatively with 2 of your friends, and does a nice job introducing the mechanics of the game in a fun way. The campaign itself is short but sweet, and intentionally tries not to drag on to long, which is good in my opinion because you can't do much character work with a space marine because they are emotionless supersoldiers. The appeal of the campaign are the missions, and the set pieces within them. The 40k universe is bombastic yet intriguing and mysterious, and watching Titus and his team fight through futuristic gothic cities actively being destroyed by the tyranid invasion one moment and navigating through his chapters space ship with tons of details and lore is really fun and engaging. Its like a rollercoaster ride of the 40k universe where they show a lot of the unique and awesome stuff this universe has to offer. I do think it would have been smart of explain some more concepts, especially the ones directly related to the story's plot. A lot of times characters talk about in universe concepts, and people who are new to 40K will just not understand because its never explained. Its tottally playable and comprehensible to a person new going in, but I think its important to explain more stuff to really get them excited about the nuance 40k has compared to other sci-fi universes.

PVE Operations:
This mode allows your to play several missions losely related to the campaign story. Instead of Titus and his squad, you'll be able to play as 6 different classes, and make your own Space Marine. You'll be able to fully customize the look of your character, while completing missions allows you to level up and access new perks and abilities to make your guy stronger over time and really pick a playstyle you like. For 40k fans this is a dream come true since building and painting miniatures is a huge part of this hobby and the amount of customization is pretty vast for game that has just released. Its also not tied to microtransactions and all of the customization (except for a couple skins related to the gold and ultra edition) are earnable through playing the game. No ingame cash shop or lootboxes. The gamemode focusses on replayability with a good variety of maps, enemies and classes alongside the 4, soon to be 5 difficulties, makes it enjoyable over a long period of time. There is also an AI director tha mixes the missions up and tries to suprise you with changes in the enemies that show up and the objectives you must complete along the way. I have some issues with balancing though. The hardest difficulty feels very unstable to play right now, it feels you need to get lucky in order to win, but it’s very satisfying once you do. I also think the Thousand Sons faction are not very fun to fight currently of the way the units are balanced, totally fixable though. Focus has already promised to add more missions, weapons and enemies in the future which will be important to its life service, which in my opinion has the most potential in this game mode.

PVP Eternal War:

I played the least amount of PVP up until now, but it has pleasantly surprised me. It’s structured as a 6vs6 contest where Space Marines go up against Chaos Space Marines, marines who have betrayed the imperium and have sided with the bad guys. There are a couple modes to pick from, and they are all good fun to play with the same 6 classes from PVE. There only 3 maps though, and unlike the Campaign and PVE, there is not a lot of spectacle going on around or inside of them. Instead, this mode is focused on giving you a more competitive experiences, the 6 classes are all rebalanced to facilitate skill expression and game knowledge. The more you play, the more stuff you unlock for your class and once you get the hang of its surprisingly fun and way more intricate than you thought at first. Don’t overlook it, it might be really your thing.

Conclusion:

To me a perfect game is one that gets a lot of little things right, but at the same time, its art, and how it makes you feel is more important than examining and criticizing every detail. Space Marine 2 gives you the power fantasy of you being among the ranks of the Adeptus Astartes, something every Warhammer nerd fantasizes about ever since they started painting miniatures or reading/listening to the lore of this amazing universe. You get to go along this personal story of Titus to see something curated and then make your own based on the space marine you decide to make for PVE and PVP. The core gameplay is rock-solid and satisfying, with a lot of inspiration taken from DOOM while keeping its own style from the previous game. Artistically and graphically the game looks exactly like fans would envision the 40K universe alongside the overall sound design being a straight 10. The performance overall is impressive considering how many enemies can appear on screen on top of the orchestra of chaos that’s happening around you.

This by far is the best 40k game I’ve played so far and deserves all the praise and occasional criticism its receiving. I think thats because people, particularly 40k fans, care about this game and its future; the developers have created an awesome foundation for years of live service support and seem committed to fixing issues through their transparent feedback system. The game has already succeeded critically and financially, now it’s up to the devs build on it. If they do, and they are going to from the looks of their roadmap and their history as a developer, I’ll be there playing who knows how many years from now. If they somehow don’t, this game is still an incredible game and is easily worth the 60 you put in.

I recommend it, play it if your PC can run it. Thanks for reading this needlessly long steam review, but at the same time, what is wrong with you? You have wasted approximately 5 minutes not serving the emperor.... The inquisition is heading towards your exact location right now.

+++Reported Review to the Inquisition+++
++=][=++

Space Marine 2 is everything I and most fans of the Warhammer 40k universe could hope for. As a sequel to the original Space Marine game (2011), the game ramps up the intensity, scale of 40k, and brutal action in all the right ways. The feeling of being in the power armor of a Space Marine, facing off against endless hordes of Tyranids in visceral, satisfying combat, and feeling overpowered is captured perfectly. The game makes you feel powerful, and that's what we are here for.

The gameplay shines with its fast-paced mix of melee and ranged combat. The action is really fluid, and the game strikes a perfect balance between being cinematic and offering clear combat, while giving you full control over the chaos on screen. As a third-person shooter, this game manages that surprisingly well.

Graphically, the game is stunning. The environments are epic and definitely in line with 40k standards, capturing the grimdark atmosphere of the 42nd millennium perfectly. Details are really well done, down to a single servitor skull, though perhaps not the best in detail when compared to WH40k: Darktide, where that game takes the lead in the smallest details.
And the sound design? The roar of bolters, the shrieks of Tyranids, the heavy steps of Astartes weighing over a ton, or even those dusty boys with their Assault Cannons or Storm Bolters. The voice acting is also really good, with no cringe or corny lines—a high-risk factor for this type of game. All these and more contribute to the immersive experience.

The Campaign:
We are yet again playing as Titus from the Ultramarine chapter. After the incident on Graia (SM1), we are renowned and demoted from our previous title of Captain, now holding the rank of Lieutenant. We follow our new Captain's orders to help the Recidious system, which is under attack by Hive Fleet Leviathan and perhaps something else from the Immaterium. We are now in the 4th Tyrannic War In the Indomitus Era, where a lot of things are happening in the 40k galaxy, and we are to be part of this war.
Together, you and your squad, under your command, are tasked with setting destruction upon the enemy in multiple well structured missions through 3 different planets. Not spoiling any more, but it's going to be a wild ride.

The co-op mode is also a blast, allowing you to team up with fellow Astartes in the campaign and play it from start to finish with friends. Or, you can complete hard or even harder PvE missions with semi-randomized enemies, enemy locations, points of interest, pick-ups, and bosses. It's the perfect addition for those who want to share the fun with friends, randoms, or even AI bots. The multiple missions, 4 difficulties, and extensive progression system (with 6 different classes, weapon upgrades, character skills, perks, and cosmetics) provide a lot of gameplay. The Astartes customization is really well done and faithful to the lore.
And i think it's one of the biggest reasons to grind this game.
Also, we are getting a lot of free content in the future, like maps, a new mode "Horde" (similar to the first game's Exterminatus mode), and new guns, enemies, missions, and difficulties. Who knows, we might even see new classes like Librarian, Chaplain, Terminator, or some specialized Interceptors.

Multiplayer:
This game brings you back to the good ol' days when we didn’t care about our K/D or W/L ratios. We just had fun. The only thing that mattered was the adrenaline surge you got when you were destroying the enemy, either solo or with friends/randoms. Since there are no proper stats, we can play without competitive status to bother us—just levels that unlock new weapons to use and destroy our enemies.

However, the game isn’t without a few rough edges. Some AI behavior can feel a bit broken, like standing still while a Carnifex is mauling you to death, and there are moments where the pacing could be tighter. But these minor issues are overshadowed by the sheer joy of purging alien filth and defending humanity.

If you’re a fan of Warhammer 40k games, tabletop, the books, or just love action packed third-person shooters with satisfying combat, Space Marine 2 is an absolute must-play. This is perhaps one of the best 40k video games that there is going to be. This game deserves to be Game of the Year.

Pros:

+Brutal, fluid, and satisfying combat

+Stunning graphics and atmospheric environments

+Really good story

+Faithful to the Warhammer 40k universe lore

+Excellent co-op multiplayer and lots of gameplay loops

+Really good performance and visuals

+Controls on PC and controller are just right, almost the same as in the first game

+/-Challenging

Cons:

-Occasional AI hiccups

-Some audio overlaps in PvE

-No PC chat censor

-No PC and console cross-play in Eternal War, though this is a minor problem, and the devs might change this

-Some pacing issues

Hard in many ways, just like the first game

+++Transmission out+++
++=][=++
