In Warhammer 40K, Sci-Fi meets Gothic, form over function, glory over sanity. While the level design is pretty straight-forward hose-design, the game doesn't hold back on the vast and impressive scenery where meglaomaniac architecture melts with huge battlefields and hundreds of aliens in the background. You fight in the jungle, in industrial structures, huge city scapes that remind me of Mont-Saint-Michel on steroids and in space.

The classes are versatile and so are the weapons. Cosmetics are earned with successful MP mission and while the campaign is comparably short it's very internse and of high quality.

The melee system is not as clunky as some beginners portrait it. Pressing attack like a moron won't get you very far. Not ignoring parry and evade windows is the key to a successful brawl. During successful parries, dodges and execution moves, you're invulnerable while also dishing out strong damage. Learning to use that consistently early on, will make things much easier for you and the group.

I'm playing the game with maxed settings in 4K (2K native with DLDSR 2.5x) and DLSS balance, getting 65-80 FPS with no stuttering, tearing or other annoying inconveniences.

It's one of those rare title releases:

Firstly, I want to emphasize the fact that if you haven't played Space Marine 1 before playing this, you're actually doing yourself a disservice. Even if you are not a Warhammer Lore master, the minimum requirement to enjoy the Space Marine titles is simply playing from the start. They put the effort into setting it up as such!

The lore to the universe is so immense and available to explore after the fact you might just find yourself something entertaining. And this game, just like the first, has that draw that so few other titles (in my opinion) have managed to do.

They have balanced the story telling such that you're not given an overly exposed, monotonous, and overwhelming dump of information. You'll find yourself wanting to explore it for yourself on your own time, and at your own pace. It doesn't demand that you need to know anything before jumping in, nor does it make you feel as though you are missing out on too much to understand what is currently happening.

What feeds the extreme fan-base is the depth of the lore and visuals represented with accuracy, and this nails that. It doesn't try to re-write or change anything that already enveloped fans know and enjoy, and it doesn't for a moment do so at the expense of trying to introduce newcomers to the universe. It stands ground and well at that.


Overall, I'm really satisfied with the game mechanics and the weapon variety, not to mention the visual and audio representations. It's actually addictive, but not in a quick-fill dopamine sense, more so via a show of power and story connected presence. It doesn't feel like you have plot armor, but it also doesn't feel like you're the weak guy that needs to do mundane tasks to upgrade and notice the advancements in comparison to the mob character that gave you arbitrary difficulty early on.

My one and only gripe with the gameplay (on the second highest difficulty first playthrough) was the incessant damage and subsequent distraction from ranged enemies. Through self-evaluation, it's abundantly clear that in order to progress smoothly on Veteran, you need to keep moving and abuse the i-frame and armor regeneration to sweep across the battlefield unscathed. And to be honest, I don't have an issue with that premise, if anything it fits in perfectly with what you are. A genetically modified super solider that is meant to purge the heretics in the name of the emperor.

So if you're looking to focus on the story and atmospheric experience, I don't recommend picking a higher difficulty than default out the gate, which is a tad ironic. When was the last time you came across a game that had a challenging difficulty slider? It caught me off guard, and had me frustrated at points, but it never really invoked a cheesiness factor or something that felt tedious. It was an invitation to invest more understanding into the mechanics and for that I can applaud obnoxiously.

Out the gate, I can say that it does the multiplayer PVP thing. I have no interest in nit-picking the balance or modes. It serves the purpose of a social experience but in that regard it lacks. The modes are alright, but the connectivity remains to be seen. In this current era of gaming where everyone secludes themselves to minute invite-only discord channels, the process of finding new friends to play with can be outright tedious.

I'm banking on what company will be the first to recognize the potential behind API integrations with Discord such that social connectivity is revitalized like it once was with nothing but a forum hosted from someone's PC for the community.

It's a solid game at its core. The gameplay is reminiscent of Gears of War 5 without the ability to use cover, but with a better melee damage system and a perk tree for both weapons and character classes. You have to fulfil objectives in a world thorn by war, defeating massive wave of enemies at times.

The levels are typically very large with lots of details. Some elements are randomized while playing Operations, but it is quite linear in all cases. We get 6 operations out of the box, and a campaign that is about 8-9 hours long. Story and cinematics are just epic. The diversity in the type of enemies, the waves and the levels feels good. I have cumulated 30 hours of gameplay and the grinding doesn't feel repetitive yet, but I have indeed played a bit of PVP for diversity.

The PVP aspect is also excellent, thanks to the solid shooter mechanics and class abilities. However, you will see the same maps again and again: I've only seen 3 maps so far, and I think that is realistically all we get at the moment.

Some bugs are always to be expected on launch day and this game is no exception, but I didn't encounter any game breaking bug. Sure, you may fail to join a server when you launch a PVP game (as an example), but it will work on the next attempt. You sometime gets stuck for a long time during loadings, but it will usually complete just fine if you are patient (we are talking well over a minute). Nothing too serious, and I am sure it will get patched quickly.

I don't have a lot of negative points, maybe 1-2. The AI is a bit too dumb for PVE at higher difficulty levels. Don't expect him to focus fire enemies that re calling waves, and never expect any coordination between the bots; if you get injured VS a boss that covers a lit of surface like a Hellbrute, chances that you'll get revived at average and higher threat levels are low. Luckily, there is MM included in the game but it is not working really well at the moment. Getting lvl1 players who have 0 experience with the threat level you are trying to play, as an example. Better use discord for LFGs or alternative mm methods (play with friends).

It is the 41st Millennium. For more than a hundred centuries The Emperor has sat immobile on the Golden Throne of Earth. He is the Master of Mankind by the will of the gods, and master of a million worlds by the might of his inexhaustible armies. He is a rotting carcass writhing invisibly with power from the Dark Age of Technology. He is the Carrion Lord of the Imperium for whom a thousand souls are sacrificed every day, so that he may never truly die.

Yet even in his deathless state, the Emperor continues his eternal vigilance. Mighty battlefleets cross the daemon-infested miasma of the Warp, the only route between distant stars, their way lit by the Astronomican, the psychic manifestation of the Emperor's will. Vast armies give battle in his name on uncounted worlds. Greatest amongst his soldiers are the Adeptus Astartes, the Space Marines, bio-engineered super-warriors. Their comrades in arms are legion: the Imperial Guard and countless planetary defence forces, the ever vigilant Inquisition and the tech-priests of the Adeptus Mechanicus to name only a few. But for all their multitudes, they are barely enough to hold off the ever-present threat from aliens, heretics, mutants - and worse.

To be a man in such times is to be one amongst untold billions. It is to live in the cruelest and most bloody regime imaginable. These are the tales of those times. Forget the power of technology and science, for so much has been forgotten, never to be re-learned. Forget the promise of progress and understanding, for in the grim dark future there is only war. There is no peace amongst the stars, only an eternity of carnage and slaughter, and the laughter of thirsting gods.

I am struggling to find anything to complain about. My biggest gripe with this game is that I want more, and I think this is a good problem to have.

Encoutered a few annoyances:
- menuing not being too convinient (mostly, I dislike that it takes two screens to set the difficulty+mission combo in the coop mode - it really really REALLY should be one screen). I'd love to see this polished up.
- the game will queue you into lobbies where someone is already playing your class, forcing you to change your class. I feel like that's a bit meh, since I enjoy playing one class for long sessions.
- very rarely (happened about three times in the 18 hours I've played so far) the game will lock you in place for a few seconds after a finisher animation - you're invincible and it'll recover, but it ruins the momentum, allowing the enemies to move away, which is a slight problem for any melee class.

And that's about it. Everything else is awesome. This feels exactly how I'd imagine a supersoldier smashing through the battlefield. The combat system has this heaviness to it, and your hits matter. I haven't felt this much power in my hands since DOOM - and I'm glad to have a new game in my GOAT steam folder.

At its core SM2 is a polished, focused third person shooter that offers a refreshingly complete package compared to its contemporaries. Most of SM2s core elements are good *enough* on their own but get tied together with genuinely top class presentation that elevates everything on offer here.

The core gameplay loop manages to be stripped down whilst staying just deep enough to be consistently entertaining. The combat model is built around snappy gunplay that flows in and out of hack and slash melee action that does manage to incorporate a decent parry and combo system, although do not go in expecting the depth of anything like a real character action game - what is here is far more comparable to something like the recent God of War games and even then not as complex. What matters most is that it doesn't need to be especially complex in order to stay consistently entertaining. The fights feel great, enemy variety is solid and mostly well designed and the game strings you from one fantastic set piece to the next at a brisk pace. In terms of difficulty this is a fairly challenging shooter at the higher difficulty levels although the single biggest influence on challenge is whether you are playing co-op or not as the bots here are not the best.

In terms of overall variety you're getting three distinct game-modes here: A narrative campaign with optional 3 player co-op that will run you anywhere from 5-10 hours, a mission based PVE operations mode that again features 3 player co-op with a customisable class based progression system (should be noted that this is where the legs of the game seem to be and Focus have already committed to expanding it, this is also where the helldivers comparisons you have undoubtedly heard are relevant), and a pvp multiplayer mode that shares some progression elements and customisation with the operations mode.

The campaign is a direct sequel to the original game narratively although Focus have gone to significant lengths to make this work as a standalone story not only for those who haven't played the original but also for those who have limited/no knowledge of the 40k universe. It does a pretty decent job of telling a pretty standard albeit compelling war story but for fans of 40k there are some pretty decent plot hooks here and cool wider implications. In terms of mission structure and the overall campaign experience, I enjoyed the back half of the campaign a lot more than the front, the early missions have a lot of "defend this point" objective set pieces that are uninspired at best and tedious at worst, thankfully the game moves away from this and focuses on letting you explore the combat sandbox through well structured arenas and big set piece moments. The last third of the game is thrilling and it keeps building managing to end really strong which is ultimately what you want from a fairly short campaign.

Visual presentation and audio design are excellent, giving pretty much the best rendition of the 40k universe that has ever been put to a screen. Weaponry feels excellent with great feedback and weighty impacts that are reflected by responsive enemy modelling and animation. The overall atmosphere is peak large scale 40k, it doesn't quite match something like Darktide in terms of sheer oppressiveness and that game and Mechanicus both feature better OSTs but SM2 is no slouch in either regard.

To briefly the discuss the other modes on offer: I think the PVE operations have a lot of potential, the game uses an AI director similar to Left 4 Dead and other horde based games and on higher difficulties you do have those "oh ♥♥♥♥" moments that have made the genre so popular. The missions also benefit massively from not being procedurally generated, something that was a major contributor to how stale Helldivers 2 became after a dozen or so hours. Everything here is handcrafted and whilst the drawback is that the content on offer is a bit limited and will take time to produce, it is all high quality with unique mission framing and compelling objectives. Progression and customisation are great as they kind of need to be for a game based on a miniature wargame famous for its sheer diversity of design. I have some nitpicks that will matter to passionate 40k fans: theres a lack of chapter specific visual flair e.g no thematic armour pieces like cloaks and tassels for white scars or scales for salamanders etc ; also everything here is very much a product of the uniformity of GWs Primaris designs and if you hate them, you are not gonna get much reprieve here, I would like to see some of the classic SM iconography e.g Corvus helmets brought in. Also Heretic Marines are only playable in the PVP and they have no armour customisation outside of basic paint jobs and decals, this may change down the line but for now its worth mentioning.

On the topic of the PVP the original game was famed for managing to keep a small but dedicated community of players on board for over a decade after its release (shout out CM Valrak) and I think whats on offer here has similar potential but as it currently stands it feels unfinished. There is a real shortage of both game modes, weapon variety and especially maps. The maps here are way too small, spawns are bad and I would really like to see some different types of maps as most of them feel fairly similar. I like the foundations Focus have laid down but like the PVE this is a case of "good start but show me more".

TLDR: SM2 is a fantastic package that stands out amongst a landscape of half-finished content poor AAA releases. The presentation and core gameplay loop are excellent, the Campaign is a blast that gets better as it goes, PVE has tonnes of potential (especially if you are fed up with HD2) and the PVP is fun but needs some work. Worth the money.

Let me preface by saying this is more a list of pros and cons and is biased entirely towards the melee experience, I have played Assault religiously. I love real difficulty, not the artificial crap but the real stuff. Payday 2 DSOD, VM2 Cataclysm and Onslaught, Darktide Auric Storm and countless other hellish experiences. Space Marine 2 absolutely has the ability to deliver this with some fine-tuning in the future but the current experience is rough around the edges the longer you play and advance. Despite that, I believe this game is worth it, and the developers should be supported.

An incredibly beautiful and heartfelt experience, the developers actively listen and respond to the community, clearly care about the source material and they've created some of the most beautiful graphics to immerse yourself in the carnage.

Melee combat just clicks, perfect parries, perfect dodges, gunstrikes, beautiful executions. The first few hours you play will blow your mind away, not to mention the difficulty and initial learning curve is perfect.

I'd be here all day breaking this down but to put it as simple as possible: If there were 50 melee enemies after me, I can and have beat them before with use of all the aforementioned mechanics alongside the memorised combos they do, but if you were to add just even 3 small ranged units shooting me 50 metres away, I'm dead in probably 20 seconds and there is nothing skillful I can do to counter this as Assault, my preferred class. Assault is easily the weakest because it lacks utility, functionality, and a worthwhile ability; the strongest and most efficient use of the Assault's jump-pack is to simply stall and run away when the chips are down so you can get reinforcements. Vanguard mogs Assault having played both classes, not just in melee efficiency but in immense measurable utility for yourself and team.

Did I mention they take countless melee attacks? They do not give a damn. Thunderhammer in their face? They do not care, they will just attack. Jump pack attack or charged attack? Nah they get Insane I-frame dodges that break your tracking and teleports that can actually send them behind walls and covers and allow them to instantly counter attack with an unblockable flame attack, SUCK IT Astartes trash! Behold the trickery of Tzeentch!

Take every con I've mentioned, now play on the hardest difficulty, now crank it from a 7 to an 11. They. Are. Overtuned. The issues of a pure melee experience is exasperated 100-fold when you play assault against them. You will whittle them down slowly but never be able to efficiently take them down, though this feels very in their ballpark, it just feels plain bad. At least give me a way to counter this. Here is the irony, Extremis thousand sons are easier to kill. Yeah, no seriously, they really are, I can easily parry and perfect dodge their moves and finish them off because they do not teleport away. Every single unit is overtuned.

Regardless of the issue I stated before though, Space Marine 2 is a GREAT Warhammer game and one I think fans will enjoy years to come. Despite this, I think the developer Saber Interactive has shown us that they have what it takes to make a good Warhammer game and I look forward to their future developments.

Pros:
- Fantastic visuals that capture the 40k aesthetics
- Good variety in playstyles among the classes
- Good visual customization by individual armour parts
- Satisfying gunplay and melee, visceral finishers
- Large arsenal of weapons, each with minor variations along their own progression paths
- Tyranids are extremely well realized. They nailed the scope of the swarms.

The Gargoyle swarms absolutely managed to convey the scope of a tyranid invasion. While it should be even worse than this, it’s a perfectly fine approximation given limited computing power.
Tyranid dynamics were translated nicely into gameplay. Take out the warrior, so the gaunts collapse, take out the Hive Tyrant to bring an entire assault to a screeching halt.
All the special bioforms feel distinctive and accurate, with the Lictor being my favourite. The fact that auspex scan reveals him, that the initial boss encounter is basically Predator and the sound cues whenever a lictor is lurking make it a great experience.




Cons:
- Characters are cardboard cut-outs you cannot customize. Wanna play the vanguard? You gonna be playing as Decimus Jackson Jr.

- Cast and general cutscene presentation:

The cast is tragically flat. Titus being a miserable cu** is fitting, but Gadriel is needlessly antagonistic just to construe drama, and Chairon is alright, I guess. Also zero facial expressions on Gadriel.

Captain McAngus is the usual trope, hates your guts at first, but comes around when he realizes you were right all along. Boring, no air about him, probably just a GW mandated Phobos Captain miniature insert.

Amon-Ra was so-so. He had some glimpses of personality and an overall interesting design, but there was just not enough screen time to really explore his character. I’d have wished for a more fleshed out characterization because there was good potential there, especially for a tzeentchian manipulator.

Worst of all was Calgar though, no gravitas nor intensity, looked comical fighting. Could’ve had a badass scene of him 1on1ing the Swarmlord or something. Anything really to mark him as the chapter master. Quite disappointing.

In general, it seems like they couldn’t match the intensity from the actual gameplay in the cutscenes. They feel lifeless, often uncanny and unfinished. I really wanted to be done with the campaign asap to enjoy ops mode without spoilers, which is not a good sign in my book.

That being said, the actual meat of the game is good. Melee and shooting feel great, once you’ve gotten the hang of the combat flow. Tyranids are more developed on that front, with Tzeentch providing a slight spike in difficulty while lacking the satisfaction of gory finishers and internal faction dynamics.
I’ll probably spend a good amount of time playing operations, as the classes feel distinct enough to get fresh experiences out of them, even with the limited mission set.


A solid 7/10 for me as a Warhammer 40k enthusiast. Probably more of a 5-6/10 for tourists.

Solid 8/10 with a side of issues
I played through all of campaign on hard and a bit of multiplayer, long story short: campaign is great, multi could be better. I'm gonna go over what problems I noticed so it may sound a bit negative, but overall I'm having a blast with the game, so if you want some Warhammer power fantasy, this is the game

Campaign
I'll try to make this as technical as possible and [REDACT] any spoilers
I liked the story, I loved the visuals and cherished the weapons.

Not gonna talk much about story overall, characters are servicable, they are Astartes, so you don't expect highly emotional and expressive performance, they do a good job conveying their arcs, and the plot kept me engaged.

Visuals are amazing. The arenas and setpieces as well as cutscenes are absoultely gorgeous, however there is a huge whiplash when pre-rendered cutscene cuts to in-game one, and there is one bizzare scene, where Again, don't wanna get too much into individual examples, cause story, I'll only say .

About music... to be honest I didn't hear it most of the time (mixing is a bit weird), so not much to say here.

In terms of guns all of them are distinct, the sound and feedback is great (tho there are minor issues, like altfire for underbarrel grenade launcher clipping sideways from hand), and the melee weapons and executions let you unleash absolute, glorious and cinematic carnage only made better with executions.

That said, there are also issues. For campaign melee is the way to go, and for a good reason. But there are some tanky ranged enemies, which can be a pain to deal with. You see, most weapons seem to be designed for close- to mid-range combat (in multiplayer I saw a tooltip about most weapons damage decreasing with distance, don't know if it works in campaign too), so you have to either get closer to aforementioned enemies (if you can, they sometimes are on inaccessible ledges/platforms, or they just shoot you on approach), or shoot half your ammo into them, which might be problematic, because most of the time you are engaged in melee. You can use some long range guns, but then they are not very good at dealing with any other enemies. In my opinion adding a bit of stagger to shots and making you able to aim while running with side weapon would solve this a bit, and also make the small gun serve a purpose beside finishers.
The second problem: these flying f***s. You'll know which ones. This is mostly extention of previous thing, except you can't get to melee range with them at all. They have powerful range attacks and they buff the hordes. So on one hand game tells you to focus them as sort of sergeants, but you can only do this with ranged weapons (and trust me, those guys soak up your ammo) while dodging their attacks AND managing chaff. Tbh they are manageable on their own, but when there's 2 or more, you don't even have that much time to shoot at them, because you have to dodge them (some cooldown shared between all of them would be nice, but then It'd look like they are getting in queue to attack, I don't know). I'm focusing on them so much, because fighting them is one of the very few moments, that feel tedious during the game.
Also, play campaign on the controller if you can, it really isn't made for mouse and keyboard.

I'll be a bit more critical here, but that may be, because from the beginning I wanted to play the Assault class, which I think suffers from some key problems in the mode.

Remember earlier when I said melee is the way to go in campaign? Well here it's the complete opposite, I have to remind myself constantly to not use melee. During melee you are almost completely still, and time before swings is long enough enemies will just run away and shoot you, and it doesn't do that much damage, (which is weird IMO, in gameplay perspective powerful melee is the incentive to get close and take risks, here it just isn't worth it, on assault after slamming next to an enemy it is better to shoot them with a bolt pistol than use melee. And that is if they don't shoot you down on approach) This may be better with Bulwark, but I haven't played it, and they have a shield, so they at least won't be shot on approach.

"So ok, slamming down on enemies doesn't work, so I'll just try shooting them while hovering." Yeah, about that. Remember when I told you about tooltip saying damage falls with distance? Assault has a sidearm only, so you have to be close to hit your shots and deal meaningful damage. But you don't wanna be close, 'cause then other class with proper range option will just outdamage you (Emperor forbid you get too close to heavy). Long range rifles don't suffer from that, as their damage doesn't fall off, and they love a hovering immobile target on open space.

This is a bit of a rant, but I feel like every other class has a way to deal with the disadvantage, I myself had some success with Assault, but mostly when enemy team either didn't look up or I could ambush some solo players, but if they correct for that, it's over. I just love jump packs and desperately want them to have a place, I'm biased here and I don't care. I think melee damage should be upped and some movement during melee added, in this state I think it is just underwhelming, and dueling a World Eater in PvP would be awesome.

Also, left side cover is OP, your crosshair being on right side of your model makes peaking from right side of cover very good, and peaking from left side very bad, as enemies see you before you can see them. EA Battlefront solved it by allowing you to switch the side crosshair is on, but I don't know if it is possible here, so I'll just say it's something you have to keep in mind.

The game is awesome. The multi is fun. Contents of this review are critical in due to tendency to focus on the bad, me being salty about state of jump pack b0i and avoiding spoiling the game. I had a real blast playing through it and I'll be playing co-op with a friend soon, looking forward to playing this and any future content, great job devs.

I have not been so engaged on a game like this for a long time.

Well done.

Few are the games that make me want to spend 25 hours in 2.5 days on them.

The game has 3 aspects - Campaign (Story), PVE Operations (CO-OP) and PVP.

The campaign is serviceable enough, albeit basic and the story is nothing to write home about. The story is the classic "hero is for some reason the chosen one and gets dropped into a myriad of crazy situations which for some reason only they can solve". It's nothing new, but it gets the ball rolling and sets up the world in a way that's easy to understand. Anyone who knows the WH40K universe will not have anything mind-blowing come up here, and those new to the universe will probably recognize many of the themes. It IS pretty cool to see some characters from the wider universe show up or be mentioned, though.

The campaign is mostly there to introduce several mechanics, combat and weapons, which you will use everywhere else in the game. it's still a fun ride, just nothing amazing.

The PvE coop is a blast. There's a lot of progression to be had, 6 unique classes each with variations on their playstyle, several weapons and toolkits that each class can use, and so on. There's a "grind" associated with levelling up a class, unlocking more abilities and cosmetics, but there are NO micro-transactions and you simply have to play the game to get stronger, which (and I can't believe we've gotten to this point) is honestly a breath of fresh air in today's gaming landscape. Similar to Helldivers 2 in a way, progression is gated behind playing, and there are no fat-wallet shortcuts.

The gameplay in the PVE coop missions is similar to the campaign. Incredibly fun, power-fantasy-filled combat, with slightly varying objectives between runs, several difficulty options and many customization options to unlock. The class based system makes for interesting compositions and characters will have different dialog depending on which classes were picked for a given mission. Overall this is a good, strong opening, for a game that will be growing in scope in the live service model.

PVP is, well, basic. Definitely not the game's focus, but its very fun and brings the late 2000s early 2010s vibe of slower shooters with higher TTKs and more emphasis on positioning and teamplay rather than "cracked 14 year olds with ADHD" levels of AIM. Some classes (Bulwark) are a bit frustrating to play against, but this will probably get toned down a bit as developers are already aware. The game's not even out yet (officially), so its kinda hard to really address balance issues in a meaningful way.

The big elephant in the room which I haven't mentioned is the servers and matchmaking + myraid of loading screens. This is a massive downside and stability is massively affected by this. Every PVE mission is a crapshoot as to whether you will successfully load in, and then, upon completion, successfully see the rewards screen. You will get the rewards regardless, but you might not see them being dolled out, leading to a hard ALT+F4 restart being required. This is less of an issue for PvP, but still happened once across my 40 or so matches.

All in all, definitely a game I would not skip. It's going to really shine in the next couple of months, and those will be the best time to play it, as games like this tend to die out slowly after the initial hype, with people returning when new content drops.

Do I recommend this game?
Overall.. yes. This game is the definition of 'Hell Yeah'.
Do I regret buying the ultra edition? Yes.
The servers & load screens are genuinely frustrating, trying to load into a friends lobby over these first few days has been an insult to the emperor himself & the inquisition would take action.. if they could.
If & when these issues do get fixed however, this game will be phenomenal. The game play itself already is, I initially played the campaign through on normal difficulty(2nd lowest) and still found it challenging at times. It has an amazing progression system with no micro-transactions for a pay to win experience. Even if you pay the full price for this game you will easily(EASILY) get 50 hours of bug smashing, heretic purging fun.

Being a big Fan of Warhammer 40k, I couldn't wait for this game to release. But with the current landscape, I was a bit sceptical of the final product. I also jumped into this game straight after beating Wukong. So Space Marine 2 had some big shoes to fill. I will divide this review into 3 parts. Getting this prelude out of the way, lets head into the review.

Disclaimer: I'm dutch and dyslectic (meaning i can't write for shtt), so I will apolegize for grammatical errors and writing errors in advance.

The Campaign:

This campaign picks up after the first game and follows Titus. If you are jumping into this game, i would strongly advise you to play the first game. As there is a red line of story that it follows from the previous game right on trough to the end of this second campaign. You could also watch a recap, if space marine 1 is to old for your liking.

The good:
The story is not to long, not to short and is a thrill from beginning to end. The cutscenes and background (wars being fought on the horizon) are great. The tutorial is woven into the narrative and makes it one of the best tutorials i've played in a while. Just due to the story and spectical. The rest of the story is comparable to the thrill ride you know from games like Gears of War or even Halo. The characters are written well enough and actually talk like they are from the 40k universe. The game also doesn't pull any punches. Death is all around you and normal humans die like its going out of style. Co-op also works like a charm, eventough the servers were getting hammered during the early acces.

The bad:

It can feel a bit furmulaic and apart from the story, there is no reason to do the campaign. There are no upgrades, unlocks (apart from your loadout), or real cosmetic options to dripp up Titus. The game also has a need to escalte things further and further to the point it sometimes becomes to ludicrous for its own good (im talking about the ending). The bots are also horrendous. If you play the campaign on your own and wanna complete it on the highest difficulties, I would recommend to get a pillow to bite in and some lube. Your on your own and the bots will cheer the enemies on while your having a fit after dying the third time in a row.

Multiplayer: Co-op and PvP

Its great. The pve missions are replayable and getting to know the maps is a big part of tackling them on harder difficulties. Make no mistake, this game can get HARD. If you just wanna hit buttons, this game will whoop your bottom. There is also no point in doing these harder missions on higher difficulties with bots. But with people, this becomes a tactical game where you have to lean on eachothers shoulders to make it trough. Sharing healthpacks, ammo and grenades to get the best chance of making it to the end. The custumisation is also great. Enough chapters to pimp your Space Marine to your hearts liking. I would also like to point out that the game is a huge commercial succes (by the looks of it) so there will be more content in the future. The progression in unlocking cosmetics and gear is also nicely woven into just playing the game. The gear you use have stats and you got a few versions per class to run with. You can also further personalise with perks on weapons and on your character.

The pvp is also great. It feels balanced and fun. A match takes between 10 to 15 minutes and brings back the old formula of just 6 v6 with loadouts to beat eachother into the ground 40k style. Its fluent, doesn't take long to find matches and people are not toxic in the 30-40 matches ive played. pregression in this is halway interlinked with the co-op mode, so cosmetic unlocks carry over between modes.

The bad:

An Imperial Guardsman, a Space Marine, and an Inquisitor walk into a bar.

The Guardsman says "ow."

The Marine breaks right through the bar with his reinforced skull.

The Inquisitor accuses the bar of heresy. When the bar refuses to confess or even move despite sustained torture, the Inquisitor executes the Guardsman for failing to defeat the bar in combat.

Its just a best Warhammer action game. 9/10 for Warhammer universe fans and maybe 7-8/10 for regular players. I just finished the campaign after 12 hours and still have 3 operations left to do, which is about 1 hour more of content. Sure, the 6 operations are meant to be repeatable, the same way Left 4 Dead, Darktide, Diretide missions are meant to be repeatable. Same concept: A linear map with completion of certain objectives, with some rewards for limited exploration. If you like that type of repetitive gameplay, then you'll enjoy this.

The Co-Op progression is nice so far. You have 2 progression paths, the class progression and the weapon progression.

Leveling up the class gives you access to more class cosmetics and class perks, to improve/change your playstyle of that specific class.

Leveling up the weapon gives you access to improved weapons stats, cosmetics as well as weapon perks. The weapon progress is shared among all classes that use that weapon, which is very nice, makes so that if you like a particular weapon, but want to change classes, if that class uses that weapon, you continue with that progression.

The problem I see (maybe it might amount to nothing), is that there are only 6 maps for the Co-Op experience right now. Usually Left 4 Dead kind of games have 10+ missions. But if you think about it, Left 4 Dead started with 7 missions and Left 4 Dead 2 started with 6 when they came out, and they were great games.

I saw some reviews and there are some people complaining about connectivity issues. I haven't had such, so I cannot speak about that.

One last thing, that bothered me a bit, is that it seems that no two players can use the same class at the same time. At least not when joining someone else's game midway. The same is with Deep Rock Galatic. As the host, you have the option to limit or allow class repetition. Maybe it's the same here, I don't know.

Since they will continue to release new content over time, new missions and such, it will get better over time, as they all did. Is it worth it now? That is up to you.

This is Pre-Release, so things might change after release. Take all of this with a pinch of salt.

Warhammer 40k: Space Marines 2
Release Date: 05/09/2024 (PRE-RELEASE)

Overview
In "Space Marine 2," players once again take on the role of Captain Titus as he battles against the relentless forces of Chaos and the Tyranids, a swarm-like alien race. The game promises intense, visceral combat that combines brutal melee attacks with devastating ranged weaponry, staying true to the original's blend of action and strategy. The game is set to deliver improved visuals, more dynamic environments, and larger battles, taking full advantage of current-gen hardware. It also aims to capture the dark and oppressive atmosphere of the Warhammer 40k universe, appealing to both longtime fans and newcomers.

Story
Players continue the saga of Captain Titus, a seasoned Ultramarine who is thrust into a desperate battle against the relentless Tyranids, an alien species known for their hive mind and insatiable hunger. As the Imperium of Man faces overwhelming odds, Captain Titus must lead his squad through war-torn environments, using a mix of brutal melee and powerful ranged combat to defend humanity from annihilation. The story explores themes of duty, sacrifice, and the eternal struggle against the dark forces threatening the galaxy.

The gameplay in "Space Marine 2" centers on fast-paced, brutal combat as players control Captain Titus, blending heavy melee attacks with powerful ranged weapons. It emphasizes the visceral experience of being a Space Marine, allowing players to chain attacks, execute combos, and use tactics to battle the Tyranid hordes. Designed to capture the intensity and scale of Warhammer 40,000, the game offers a mix of strategy, skill, and raw power.

Short review: Do I recommend the game? Yes. But to people who are interested in Warhammer 40k. And not the expensive editions, just buy the regular one.

Long review: I loved the first Space Marine, actually, I beat it last week for the first time in anticipation for the sequel.
Space Marine 2 leaves you in awe of how amazing the environments look. The hordes are stunning and give you the "oh shi-" feeling when you realize that the hundreds of Tyranids running towards you aren't some backdrop but the actual enemies you'll have to fight.

Some gameplay mechanics are questionable. Executions now replenish armor instead of health unlike in the first game, this makes sense from a Co-Op point of view but in the campaign it really pulls you out of the moment and frustrates you. In fact, if you fully die, you just restart from the previous checkpoint with reset to your "downed" limit. Which means that if you got into a boss fight with just "down" left, it's better to just let the boss kill you to restart the fight with a reset "down" count.

I'm also not a fan of the limited weapon slots. In the previous game you had your pistol, your primary and two other slots for big guns. In this game, you have your pistol, your primary, and an occasional big gun which you can pick up but have to drop if you want to switch to the others. This left me wishing I had picked another gun as my primary before specific boss fights.

There were very few bugs, and I had encountered only 1 soft block during a mission, but luckily I had a checkpoint right before so I reloaded and didn't lose any progress. Checkpoints in this game are very generously provided.

The game is great for 40k fans, but some of the gameplay mechanics make it frustrating to play on the higher difficulties. I played on the "Veteran" difficulty which is the second highest and the intended one by the devs, and I do wonder if people were even more frustrated with the highest difficulty.

Tl;Dr: Space Marine 2 is a great game for 40k fans but will likely leave non-fans frustrated due to a handful of gameplay design choices that really piss you off. Only the standard edition is worth it, don't waste your money.

So far Warhammer: 40,000 Space Marine 2 is an absolute MASTERPIECE. The improvements this game has made since the first game are absolutely unbelievable. Space Marine 2 introduces a new unique melee and ranged combat system, massively upgraded graphics, massively updated visuals, introduces new weapons and so, so much more. This game is a MUST PLAY!

The new combat system in Space Marine 2 is a very unique in depth system. Just like in the first game, you can obviously still shoot, hack, and slash. The biggest difference in the Combat System in Space Marine 2 is Parrying. You can now Parry attacks from the Tyranids, and I've just gotta say that I am a HUGE fan of it. When you are about to be attacked, there will be a blue indicator indicating that you are about to be attacked. You press whatever button you have it set to, and then you succesfully pull off the parry. When you parry an attack you get this sick animation of you obliterating the Tyranid. The dodging mechanic is very similar to the first game, but there are also indicators of when you are suggested to dodge. Also, The executions you can perform on the Tyranids are just absolutely awesome.

I haven't finished the Campaign as of now, but so far it is just awesome. Just like the first game you play as Captain Titus, and your goal is to ultimately prevent the Tyranid Invasion. If you don't want spoilers then skip the rest of this paragraph. This intro is super epic... me describing it in this review obviously doesn't do it justice, but this is probably the best intro to a game I have seen in a while.

I did have some issues getting the game to launch, but once I got the game working it runs very well. I recommend tweaking the settings before you start the Campaign. My main recommendation would be to cap your frame rate straight away, but otherwise unless you know you need to make any other tweaks, you are good to go.

Overall, I think this game is a MUST PLAY, especially if you played the first Space Marine Game. If you liked the first game in the series, I can almost guarantee you will love this game. Sure, the parrying may take some getting used to, but once you learn the parry system the combat is awesome, especially with the executions.

Space Marine 2 is an amazing game and excellent entry to the Warhammer 40k series. Most of us know that GOOD Warhammer games are hard to come by. Many games were hit and miss & eventually faded away to time. But, this entry to the series in my honest opinion is going to be what puts this amazing series on the map more than ever. New and Seasoned fans are going to be in for a delight as they mow their way through the Tyranid filth & Expel the heretical chaos cults. It has been so long since we felt this way. Warhammer fans rejoice. This game offers something to scratch the needs of almost all players. Looking for a campaign? We got it . Looking for a PVE co-op experience? We got it . The campaign is good but, its not great. It feels like they wanted to combine God Of War & Dark-tide. But ultimately it fell a tad short based on my opinion. For such a series packed to the BRIM with lore and amazing characters. I felt like a-lot was missing from the experience. The voice-acting felt a bit complacent and dull. Some moments where good, some moments where bad. Overall I felt a inconsistent experience. A-lot of the factor starts to wear off pretty quickly. Once you experience it a few times. It starts losing its touch real fast.

Now Space Marine 2 has two different co-op experiences that it can offer. The co-op campaign & the operations mode. The Co-op campaign is as much as you'd expect from this game. Its fun, moderately paced & great with friends. Operations mode feels like it lacks quite a-lot of repeatability. Every mission is the same with the only change being where you grab an objective off a corpse. There is no "modifiers" or anything else that you can think of to keep a fresh experience or, a less bland one. The only variation you get is your classes and armors. That's all. To me, thats a HUGE let-down. Warhammer: Dark-tide offers more variation in one mission then all the operation missions do combined. Thats a big oof if you ask me. I don't ever really feel like running those missions more than once its really worth my time as it becomes boring and repetitive quite quickly. Truly is a shame as I feel like the selling point for this game was its operations mode.

If you loved space marine 1 or a fan of Warhammer 40K, you'll love this game. As a direct sequel to the previous one, this game also stays true to the gritty and hefty feel of being an astartes fighting impossible odds as you clash against a never ending horde of enemies in a desperate gambit for survival.
The game does a wonderful job with major set pieces, absolutely gorgeous visuals, and really sets the atmosphere you would get from your favorite Warhammer books. The game was definitely made for 40k fans in mind and it shows.

Mechanics wise, it feels very similar to the first one with its somewhat janky combat system and it's repetitive hack n slash feel. If you love that kinda stuff, you'll feel right at home. Operations and eternal war feel a lot better than the story gameplay wise giving you a variety of different classes that all have different play styles and limits of what you can do. The pvp is a great homage to the early 2000s style of run n' gun around the map without making it too complicated and honestly, it's a lot more fun and addicting than it sounds.

The game itself is a huge tribute to the fans of Space Marines but it's a mixed bag for anyone who is new to the universe. The game does not in anyway try to teach you what is what and who is who so prepare for some reading or YouTube videos if you happen to want to get into the lore. The game story is easy to digest and the combat on normal mode is very noob friendly but it's recommended to go through the story with a friend or two as it definitely makes the gameplay more enjoyable. Saber interactive hit the spot in getting the feel and soul of a Warhammer power fantasy and this is definitely one of the better Warhammer games. Do not miss this game if you love Warhammer.

I almost didn't buy this game due to the review bomb from people who don't read the EULA. Luckily, I read into the negative reviews and saw they mostly had that in common, and decided to give it a try. I don't normally post reviews, but I think it's only fair to add a positive one to counteract the unfair negative reviews this game is getting.

The pros (only playing Multiplayer COOP so far):
* You can join matches in progress and have people join in progress on you, so you don't need to worry about people dropping out.
* The missions are fairly linear, but it works similar to L4D2 where the locations of items and when enemies attack can be somewhat random.
* The AI direct is brutal but balanced.
* I don't see anything with an advantage behind a paywall so far. All cosmetics only really.

The cons?
* The learning curve is higher than you'd think with team dynamics. It takes time to realize what skills to bring, and even normal difficulty is brutal without the right skills and synergies in coop.
* It's sometimes hard to find games at odd hours of the day.
* I've had the game freeze during joining games on occasion, and the loading screens are a pain.

Overall, it's a bit of a grind and it's a little repetitive. If it had to rate it, I'd give it something like a 70-75%. I'd like to see more content, but I don't feel my money was wasted either.

It's a really good game and worthy successor to the first game. It's let down by a few things which I'll cover but which can probably be fixed easily with updates;

1. Not the biggest fan of the balance of the new health/armor system in single player.
2. Fix it so we can choose not to join MP PVP games with 200+ ping - not having a settings for this in 2024 is ridiculous.
3. Way the tool tips are explained for parrying/dodging doesn't really line up with how the systems work in game and should be ironed out (It's not necessarily "bush button when you see red/blue light" - it's a little more nuanced than that.
4. The UI for armor customisation etc is just ♥♥♥♥ to navigate on PC and was clearly designed with consoles more in mind. Please fix this.
5. Some optimisation in frames and loading times would be good.
6. Some of the difficulty modifiers are a bit extreme especially on AoD level difficulty, especially playing solo.
7. Some minor bugs esp with how AI helpers behave.

That said the good things;

1. It's a blast.
2. Story is fun.
3. It's really gorgeous to look at.
4. Really leans into the grim dark.
5. Sound is great.
6. The way they've integrated the operations missions into the actual story is genius. I hope they plan more content along these lines.
7. With the way they've built it out I can see it being a game that has content coming for it for a long time.

Overall I'd give it a solid 8/10, room for improvement being in the things I mentioned at the beginning.

Finished the campaign and dived into the Co-op a bit at the time of writing this. This is a love letter to Warhammer fans. I have personally experience about four bugs total in the game, that a simple restart has fixed and thats with the four day early access, stuff I am sure they will clean up. My major complaint was that campaign missions felt too long, and thats a wild thing to complain about. Everything else is so perfect. Combat feels great, animations look amazing, writing is solid, every faction is represented so well.

I played through alone and with friends, and had equally as much fun both times. Towards the end of the game you gets some moments that are worthy of going on box art they look so good.

I found myself stopping often to look at the scenery, the background fights, and even just to look at the little NPC guardsman uniforms. It all was clearly made by people who care to represent warhammer right. I am still dissapointed Darktide has nothing close to these guardsman uniforms, and these guys and gals are literally background characters... wild.

Space Marine 2 is easily one of the top games in the Warhammer 40K universe. After 13 long years of waiting since the excellent first game, it was absolutely worth the anticipation. To be completely honest, I got my hands on it early thanks to the leak in July, but since I knew I’d be buying the full version (and went all out for the maximum edition), I think that excuses my impatience. I simply couldn't wait!

Campaign

The sequel’s story picks up directly from the first game, even though about 200 years have passed in the timeline. The campaign is as grand as you’d hope, fitting perfectly within the Warhammer 40K universe. Blood, gruesome executions, and limb-tearing battles define this world, and the game delivers on all fronts. While it’s linear and heavily focused on combat, I found the whole experience a ton of fun.

Combat Mechanics

The combat truly nails the feeling of being an unstoppable, armored giant. From the moment you start the campaign it’s clear that you are super-human. The Ultramarines stand out from the surroundings and look like some sort of Titans, with their sheer size making them equals to the Tyranid warriors. The weight and power of your weapons – both melee and ranged – feel spot on, especially when playing with a controller (I’m using an Xbox one). Each hit, shot, and headshot feels impactful, and those bloody finishing moves? Just perfect.

Co-op Mode

A great addition is the new co-op mode. After the introductory mission, you can jump into the campaign with one or two friends, and it works flawlessly. It really amps up the excitement of playing together. If you're playing solo, the AI companions are excellent, so you won’t feel left out.

Multiplayer

And now for the real treat: multiplayer. If you have fond memories of the multiplayer from the original Space Marine, you’re in for a treat. It was brilliant back then and kept me entertained for hours. Now, after 13 years, we finally have what we’ve been waiting for. The multiplayer alone makes Space Marine 2 worth buying. If you're into the Warhammer 40K universe, there’s no better PvP experience out there.

In my opinion, it’s a solid 10/10. Definitely worth checking out!

Space Marine 2 is a masterclass of game play, aesthetic and story adaption.

It's rare we get a down in the mud war game that is just big sweaty men beating other big sweaty men for 15+ hours but here we are, haven't touched the operations or PvP yet but the story and single player campaign alone more than deserves its asking price with how faithful and intense the story is to the world of 40k.

Even on my 1080, the game is smooth and optimized properly and doesn't rely as insanely heavy on modern gimmicks to have the game run smoothly and look great, it actually makes me want to upgrade to see it in its full glory.

To me it's a mixed leaning more positive, I'm also making it a positive review as there's far too many review bombers nowadays that rate a game badly because of connection issues and not the actual quality of the game itself, but here's my personal reasons as to why:

Pros:
- Gameplay is VERY fun to me, I feel like I'm playing a slightly slower paced doom and I am absolutely all for it
- The devs absolutely nailed the aesthetic of every faction/race involved in the game
- The missions are memorable and the story is well written, it combines the main campaign with the operations mode so you can see another section of the story being told (cool concept imo)
- Gunplay feels nice and very impactful, some enemies feel quite spongey but it's to be expected of them, whereas the trash gaunts and such really feel like they're weak and puny compared to you as a space marine.
- Customizing your marines for operations and PvP is so nice, some minor things could be changed such as chapter icon placements on both shoulders instead of just the left, but past that you can make the chapter you want or even your own unique chapters and I love that!
- The game is a real power fantasy of being a space marine, nice.
- The classes are all very unique in their own ways and it gives you a sense of responsibility in a certain way? Like how a Bulwark will tank most of the hits for your team, a Sniper will target Majoris enemies that may cause your team issues, Vanguards will grapple around to enemies dueling them and so on. The visual aesthetic of each class is noticeably different per class too so you can really stand out if that's your thing.

Cons:
- Me personally, I've experienced a few bugs far between one another, the gamebreaking ones being the infinite loading and some are just a minoris (get it?) inconvenience such as cosmetics changing back to being a blueberry marine, no biggie.
- Campaign felt quite laggy as I went on through the missions, whether it's my CPU (which is well above minimum) or if the game is poorly optimized for CPU usage currently, I'm unsure, but time will tell.
- There really isn't enough content in the game to warrant the price tag, it's an absolutely beautiful and well built game, but considering the campaign length and the current 6 operations available in the game (which some mentioned will actually change each time, all they seemingly meant was item placement and enemy placements during the mission), now we are getting more content but that all comes next year sadly.
- The connection issues are reminding me heavily of other super hyped up game releases such as Helldivers, so fingers crossed these get fixed up before the full official launch of the game.

The game is a solid 7.5/10 currently, it has room for improvement but it has no real way to retain its playerbase, which frankly makes me quite sad considering how hyped I was to be a space marine in current year gaming.

Gears of War (minus the cover mechanics) meets Dark Souls (minus the stamina)- that is basically the gist. I think this game is insanely good. There is a lot to like here and a completely different play style is involved in being good at it. To all the people who are saying the game is unplayable, it is because you are trying to play the game like it is something it is not.

Here are 10ish tips I use to play harder missions:

1- Don't try and run from enemies... it won't work. They will tear you to pieces while you roll or run away. When you get in the thick of it, you need to be able to keep smaller enemies back while engaging elite enemies. Tyrannids will die when their elites are killed near them, so killing an elite will wipe the mob. With Chaos Marines you should ignore the elites for the most part and focus on the mobs- the little humans can decimate you with their charged shots and the units with swords and shields are priority to remove.

2- Get used to parrying/dodging (like Dark Souls... kinda) and don't try to button mash your way through melee combat. Parry/timed-dodge give you room and open up attacks that do massive damage to single targets and can give you armor back. That is the way you play the game. All classes can hold it down in the thick. Some are better than others, but the only class that can break aggro is Sniper (cloak). Everyone else just needs to learn to hold it down.

3- If you are a ranged class, it serves you best to get near melee units when surrounded, let them get most aggro while you pick off.
3.5- If you are melee, don't leave your ranged guys behind too far. They are vital to controlling mobs and helping you bring down the ranged elites that make it hard to sit in the melee.

4- Don't be afraid to take a little damage to get off a big hit. Some melee charged attacks leave you vulnerable, but the effect of that attack is worth taking a little damage. It can stagger enemies and open them up to executions or one-shots that replenish armor. (This is especially useful for Heavy class when surrounded by trash mobs. Charge the stomp and take the hits. The slower attacks are not going to give you breathing room.)

5- Let ammo classes have the ammo when you are melee and let the melee classes have the health packs. Don't be the melee guy using an ammo pack to replenish your side arm with 10 rounds where it can give a heavy another 90. The heavy can do FAR MORE work with 90 than you can with 10.

6- Look around the maps after they are clear for pickups. They are often in green stacked boxes with labels on them. Roll into those boxes to reveal some choice rewards.
6.5- Use environmental objects to kill mobs. There are explosive barrels everywhere in the maps. Even if you are standing right by them, you can shoot them. Space Marines don't take much damage from friendly explosives of any type.

7- When you hear the weird vibrating wave noise and see the indicator that an elite is calling in reinforcements... target that character with headshots, heavy hits, or nades. It will cause the timer to end and it takes time before the enemies can call again. Don't let them call in reinforcements all the time. THIS IS ESPECIALLY TRUE WITH CHAOS MARINES!

8- This is actually one of the more important points I have: DON'T RUSH. Slow is steady and steady is fast. Everyone trying to rush ahead will get you split up or bottlenecked in an area that can make engagements too hard. While some missions or areas can be advanced while under attack, hordes can often move to the next area and be waiting for you, so you actually don't skip anything. THE ONLY TIME TO RUSH is on the last objective. You can often end the objective without having to clear all enemies.

9- A.I. is not useful in harder difficulties (ESPECIALLY SNIPER CLASS ***absolutely useless***). I wouldn't recommend even trying it. It CAN be done, but it is adding an extra layer of difficulty on what is already a difficult game. Just wait to pick up players. The missions can take a good 30-60 minutes to complete on harder difficulties. You can wait a few minutes more for a third.

10- Each class has a way to either keep up their ammo, or keep up their armor/health (some have both). Learn those tricks to keep you alive and get good at exploiting them. For instance: Bulwarks get all of the depleted health from their special the second it is used. You can turn all that health back in full if you can execute an enemy soon after. Sometimes it is better to get an enemy in an execute state, drop your flag and then execute the enemy to get all of your remaining health back... you don't need to use a heath pack.

ive never written a review for a steam game before but im glad that space marine 2 will be the first. I really enjoy this game but it def has its issues. I understand that the game just came out so things wont be perfect so im writing this as just some things that hopefully will be changed or touched upon in the upcoming updates and final release.

This game is a very fun but kinda clunky game. ive been playing with my brother and were having a blast but we have been experiencing some issues.

1. The resources in the game that allow you to customize and upgrade your space marine in my opinion are kinda hard and annoying to get. I understand that you gotta grind for them but i think that you dont receive enough of them after each mission.

2. oncoming range damage needs to be lowered a lotttt. I find myself entering a area and then almost instantly losing all of my health and armor due to playing a melee space marine. This causes me to have to dodge a lot and space marines dont really seem like the guys who roll around dodging everything like in a dark souls game. It just feels like im rolling around trying to get out of line of fire way to often.

3. That brings me to the health. The white health needs to be either removed or touched on. It lasts for almost no time at all so its very difficult to gain back the health you have lost in that time. Executions being the main way to get back health besides the stims i think is a really cool touch to the game. I think that having the executions heal a percentage or some amount instead of the white health bar would be a lot better for the game. (you could also lower range damage)

4. Parrying in this game is wack. i can either do it or i straight up cant. I also find myself parrying on a blue icon but just to get hit out of it by some dumb alien. I then proceed to get ganked and stun locked by everything. I dont know if this is a skill issue or not but something needs to change about the parrying in this game.

5. The ai in this game is actually laughable. Before writing this review i was in a mission where one of the space marines was using the sniper class. I watched as our man used up all of his sniper ammo on the small waves. he then took out his pistol after he ran out of ammo and would shoot the big guys. This literally doesn't make any sense. They shouldn't do this and they should also be able to pick up ammo or something. Also sometimes ill see them just standing while im fighting everything. They also arnt very focused on by the enemy and they almost never perform an execution.

Overall i really enjoy the game but i def see some things needing change in the future. I will continue to play this game with myself and my friends.

As a long time Warhammer 40K fan, i was really excited to hear that we were getting a sequel to the first Space Marine. I was not let down at all. Space Marine 2 is a game that took the first Space Marines, 40K Lore, and modern day mechanics and made a great sequel.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Good.

The Campaign is fun to play with friends or even if you are by yourself. Having played both, they both run smooth and leave plenty of fun to be had. The executions do not feel as needed as the first Space Marine which gives the game a more open feel when it comes to combat. The melee system is great and while some may say that it is clunky... Your a space marine not a Ninja... The weapons are all great and i found myself having plenty of opportunities to choose a new one based upon what situation i found myself in. The story kept me wanting more and there was nothing that i felt was left out in the progression.

I never really found myself feeling as if I was playing something that was a filler. Everything in the game made sense and seemed as if it had a purpose. It would have been cool to have some missions where you were able to man some type of vehicle or heavy weapon but that's really picking at the bone.

While in a mission there was no loading screens that took away from the immersion. Which is something to me that I find very refreshing. I think that there's a huge emphasis now on open world games which takes away from the detail that's able to be put in from these types of stories.

The graphics are fantastic. I think that a lot of people are not looking at the minimum requirements prior to buying the game and are now blaming it on the game itself. The graphics require some beefy internals but nothing that goes far enough to render a newer 30 series any problems at all.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Not so Good.

While we are still on the first seasons and I'm sure that there is more customization to be had right now customization feels a little empty. Don't get me wrong I think that it's great that you can change your armor and add different styles to your character, I just feel as if it would be nice to be able to customize the actual character itself.

Along with the PvP customization feeling a bit empty I also feel as if the PvP modes feel a little bit empty now as well. It would be nice to have a little bit more room for some of the maps versus a very tight 3 lane system. I think that there's plenty of room to be able to play with this in the future, but I would love to see a more open concept with some of the maps.

I didn't have any glitches until the end once Titus was sent up off of the map and into an unplayable area this only happened to me once so I really wouldn't call it a bad thing, but it did make it to where I have to load from a checkpoint. Again, this is really nitpicking to try to find something whenever it comes to the game play itself.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Overall, I think that Warhammer 40K Space Marine 2 is a very fun game even if you're not a fan or knowledgeable of Warhammer. Especially for the state it's in at launch I believe that there is a lot coming to the game in the future that is going to keep fans wanting more and more.

While Space Marine 2 is solid, a worthy successor to the first game, it suffers from several critical flaws that actually are steps back from the first in some areas.

First, in terms of weapon selection the game suffers from having too many that essentially perform the same role. 3 different assault rifles, 3 different marksman rifles, several carbines; each are only different to such a minuscule degree and perform the same function that they may as well not exist. It's not particularly exciting to approach a supply pod to choose from what is essentially 3 or 4 of the same weapon. This gun has 2 less shells in it, but does 3 more damage; this one has 5 more bullets, but more recoil! Who cares?
Second, the AI companions are frustratingly stupid to the point that they are actually a liability. On numerous occasions I've failed the objective because the NPCs would prioritize slap-fighting with a single termagant over defending a mission critical target or running out of the capture area to go melee a handful of minor enemies and leaving you to hold it by yourself, drawing all the enemy fire and dying. Worst of all, the devs seem to be aware how stupid their bots are as they have relics that can let you self-revive and the take-and-hold objectives only require the player to progress.
Speaking of objectives, defend the thing and stand in the capture area are two of the worst, most boring tropes to pull out of the generic game design hat. How is standing around in a highlighted area for 5 minutes w/ no cover fun? It's not, it's padding.
Then there's lack of polish is some areas. Like how your melee and primary weapon just vanish in your hand when your switch to them, or how if you charge your plasma pistol and swap weapons the plasma coils will continue glowing and stay inflamed on your hip, or how in a cutscene where some Cadians are burning a chaos tainted tech-priest their lasguns are shooting out fire because the devs forgot to use the guardsman model w/ a flamer. These are minor things, but noticeable.

The co-op and multiplayer is pretty good, but the fact you can't customize your chaos marines beyond colors is a joke. The 2011 game had more chaos armor customization.

It's a decent game, but not worth buying at the $80+ edition's price point and would be beneficial to just buy at $60 or wait a few years for a complete all DLC edition.

Fun, but a little clunky and not quite what I was expecting. I'd be enjoying myself until encountering a bug or getting stun locked in an enemy's combo. Spamming dodge roll was not the way. Parry instead, then attack and execute.

Operations mode is a lot of fun with friends.

Campaign is sort of criminally short, maybe an hour or two shorter than the original which was already not a long game. However, there is more variety in locations, biomes, and areas. A couple of questionable game design choices and areas, like a whole segment with one of the worst flamethrowers in videogame history.

Game still has some of the fundamental design issues of the last one, except magnified a bit because now fury is the only way to recover health outside of medkits and executions only recover armor.

Tyranid enemies swarm, are fast and numerous, and feel good to shoot at. They will however always close into melee barring some good chokepoints to shoot down, so get used to living on the edge between executions.

The other faction still completely shred you at long distance, so rushing them to try and get into melee range is the best strategy, and once again, you will have to get used to living on the edge between executions. Squadmates can revive you to make it somewhat less punishing.

The real meat of the game is the WWZ-like Operations mode, which they expect will keep people playing despite the campaign being short.

Game is very pretty and runs well. It's the best-realized vision of WH40k we have right now, so if you bought it you know why you bought it. Non-40k fans, maybe it's best to wait for a sale. All the same, to have a game launch with full campaign co op, a co-op class based progression mode with XP meters, and a multiplayer deathmatch mode in 2024 is a rarity, so it's worth giving the developer some props for delivering what used to be standard for a full price video game.

Space Marine 2 Review: A Colossal Tribute to the Emperor's Legacy

Graphics and Environment
Let’s get this out of the way: the graphics, while not the heart of a game, are absolutely stunning here. Every environment you march through is a feast for the eyes. The towering structures, massive landscapes, and the overwhelming scale of everything around you are crafted with such attention to detail that the world feels both epic and alive. This isn’t just a game of massive, empty spaces—each area is filled with intricate details that contribute to the narrative and the lore of Warhammer 40K. The environments themselves tell a story, pulling you deeper into this universe with every step you take.

Animation and Weight
The animations in Space Marine 2 are where the game truly shines. The fluidity with which your character moves, swings their chainsword, or unloads a Bolter is beautifully captured. Each action feels deliberate, grounded, and—most importantly—weighty. You are a three-ton walking fortress of destruction, and the game makes sure you feel every ounce of that weight. There’s a tangible sense of power as you crush enemies beneath your boots or charge headfirst into the chaos. Every animation, from the reload of your weapons to the way your armor clangs as you run, is executed with precision and adds to the immersion.

A Seamless Continuation of the Story
Fans of the original Space Marine will be delighted to know that the story picks up seamlessly from where the first game ended. It’s engaging, well-paced, and dives deeper into the rich lore of Warhammer 40K. Though the campaign may feel short, it is packed with intensity and emotion. The writing is sharp, with enough twists to keep you on your toes, and you never feel like a passive observer; you’re in the thick of it, commanding the battlefield.

Companions and Dialogue
One standout improvement from the first game is the addition of your companions. No longer do you feel isolated in your battle against the enemies of mankind. Your comrades are constantly by your side, not just in combat but in conversation. The dialogue is rich, filled with anecdotes and banter that breathe life into your squad. You’ll find yourself lingering to catch every line, reluctant to miss a single exchange. It makes the world feel more connected and the journey more personal.

Customization and Armor
The level of customization available for your armor and weapons is downright insane—in the best possible way. The care and love poured into the design of the armor pieces, the weapons, and their customization options reflect the deep respect the developers have for the Warhammer 40K universe. Every adjustment, every new piece of gear feels earned and enhances your immersion, making you truly feel like a warrior of the Adeptus Astartes.

The Bolter Experience
And then, there’s the Bolter. It feels like a Bolter—every shot, every burst of fire is satisfying beyond words. The sound, the recoil, the destruction—it’s as though the developers bottled up every fan’s dream of wielding a Bolter and delivered it in perfect form.

A Love Letter to the Warhammer 40K Universe
At its core, Space Marine 2 is a love letter to Warhammer 40K. Every aspect of this game—from the lore, the world-building, the massive battles, to the smallest details—shows how much the developers cherish this universe. It’s clear they took their time, ensuring that every fan feels the same reverence for the Emperor’s legacy while playing.

A Bug-Free Experience
As an added bonus, my playthrough has been nothing short of flawless. In an era where games often release with bugs and glitches, Space Marine 2 stands as a rare exception. I didn’t encounter a single bug during my time with the game, which in itself is a testament to the care and dedication of the development team.

Conclusion
This is more than just a game; it’s a triumphant ode to the Imperium of Man, a masterfully crafted experience that brings the brutal, dark, and magnificent world of Warhammer 40K to life. Space Marine 2 is a game fit for the Emperor himself, blessed by the Omnissiah, and delivered to us mortals with divine precision. Thank you to the developers for creating one of the best gaming experiences of 2024.

Final Verdict: A must-play for every Warhammer 40K fan, and one of the top games of the year.

I can only review multiplayer because that's all I've played. I'll edit this to include campaign when I finish it.

MP Gameplay: (The Good)
-I actually like that there are class limits. I couldn't imagine getting stomped or stunlocked by 6 assault marines even if it's a good meme. One of the few games so far where I think it made sense to lock classes.
-Armor customization is amazing AND I love that they give a few slots for you to make several custom outfits.
-Pretty simple UI. Took me a second

MP Gamplay: (The Bad)
-Not much to put here other than a bit of server instability. Seems some people got hit hard with it, but I've only disconnected a couple times in about 8 hours of multiplayer.
-Armor customization is AMAZING, but sometimes it won't apply right away and you need ti force it to update by changing it around and then back.
-Limited to 6v6. Part of the appeal of warhammer is the scale. I love the 6v6 mode, but I do wish we had a bigger lobby size.

MP Gameplay: (The Ugly)
My frames. I've noticed a drop in frames when there's a lot of fire or visual effects (grenades, barriers, etc) all going on at once. Obv this depends on hardware though so take that with a grain of salt.
