When a Warhammer 40K game is made by passioniates of the universe and the franchise it makes Space Marines 2. They understand that a Space Marine is heavy so the movement is heavy, but they also understand that those boys are geneticly modified so they have really powerful attacks. It's like RDR2 physics meet Doom Eternal. Exactly what i wanted for this game. Do i have to talk about this gorgeous artistic direction ? I mean everyone saw it and it's more impressive in game. Optimization is on point too, it's been a long time my PC was capable to get full ultra on everything + 4K resolution on a triple A game, and on this one i can, even with a setup made at the time of RTX 3080. For the gameplay part, it's great too, i didn't watch all videos cause i absolutly hate getting all infos on a game before buying it, i watch like 1 or 2 trailers and that's all. So i got really suprise that they went for World War Z type of gameplay, which is awesome considering we are fighting Tyrannids that comes in hordes. They even also implemented a part of the gameplay from Plague Tale Innoncence replacing rats with tyrannids ones. This game is well thought for what it want to be. I mean this game is filled with great ideas, love for the universe. Combat is really smooth too, having to block at the right time, to get a automatic shoot on a ennemy and then having to go on him to finish him with a brutal animation feels so good. I mean content is already HUGE from the start. I really dont get how people are not rolling with extremly positive reviews about this game after the last triple A games being Star Wars Outlaws, they should support this type of games made we love. Tyranid medium sized enemies, from Warriors and up sponge ranged firefights and are mostly dealt with in melee. Except the sniper rifle and guns with low ammo count, the guns are intended to deal with hordes.

Game is great, solid characters and amazing gameplay and the visuals are stunning, clearly made by a game studio who wanted to make a good game from the start, also a rarity these days.

I may be somewhat partial, having been an avid Warhammer 40k enthusiast for the majority of my life, but this game has truly been exceptional. It retains the essence of the original while incorporating a contemporary feel. As a Space Marine, one genuinely feels like an indomitable force, with the bolters delivering a powerful impact as they rightfully should. The Tyranids are visually stunning, and the Gaunts evoke memories of the raptors in the long grass from one of the Jurassic Park films.

The worlds are visually breathtaking, and the level design scarcely feels linear. I often find myself immersed in the environment, captivated by the universe. The swarm technology is ideally suited for the Tyranids, although the animations are not flawless. When the Gaunts charge, there is a lack of variety that makes them appear less individualistic, but this aligns with their nature as hive mind-controlled entities.

Saber Interactive has excelled in creating a game that seamlessly fits within the 40k universe, appealing to long-time fans and newcomers alike. I eagerly anticipate what they will continue to bring to the table.

Thank you Saber Interactive from a Blood Angel painter and player.

This game is Phenomenal.

PROS;
- Full COOP Campaign and PVE Standalone Missions
- Massive customisation options which are unlockable through playing the PVP and PVE modes.
- Awesome Visuals and challenging gameplay at higher levels.
- The undying desire to protect those guardsmen as they're getting mauled by a huge swarm of nids.
- The tech from WWZ zombies has been brought into this game. Meaning the hordes will literally fill your screen and make you think "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, how am I going to do this"
- PVP isn't just reaction based, work as a team to win.
- The Imperial guards have been done justice, they feel how UNSC Marines felt in the earlier Halo games.

CONS
- No Widescreen support (this was outlined in the roadmap before release, though it should be included day 1)
- PVP can be a bit too punishing to start off with.
- Getting used to the menu system can be a pain at first (But it's nice it's all built into the hangar)

NOTES
Epic Services are installed to accomadate for cross-platform capabilities, The game is made with Unreal Engine.
The EULA exists, don't worry, they're not going to use it as an excuse to kill you like Disney.


SUMMARY
A game best enjoyed with friends at every level, though still an incredible game to experience alone. Space Marine 2 has done Warhammer 40000 and Space Marine 1 fans proud.

*at the time or review friends have mentioned multiple connectivity and crashing problems when joining other to play.

-It has taken me about 13 hours to beat the campaign even with repeating a few missions to play with a friend. The game ran a decently well for me with only 1 connectivity issue to note.
-The game was fairly enjoyable with gameplay loop being repetitive, but rather enjoyable for the duration.
-Environments and graphics were beautiful and really made the experience feel like a proper 40k game.
-Weapons sound effects were acceptably meaty, especially compared to the 1st game.
-Difficulty was pretty decent on normal for a first run
-Enemy Swarm mechanics are amazing to watch and throw explosives at.
-Story was merely acceptable, akin to the 1st game or another shooters campaign
-Coop missions, while i have not played any at this point, seem nicely weaved into the main story to make it feel like there are other teams out there making a real difference.
-Campaign is fully playable in coop, however it is missing modern quality of life features, such as collectible sharing on pickup and ammo, health, and grenade pickups being limited to whoever picks them up first.
-Overall an acceptable sequel to the 1st game
-Time to take a break and maybe look up how to make a proper paragraph.

Even as a newcomer to the Warhammer universe, I found myself irresistibly drawn into this game after just four hours. It effortlessly recaptures the magic of the PS2 and Xbox 360 era, combining a nostalgic vibe with electrifying action and satisfyingly brutal combat. The visuals are absolutely stunning, the gameplay is both straightforward and captivating, and the campaign delivers a premium experience that stands tall against other survival shooters like Left 4 Dead and Back 4 Blood. And I haven’t even touched the PvE (Co-Op) or PvP modes yet!

I’ll update this review as I explore further, but for now, it's a definite recommendation!

Update 1:

Having tackled the campaign on the Angel of Death difficulty, I must say the experience can be exasperating. The game’s extreme challenge often feels borderline unfair—enemies seem to have pinpoint accuracy, and defense missions inundate you with overwhelming hordes while your AI allies remain passive. While dialing down the difficulty may alleviate some of these frustrations, solo play on the highest setting can be incredibly grueling.

Update 2:

I recently completed the campaign in Co-Op mode, and it was a phenomenal experience! Despite my lack of familiarity with Warhammer lore, the game’s thrilling combat and grandiose interactions kept me thoroughly engaged. It felt like a nostalgic throwback to the golden age of 360-era co-op shooters, where teamwork and over-the-top action were the ultimate thrills.

Playing with friends is definitely the way to go. Although the game doesn’t adjust difficulty based on the number of players, managing a three-player team can be challenging due to some AI quirks. Despite this, the overall experience is a blast, and I highly recommend it for co-op fans!

Now I’m diving into the PvE operations—side missions that run parallel to Titus and his squad’s main storyline. While these missions often reuse maps with different objectives, the depth in the skill trees and class systems adds considerable replay value. Sure, optimizing your setup might will just be following online guides, the game remains engaging and enjoyable, making it well worth your time.

Final Update -

If you loved the Xbox 360/PS3 era of online co-op shooters, you owe it to yourself to grab this game—it’s essentially a revival of that classic style, now with a 2024 twist. It also boasts some of the best graphics to date, rivaling titles like Demon’s Souls (PS5) and Alan Wake 2. At $60, it might seem steep compared to the plethora of indie and roguelike games offering endless hours of gameplay, but the unique experience it provides is a rarity in today’s market. Don’t miss out on this gem!

I was halfway through the opening level of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2’s campaign, unloading bolt rifle rounds alongside my two squadmates, when I found myself smiling at just how good it feels to be back in this futuristic grimdark fray. It’s been over a decade since the original, but Space Marine 2 reinvigorates the squad-based shooter series with seeming ease. The environments are varied and breathtaking, the running-and-gunning feels great, and the sense of comradeship while fighting with your team, be they bots or friends, can be exhilarating. It may not break much new ground in its genre, but it didn’t need to for me to have a blast playing through its dozen-hour campaign.

Let’s get this out of the way early: The original Space Marine clearly took inspiration from Gears of War, and this sequel follows suit. It’s a squad-based shooter starring heavily armored dudes who growl their dialog while either shooting guns or revving Chainswords to ward off invading aliens. The similarities don’t bother me a bit (especially when one could make the case that Gears borrowed from Warhammer first). It’s been years since I’ve played a game that scratched that particular itch, and Space Marine 2 uses the rich lore of Warhammer 40k to carve out its own identity. That’s true in both the meaty campaign that can be played solo or co-op, as well as two additional modes that let you upgrade your weapons and customize your armor between rounds, which are meant to keep you coming back after the credits roll.

Its a pretty solid game and definitely worth it if you liked the original Space Marine. A lot of people are hate farming over ultrawide support(already announced that it's coming) and the optional epic connectivity for cross play.

While I will admit the game does use a good deal of power(CPU moreso than GPU from what I've seen on my end) its pretty optimized and sits comfortable at around 60fps even when huge swarms are on screen. I did have one crash when I was trying to close the game to go to work but haven't seen another since. I do have a pretty powerful computer(for transparency I have 3950x and 3080ti) so I cannot speak to performance on lower end computers.

As to the complaints about the campaign team-mate AI most of it is a skill issue on the players part. They aren't the best by no means but they get the job done, they shoot at enemies and will revive you if you go down. Overall the difficulty is pretty accurate to what the Warhammer world would entail and I've yet to see anything too cheesey happen.


TLDR: A bunch of fun and definitely worth it and as usual people are blowing things out of proportion either out of misunderstanding or a desire to farm engagement. I'll update this if anything major changes but it is a recommendation in my opinion.

If you're a huge 40k nerd like me, buy it. Otherwise, I'd wait for a sale. I've finished the campaign in ~8 hours which is less than I had been hoping for by quite a bit. Every mission except for one (rippers) was really great though. I was playing solo and the AI is really not very helpful with a lot of the bigger objective fights, but once I turned the difficulty down it became less of an issue, and it was more fun tearing though the 'nids that way anyway. On harder difficulties they really should've had you playing as a member of the Imperial Guard since that's more in line with the toughness level.

PvP is fun but weird. Frag grenades shouldn't kill a Space Marine from full health, and the overall TTK just feels off. Sometimes you die instantly, sometimes you get pounded and keep on fighting. At least one map also has way too much fog. Hopefully the balance will improve but, having played Saber's Evil Dead game quite a bit, I won't be holding my breath.

Operations is a stripped down 'tide type gamemode. It only allows one of each class, which means that if you want to use a specific primary weapon, you might be out of luck, and progression is several linear tracks. Each weapon has its own progression that unlocks better versions of the same gun. These require a resource you find by scouring each level for tiny little servo-skulls. These are incredibly easy to miss so if you don't get it and your weapons are already "mastered", you just wasted all that time. Add the fact that there are only 6 missions (I've seen some people say there are 8 but it only shows 6 for me), and it gets old real quick.

The customizations that are included are nice, but severely lacking. Especially for Heretic Astartes in PvP. They didn't even include every Legion! Things like patterns and emblems are way too sparse as well. Not nearly enough versions of skulls and the only options for pauldrons are solid patterns. Weirdly, one of the traitor Legions that they did include is the Iron Warriors, but NOT with their trademark chevron patterning. They're just a dull green-grey that's barely different from the Death Guard who are also missing their trademark mouth-gut. I have a feeling that most of these gaps were carved out as future paid DLC.

Hopefully they'll keep improving it and adding more content beyond the cosmetic-heavy road map but Saber has never been shy about pulling the plug on continued development, so we'll see.

My name is João, John in english. For many years I am single, and in true, I never had a girlfriend even though I had some "sorts" of relationships. My friends and family from time to time keep asking me when I will find a girl, specially my grandmother and aunt. I am 23 years old, 24 soon enough

I answered my grandmother by saying the following words: "In these dark times, there is only war, and the Emperor calls his followers and children to fight for our survival, our right to live and to also fight in his truly name". She didn't understand and said "João what are you talking about, you have diabetes you can't go to war".

"My honor is my duty" - I replied - "And my craft is to kill". She looked at me thinking I was joking, maybe even crazy, as my grandmother looked for earphones with me thinking about the possibility of me talking to my friends - how naive.

I gave up talking to the beautiful girl that lives nearby, because the flesh is weak. I gave up increasing my work hours because money is temporary and blinds the men. I gave up all my dreams because there is no world for me where the emperor is not in it, and therefore would be no dream to follow in such a place anyway. I even stopped masturbating since I must spend all my energies and fix all my thoughts for the Imperium and humanity's future alone.

Now, the tyranids are attacking and I must answer the call, my call.

A very beautiful masterpiece that reminds us what games could be if aimed for the target audience. Although the story is short, it was not lacking at all. The breathtaking environments, general feel of the battlefield you drop in, horde mechanics (if you have played World War Z you can guess what it means), rawness of combat combined with brutality in the animations and the lore you get to learn even though you do not fully grasp it (if you are not a fan) all come together nicely to present an enjoyable gameplay. Moreover the multiplayer part of the game is crafted very well. PvP modes are short so it feels refreshing to play multiple rounds back to back. The fact that, there can only be two of each class present in a match makes it very balanced as well since every class has their advantages and weaknesses. Personally it was also a good choice to get cosmetic upgrades as you win games which forces players to do their best if they want to progress their "fashion". When everything is considered this game deserves to be bought in full price.

Let me start with the cons (Played on release day)
- Audio glitches
- Occasional stutter (my Pc meets the recommended specs)
- Single player campaign was somewhat design for co-op play. Having to do "protect the objective" or crown control short range and long range enemy units with the help of the Ai feels odd at times. (playing on the second hardest difficulty)

All that said, I still recommend this game. The game play is solid, the world design is very faith full to warhammer 40k and the grimness of the entire thing is well represented. (Expecially if your a Tyranids fan).
Saying anything more would risk spoilers.

Posting review as a PC player who has only spent time with campaign and operations, as PvP does not interest me in the slightest for this game.

Overall, this is a very solid game. If you are very into the Warhammer 40K universe, or you are open to Co-Op/PvP gameplay, this game is worth MSRP. If you are only interested in the single-player campaign, I would wait for the game to go on sale for something at or under $40 US, as the length of the campaign is not worth MSRP prices. The game has its share of problems, but the enjoyable gameplay more than makes up for those faults. Steam currently has this game at an 80% positive rating, and I think that is a pretty fair assessment of where the game is in September of 2024. I do wish the game had more content (I don't count cosmetics as content) and polish at launch, but I will give credit in that this game's launch was better than most others, lately. All things considered, I do not regret purchasing at this time.

Pro's
- Looks great graphically
- Fun, well-paced combat
- Writing is very good, barely anything cringe and no IRL political agenda's being pushed
- Very good attention to detail in terms of Warhammer lore adherence, etc.
- Great atmosphere, about as immersive as a Warhammer 40K game has been, for me
- Nice diversity of weaponry and armor customization

Neutral's
- Controls are ok. Certain actions are made awkward by sub-optimal controls (i.e. scoping ranged weapons with mouse 3, weapon switching with v). Could be better, but could be worse. Controls are playable, but likely need manual adjusting to be good for most players.
- Number of graphical settings for PC is nice, though most have little to no impact on actual framerates, which is a possible indication that the game or the engine it runs on is not as optimized as it should be.
- Class balance probably needs some work. Certain classes such as Sniper start out weak, while others are effective all the way to lvl 25. Not bad enough to be a 'Con', but not good either.

Con's
- Mediocre framerate for my hardware (4090, 13900, M.2 SSD, latest drivers, etc.). Framerate, even on lowest graphical settings, usually sits in the 60's for me. Needs to be in the 80's to feel fully 'smooth' for high-motion shooters like this one. Needs work.
- Campaign is a bit on a short side, and there are only 6 missions available for Operations. Makes the game a bit shallow, in my humble opinion, and will likely not hold people's attention for a long time. Campaign replayability is low, so Operations is really all there is for end-game content.
- Needs an FoV slider. Just a few extra degrees on the FoV would make the game feel a lot better, for me. For a third-person shooter to not have this in 2024 is a bit absurd.
- Game installs Epic Games' API service on first launch. This should only happen if the player goes into the game settings and enables crossplay with EGS (if its not an option, it should be). And more importantly, the game should be thoroughly tested to work in all other areas fully, without this being installed, which has not been done.
- Getting this game to start up normally and make it to the main menu has been more of a headache than for any other game I have played this year. Sometimes the game starts up, sometimes it doesn't. There seems to be multiple bugs caused by things such as Steam Overlay, the EGS API service, and others, that make even getting to the main menu a frustrating and inconsistent experience.
- Possibly the worst Con for me, or the least excusable, is the matchmaking. The biggest problem is that matchmaking will commonly only find 1 other player for you to play with, and won't fill up the 3-man party. The developers MUST add a feature to expose your current party to the public matchmaker queue, so that you can always go into an Operation with a full 3-man. Its not a problem due to lack of players, it just doesn't work correctly in its current state. There are other problems as well. For example, the matchmaking should not add you to an in-progress party, when a member of that party is playing the class which you have selected. This is basic sense sort of ♥♥♥♥, and its clear that the matchmaking is basic in its execution and thoughtfulness, probably due to the devs having to cater to the lowest common denominator, being consoles. The devs can, and should do better on this.

Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 review:

The genre could be classified as a horde shooter game - feels like it's leaning very heavily towards this genre

I only played Space Marine the previous game for a few hours because I was put off by the rather sluggish movement.
I was hoping for Space Marine 2 to be different and a bit more fluid and my hopes were fulfilled.

I am not into Warhammer lore and I know very little so this review is focusing on the game itself and is ignoring WH40k lore-accuracy.

While the graphics are stunning, I prefer playing on low graphics as with every game (I would exchange low latency and crisp gameplay every time over good looking graphics and screentearing)

Be that was it may, I am now 57 hours in having a blast.

The game offers a albeit quite short (only 6 hours as of offical playtime) campaign, but the game feels more focused on the online aspect such as PVE and to a less extent PVP.
I will skip PVP completely in this review because I didn't buy it for PVP but mainly for the PVE mode.

Neither do I intend to play PVP nor have I bought this for PVP.

PVP just feels like a slug fest to me and that's about as far as my experience with PVP goes.



You have 4 difficulty levels in single player and in the online PVE mode which is called Operations
There are only 6 levels so far for operations, be prepared to run the same maps over and over to level your character.
There should be new maps coming with future updates and a 5th difficulty level as well.

Which brings us to our next point:


There are currently 6 characters in the game which each specialize in a different combat role.
From Tactical (scanner that reveals enemies), Heavy (lets bullets rain while tanking) to a Sniper (that can go invisible and conventiently aggro every enemy on your teammate - because that's how most people play Invis Ults apparently ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ )
There should be a class for everybody to find his most favorite playstyle.

As for the difficulty, some people say it's to easy (mostly those who use out of whack weapons such as Melta) or on the other side of the spectrum people who can't cope with the melee combat of the game.

Which ever spectrum you fall into know this the melee combat is a very interesting part of the game.
Mechanics such as dodge (apart from feeling satisfying to dodge a incoming attack at the last second you get a slomo sequence which let's the player land a free shot on a target) to parry (which is the more interesting part for me personally, because parry is where the skill ceiling is at) - perfect parry also gives you slomo sequences that are called Gun Shot - free shot on target) and executions (Doom style brutality executions - ripping arms, tearing heads and cracking skulls that sort of thing)

Now if that last sentence alone doesn't convince you that this game is blast to play let me make another point why you should consider this game.

A horde mode was promised to be released in the future which sounds like fun.

No details are known yet I am afraid - I don't know if this will be more leaning towards Operations Mode levels or just endless horde mode.

There are tons of options to customize your space marine for different legions - those customization options are limited to Online Modes (PVP and PVE).
As far as I am aware you can't play Singleplayer as a different legion other than Ultra Marines.

So with that said, let the emperor guide your chainsword toward your enemies annihilation

For the emperor! (or slaanesh, khorne, tzeentch, nurgle - whoever you worship)

First off, they really nailed the setting, atmosphere and general aesthetic of the 40k universe.

Overview
The campaign picks up where the last game left off, with a time jump of about 100 years into the future. The tutorial is used to bridge the gap between then and now, without explicitly telling you everything until the reveal at the end of the mission.

The campaign is good fun, and will take about 8-10 hours depending on how much you scrounge for loot and collectibles. It can be played fully alone, or in Coop with up to 3 players total.

The additional PvE MP/Coop content consists of several missions that tie into the campaign, and they all happen in parallell to your main story. Here you don't play as Titus, but can choose a class (armor type and gear) as well as customize your Space Marine quite a bit. You can paint individual armor parts, apply decals from various chapters, etc. This content is probably what the developers intend as the main time sink after clearing the campaign, and their road maps show additional missions on the horizon, as well as a horde mode.

The PvP content is not really that interesting to me, but it's there if you like that sort of thing. It has a bit of classic MP feel to it, and let's you play as traitor marines for the opposing side in various mission types.

In general, this game plays a bit like a cross between God of War/Doom/Darksiders. It's generally corridor based, with a few open areas in between. You are usually punished for playing too defensively if the enemy has ranged units, as the only way to recover shield without hiding behind cover is to perform executions and quickshots on stunned enemies.

The boss fights are usually testing your coordination and multitasking abilities, as they will force you to alternate between blocking, dodging and clearing adds while continuing to deal damage to the boss.

Ammo is scattered around, but with a full human player team it might be neccessary to swap weapons intermittently to avoid shortages.

While the story and exposition keeps you interested, the gameplay loop can get a bit stale if you don't play with friends and have a laugh on voice.
Ultrawide monitor support has been promised in a patch this month (September 24), but for now we play with black bars on the left and right...
No HDR support sadly, but the Nvidia overlay can apply RTX AI generated HDR as a filter, which looks pretty good if you tune it.
Some are locked behind a battlepass, but no gear/equipment as I understand it.

Get it if you enjoy the 40k setting and have a blast with the campaign. If you have friends to play coop with, you'll get some extra playtime out of the game.
Don't get it if you can't deal with the hybrid melee/ranged combat, which is a neccessity to survive.

TL/DR: Space Marine 2 is a great co-op 3rd person shooter/hack n slash that will be loved even more by fans of Space Marines and the 40k universe in general, 8/10.

The only thing I find to be wanting is the content; the entire campaign is great but the ''operations'' game mode really does need more meat on it's bones as 6 maps will get old fast, even with the combat being as fast, frantic and fun as it is. I'd also prefer it if the devs allowed players to choose whatever class they want to be rather than only allow 1 class per mission as it's quite annoying to be trying to get progression on one class only to be forced to play another. Customization is good, weapon choice is good and there's a class for everyone be it the versatile but generic tactical marine to the ranged focused heavy marine to the melee focused stalwart marine.

Hopefully the devs will keep expanding and refining Space Marine 2 into a larger, broader and meatier experience. I have hopes that Space Marine 3, if it ever happens, leans more into being your own marine within the Astartes, in a co-op setting, but with more varied co-op missions that incorporate procedural generation to some degree, I mean, if you took this game but crossed it with Helldivers 2, with you and your friends being part of a 3-4 man kill team from the Deathwatch chapter, rocking up to new planets and fighting any number of 40k factions for any number of reasons, this would be an easy, EASY 9.5/10 right off the bat, even with it's class system, 10/10 if they did away with the class system and just had the class abilities as wargear.
So, fingers crossed for the next iteration of the game being a more diverse experience. but as it stands, if you love 40k lore and the Adeptus Astartes, you will love this game. It's not perfect, but it is a good and true representation of the 40k universe and lore with solid gameplay.

Its a technical achievement to be proud of and truly a power fantasy simulator. I felt every moment and detail that was lovingly applied to this game.

Service: 1/10 Live-service will always be the worst way any game can be delivered because a game that can be taken from you and desupported is not a game you own, its one you rent on a lease.

Story: 6/10 This part is going to sound harsh, but thats just passionate opinion and wordiness speaking. I love the game, but it lacks a bit of daring. While not a bad thing, it is almost a direct, beat for beat retread of the original game and plays itself far too safely in the comfort of being both a retread and a power fantasy. There is true vision and the clear affection of careful hands on this game which makes it a little more disappointing that it doesn't dive deeper into it's characters or it's setting.
It over-archingly loses what has allowed the best Black Library novels to be so successful and that is the ability to paint a human face on the absolutely inhumane and unimaginable cruelty of the setting. A key part of that is bludgeoning its myriad characters with their own mortality and the visceral doom that pervades all things in the 41st Millennium.
At no point did I fear for these characters. At no point was I afraid that they would fail, because they never fell victim to the most human parts of space marine psychology. What makes 40k's child soldier post-humans so compelling *is* that they are elevated child soldiers with scars deeper than just flesh and bone destroyed by shamanistic surgeries; that they are Imperial heroes is itself an indictment of the Imperium. But they have so little to work against or see their brutalist ideals rebound off of. Threats are hardly threats because the game is an unfaltering power simulator. I think a greater balance could be found in delivery, in character and making you feel superhuman through the horrors you endure not just vivisect with a chainsword.
To this end the perpetual doom of the Imperium and this setting never really grace this game. The themes of endless sacrifice to a meaningless cause never really resonate, nor the futility of noble defiance. Theres never a sense of loss, or an emotional lingering made long enough for weight to settle in. Which is understandable, because very clearly this ontop of a sequel is a way to get your friends into the setting, not my wish for deeper story telling. Still, its a criticism nonetheless.


All this said; I had a great time! Titus, Chairon and Gadriel and Varrellus, Saarkana, The Brother Chaplain and all these other characters were little sprinkles of delight and I thank the Devs greatly for sharing them and even more for the absolute talent of every actor and voice actor.

8/10 Overall - I've more than got my moneys worth and Ill have more, I'm sure. Absolutely worth picking up and playing!

!NOTE THIS IS A SPOILER FREE REVIEW! if you played the first game SM2 plays similarly with a few additions here and there. Since there's three parts to the game at the time of writing its best to rate them individually

Campaign: Excellent set pieces, the maps have good variety. Combat mostly occurs in open arenas which often have multiple levels but ambush waves can occur on transit to said arenas. The story is decent enough with the presentation being A+ tier hitting on all the themes you'd expect from the Emperor's Finest, the game play however has large spikes in difficulty between normal to veteran with angel of death being nigh unplayable without extreme planning with a full squad as even mobs become bullet sponges with some basic enemies taking a full mag to down. In addition your AI companions arent the brightest bulbs in the closet having odd behaviors that need some ironing out but with playing with your mates resolves a lot of these issues.

Multiplayer Modes: Quick foreword, there's a distinct lack of QoL features within the modes ranging from friends lists to simply saving skins between mode swapping. You have been warned.

PvE: Unlocked after a few missions you run through the sidestories that occur during set campaign operations. Here you have access to the 6 classes which you are able to customize your looks and loadouts and spend tokens/exp earned to unlock new items and class perks. While mostly good there are some major balancing issues that Saber need to look into adjusting between weapons and classes but it works well for the 6 maps currently available.

PvP: Okay here's where things get a bit more negative. While fun at the time of launch there are only 3 MAPS! Additionally the balance between classes is hilariously bad with Vanguard and Sniper being auto picks and Bulwark not far behind. Its clear that PvP was on the low for priorities and it suffer for that. Between instant kills to spawn camping its really simple stuff that could be fixed if they payed more attention, hell if you look at the chaos skins they are just Tacticus primaris armor with spiky bits on. Cheaters are also a common occurrence and the game has only been out for a few days, which is expected but THERE'S NOT EVEN A REPORT FEATURE IMPLEMENTED! I'm hoping Saber irons this out because this mode will be dead within a month if they don't jump on it

Overall its a faithful if not rushed sequel to the original game, it can be played casually as a pick up game but the difficulty curve is harsh. If you're a 40k fan this is a must pickup otherwise I'd say give it a few patches for Saber to polish this gem up. 8/10

Not a fan of Warhammer, but this game is fun. It's just a shooter game with a relatively long, engaging story campaign, crazy enemy numbers, and lots of well-realized, fun mechanics to keep the combat fresh and fun.

I will say, however - this game is SIGNIFICANTLY better when in co-op. It is designed as a co-op experience first and foremost and the AI bots at your side when playing solo are... uninspiring in their performance. Highly recommended if you have a couple of friends to jump into it with, hesitant recommendation if you intend to play it totally solo.

This is one of the best Warhammer 40k games.

As an experience I can't fault it, as shown also by the amount of people who just RP casually while playing Operations.

From being called "Brother" to matching the party's chapter etc., you can tell a game has nailed the universe when people get invested.

The game doesn't try to bend Warhammer to be "slightly less Warhammer because someone might get offended." It also just tells the story it needs to tell straight to the point and without having a heart-to-heart talk every 5 minutes. You might or might not like the plot, but that's subjective. Having said that, the game doesn't try to be offensive either. It's just true to lore, no nonsense and just tries to be a fun game. Nothing more, nothing less.

The only politics you see are the ones sanctioned by Emperor within the Warhammer universe.

Combat wise the game requires practice and skill expression, and that's great, but some mechanics need some tuning.

Matchmaking is rather clunky at the moment, with parties disbanding when people with the same class are put in the same lobby (you can't have the same class in Operations). Picking a specific mission is not a guarantee that you will get to play it, as the leader of the lobby can change it in the Battle Barge. This game should take a page from the Mass Effect multiplayer's book, i.e., let people decide whether they are hosting or joining someone else. And also allow people see what others are playing before they get through several loading screens and can actually start playing.

There is a lot of stunlock here, and some enemies don't seem at all phased by your weapons in certain circumstances where they should. For example, when you land with your Assault, and there is an enemy that is mid animation, it should be interrupted and staggered. Instead they finish their animation and you get hit while landing without recourse. It doesn't matter that a flying human tank has just landed on them, with a thunder hammer to boot.

The reward for a perfect dodge is a counter shot. The gun shot locks you into an animation and zooms the camera really close to your character. Yet, you can get stunned out of that animation, which turns the reward for a perfect dodge into a punishment. If you are going to lock a player into such a long animation and obscure their view of the surroundings, you should make it so you can't get interrupted. It's a reward for dodging perfectly, which becomes meaningless if you can get punished.

There are other instances of this kind of mechanic where regardless of your size compared to the enemy's, regardless of momentum etc., the AI wins and you stumble around and can't react.

You use requisitions for almost everything, weapon unlocks, cosmetic unlocks and perks. I understand that you'll want to use requisitions for weapons. But their perks cost requisitions on top of the time spent leveling them or the data tokens you pick up in missions. If I am paying with time or the data token, why am I also spending requisitions? The same goes for the class perks. I am earning levels but I also need requisitions to unlock the talents.

The game is grindier than it needs to be with currencies that overlap in function.

Weapons need some balancing, as a lot of the bolters feel underwhelming, but I understand that balancing cannot be done easily within the first few days of launch, so I'll give the devs the benefit of the doubt here.

I know I spent most of the review talking about things I don't like, but the game has generally great moment-to-moment gameplay and, like I already said, great atmosphere. I still recommend it, but I just wanted to make people aware of some frustrations they might encounter. Space Marine 2 is not perfect but it certainly is, quite literally, a blast.

As a 40k player and fan for 25+ years, I will try to be as unbiased as i can about this game. That being said if you are a fan of 40k, this is a game to get.

So far I have only just finished the campaign and looking forward to the multiplayer side of it. Having played the first game back when it was originally released on PS4, and the PC port, this game is much better. The melee combat alone is an incredible improvement although getting the parrying and dodging down was a bit tough. What I thoroughly enjoyed about the game though is that this one actually FEELS like you are in the 40k universe and in an actual 40k battle (at least how I imagined my tabletop battles would go). From the small little side bar conversations to the scope of the buildings, I think they nailed it.

As far as the story goes, you can tell they didn't really rely on the roster of writers Games Workshop typically goes to, so just keep that in mind. This is not a Gav Thorpe or Dan Abnett level of story, which is OK I guess but yea they could have made it a bit more interesting.

If your not a 40k fan, still worth a play through if your a fan of hack and slash with a lot of shooting. It is also pretty challenging game on Veteran Mode.

Lastly, although the developers said you didn't need to play the first game to be able to understand the story of the second, I feel like that was not an honest statement. Sure, maybe you didn't need to play the first one to get the basic story (which is really just bad alien invasion, kill aliens, unleash another evil, and kill that evil while trying to convey a tale of battle brothers) but in order to actually know the overarching story and the bigger picture, you should absolutely play the first one.

I love Warhammer 40k, and despite being somewhat of a middle ground lore nerd, this game really embodies what we need more of in its gaming adaptations.

The campaign is somewhat longer if you play harder difficulties so your mileage will vary here, with my run on Veteran lasting around 10-12 hours, but length is not indicative of its quality. This is a pure power fantasy game through and through, and if you like older style brawler/beat'em up games, it feels like just the right amount of nostalgia with modern flair.

All base games cosmetics in Operations can be earned for free by playing the operations, with DLC being purely cosmetic packs for chapters and successor chapter heraldry, which nowadays is (VERY SADLY, it's downright depressing) not common. This mode also has an extensive skill tree for each class (which arguably some classes could be little stronger) but they mostly all feel very good to play in their respective roles.

I have not tried PvP yet myself but I've mostly only heard good things, just don't have an opinion myself here.

Overall this game is so worth it and a breath of fresh air in a gaming world where no one really respects your time or money. I wish it all the best and hope to see more content to keep this game going.

I'm going to give it a thumbs up solely for the campaign and how well it follows up from the first game while sticking fairly true to the characters.

Multiplayer as of the 9th of September just does not work. The load in time is literal minutes, i have the game on an SSD, and have great internet, so it is the games servers. Even if you do get into a squad, the load can freeze on another player, so theyll have to quit their game, then youre stuck waiting 5 minutes for their replacement to load in. Kinda sucks to pay extra to only be able to play the campaign a few days early.

Over all its basically more of the first game, but it looks nicer. The combat system is a little different, and it does work (the parry follow up shot never gets old) but I dont love the health system. I found myself multiple times hanging back waiting for my armor to regen, as, regardless of how careful you are, the swarms will chip your health away if you melee. Blocks dont really work unless the enemy has a blue bar, and you cant keep track of 30 enemies encircling you.

Because executions can now only be performed on large enemies or specifically stunned small enemies, and now ONLY heal armor, not health, you can die very quickly if you arent careful. I dont mind that, it makes it interesting, but the lack of healing makes the game play towards a more reserved, careful style. And that just isnt how I want to play as a 9 foot tall killing machine with a chainsaw. One of my favorite parts of the first was jumping into the biggest group of orks and cutting them all down. Youd be constantly taking damage but with the execution heals, you could pull it off with a little luck and a bit of skill. You "can" still do that here, its just a lot more luck based, or requires slowing the combat way down to stun small enemies.

The graphics look stunning. The game, of course, runs perfectly well on my 4090 with everything set to max. It does use the card substantially less than other modern releases, like Ghost of Tsushima. It also runs much cooler than those games do when under full load. So it seems very well optimized, and I presume it would run very well on older systems. I only had one instance of stutter and it was during a gigantic swarm.

The swarms are incredible and one of my favorite parts of the game. I saw a cinematic swarm in the distance, and took a pot shot at them for the heck of it. To my amazement, it actually connected. As it turns out, aside from a few in the extreme distance, each swarm, including many that you dont even interact with, are individual enemies. I assumed that the swarm fights were basically a spawner with a certain enemy kill count, and then they would all despawn. Nope. Theyre just a huge bunch of enemies, and the attack ends when you kill every last one of them. If youre fast enough, you can kill the swarm before it even climbs the wall. In smaller areas enemies will run past you through a vent or something, and they arent there for show. Those are real enemies, running to a choke point, that you can gun down before they make it there if youre quick enough. That helps make the world feel very alive, nothings really there as dressing. Theyre all things you can attack, because they exist in the game.

The AI is quite decent. I only had a team mate get stuck one time. They arent just there for show. They are so helpful in fights that I would rely on them, just like real human players. There were many battles I could not have survived without them. They fight, and fight hard. The enemy AI is lethal and surprisingly smart. I had two moments where I was watching an enemy group, deciding how I wanted to approach them. I assumed I was out of their agro range, as they hadnt moved for several seconds. Then one of them presumably *saw* me and alerted the others. I was not expecting anything more than simple agro circle enemies in this game. That was a pleasant surprise.

Aside from multiplayer, everything feels really good. They have great attention to detail, even down to the voices changing whether you put them in a helmet or not(if only they could be toggled for the cut scenes..) Cut scenes without controls are rare, unlike the first, even during elevator rides you have full control of your character. That helped me stay plugged into the game and limited frustration.

Over all, I would recommend it if you really liked the first, or like space marines in general. As someone whos never played the table top, but casually enjoys the stories and books of big armor guy go brr, theres a lot of cool lore moments and little secrets you can uncover.
The campaign is about 10 hours, and the broken co-op missions are only going to give you another 4 or so, if they ever fix it. At the moment, its pretty bare bones for $60, but most of the game that is there has a high level of polish, and its warhammer. This is certainly the 40k game I was hoping for, and I couldnt think of a better sequel for the first game. No character assassination, no politics, no messaging, no micro transactions, just chain sword. Very pleasantly surprised.

CAMPAIGN AND PVE MODE REVIEW
At its core, Space Marines 2 is a fast-paced third-person shooter with an emphasis on tactical combat and cooperative play. The gameplay is refined from its predecessor, featuring:

Combat Mechanics: The combat system is both fluid and engaging, blending cover-based shooting with dynamic movement. New weapon options and abilities offer a greater variety of tactical choices. The game’s arsenal includes everything from rapid-fire plasma rifles to heavy-hitting boltguns, and satisfying melee weapons that pack a punch (especially during executions).

Squad Dynamics: Teamwork is central to the gameplay, and Space Marines 2 introduces a more sophisticated squad management system. Players can now issue commands to AI teammates with greater precision, and cooperative multiplayer allows for seamless coordination with friends. The synergy between different squad roles, such as assault, support, and sniper, is crucial for success in the game’s more challenging missions. The operations are a blast!

Progression and Customization: The RPG elements have been expanded, offering a more intricate progression system. Players can level up their characters, unlock new skills, and equip various upgrades. The customization options are extensive, allowing for deep personalization of both the player’s marine and their equipment.

Graphics and Audio
Space Marines 2 boasts impressive graphics, utilizing the latest technology to deliver highly detailed textures, realistic lighting, and fluid animations. The game’s environments are visually striking, and the alien worlds are particularly noteworthy for their imaginative design and scale. The visual design of the Tyranids and the Chaos Space Marines are incredible.

The audio design complements the visuals with a high-quality soundscape. The soundtrack is epic and immersive, featuring a mix of orchestral and electronic elements that enhance the sense of grandeur. The voice acting is top-notch, with well-performed character dialogues and convincing enemy vocalizations that add depth to the narrative.


On my older PC sporting a 1080TI, Space Marines 2 performs admirably. Load times are quick, and the game maintains a steady frame rate even in the heat of battle. However, there have been some reports of minor bugs and glitches.


Six missions available with a nice range of difficulty. All feel like additions to the campaign. The missions can be done with bots or other players but offer a nice PvE loop for those than don't enjoy PvP but still want to customize their Space Marine.


Space Marines 2 succeeds in building upon the solid foundation of its predecessor, offering an engaging blend of tactical combat, cooperative gameplay, and rich storytelling. While the game does have a few minor technical issues, its overall experience is both thrilling and satisfying. Fans of the franchise will likely find much to enjoy, and newcomers will appreciate the game’s robust mechanics and captivating universe.

Space Marine 2 is a significant leap forward from its predecessor graphically. The environments are richly detailed and the grim and dystopian atmosphere of the game is especially noteworthy, creating a sense of immersion that aligns well with the 40k universe. The battles are extremely bloody and gory, which make the combat feel epic and desperate.

The gameplay revolves around a blending of 3rd person shooting and melee combat. This sequel adds new weapons, new abilities and new customization options. It also introduces a much more focused approach on multiplayer with its reward system for the Co-Op, PvE and PvP game modes. The replayability of the game consist of completing the game on higher difficulties, finding all the collectibles and hidden lore scattered throughout the game. Unique PvE missions can also be completed only through the online mode and a PvP mode is available for the more dedicated players.

Overall, the game is stunningly beautiful, improves upon the prequel and has engaging combat. The story is well written and is a worthy addition to the 40k universe. Whether you are a longtime fan or a newcomer, the game offers a gripping journey into the dark and war-torn future of Warhammer 40k.

Great game with solid action and impressive SFX (when they work). It runs smoothly on a 3080, though there is some slowdown during enemy-heavy sections. The campaign is a dream for 40k fans, feeling as if it's ripped straight from a novel. However, there are a few areas that could be improved:

Sound Mixing: In some areas, the sound is oddly mixed. For instance, there might be a huge battle in the distance while the immediate surroundings are silent. Hitting enemies in melee sometimes produces little to no sound, which feels strange. Additionally, your teammates' guns are nearly silent, which breaks immersion. The game itself? So far, it has been sublime. Melee combat has been greatly expanded upon since the first game, with parries and blocking making their way into the game. Shooting feels good and the bolters feel very satisfying to use, although I wish that the sound was a little lower in pitch. Would make it sound a lot more chunky, I think.

Fighting Tyranids is a lot more fun than fighting the Orks in the first game; fighting the bigger warriors first is actually beneficial this time around since, if a Tyranid Warrior falls, the Synaptic Shock will cause all the smaller buggers to die as well, which gives you another approach to dealing with enemies. You can wave clear like normal or engage the leader in a glorious melee duel.

The main bad thing about this game are the AI companions that kind of refuse to shoot at anything that is currently beating the hell out of you, which may get a little frustrating on higher difficulty missions, mainly with objectives that are more complicated than your standard 'kill enemies in area'. That's what the Co-op is for, though. The co-op is fun too, I've spent a great deal of time just customising my Bulwark.

PVP is very nice with a much lower TTK (Time to Kill) than one would expect. Gunfights are actually rather short and you cannot reasonably take on the entire enemy team alone without good positioning and the element of surprise. Whilst it IS 6v6 players, you cannot queue up with more than 3 players. If you have a fourth friend that wants to play with you, you're going to need to get very lucky with the matchmaking.

Game is fun! Is it the greatest game ever? No. Is it bad? Also no. If you like Warhammer 40k, you are probably going to love a lot about it. They absolutely nailed the 40k atmosphere and universe. Probably the most faithful 40k adaptation I have played to date. The environments are breathtaking, with beautiful set pieces. The voice acting is also great (although I find a lot of the space marines have similar sounding voices, so sometimes it's hard to tell who is talking).

The combat is fast and visceral, but it does kind of get old after a while. Once you've seen a handful of execution moves, you've seen 'em all lol. Sometimes when there are large swarms of enemies you can't even really tell what is going on and just kind of mash buttons and hope for the best. Some of the boss fights are also a bit tedious and tend to drag on. It can also get kind of clunky when you are trying to fluidly move from one combo or execution to the next, and the models kind of snap into place awkwardly, or environment stuff gets in the way, etc. I found the dodge and parry mechanics a bit cumbersome, but might just take more getting used to. I also find it weird how you can't execute enemies from behind, their model will just snap forward and do the scripted animation. Ah well, not the end of the world. The gunplay leaves a bit to be desired as well, which kind of sucks as 40k has some awesome guns, but it's not terrible by any means. Experimenting with the different weapons is a lot of fun, and there are plenty lying around.

Another mechanic I was not fond of is the health system. You can execute enemies to restore armour, but for health you need to rely on these little stimpack pick-ups, which are not super common. Sometimes I found myself just letting myself die so that my teammates would revive me and I'd go back to half health lol. I'm not really sure what I would want as an alternative, but I found myself sitting at low health a lot. Maybe I just need to get good lol.

The story / campaign was decent and engaging, but I found it very short. 8-9 hours and done. Hopefully they release another campaign or something down the road. Don't get me wrong tho, there are some truly epic moments in the campaign, especially toward the end. I won't spoil anything, but if you're a 40k fan, you'll probably c*m a lil bit lol.

I am just starting to get into the Co-Op and PVP stuff now, and so far it seems fun. I am not huge on multiplayer games, but it seems like I could maybe have some good times here. The class progression and weapon progression seems cool. Love the character customization (also LOVE how they included Chaos Space Marines / Heretic Astartes for the PVP). The matchmaking hasn't been the greatest, but I am told they are addressing that.

One final gripe: I play on a 1440p Ultra-Wide monitor, and at the time of writing this review, the game does NOT support ultra-wide resolutions, so there are big black bars on either side of the screen. Kind of a bummer, but it is on their official roadmap to address in September 2024, so shouldn't be that long of a wait. Still, kind of lame to not have it at launch.

Long-story-short, if you are a fan of 40k and/or enjoyed the first Space Marine game, you'll probably enjoy this. If you aren't familiar with 40k, some of the story and fluff might go over your head or just seem silly or over-the-stop to you, but I don't know what to tell you lol. It is obvious the makers of this game are big 40k fans, and made this game for fellow fans to enjoy. The actual gameplay mechanics leave a bit to be desired, some other games probably do it better, but I still enjoyed my time and had fun, which is what's it all about at the end of the day, right? Enjoy!

This is pure Warhammer 40k. Massive battle-scenes with lots of love and care for the lore. Lots of nods to different events and aspects of the lore every fan will appreciate. No forced woke bs either. This is a perfect WH40k game!

I guess folks who aren't into the lore yet, may have some difficulties understanding what's going on exactly though.

The main campaign is a good first 6-8, something like that hours spent. I liked it a lot. Story-wise and gameplay wise, towards the end though, it does start feeling a bit dull against the Tzeentchian forces.

So far I like the game, however, getting into the Operations, which is where the replayability is supposed to be coming from, I am starting to see a lot of future shortcomings for me personally.

What I would like to be improved:
1) Tzeentchian forces are boring to fight, Tyranids are a lot more fun to face. The Traitor Marines just stand still like damage sponges, shooting you, occasionally maybe teleporting 5 meters away from their previous position.
2) Tzeentchian forces in particular, the smaller daemons with shields, why the hell do I need to do a heavy to be able to get through their shield when I am like, 4 times their size? Its weird, because in the meantime, I can literally RUN THROUGH other enemy human forces. One makes me feel like a weakling, one makes me feel like a super soldier.
3) For the classes... We need big buffs. Give us better perks, more perks, good perks EARLY (not at level 21 or whatever) and also, more weapons to choose from.

I think its mad silly for me to be able to only have 1 sidearm on certain classes.
4) More executions, for in particular, Tzeentchian forces.
5) The Hammer and the knife melee weapons need some serious buffs, besides that, I feel like taking Cleave on the powersword over single target damage on the other mode/stance is always better. We need single target melee weapons to deal bigger damage against those single targets.
6) Armor should be stronger, easier to regain and should passively regenerate more quickly. I foresee a peeking simulator where I can't afford to go in at all, because I'm just going to take more damage than what I can regain, regardless of how good I am playing.

I don't just want to be negative, so here what I like so far:
1) Character customization.
2) Main campaign story.
3) The scenery.
4) Voice acting.
5) The Hive Tyrant operation and boss fight.
6) No abrupt crashes encountered.
7) No high ping or packet loss encountered.

Its just that I think this game is good enough for me right now, but has so much more potential than it currently has. It could be the best Co-Op game ever to me, if my mentioned shortcomings are just addressed.

Verdict: If you are a Warhammer 40,000 fan this is a must-have. I don't remember the last time I had so much fun with a game.

+ Positives +
+ Steam trading cards (3 drop, 5 to make a badge)
+ Steam achievements (50 achievements, grind, campaign, PvP and PvE)
+ The scenery is stunning. I must have spent a good 2 hours just looking around when I was playing the campaign
+ One of the best campaigns I have played in recent years
+ The campaign can be played as 3 man coop
+ Ability to replay any mission from the menu
+ Data slates with some lore as collectables
+ 6 Space Marine Classes (Tactical, Assault, Vanguard, Bulwark, Sniper and Heavy)
+ Classes feel quite different thanks to their available weapons, playstyle and ultimate abilities
+ PvP and PvE are both fun and well-cooked modes
+ Quite a lot of customisation and each armour piece can be customised individually
+ Soundtrack kicks ass
+ The community is full of Warhammer nerds and I love it

- Negatives -
- there was an early access period for higher tiers. Although it is an industry standard at this point, I quite hate it
- achievements are buggy (I had my total kill count reset twice by the game)
- for some reason the intro and outro stuttered on my PC, completely ruining the experience for me
- Quite a serious lack of multiplayer content
-- There are only 3 PvP maps
-- Only 3 PvP modes (2 are capture based, 1 is kill based)
-- The 6 PvE maps are not exactly enough for how much you need to grind
- There are quite a lot of bugs you can encounter (clipping textures, enemies going to space, etc.).
- p2p coop multiplayer is hell as always
- Basically no ability to customise Chaos space marines in PvP (besides colours)
-- also chaos is visually easy to tell apart, giving them a serious disadvantage in PvP

The long awaited sequel doesn't disappoint. I really enjoyed my time with the campaign (for the most part) and I look forward to getting started in the PvP and PvE modes. Combat has weight, your movement has weight, the Bolters sound and feel amazing. It really feels like you're firing dumbbells at your enemies. I played the game on Veteran (the 2nd hardest difficulty) assuming the game had difficulty achievements (it doesn't) and I will say, it was pretty obnoxious in some places lmao. For the most part, I enjoyed the more involved gameplay and challenge, but there is one constant source of frustration for me. Ranged enemies really don't feel *that* balanced and I really feel that a lot of damage is simply unavoidable. The game encourages you to prioritise melee combat as it keeps your health and shields flowing, and it just doesn't sit right with me when you're slashing away, parrying and using the super sick quick shot mechanic, just to have half your health disappear in the blink of an eye because a small group of ranged enemies set up out of your peripheral. I don't want this to come off as a "I picked hard and the game was hard, what gives?" but I would recommend playing through the campaign on normal for a better experience. This could come down to a skill issue from me, but the ranged enemies consistently annoying and kinda flipped the flow of gameplay in my opinion.

I don't often leave reviews. In fact I can't remember ever leaving one. But I feel in this case I really have to.

If you are a Warhammer fan or even just interested in the lore then this is an absolute must. Apart from perhaps the Total War series, this is the best Warhammer game ever released. You can absolutely tell that the developers are fans of the universe. Every detail in the game is relevant, the architecture, the armour, the weapons, the absurd 40k scale, the characters, the sound and the atmosphere. There are details in here that are obscure to all but the oldest nerds and it feels incredible to see the hobby brought together in such an incredible way. The care that the Devs have shown to capture all that makes Warhammer what it is is obvious.

And for those who don't care for the lore, its a fantastic game in it's own merits. The weapons are great and varied, the enemies are fun to fight, the classes are very distinct in terms of style. The swarm system means you can fight entire hordes and really engage that power fantasy. The customisation system could do with some areas of improvement but it is more in depth than most games which is only set to improve as more chapter cosmetics are released, which is the only area of monetisation in the game.

Is it perfect? No. The Campaign is short which isn't unexpected and the story isn't the next GOT but its perfectly fine as Warhammer stories go. The Operations variety is also a little low but this is due to be added to. The PvP is fun but likewise a little barebones, don't go into this expecting the next big PvP title. On the technical side I have heard of people having issues. But I can only report on my experience, which was a single server disconnect during the campaign. I didn't encounter any glitches of bugs visual or otherwise. Performance wise, on my above average set up at ultra setttings, it wasn't incredible but it consistently stayed above 60FPS which is what mattered, at least to me personally.

The two only true area's of criticism are the difficulty and dodgy matchmaking. Sometimes the game seems to lock and you can't find a group until you restart the game. And when you do find one, they can often have someone with the same class which is frustrating as each player class has to be different. If you are set on playing that class you then have to leave and find a new one.

And with difficulty, game scales damage and enemy health poorly and the armour/temporary health means that on high difficulties, winning operations is absurdly difficult. And not 'Elden Ring fun difficult' but frustrating difficult, an issue that is exasperated by stun locks and animation locks that often see's your entire heath bar vanish with no way to get it back beyond screwing your teammates by hoarding ineffective stims.

But what is great is that these are easily fixable problems. If you are the kind of gamer that refuses to play anything less than the most perfectly optimised game, you'll have to wait. But I can honestly say this is the smoothest launch (on a major title) I have experienced in a long time and if you're even remotely interested in this kind of game or Warhammer in general, I can absolutely recommend it.

Worth the 13 year wait. The game that got me into 40K finally gets its much deserved sequel. So many great moments to count, and I won't spoil any. If you're a fan of the setting and the genre, pick it up asap!

[EDIT] Original review was a meme written after a few hours of playing, so this is updating it to correctly reflect how much I enjoyed the relatively short (but sweet) story. Coming from playing Spacemarine 1 all those years ago, it absolutely smashed my expectations out of the water, it was the same experience but coated with heaps of spicy gameplay and tasty visuals, seasoned to perfection.
There is nothing to hate, you can very well be a pedant and insist that that plot-armoured hulks saving mankind by chasing a bunch of bugs isn't exactly fuel for a complex narrative, but who cares, just let yourself enjoy it, you can literally rip the head off a bug twice the size of you and better yet, you can do it in campaign co-op with friends.

This has also been one of the very few times I've actually gone out of my way to use the photo mode, the game is STUNNING, and I say this entirely from the perspective of a 3D Environment Designer, so it's normally typical that I overlook the visuals to favour level design, but not this time. Oh lord, the amount of times I just stopped to watch ensuing battles in the near distance, or gawped at structures falling apart for no other reason than it looking cool.

The combat takes a little getting used to, but after getting into the rhythm of it it's super gratifying to chain attacks between targets, turning bugs into a fine mist as the bolter lets off a hefty noise every single time you fire. The mission objectives aren't greatly involved, but they are nestled in with enough entertaining story-telling and pretty environments that I just couldn't put the game down, anticipating the next gorgeous location for Titus to get into a pickle at.

If you're genuinely a stickler for good lore, I only know it at a surface level so it perfectly appeased me, it has nice links to various factions, and it of course insists on pushing the Ultramarines and Cadians because they're the fan favourites, but it doesn't go deeper than that... And that's fine! I honestly didn't need any more from a third person shooter. The experience you're getting isn't a deep RPG storyline or novel tier narrative, it's just an excuse to cut loose and shoot some bad guys and feel unstoppable while doing it!

tl;dr game is very good, darktide walked so Spacemarine 2 could run, minor issues with booting the game up initially solved by using the alternative .exe in the game files, otherwise the game runs silky smooth even on my fire hazard of a laptop, gameplay is satisfying and I get to see my beloved titus again <3

My no spoiler review mostly based on Multiplayer so far:

There's no premium currency in this game. All in-game cosmetics are earnable and free outside of the DLC ones they're going to be releasing

Maps are symmetrical and well-balanced for PvP; there's a definite niche each class fills that never fully overlaps one another.

My first issue is the servers and disconnecting frequently, though since SM2's first maintenance a day ago, these online disconnects went from being EXTREMELY frequent, to being rare but still noticeable.

Some abilities feel that they need work on balancing, but at times it also feels like this is a player or team issue. Example:


Another example:


Let me say that the game is NOT particularly imbalanced. In the times we've had to deal with enemy Sniper cloak, we were able to adapt to their tactics, using Bulwarks to take the first shot and detect them. Vanguards though, their grapple is nearly inescapable and almost impossible to survive if they start zipping to you. Vanguards don't need to engage in melee, but a good melee Vanguard can beat a Bulwark because of guaranteed stun.

Aside from me ranting about the class, the game is surprisingly well-optimized. The gameplay is reminiscent of Space Marine 1, though you will quickly see how different it is. Current cosmetics in the game are free and entirely earnable through playing BOTH PVP (Eternal War) and PVE (Operations), in-case you prefer a more casual and fun of playing the game.

This game is amazing, hasn't changed or deviated much from SM1's achievement system, and you don't have to worry too much about game balancing issues. Story mode is great, and you unlock more Operations the further into the story mode you are. Currently there are 6, but there will be more PvE content. Can't wait for the future of SM2!

Let me preface by saying this, if you are new to 40k or don't understand the lore at all; you don't need to in order to enjoy the game. The game does a fine enough job to explain what is going on, you'll only miss out on a few in-jokes and references. Also, if you're expecting a stellar or seriously in depth story than you're looking at the wrong store page; this game is peak 2008-2012 mindless fun in the same vane as Gears of War or the OG CODS.
Which is really all you need to know in terms of the game-play, it's super fun, simple and easy to understand; if all you care about is the game-play than just know it's the best part of the game.

The story is serviceable at best and if you're not a huge lore head I can see how alot of the stuff that happens late game will be lost on you, but if you have even a basic understanding this ♥♥♥♥ is some of the coolest and most outrageous ♥♥♥♥ possible in a 40k game. Honestly that's all there is too it from the campaign side, it's there to introduce the world of 40k and Space Marines and it's a fun mindless romp you can play through at your own speed.

The online operations is where the game truly shines, the customization level of your own Space Marine is insane, you have a huge array of different perks, weapons, equipment and classes that you can play with to your hearts content. The cosmetic customization of your Space Marine is insane, you can color basically any part of your armor in whatever color you want(as long as you unlock the color first however), if you wanna make your Space Marine a hodge podge of every color in the rainbow you can and then some; and if you're a lore head there's a good chance your super obscure Successor Chapter nobody knows or plays besides you is in the game as well.

The level of detail this game has makes it very clear that this was made by fans of Warhammer 40,000 for fans of Warhammer 40,000, every little detail you'd think they'd overlook, they didn't.

If you're a fan of 40k you've probably already bought the game, but if not than know that this game is 100% faithful and shows the proper respect to the IP you'd hope for.

Ah, Space Marine 2, a game worthy of the the Primarch’s embrace. The first taste of its brutality hits like a bolt of lightning in the dark—swift, merciless, and glorious. As one who revels in the screams of the weak, I must say this offering does not disappoint. The visceral beauty of cleaving through the enemy, the symphony of destruction wrought by the Adeptus Astartes is intoxicating.

The graphics—sharp as a freshly honed blade—make every kill a work of art, every spray of blood a brushstroke on a canvas of chaos. The attention to detail is exquisite; from the crackle of power armor to the haunting shadows that cling to every corner of the battlefield, it immerses you in the darkness, the brutality, and even at times, in the fear. Ah, yes, the fear. One can almost taste it.

The combat? A delightful storm of rage and precision. Every strike feels as if you hold death itself in your hands. They’ve captured the sensation perfectly—brutal, unrelenting, and oh, so satisfying. You are a weapon, an instrument of war. And how sweet it is to unleash that power upon the hordes, to crush them beneath your heel like the scum they are. Whether tearing through xenos filth or obliterating the pathetic wretches known as the Thousand Sons, each battle is an opportunity to revel in their demise.

In short, if you crave destruction, if you hunger for the thrill of battle, this is your feast. Space Marine 2 is a masterpiece of carnage, a hymn to the carnage that resides in us all. The Imperium's 'finest' are here to deliver death—swift, brutal, and without mercy.

This is a game for which the yes/no review scale really doesn't work well.

I played through the campaign in around 8.5 hours. It's not all that long, but I don't mind that. What I do mind is that I was quite bored by the end of it. The combat system feels good at first, but never develops or progresses, so it ends up quite shallow. Enemy variety is pitiful, making combat even more repetitive. Guns feel weedy. This may be to push players into more melee combat, but it still feels out of keeping with the setting.

The story moves along at a decent clip. There are some decent set-pieces and the character beats, while somewhat repeated from the first game, basically work. It's not the most sophisticated take on the WH40K universe. It's basically "OOH RAH SPACE MARINES", which would be disappointing at the best of times, but feels a bit sinister with a Russian developer. Your regularly scheduled reminder - the Imperium are not the good guys.

Visually, it does the minimum necessary. There visual design has a few good moments, but it's weird for a major 2024 release to have no ray tracing and be 100% rasterisation. The lighting looks flat and artificial throughout.

I didn't dislike the game, but it's nothing special. It's a short, shallow corridor shooter with some decent WH40K trappings. I've given it the thumbs up because it is very slightly more good than bad, but overall... wait for a sale.

PREVIOUS NEGATIVE REVIEW BELOW:

Unfortunately, as much as I love the game and the universe I cannot recommend this in this state. And feel like Early Access from preordering is another word for free QA.

The game idea is great, and the multiplayer is great...when they both work.

At the time of writing this I have messed about with a few of the lower end difficulties, and even then I'm finding completing certain tasks impossible.

A single player mission is insane to complete when it seems to be built with co-op in mind. And with the operations, with other players the difficulty curve on Easy difficulty is strange. I feel the focus on gaining armour and such from combat doesn't always seem to work. Or you get stun locked when you fail one of the parries, losing most armour and health without coming out of the stun. Again, this was on the easiest difficulty. Some enemies are a pain to fight, either attacks that are poorly telegraphed or attacks that you seemingly have no defence or hope to avoid.

And then there's the technical aspect, which is mostly bugs. I've had cosmetic issues, with certain customisation constantly failing on multiplayer. And texture pop-in, with the latter being understandable. But then there are game breaking bugs that have caused me to have to stop progress and restart the game. Or have to alt + F4.

The main two that come to mind are:

Audio bugs, where the sound will either not play certain aspects or cut out altogether and requires a full restart of the game.

Multiplayer loading, getting stuck on the Joining Server screen infinitely and having to kill the game process. The fact that it has to Join Server just to get to the main menu if you want to play single player can really affect this last bug.

So again, unfortunately whilst it seems like a great game, with the strange gameplay decisions and the bugs that often ruining experience, I cannot recommend.
