Loving the game and the visceral combat, but I have one very important question for you Saber.

WHAT THE HELL DID YOU DO TO MY FLAMER?!

IT'S SO WORTHLESSLY IMPOTENT IT STRUGGLES TO KILL THE PUNIEST TERMAGANT!

I MUST BURN THE HERETICS AND THE XENOS IN THE RIGHTEOUS FLAMES OF THE EMPEROR'S LIGHT, AND THIS...THING...WOULDN'T EVEN BE CAPABLE OF WARMING UP A CAN OF CORPSE STARCH!

As 40k and Tyranid fan this game was a must buy for me. I am a bit sad that the Single Player campaign is only about 10 hours long. Probably shorter, as i was taking the scenic route, gawking at scenery and whatnot.

The game looks the part, but I am not sure I agree with it feeling the part. The Bots you play with are terrible. They are sluggish to perform orders like “Engage/Defend (Area)” or simple Targeted Commands that they should focus on a special. Even when they move to the place, they tend to forget their order at the first opportunity.

This has made some of the missions very difficult to deal with. When I started the game I started it in Veteran Difficulty, because the game said this was the intended difficulty. Which is information I like, when they tell you which gamemode it is balanced around.

And while i had no real trouble, i mean i died once or twice in the Tutorial, but that was fine… when i got to the end event of the first mission where i had to defend 4 objectives, while dealing with a bunch of horde and specials… I ran into the problem that the Bots were useless. Having to do everything myself. Even when I gave them orders to Defend the objectives, they would only go to defend the objective when no enemy was nearby. And so i kept failing the mission over and over again… even when i could defend the objectives, it was the specials that killed me, as i had to eschew my own survival in order to clear the objectives in time… and all because my Bot-Mates would rather pummel a Gant than shoot at one of the Specials or engage them in any meaningful way, despite me ordering them to do so, by marking the enemy.

So I had to drop down to “Normal”... Normal on the other hand is way too easy. Even though you have to do everything yourself. I feel like Veteran is probably the difficulty to play with a Co-Op buddy.

The Story wasn’t good. It wasn’t really bad either, but it definitely wasn’t good. The Dev knew I wouldn't care, and thus didn’t put any effort in. I mean, I would have cared if they had cared, but they really didn’t.

I haven’t played the Co-Op content, so I am not sure what the Operations are like, but the PvP is fun. Seems more stable than it was in the first game. But of course, you are locked out of higher level gear until you played a lot and it makes a lot of difference. I’ve ran into people that threw their Thunderhammers around with their Jump Packs… and I expect the old Meltagun Meta to make a return as well.

There also seem to be only 3 PvP maps. Admittedly i was jumping around at first, but after a little over 2 hours of PvP games, i only seens 3 maps. Gamemodes are okay.. The abilities don’t feel overpowered, just deadly in the right circumstances. Locking gear behind player levels is a bad idea tho.

Overall i am giving this a 7 out of 10 on the arbitrary review scale and recommend it being picked up on a sale. If you have friends to play Co-Op with or want some PvP content, that isn’t as good as Eternal Crusade was, then paying full price is fine, but for a single player experience, wait for a sale.

I can absolutely say this game lives up to being a phenomenal sequel to the original Space Marine game. Even as I am writing this I am continuing my campaign against the Tyranid threat. Saber Interactive have truly put together something to be proud of, you can tell with the world building and the discrete details in the environmental storytelling that you are not in this fight alone. It truly feels like the Imperium of Man is attempting to hold the line. Walking past the brutalised and dismembered corpses of your fellow brothers and guardsmen alike as hordes of Tyranids breach defensive lines and push further into friendly territory gets you exhilarated as you partake in such a desperate struggle to defend the planets. If you are like me you will rush to the aid of the guardsmen serving with you in a hopeless, but nevertheless needed, rescue attempt.

I truly believe that if you were considering this game, give it a shot. This will be one to remember.

I do see a lot of individuals are reporting crashes and optimisations issues or EOS issues which are understandable. However, EOS is for the cross platform play and the individuals experiencing some issues with the EULA please look up pirate software, he gives a great explanation on the subject. Unfortunately if you read the EULA of all of the your favourite multiplayer games, they will be very similar.

The EOS issue is the only real problem and unfortunately as time goes on some older computer parts may no longer be up to snuff to play the game on High or ultra quality. So before complaining about optimisation don't forget to configure your own system to play smoothly. However give the game time. As it stands I believe this is still one of the smoothest launches of 2024.

The only downside I have found to this game is the AI controlled space marines that run as your squad mates. They unfortunately do not always perform the best, however I understand these are also here to allow your friends to join you in Coop which in itself is truly amazing.

Overall the 40k world is a brutal mistress and playing this feels true to its lore. This is not a story of sunshine and rainbows but one of death, fire and brimstone. The Emperor protects.

As someone who has been eagerly waiting years for a proper Warhammer 40K game with space marines. When I learned that they were going to make a sequel to Space Marine, I was a bit worried as much as I was excited.

Space Marine 1 had many faults and a sequel released in 2024 would have much to live up to.

And I can happily say that WH40K: Space Marine 2, not only met but exceeded every expectation I had.

A lot of people are mad about the clunky gameplay, and while that is a complaint. Its not so bad that it ruins the gameplay. It is also worth noting that you are a 8 foot tall man in a suit of insanely heavy armor, moving is hard, I MEAN DO YOU SEE THOSE KNEE JOINTS? THERE CLIPPING MOST OF THE TIME! Anyway as someone who has hard times enjoying single player games, I genuinely enjoyed this game and played through the 12-16 hour campaign in one day.

Which is a good seg-way to reviewing the story! The story was clearly made with a lot of love and care behind it, making references from space marine 1 while being completely original in its own right. For the general audience of gaming it may seem like a bland story, very linear. And easily forgettable, but to us Warhammer 40K fans this is a masterpiece. The mentions of the last game, the Tyronids, the Chaos marines, fighting with a dread-knought even just for a little. This is exactly what we have wanted for years, a full realization of space marines in a video game that has multiplayer and you can play with friends in both campaign and in matches.

Lets talk about multiplayer now. Its okay... The clunky slow responsive mechanics are okay in the campaign but in the multiplayer, the issues with it really come out. I cannot exactly describe the issue, its more something I recommend you experience for yourself. Other then that the lag and rubber-banding is good enough, it is playable and even fun, but sadly if you are new and near the point of initial release you may encounter a level 13 in your level 1 game.

The graphics... The graphics are amazing, nothing more needs to be said here. Some levels need more optimization then others, especially in the later half, however I will survive with 30 fps.

Weapon balancing... During the campaign the weapon balance is pretty good, Personally I would make changes like increasing range and damage on flamer and melta, a faster firing speed for the plasma rifle and more ammo overall, especially for the lascannon. But that is it, most if not all weapons are decently fairly balanced and I cannot complain too much.

A lot of game studios think open world or bigger is better ideals for games are better, and its also true the audience has gotten tired of linear shooters over the years. But I am happy this is a small linear hack and slash shooter. This game and the DOOM games are proof that Linear games simply haven't lost their edges. They are still needed and still relevant, its just greedy companies taking the passion out of the developers that's really killing these kinds of games.

Either way, I give this game a 9/10 and I really hope they make updates and events or even add DLC that add more story. Cause before this game I was not invested in Titus... But now I am, and I kinda need more of the brother.

Anyway hopefully you found this helpful!

Pity the guardsmen



A weak sack of flesh destined to die for a dead god that never cared, it spends its pitiful, brief life, alone in his foxhole with nothing to keep him company, or to keep him safe, than the cheapest, most disposable of equipment. Perhaps the glow from his lasgun barrel keeps him warm at night.



Me? As a servant of the powers I enjoy the delights of all this world and the warp has to offer. Power, it courses through my veins. The gifts of the chaos gods will soon overtake me, and one day I may even ascend. What has the guardsman to look forward to but a grim life, and if he is lucky perhaps he will feel nothing as my axe sends his soul to Khorne.



He lives for a corpse god, and he shall join his god, as a corpse. I shall spare a half second to think of him and his kind. Then i shall only laugh. Hail Chaos!

You would laugh monster, But let me remind you.

Within that weak sack of meat and bone, uncared for by his god and wept for by none, beats a heart. A human heart, that carries with it the strength and courage of all mankind. Within that sack of meat is ensconced the hope, the will, and the fury of every man woman and child from every corner of the Imperium. Within that weak sack of meat, festooned in thin armour and weapons only powerful in numbers, beats the heart of a man. And for ten thousand years, the hearts of men have beaten, strongly, in defiance of your so called "powers". For ten thousand years, the hearts of men have stood united against a galaxy that despises them for no reason save that they had the audacity not to lay down and die. For then thousand years, your black crusades have been pushed back, beaten down and made a mockery of, by weak sacks of flesh with cheap weapons and disposable equipment.



For that weak sack of flesh that you so gleefully mock is no super soldier, no immortal warrior, no creature cursed by chaos like you. He is a man, an imperial guardsmen drawn from some forgotten corner of the Imperium to fight for his species and for the safety of the people he loves. He is a factory worker, a farmer, a storekeeper, a father, a brother, a son, a mere man. And against creatures like you, teeming and numberless, powered by the very will of thirsting gods......... He holds the line. He has held the line for ten thousand Years.



So whats your excuse, monster?

It's an amazing game. Definitely recommend it, BUT:
HOLY SMOKES the AI is so UTTERLY worthless and plain ♥♥♥♥, the devs would have been better off reducing enemy army size ba a third for every slot not filled with a player.

Let me be clear devs: Your AI is so worthless, I'd rather not play the campaign on high difficulty without my friends online. Co-op is similar, the AI is so utterly ♥♥♥♥ and useless, playing anything above easy with 2 players and one AI companion is like playing with 1.5 players, because one has to make up for the complete lack of everything the AI is SUPPOSED to provide. It is an insult to the word "Bot".

Everything else is pretty friggin great, though. The guns all have their uses, despite my personal absolute disdain for the the basic Bolt Pistol. They all sound heavy, they all sound like the pack some serious firepower. Melee sounds heavy and appropriately metal-y, too. A lot of the stuff you would expect from Warhammer 40k is in here, lots of heretics, lots of blind fanaticism and faith, an unhealthy amount of reliance on the machine spirit, Marines and Mechanicus not exactly being the fondest of one another in most careses. Oh, and evne more heretics and herecy to stamp out. Great for someone that has absolutely no idea about the lore, and probably even better for someone who actually knows parts of the lore!

Visuals are equally great. The detail may be a bit offover long distances, and the game definitely excells when you're in the thick of the melee, but in general, it holds up REALLY well, and it runs amazing, too! No DLSS requires to make up for the lack of optimization or the publisher rushing things through. DLSS still helps, mind you, but it definitely runs really well!

Now, the controls. ooof, the controls. The basic keybindings may make sense on a console, but whoever set the standard keybindings for PC either simply DOESN'T play on a PC, or has a third arm and hand. I had to rebind about 50% of the basic keybinds for them to even make sense, and even THEN I wish I could set bindings per class (in multiplayer) and game mode. Also, the game has non-optional input queueing. An option only absolute idiots put in their game.

I don't walkt to talk much about the story, since spoiler and all that, but the story actually explains why the co-op exists, and that's neat!

Overall, around a 7/10. It would have been an 8/10 if the AI wasn't hot garbage. I'd rather face 2/3 less enemies in the campaign and not have these two bozos tagging along. I give this game a 7/10 for a few specific reasons.

But first, a disclaimer:
I wrote this review after approximately 20 hours of playing this game. I wrote it specifically from a beginner's perspective.
At the time of writing this review, I have played the campaign on level 2 difficulty and am currently playing the co-op PVE mode.
I've yet to touch the PVP modes.
This is based on my experience from before the patch on the 11th of September.
Also there's negligible wokeness in this game, and it's ignoreable.

-1 point because no game is ever perfect.

-0.5 points because there is potential for them to do more that is not realized and it's a damned shame.

-0.5 point because of a multitude of minor design oversights that on their own aren't meaningful but they all stack up to create a bit of a problem.
I will elaborate further below.

-0.5 points because of technical issues on release which could have been resolved if they just had more public tests and took a bit more time to iron these kinks out.
I've experienced a couple of unexplainable disconnection errors over the course of the first few hours of playing the online co-op mode as well as one CTD.
That being said, these incidents of technical issues have been relatively far and few between.
But the technical state on release is overall very acceptable.

-0.5 points for some of the story tropes - some of them seem bizarre and there's one that does not fit in the lore of Warhammer 40,000.
One character in the campaign behaves in a way that is far from typical for the culture of his military unit.
Also there's this one girlboss character that I was glad is not present for most of the campaign. She should've been made as a male character instead, judging by her rather masculine appearance and behavior.
Lieutenant Mira from the first Space Marine game was spot on though, I really liked her.
Compared to Mira, this character who is her equivalent in Space Marine 2 is simply boring.

As for the gameplay design oversights:
It's an amalgamation of very minor things such as maneuvers, animations, delays and various nuances of gameplay that both players and enemy NPCs have, as well as weapon balance and its own subtle nuances.

Simply put, the balance of combat feels very frustrating for a beginner. It goes beyond needing some getting-used-to and player skill.

The enemies' set of combat maneuvers applies extreme pressure on individual players.
Player teams that split their attention - which happens far more often than not in horde shooters like Space Marine 2 - can find themselves vastly overwhelmed, and this can cost rookie players the mission in a way that feels a bit more than frustrating.

It feels like the current state of Helldivers 2 (before the balance overhaul on the 17th of September), to be quite honest. I just feel like the game hates me for whatever reason that it won't reveal.

Tyranid enemies with ranged weapons have the ability to knock a player over and interrupt those players in the middle of fighting a horde at melee range.

On top of that, Tyranid warriors (the medium-size enemies) often knock over players with their sword strikes, contributing further to the inability for players to do anything for several seconds at a time.

This combination means that enemy units that have ranged weapons are far more than just an annoyance: their knocking effect can result in a stunlock.

And remember that this is a horde shooter, you're not dealing with just 1 or 2 of each type. Oftentimes there are 4 or 5 of each of them that you have to deal with while your teammates are off fighting another swarm that's just the same or worse.

TL;DR = THE STUN LOCK IS REAL, EVADE EVADE EVADE EVADE EVADE

All of this is aside from the sluggish and slow reactions of the soldiers that players control which give this game a feeling of mild slowness.
Striking enemies with melee weapons feels somewhat underwhelming as well, as it takes more than one strike with the medium-sized melee weapon types like the sword-chainsaw against the small fodder enemies (which, if you ask me, really should be beat by a single swing - the small fodder enemies in Space Marine 1 were beat in one swing, so why not in SM2?).
(notice I said types.)

And the last point I want to make is the unlocking of cosmetic items.
WHY DO I NEED TO UNLOCK STUFF I DON'T WANT JUST FOR THAT ONE COLOR THAT I DO WANT?
I only want one color, I DO NOT want the entire pack of emblems and colors. Let me unlock only the one color I want. (for example: Golden Griffon in the Night Lords unlocks under the Heretic legions tab)

These are the negatives I found so far in 24 hours of playing, and I don't believe there's much else in the negative side of the game.

Overall the game is very good.

The campaign has many epic and cool moments that real men with more than a drop of testosterone will enjoy a lot.

Classes feel like meaningful choices that have more to do with your preferred playstyle rather than being better or worse than others.

Despite the necessity for more tuning, the combat balance does feel like a lot of thought and fine-tuning went into it. It's just ALMOST where it should be, in my opinion.

And as stated above, technical issues have been few and far between, so this game is on the better side of matters of technical stability.
My 6-years-old, poorly-maintained PC with i7-8700, 16 GiB RAM and RTX 2070 produces around 20 FPS in the busiest sections. It is holding, but only just. (Maybe I should request that my Magos perform the rites of restoration to appease the machine spirit, then it may produce higher framerates)

This game is good fun and I recommend it to everyone who enjoys a good souls-lite 3rd person horde shooter.

Warhammer 40k Space Marine 2 is essentially an oldschool game with modern graphics. This is especially true for its multiplayer mode where the underlying mechanics are quite simple but fun. It oddly reminds me of Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy's multiplayer mode.

The campaign is relatively short but decent; the operations mode seems like a cool idea to extend the campaign experience by putting the player in the shoes of Titus' subordinates who operate in parallel with Titus' own squad. Perhaps oddly, I have found the multiplayer mode to be the most engaging one out of these three even though it seems more like an afterthought in comparison. I hope that they expand upon the existing content with new maps and new modes, perhaps containing AI swarms that are hostile to both teams, like in the campaign.

While it is generally good that it feels like an oldschool game, the game also inherits the pitfalls and annoyances of oldschool games such as unnecessarily many and long loading screens and lack of various quality-of-life features.

Overall, it is a very solid game worth trying out for fans of oldschool games. Their published roadmap seems somewhat shallow; I hope add even more content in the future. Additionally, I also hope to see DLSS 3 Frame Generation implemented as soon as possible given how severely CPU-intensive the game is. Of course, proper engine optimizations would be preferable but I'll take frame generation over nothing. Lastly, I'd also like to see them implement NIS sharpening to combat blur introduced by DLSS/DLAA.

When a game is as hyped up and anticipated as this game was, it is very hard to live up to said hype. I can wholeheartedly say that it tickles every inch of my 40k nerd brain. The story, while not a masterstroke in narrative design, is exactly what it needed to be for a Space Marine story. It took me roughly 9-10 hours playing on normal, while doing a bit of dense exploration here and there. It is a spectacle through and through, you couldn't ask for more.

The game looks phenomenal, runs smooth as butter on my mid-tier system and plays like a dream. The first Space Marine game is very nostalgic, but I don't think it holds a candle to its successor. I've yet to try out the PVP modes, I'm not much of a PVP guy, but the PVE is extremely fun, if a bit limited in scope. With only six operations at launch that only differ slightly in enemy numbers, variants and spawns, I feel as though it may get a bit stale over time. The Devs have stated that new free operations will be on the way so I look forward to that.

I think this game is a very, very solid 9/10. I can see myself playing this for hours and hours if the Devs perfect the amazing base they have here. All in all, if you're a fan of 40k, love mowing down tons of enemies of Mankind and want to experience a superb power fantasy, this is the game for you.

And with that, I will leave you with this: I may be a Son of Guilliman in the campaign, but in my heart I remain a proud Scion of The Praetorian. Primarch-Progenitor, to your glory and the glory of Him on Earth!

Huh so I just completed this. Steam says I have 21 hours in the game, but probably 6 of those were AFK and another 2 were spent messing around in multiplayer and dealing with some crashes on the initial cutscene. Overall, I guess the main story probably took me ~13 hours to beat, and I tried to be pretty thorough about exploring maps and listening to all the dialogue. The game that is here is very good, and it uses enough memorable setpieces for most encounters to feel interesting and unique. The early Tyranid encounters and the entire last mission are especially fantastic. They really succeeded at making you feel like a space marine, although there were some times where I felt a little more like John Dark Souls roll-spamming through enemy fire. My main complaint is just that the story felt a bit flat. Not necessarily short, rather it felt like a somewhat simple story which was a little disappointing considering the various intelligent agents at play. I haven't touched the Operations (Co-Op content) yet though, so it's possible that adds some nuance to the story. I played on the apparent intended difficulty and it felt very well balanced with the exception of one specific tyranid encounter. The combat feels great, the game looks awesome, and the small bit of Co-Op I played was very fun (aside from the very long load times), I'm definitely going to try and grind this game to get all the cool cosmetics and whatnot, but I can't help but be reminded of MGSV with its abruptly short ending compensated for with a questionably integrated "endless" multiplayer mode.

After 13 years of waiting, Titus returns to destroy everything xenos and heretic for the glory of Ultramar and the Imperium. And he freaking rocks !

At the time of writing this review I'm almost 5 hours into the game and have only touched the campaign mode with my friends in coop. However, it has already proved itself as a true continuation of the game from my childhood.
From the visual standpoint the game looks brilliant and everything, that will surround you, will absolutely feel like 40k and will immerse you till the end.
Sound Design is also impressive, from firing bolters to the crunching bones and flesh of your enemies. Yes, sometimes it can be loud af and if you play in coop you won’t be able to hear your teammate, but that’s the whole fun of it.
Gameplay, in comparison to the first game, did see some major improvements and feels more dynamic and enjoyable (sometimes even hard, even on normal difficulty). Additionally the possibility to play the entirety of the campaign with your friends increases the scale of fun by 10.
I won’t be writing about the story this much, because I'm still going thru it, but I will say that the story is engaging. Just seeing Titus once again reintegrating himself into his Chapter after such a long time and the reactions of people on his past feels interesting. The rest of campaign you will have to discover on your own, but believe me, you won’t regret it.

The only minor problem that I have currently encountered was the connection to the Space Marine 2 servers and I had to reconnect to them several time in my ~5 hours of gameplay. But as I said, it was a minor problem that will probably be fixed in the future. Or maybe I just need to speed up my Internet connection, I don't know :P

Anyway, was these 13 years worth the wait ? Yes. Should you play this game just to enjoy the slaughterhouse that is happening there ? Also yes. And if you are a 40k fan, then Yes x10.

I currently rate it a solid 9/10 and claim it as a worthy successor to the previous game.

Alright now that ive put some time into it I want to give a honest review.

Im only going to be talking about negatives, *real negatives* not stuff like no ultra wide support on launch. Because for the most part, if you look at the trailers and go “yo that looks cool”, thats all you really need to know for positives. The game lives up the expectations.

1. Campaign length. I thought the campaign was good, better than sm1, but I played on tier 4 difficulty and did the operations when they unlocked (you can do pre campaign, but theres a spoiler warning) and it took me 12 hours. Without the operations and on normal, id estimate its only 6-7 hours which is what others suggest.

I think its a good campaign, but 8 hours would have probably been the sweet spot.

2. Pvp chaps customization is lacking, and we are currently missing thousand sons, emperors children, and word bearers. Hopefully they will come with class releases which would be free, but to all my thousand son brothers yeah it sucks.

Furthermore, your actual options are paint and emblems. No physical changes. I get loyalist getting more fashion because of pve, but it would be nice if we could have 1 legion specific armor set per class and 2 general chaos armor sets to mix and match.

3. Pvp only has 3 maps. The pvp is super fun, im actually playing more pvp than I am pve which is very surprising, but its a shame there are only 3 maps. 3 is the minimum but 5 would feel much better and it wont be till early 2025 when we get more.

4. Assault in pve. In the campaign and pvp, you have a super fast recharge on your jump pack. Furthermore you can really sore high into the sky. Yet in pve operations, for some reason the assault class has super slow regen, and barely goes up maybe 4 space marines high.

Now, I get nerfing the regen a bit compared to pvp. In pvp its risky to be in the air and no ground slam can instakill versus pve where its a good escape tool and is great for swarms, but it should be a minor increase in cooldown. I assume it will get buffed as its considered the only “weak” class by the community rn, but if you are a Blood Angel or Raven Guard fan, you may be disappointed.

————
Thats really it. Again, gameplay is great, music pretty good, story actually good (not sure how good to someone who doesnt know 40k but I assume it isn’t bad), operations are fun and the classes all feel good. Pvp is surprisingly really fun, as someone who expected to ignore it. Visuals are great and do 40k justice.

Basically its worth the money, but I wanted to go over some of the negatives from a perspective of someone who likes the game.

Great Game but it definitely needs some ironing out.
Operations mode is really fun but just from playing it on the lowest difficulty as you start out, the ammunition is so low especially in your reserve, some weapons dont have this and just have one continuous stockpile, on the higher difficulties you'll find even less ammo around the maps
you're always looking for ammo some weapons in particular start out with even less ammo and the maximum amount you can hold is atrocious. In a horde shooter this shouldnt be such an issue, a lot of these 40k games like this one put a lot of emphasis on the melee combat but even then you wont always break the tougher enemies guard with heavy attacks, they can even keep hitting you and your dodge and parry doesnt always register, theyre relentless and again Ive just started out and arent a high level in any of the classes, my highest being a 7. I cant imagine how this'll pan out on the higher dfficulties and you WILL have to play them if you want to keep upgrading the classes and weapons. Just liker Helldivers 2 there are upgrade "tokens" to be found the better ones you need are on the top 2 difficulties.
Any enemy that isnt a grunt is its own tank and they spawn these just as much as the grunts, theyre so tanky all your ammo will be depleted before youve killed half of them, that'll again be even worse as you turn the difficulty higher.
They need to make adjustments, I get theres supposed to have a challenge but we're space marines after all and this doesnt feel like we are anything special, the cooldown to regenerating your armour/shields also feels like like a lifetime.

While the game looks visually incredible, the performance isnt the best, unless you dropped several grand on a PC youre not gonna run this game all high or ultra, Im usually at 60 FPS with an AMD Ryzen 7 5800X, RTX 3070, and 32 GB RAM, I dont think this system is low spec at all. DLSS does a minimal job at helping and I do not play with it on anything else then Performance

The game is an incredible grind, you will drop over 100 hours to unlock all the customisation and upgrade your classes across the board since the same currency used for unlocking customisation and upgrading your perk trees in every single character

All in all I love this game so far but it needs adjustments to the grind, enemies/combat, and performance. I do like that they have a whole roadmap with future modes and maps etc coming in the near future before the year end and onwards

Super new to the Warhammer franchise. Been interested for quite a while though, because of all the YouTube shorts about Warhammer lore that's been flooding my algorithm. So my review will be in the perspective of someone new to the franchise so don't forget to take that in mind.

The Story/Campaign will delve shortly about the main characters backstory, so if you're worrying that you didn't manage to play the prequel game fear not as you will be given backstory, regarding what happened before this game. Summary:
-Campaign is a fun, classic, 12ish hour romp for single player third person shooter fans. Co-op with friends is a plus
-PvP is fun but shallow, some classes obviously better than others (melee just isn't very good for obvious reasons)
-Operations (PvE co-op missions) are odd, a little awkward to play, and at times boring, but they're fun if you have friends to play with and they are likely to get a lot of attention in future updates as the devs decide what to make this game into post-launch

This game is in a very odd place at launch. As a single-player 3rd person shooter focusing just on campaign, it's a pretty classic 8-12ish hour experience, and it's done very well. There's a mission or two in campaign that I consider stinkers (mission 2 with the pyreblaster) but overall the campaign skips along at a good pace and is very fun in a way that's reminiscent of games like gears of war, spec ops the line, and other third-person shooter classics. Good set-pieces, pretty good pacing, fun weapons, and shockingly cool and fun boss fights (again, minus mission 2's boss. the lictor as a boss doesn't work very well imo, and I just don't like mission 2 lol). The campaign builds up to an AWESOME finale with a final boss fight that feels like something out of kingdom hearts 2.

Then you finish the campaign - and you're prompted to try out the other game modes which will obviously be the focus of the devs moving forward. With a season pass they are clearly trying to keep this game alive post launch as a multiplayer experience both in co-op operations and pvp. The pvp is kinda shallow but fun, while the operations are... very hard to rate right now. I like op 2: "decapitation" but the others all feel very generic, gimmicky, and shallow somehow. Not being able to switch around weapons like titus, not having access to his "ult" which they call "abilities" in this game, being locked into a specific playstyle (unless you pick an all-rounder class like tactical marine) for an entire mission, set-piece and enemy scripting that was very obviously a lower priority than the bombastic, crazy campaign. It all just feels second-rate.

I dunno. the operations feel weird, and for some reason they gimped the assault class to only jump a singular foot off the ground in this mode unlike the 30 foot jump you do in campaign and pvp.

Overall the campaign is worth $60 in today's market imo. It's great and games like this don't get made any more. It feels like these devs revived a lost art from the late 2000s. The other modes are an after-thought to me. Take em or leave em, see what they turn into down the line.

It's hard for me to objectively review this game without thinking constantly of the "what it could be". So that taints my POV. After playing games like Helldivers which captures perfectly what is a "galaxy wide" conflict, I suffer seeing Space Marine with such an old formula. I know the game is not pretentious and it tried to focus on visual imapct and action, but those too have a really steep diminshing return rule in the pleasure they provide. For a $60++ game, that feels lackluster.

Also, this game took over 13 years to arrive. Production took multiple years. It got delayed almost one year. And this is what we got? Sorry, it was not enough. I applaud the effort, but no guys, this was not the game we deserved.

The Pros:

- Visuals, we all agree on that
- Lore, its really respectful of the lore, but at the same time not annoying for the newcomers
- Sounds (not soundtrack), they are on point

The Bads:

- Combat is just...messy, and not in the good way of messy as chaotic-fun. Its more chaotic-evil lol. You will read it everywhere. Ranged combat is not encouraged at all and actually a detriment to you. QTEs and parry system gets lost immediatly as soon as you get swarmed. Also telegraphs sometimes show up, sometimes they don't. Sometimes you have to time based on animations, sometimes it won't work.

- PvE gets boring ASAP. Operations is a one trick pony. Progression is non existent and just a fake front.

- PvP is atrocious. Was it THAT HARD to add a layer of Galaxy Wide conflict between chaos and loyalist? Playing 5 minutes TDM-like matches its just a WASTE for a game with the potential this one had. Why not add some PvE content inside the PvP? Was it really necessary to make simetric maps like if this was actually gonna be a "competitive" game? 3 maps? Why not reuse assets of the campaign to make more? It feels so sadly basic.

- Having only two enemy factions is meh. I think with the development time and production this game had, you guys could've gone the extra mile to add more. I was so hyped when I was in the final world expecting a surprise there, and you guys let me down so much not seeing "those" enemies show up.

So all in all, I would recommend this game, but not at full price. And I would mostly recommend it to die hard fans of WH40K, or people who just wanna have 10-12 hs of fun for what they pay.

The Sniper and Heavy classes are much stronger than others in the game, easily getting the most kills and damage. Instead of weakening them, the developers should make other classes stronger to match their power.

Dodging some enemy attacks, like AoE flames or charges, doesn’t always work correctly. Even when you dodge, you can still get hit, which feels unfair and needs fixing.

Some enemies, like flying Tyranids, are hard to deal with if you’re using melee-focused classes. These classes don’t have the right weapons or enough ammo, making these fights feel unbalanced.

Healing with melee weapons is much weaker than with ranged weapons like the Multi-Melta, which can heal a lot of contested health quickly. Melee healing should be better, given the risk of fighting up close.

Chaos Warriors are annoying to fight at higher difficulties because they teleport too much and seem to cheat by knowing your moves. They need limits on their teleporting to make them more fun to fight.

The Assault class is supposed to be good at melee but has clunky dodge mechanics. You can't cancel attacks into a dodge, making it hard to avoid damage. The jetpack is also less useful in operations mode than in the story, which should be fixed to keep it consistent and powerful.

Ranged weapons like the Multi-Melta and Las Fusil are much stronger than any melee weapons, making melee combat almost useless. Melee weapons need a big damage boost to make them worth using.

Lastly, a major bug lets enemies shoot through walls, objects, and terrain. Players can also accidentally walk through some walls and get stuck. This bug is surprising and needs urgent fixing to make the game more enjoyable.

Pretty good, but It's lacking overall in content right now to justify the full price. After 12 hours of gameplay, I've mostly seen all the new stuff there is to see and at this point now have the choice of grinding to higher difficulties and gear to get to harder difficulties or play the PVP. There's a lack of secondary weapons, and such, but the spectacle is just so incredible and the actual missions themselves are pretty fun. There's a fair variety of objectives, but I can't imagine just wanting to run through the same missions so I can run through them again with the same gun with a stat upgrade for all that long until I am going to need another game play loop to really keep me invested over the long term. For Comparison I found Darktide fairly disappointing and wouldn't hugely recommend it, I think at least better uses the fewer maps they have by varying up the mission types and conditions somewhat.

So why do I recommend it? Well for one, because steam does not do mixed reviews. But also because the stuff it does right I really enjoy. Some people don't like the combat style but I really love it, especially in the coop mode where, due to being a bit more specialised in your fighting style, has a flow that I really enjoy. The campaign itself is just a fun blast too, and whilst the story is a bit of a let down (especially because it ends on a very "to be continued" ending that just doesn't feel great) the mission to mission gameplay is incredible. It feels like fighting through a war and really delivers on the power fantasy.

Overall I recommend this game if you know what you're getting into, but if you're tight on cash- maybe skip this one for something that is overall better value for money.

I'll immediately note that the campaign should be perceived as a large tutorial for a network game (!)

Everything is done qualitatively from the graphics and the presentation of plans in the background during the battle to the sounds and voice acting directly in all languages (!)

The game also has an operations mode. In essence, the same campaign, only forced fortunately with 2 other players, the events there unfold for another squad in parallel with the main plot. There you can choose, as in the network game, one of 6 classes.

Saber Interactive has done a great job of introducing the product to a new audience unfamiliar with the universe.

I'm probably biased as a big fan of the first game, but this game is awesome! Great graphics, awesome guns and melee combat. What's really impressive is how my PC can run all of the hordes of enemies on screen all at once.

My only complaint is that special enemies are a little bit too tanky on higher difficulties (headshots don't really do anything compared to mag dumping) and that your squadmate AI are as dumb as a bag of bricks and are incapable of picking up in game weapons and items. Those are my only complaints so far.

Looking for a polished horde-melee/shooter on rails similar to Darktide and set in the same universe? You've come to the right place. What this game tries to do, it does well.

Combat is a visceral rotation of parrying blue melee, dodging red melee, clearing trash swarms, breaking armor, seeking snipers, and of course clicking on heads. While you may be a Space Marine, unfortunate budget cuts across the Imperium have resulted in a shortage of power armor. Instead, you'll have to wear that paper-mache cosplay you made for last year's convention. This naturally means a good defense is a good offense, and that only by bathing in the blood of your enemies can you hope to maintain your health and cosplay. Blood for the Emperor, Skulls for the Golden Throne.

- Aesthetic, audio, and voice acting are well done and on-brand.
- Weapons mostly feel like they carry weight and pack a punch.
- Music is fitting, though nothing as epic as Jesper Kyd's work on the 'tide games. Most of the time I forgot it was there.
- Bot intelligence of your fellow marines in singleplayer story leaves something to be desired. This primarily has to do with where they choose to position themselves, engagement range, and target priorities. Their one saving grace after they abandon your side and the objective is that they'll come pick you up directly if you suffer a mortal wound.
- In some stages, hordes can be delayed or thinned by targeting the piles they build to scale walls, much like piles the bugs build in Starship Troopers. Cool feature, and generally it's easier to tell the direction waves are coming from. Generally.
- When I describe the game "on rails," I mean that the maps you play through are generally a series of corridors, catwalks, and confined spaces. You might see sweeping vistas and even shoot hordes as they cascade over the hills to your position, but most of that space is for them to run on, not you. There is little to offer in terms of exploration.

All that said, if you don't like being led by the nose or would rather play something tactical, thought-provoking and innovative, you'll want to look elsewhere or at least wait for it to go on sale.

What it is: A love letter to WH40k fans looking for a lore friendly option of a long standing persistent grim dark future fantasy creation from the early 1980's.

What it isn't: A standalone best of in the genre that feels 100% complete instead of a somewhat grindy, almost live service-y game.

First off, do you have your copy of the Lectitio Divinitatus handy, guardsman? WELL PUT THAT FILTH AWAY, FOR THIS GAME SPEAKS TO THE SONS OF THE EMPEROR... 's sons...

The presentation, is - flat out - flawless. The dedication to the environments, the sky boxes, the feel of overwhelming numerical superiority from the enemy; the touches from the executed Rubicae, the screech of Binaric cant when you pass tech priests in the halls of your wonderfully gothic battle barge; it's ALL there.
Much like the world building in Darktide, the developers here spared nothing when it came to drilling deep into the detail of the lore.
From the moment the first cinematic has you load into the tutorial, grab your seat - you're in for a ride.
The nods to the lore-hungry are everywhere. Expect the game to provide, in engine, things that you would have always dreamed of. The first time you saw those space marines hoisting their standard in a last stand over their enemies on the cover of ... well, pick a White Dwarf - yeah. They know their audience.

If you're a fan of the series; every cut of the power sword, every thump of your thunder hammer; the squish of organs under your power fists and the splatter of your bolt rounds feels like a delectably bespoke optical and aural experience for the WH40k fandom. This is a game that was made for you - as long as you like space marines.

It is not without its faults. While the game play loop is enjoyable in its visceral nature, you can't help but feel like the game is incomplete. Sure, the roadmap promises more, and one can argue that the hallmark of a good game is that it leaves one with the desire for more - and while there is longevity in the RNG nature of the Operations, and PvP; the customization (looking at you, chaos) leaves a bit to be desired and the grind feels artificial at best. Also, why is there only a bionic arm? What about the legs? And why can't I do both arms and both legs? Just the one right arm? Really? Nitpicking, sure, but there it is.

Layers upon layers of complication affect the unlock system, whether it's trying to determine which weapons need what xp or what specific currencies are required to unlock weapon or class perks. While the perks are clearly defined, their measurable effects vary from slight to game changing. Not to mention the drip of materials and xp from the missions themselves, and you can find even the best gameplay loop can wear thin pretty fast.

All in all, it's a stellar throwback to games and masculinity of a time long past. It's nostalgia layered with lore in a perfect serving that doesn't sit too long.

If you are a fan of the lore, buy it. If you are not; try it. If you think space men are silly, watch a broadcast. It's an acquired taste, sure; but if you have acquired the taste, it would be very hard to do better.

Space marine takes up the story the original 2010 game left for us, following the adventures of (former) captain Titus of the Ultramarines. Its been a while in the setting too, a century even and alot has happened in the lore to bring our intrepid ultramarine to the new standard of heros in the current canon.

The gameplay is largely similar yet its been evolved. Those who played the original might almost frustratingly feel so close to the original yet the new mechanics get in the way...this is wrong and you'll shake the feeling off before the tutorial is over. The new mechanics are solid and once you get the timing down and general learning curve of the melee system it can feel natural at times. theres some timing issues i think still need hammering out but these are the early days and patches will come along with additional content that has been promised.

The story is great and i actually laughed when i saw what they were doing with it having played the original again shortly before this dropped. Any veteran will get a sensible chuckle as well i surmise, this isn't a bad thing at all. Theres a grander narrative focus here, we get more of a view inside Titus's head now, it feels like we have more writing talent behind it than back in 2010 and it comes off nice as the visuals which are fantastic.
Its easy to get lost in the carnage of combat both near and far as you can see massive battles going on in the distance, guard lines barely holding against a tide of blue and grey monsters.

And all of it in a package less than 70 gigs and can run on older hardware with little issue. Optimization here is good, not perfect but good. Some complain of server issues with its extensive coop mode and others complain of the difficulty spikes the campaign throws out. One will be ironed out in time the other is a filter for heretics.

Space Marine 2 is a proper nod to the might of Space Marines and a proper nod to the 40k universe as a whole, its another step in a growing trend of seeing the franchise break away from being purely a RTS or other strategy series and into somthing bloodier. I only wish for more like it.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is nothing short of a triumph in the gaming world! From the very moment you step into the hulking boots of a Space Marine, you are thrust into a richly detailed universe that perfectly captures the gritty essence of the Warhammer 40k lore. The game does an incredible job of making you feel like you're truly inhabiting the role of a Space Marine, facing down waves of enemies with unyielding resolve and a wide array of powerful weapons.

The combat is visceral, intense, and deeply satisfying. Each encounter feels like a tactical challenge where your skill and quick thinking lead to moments of genuine triumph. The developers have masterfully balanced the game's mechanics, ensuring that every battle is a thrilling experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat.

The storyline is engaging and keeps you invested from start to finish, with plenty of twists and turns that leave you eager to see what happens next. The graphics are stunning, and the environments are beautifully crafted, adding to the overall immersion of the game. Whether you're a long-time fan of the Warhammer universe or a newcomer, "Space Marine 2" delivers an experience that is both accessible and deeply rewarding.

In short, "Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2" is a must-play. It's a game that understands its roots and builds upon them to deliver a truly exceptional experience. If you're looking for a game that makes you feel like a hero standing against insurmountable odds, this is it.

After over 60 hours of Playing Space Marine 2, getting all 50 achievements and playing all the game modes all I can say is wow!

The game is phenomenal! It met my every expectation and then some! And as a 40k fan I had very high expectations for the game. The 13 year wait was well worth it and the £79.99 for early release was worth every penny!

Campaign:
The campaign is 7-8 hours long and is very well paced, it keeps you engaged and intrigued the entire time with non-stop story and action! The writing of the story is great as well, there is a reveal after beating the campaign that I saw coming from about halfway through my play-through which I only clocked onto because of playing the first game and the incredible writing that the story has. I have heard people say it's too short but I think it's just the right length and doesn't overstay its welcome. The enemy variety is nice and the hack and slash system with a twist is very visceral and fun! But what I enjoy most of all from the gameplay aspects of the story is the boss fights. Space Marine only had one real boss-fight in the game so I didn't know what to expect with this game, but there are a good amount of fun and unique boss-fights in Space Marine 2. I really enjoy the arena design and the bosses attacks and patterns which truly makes each boss a delight to fight. The game is well worth the price for the campaign alone.

Operations (Co-op PvE):
The Operations mode is very fun to play alone or with some friends, the 6 current Operations missions are great to play and each have their own unique aesthetic and style to them. There's also more boss-fights in Operations as well as some bosses from the campaign showing up occasionally as well. The 6 classes are unique and fun to play and each have their own playstyles. The class I've primarily been using is the Bulwark, which once you get to the max level he just becomes an unstoppable tank that has good crowd control and can turn choke points into death traps with his perks that makes him drop a shock grenade at his feet when he perfectly parries a blow or loses all his armour. I have dabbled in the other classes and they all have their own fun ways to play them and I look forward to levelling them up and seeing what they can do. The Operations mode also runs alongside the story narratively, further adding to the story and making you feel like you're involved in the main story and that it's not just Titus, Gadriel and Chairon advancing the plot. With the plans to add a prestige system, more missions and potentially new classes like the Apothecary in the future the Operations mode looks like it's only going to get better as time progresses.

Eternal War (6v6 PvP):
The Eternal War mode is Space Marine 2's PvP game-mode, it includes Annihilation (Team Deathmatch), Seize Ground (Domination) and Capture And Control (Hardpoint). All 3 of the modes are very fun and the 6 classes from Operations are balanced well for PvP in this mode. There's only a handful of maps at the moment and the mode feels bare-bones but I have to say I like it like that. There's no meta chasing or min-maxing builds to give you an unfair edge in a fight, what wins matches is good team play and martial ability. There will be new game-modes and maps added in the future along with new weapons like the Neo-Volkite Pistol. It also has the potential to be a very fun mode that you can just hop into for a few hours and have some fun.

Customisation:
The customisation is incredible for both the PvP and PvE modes, there's a plethora of different options to customise your marine. The only issue I have at the moment is that the Heretic Astartes are limited in what they can do to customise their classes looks, however I feel that is something Saber will add in a later update alongside even more cosmetic items for us to pimp out our Space Marine's with.

With all that being said I'm going to have Space Marine 2 an 11/10! It's my Game Of The Year for 2024! I have enjoyed every second of this game and shall continue to do so! I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a fun time! And if you feel like you need to be a Warhammer 40,000 fan to enjoy this game let me tell you that's not the case, you can just hop on and have fun without feeling clueless to the world around you.

If you've read this far, thanks for taking the time to read my review! I hope you have a wonderful day!

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Review
Rating: 4/5

Pros:

Stunning Visuals: The game boasts impressive graphics that bring the Warhammer 40,000 universe to life. The environments are richly detailed, and the character models are top-notch.
Engaging Combat: The combat system is fluid and satisfying, with a variety of weapons and abilities that make each encounter thrilling. The melee combat, in particular, feels visceral and impactful.
Immersive Storyline: The narrative is compelling, with well-written dialogue and a plot that keeps you hooked from start to finish. The lore of the Warhammer 40,000 universe is well-integrated, making it a treat for fans.
Sound Design: The audio experience is exceptional, with a powerful soundtrack and sound effects that enhance the overall immersion.
Cons:

AI Squad Issues: While the game is mostly a joy to play, the AI squad can be frustrating, especially on Veteran difficulty. They often make poor tactical decisions, which can lead to unnecessary challenges and detract from the overall experience.
Difficulty Spikes: There are moments where the difficulty spikes unexpectedly, which can be jarring and may require multiple attempts to overcome.
Overall: Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a fantastic addition to the franchise, offering a visually stunning and engaging experience. The combat and storyline are highlights, making it a must-play for fans of the series. However, the AI squad’s performance on higher difficulties can be a source of frustration. Despite this, the game’s strengths far outweigh its weaknesses, making it a worthy sequel.

This game left me absolutely elated. The combat, visuals, soundscape, story all knocked it out of the park. The art team in particular blew it out of the water, and if you're a fan of 40k you will spend quite a lot of time admiring the environment.
Numerous times throughout my play-through I found myself on Games Workshop's webstore debating buying some Tyranid and [REDACTED BY THE INQUISITION] miniatures. The only part of the presentation that wasn't outstanding was the music, which was still really good - just nothing I'll be listening to on Spotify in my day-to-day life.

The story was a marked step up from the first game, with the plot and the character development being far superior. It took me roughly 12 hours to play through the story, however I was on the second hardest difficulty and was also frequently sight-seeing so your mileage may vary.
It is a semi-direct continuation of the first game so while you don't *need* to know what happened there I would look up a plot synopsis or something. MandaloreGaming on Youtube does a decent sparknotes review of the story in his review of the first game.

The multiplayer modes are an absolute joy as they give you an excuse to continue playing with the combat, and customise your own Space Marines.

The only complaints I have are the lack of maps for Operations mode, which will almost certainly be improved with time, the lack of customisation options for Chaos Space Marines in PvP, and the fact that if you play the campaign with helmets on, the characters magically lose their helmets for every cutscene.
These are minor gripes ultimately and in the end this is a solid 9.5/10 for me.

Early Review after only a couple of hours -

Overall - Extremely positive with a few unfortunate drawbacks

Pros:

Combat - Visceral, satisfying and brutal. Well implemented hordes of enemies feel overwhelming in a good way.

Sound - Voice acting, Music and general audio design is fantastic. The game has a great atmosphere and presence.

Visuals- Visually stunning. Enemies, environments and characters are all very detailed and graphically impressive.

Performance - Generally the game runs great on my 4070 and i5-13500. I have had a few dips here and there but nothing major, quite impressive considering the amount of enemies on the screen at any given time and the game looks great too.
I am running the game on Ultra/High on all settings at 1440p with DLSS turned on. The game does not feature frame-gen.

Cons:
One minor complaint is that so far there hasn't been a great deal of variety in combat although its still VERY early days, what there has been has been great and the variety of enemy encounters (if not variety) has kept things interesting and combat is always satisfying.

My only major complaints are:

1. No matchmaking for campaign co-op. There ARE modes with matchmaking but for the campaign you need to use a code to join up with your brothers which, I don't really understand why there is no online group finder or matchmaking for the main campaign

2. Friendly AI is very bad. If you choose to go it alone in the campaign the game will assign you 2 computer controlled marines to form a squad and I'm not exaggerating when I say they are utterly useless.

The game is made far more difficult when you don't group with friends because enemies will rarely target them, instead choosing to swarm the player character in a way that sometimes feels unfair/unbalanced. Meanwhile your AI squadmates will often just stand there doing nothing and you have to fight the majority of enemies on your own.

3. Difficulty feels unbalanced. I started out on Veteran because the game describes it as the "intended difficulty" but even some early missions are VERY difficult on this setting, you will die quickly as hundreds of enemies swarm you at once, while ranged enemies peel away your armour quickly.

You can still get through it but expect to have to retry sections frequently. This is compounded by my point above about AI allies doing very little to help, and makes the game a slog even on earlier missions. I restarted on Normal instead and now the game feels far too easy, armour restores more quickly, enemies die much faster and do about a third of the damage as on Veteran, although this is generally a better balance in my opinion and does still provide some challenge.

Summary: Despite being unable to play co-op due to being one of the very few people in my friend group that has pre-purchased the game and there being no public matchmaking for campaign co-op, and some struggles with picking the wrong difficulty setting to start I am still absolutely loving the game so far. Everything about the combat feels satisfying and punchy, the game is very visually impressive and has incredibly impressive performance considering the sheer number of Tyranids that will swarm at one time and the environments and sound design really immerse you in the experience.

!!PICK NORMAL DIFFICULTY UNLESS PLAYING WITH FRIENDS!!

8/10 (with the possibility of 9/10 if they improve some of the balance and co-op matchmaking features)

If you are coming into this with it being some revolutionary gaming experience you are going to be disappointed, its just a very solid, fun and extremely stylish 3rd person shooter-hack and slash hybrid.

But

BUT

If you are fan of Space Marine (2011) or a 40k fan in general this is the definitive 40k action game. Story campaign about 10hrs (singleplayer/co-op), six co-op "Operation" mode Left 4 Dead style missions that tie into the campaign and old school PVP with three maps and three modes. It improves upon Space Marine (2011) in every single aspect; graphics, cinematic style, art design, level design, environmental variety, size and scope, gameplay, DLC plan. I think there's good amount of content here for people to enjoy at launch now and if the developers stick to their 1 year plan it will be even better in a years time. I've been a 40k enjoyer, reader, miniature collector for over 20 years so this was a real treat. The developers clearly love the setting.

Gameplay:
Similar to the first game, some melee weapons have the same movesets with the addition of parry and dodge mechanics to help you control the mob better. You'll still be rolling around a lot like the first game but now whenever you get a perfect parry or perfect dodge you also trigger and auto-aimed headshot called a Gun Strike. Very satisfying. Health and armour were tweaked so you heal with health kits or special abilities and armour is now restored on executions, you are also immune to damage while performing executions. It takes a little bit of getting use to but once you get a hang of it its awesome fun and the change to executions mean you get to relish in the gratuitously bloody spectate. Only issue is that a lot of the bolter type weapons feel a bit weak. I find myself using the Meltgun at every possible opportunity as enemies are almost always right in your face.

Favourite thing:
The Space Marine customiser is so good they could sell it as a standalone product with all the colours and decals unrestricted and 40k hobbyists would buy it. It is very under-cooked on the Chaos side however, with specific legions for each class which is a little annoying, colour schemes not saving and no option to change armours.

Performance:
Had only 1 crash during my play-through of the campaign. Runs great with no hitching, stuttering, frame dips(only once) though I have found my CPU runs a bit on the hotter side. Others with 13th and 14th gen intel CPUs also reported the gaming running a bit hot.

My PC:
Intel i7-14700KF 3.40 GHz
32.0 GB
Installed on SSD
Nvidia GTX 4070 TI SUPER

I locked my framerate at 90 as it generally floated at about 88-110fps at 2k Resolution and everything on ULTRA. Only had a single instance of an FPS dip where it was 40 FPS in the campaign where you first fight the chaos marines. Apart from that it ran very smoothly. The engine is some seriously impressive tech to render so many enemies on screen with such massive environments at such high graphic quality, really impressive.

Needs improvement:
Some areas need some improvement though, I won't both mentioning as they are already listed as incoming as part of the Year One plan like more maps for both PVP and PVE. Balance between assault and ranged combat in PVP needs some refinement, very heavily titled toward shooty classes currently. Perk trees for PVE aren't that interesting.

Things I don't like (mixed):
Day 1 DLC plus some customisation content pay walled. Given that all the new maps & modes will be free I see this as a good trade off. You had to pay for both more PVP and cosmetic content in Space Marine (2011). Thankfully no in-game cash shop.

Things I missed:
Mark Strong as Captain Titus. Clive Standen gives a great performance, a classic gravely voiced marine, but there was always something about Strong's understated performance that made it really memorable. This is a conflicted review tbh, On one hand I love the game, and on the other I really hate some of the systems, so I'm gonna try and attempt to break those things down here.

Story,
The story is relatively short, but as far as I'm concerned it does exactly what It needed, and is a blast visually and audibly, even when there were things happening that I didn't understand from lack of context it was still fun and interesting enough to keep my attention and push forward, 8/10

Combat,
This is both awful and amazing, on the good side it feels, sounds, and looks great, but the actual motion of going through combat isn't good at all, the main problem is that there is no reliable way to heal, so lets break it down, the only ways to heal are. Stims, Retaliation, and being revived. So what's wrong with this? Well there aren't enough stims to keep you alive and going, nor does the Bloodborne inspired mechanic of retaliation work when there are multiple mobs all hitting you thus stopping any gain back you might get, Well what about just resetting with a revive? That doesn't work either because after getting knocked twice you will permanently die in the campaign, or you re-spawn after 1 minute in COOP.

Now all that doesn't seem so bad, but it leads to frustration all around, you will die, a lot, all the time, and it will feel cheap, because as you move through the maps you will get damaged, and eventually (especially on harder difficulties) you'll die, and you'll keep dying because there is no way to fully heal after or during encounters, so no matter what you will get chipped down and die, now I know people would say well that's what the armor mechanic is for, but that at best let's you brush off 3 hits, while this helps, and lets you maintain yourself in combat it's just not enough to keep you up and going.

I would like to mention this is primarily a campaign problem, then it lessens in COOP due to perks you can get with certain classes and is probably non existent in PVP.

In total 5/10, and if we get some kind of alternative way to heal later on as they patch and maintain the game I'd give it a 9/10.

I'm gonna end it there, in total I'd say this is a easy recommend if you like this kind of game, overall I'd say it's worth it just for the story and a fun campaign at lower difficulties.

It's a great game in many respects, and a worthy followup to the original. If you are a 40k fan, it's one of the most outrageously faithful adaptations of the franchise into videogame form... if not THE most. It's not without some notable flaws that sour the experience, though.

While it's filled with incredible spectacle, surprisingly engaging story moments, and punchy gunplay, I feel like the health system from the first game was flat-out superior. In fact, I'd say it's almost the opposite of what it should be. There's no way to regain health in or outside of combat without the use of stims, and that's a complete inversion of the first game in a way that feels obnoxious. Your AI teammates are also frequently useless, and it will become a problem at a few key points in the campaign. Not enough to send you to reload a save, but enough to be annoying. This is absolutely mitigated if you play the campaign with friends, but if you don't, the experience can be undermined by the combination of the health system and the AI.

Space Marine 2 also requires a beefy CPU to play on PC if you are looking for consistently smooth framerates. I have a 7800x3D and had minimal issues, but be warned and use the refund policy if the game doesn't meet your performance standards on the hardware you are using.

Also, Darktide's combat is better. Ssshhhhhhhh......

The stuff you need to know:

Gameplay is fun, visuals are nice. That's about it. The music is not even that memorable.

The campaign has a mediocre narrative, if you look past the fanservice. Very forgettable. I am struggling to remember anything that happened between the first mission and the last mission. I remember almost none of the dialogue.

Adjusted for time-flation, Dawn of War 1 had better customization.

Co-op is fun, if you're playing with friends. But, all the Co-op missions undermine whatever you customize your Astartes to look like, since all the voice lines are Ultramarine-specific.

Only 3 PvP maps on launch is honestly pretty awful.

100 dollary-doos is not worth it for what you actually get out of it, unless you like Ultramarines.

The game is, as of right now, September 13, not very well optimized. I don't care what CPU you have, it will bottleneck the S H I T out of this game. And there are practically no settings you can adjust to alleviate this.

The gameplay makes up for most of that, though.

Overall, it's not bad, for 40k fans. People who aren't 40k fans will find little to enjoy apart from the gameplay.

6.5/10 a fair bit undercooked, but 40k nerds like it a bit rare.

If you are a 40k fan, stop reading and buy the game.

If not, this game is a mishmash of the Batman Arkham games melee combat on three buttons instead of four, and Halo-ish shooter. You have a very involved good story mode (which can be played co-op, and its about 9 or 10 hours long), a co-op mode that currently has 6 missions but is due to get more where you pick one of 6 classes and play through missions similar to the campaign in production value, and a PvP mode with 3 match types.

The PvP mode feels good, but only has a small number of maps that tend to feel samey. You have the same 6 classes as the co-op mode, but they lock most of the options for each class behind progression. Nothing really like it out there.

If you are a fan of 40k there are so many moments, and things faithfully brought to life. From the surroundings and architecture, to vehicles, to soldiers. Guardsmen salute with the aquila or kneel when you come nearby. There are scenes with commissars executing deserters, tech priests working on projects, so much attention has been spent on little details. Your exhaust ports in your backpack actually blow exhaust.

Get the game.

Space Marine 2 is a fantastic sequel to a well loved game. It expands upon and updates many of the old systems and abilities Space Marine 1 players know and love. Additionally the game is a great introduction to the Warhammer 40,000 universe for new comers, and perfectly encapsulates the setting with fantastic environments, skyboxes, character models, enemies, guns. In addition it does a great job of setting the tone of the universe with the grim dark aspect being harshly played out as you look upon the futile struggle of humanity. The campaign is a great story with well written characters and fun well designed missions and co-op. The PVE multiplayer is incredibly fun and feels like it will never get old, the progression and cosmetic systems are truly what we should expect from a AAA game in this day and age and are almost entirely unlockable without additional purchases (DLC will include large cosmetic bundles). PVP is fun and surprisingly balanced (there are some clearly better options/classes but every class is viable) its cosmetic system is compatible with the PVE one meaning cosmetics can be unlocked once and be used in both modes. I look forward to playing this game for many many months and hopefully years to come.

Looking forward to seeing the game evolve over time.

Just beat the campaign a few hours ago, waiting on my friends to do Operations (PVE), and potentially Eternal War (PVP) later on. The game is fun, while i haven't played SM1, I have seen it and it looks similar enough to where I can say... it's just SM1 with extra spice. The executions are well done, the combat is satisfying, and the gun play is fun. You can die incredibly quickly like a Space Marine would if you don't take enemies seriously; but if you fight properly you feel absolutely unstoppable.

The grand scale of the set pieces and the masses of enemies are awesome. If you're here just for the story, The Single Player is about 7-9 hours, and the PVE Co-Op mode has only 6 missions; If I say each is one hour that leaves you with about... 14 hours of gameplay that isn't PVP; this ignoring the multitude of classes, I believe 6, and the different difficulty levels and weapon loadouts; not to mention the awesome armor customization.


If you're here JUST for single player, I can't recommend it. It's awesome, the story is fun; but for 60 dollars the 8 hour story isn't very long. If you're here for the multiplayer, you'll get your moneys worth.

Also, a final bit; the cinematics are awesome, especially at the end. This game has some of the best cinematic shots and gameplay at the end; at least when it comes to 40k games.

The environment, cinematics, and graphics are top notch, probably one of the best in 2024 BUT the game-play is.... OK. I had fun with the game but it did take me awhile to get used to the controls. I had to rebind some of my buttons for my keyboard and get the timing down on some of the parries and dodging. The visual indicators for parries and dodging is kind of useless when in a swarm, I instead listened to the sound indicators to get the timing down. I was playing on veteran difficulty and got frustrated a little because I felt like I was fighting the controls more then enemies themselves but I eventually got the hang of it. When I finally got the timing down with the parries and dodges, the campaign was almost over. Which is another thing that is frustrating, the campaign is short. Also, your AI bots are useless, they are just their to revive and that's it. I feel like the developers knew this would be frustrating with the controls and bots, so they added a lot of check-points.

I'm kind of biased and love everything Warhammer, both fantasy and 40K. So I already made up my mind that I was going to buy this game. I don't regret it, most of the cons I pointed out earlier are with the controls. It does feel like your an unstoppable tank on two legs when playing this game. Some times I just stop and look around at the level design just to admire it. If you played Starcraft and wondered how it feels to be swarmed by Zerglings in a first person view, this game demonstrates that. I can see myself playing the campaign and operations (PvE Coop) for awhile.

I am a big fan of W40K and SM1. Although I was initially Disappointed by the Controls and Console-Oriented gameplay, I am getting used to it, and it's Fun.

The campaign is great, with a good story and a lot of Epic scenes, but it's a COOP Campaign. If you do not have 2 friends to play with, stick to Normal Difficulty, and then you will enjoy it!

Gameplay: Well, it's very console-oriented. You can use the same button for Melee and shotting (while ADS). It's very annoying, but you can adapt if you love the game and Theme.
Parry is kinda of annoying to figure out but it seems you have to be out of animation for it to work properly and since devs empathes on big chunky clanky Space Marine there is a lot of momentum this makes Parry, and dodge tricky to properly time since your most of time swarmed by small enemies.

PVE COOP is great when you have 2 friends or get matched with 2 other competent players.
Ironicaly if you dont get matched with anyone and got stuck with 2 bots you can get through them much easier. But if you have 2 bad players or worst only 1 player and 1 bot. Then it's pretty much 0 win chance. Most of the time you will get Zerg by AI getting focused from Ranged and elites while swarmed by smaller enemies gives you no space for error.
PVE also has quite massive grind and this blocks you from challenging higher difficulties.
Differenc between green weapon and Purple is Massive. Stock weapon - LVL1, Green - LVL1, Purple - LVL2,3 this is how it seems right now.

Armor Customization/Paint job is awesome so many options styles etc. Class weapon limitations are insane and most classes are kinda unplayable cause of this but as you LVLup and get better weapons (well skins and stats) they will get very strong.
