I was dubious at first, as it relies on a counter/parry combat system, but after playing through the campaign and doing some MP PvP I'm convinced that this is better than the original, which was a great game itself.

The combat is meatier than ever, with exciting executions, fountains of blood and guts and a design that is much more fluid than at first I gave it credit for. Combat has an excellent flow to it as you time your strikes, plan your combos and execute them with brutal effectiveness. The boss fights are genuinely challenging even at lower difficulties, and never felt boring to me. Using your dodge ability as well becomes crucial during at lot of these kinds of fights, using it to effectively counter AoE effects.

The enemy variety is good, could be better perhaps, but I wouldn't say it's anything really worth complaining about. Would I have liked to see more than mostly 'gaunts and Warriors for most of the playthrough? Yes. Did I ever get bored of fighting 'gaunts or warriors? No.

Venturing into spoiler territory a tiny bit, it's very refreshing to see the Chaos villain here being neither Khorne nor Nurgle. Both of these particular godly factions are a little overrepresented in Warhammer games, so to see the Chaos faction include neither was refreshing, and allowed for the Marine on Marine combat to feel different than otherwise might be expected.

Lastly, the voice acting was top notch. I was afraid when I heard that Mark Strong wouldn't be coming back and instead he'd be replaced by Clive Standen, who was pretty good in Vikings, but in the first few trailers I thought his voice sounded well... bad. I thought it sounded far to much like a man trying to an epic voice instead of just naturally having one. Pleased to say I was very, very wrong. Clive Standen is fantastic as Titus, and the rest of the cast are top notch as well.

If I had to give a complaint? Tzaangors are ♥♥♥♥♥♥' annoying and I hate them, and the pylon mission was (at the time) infuriating, but that's a 10 minute segment of a 8+ hour campaign so I forgive them. Your AI companions aren't great, and especially felt useless there, but they do do SOME of the killing work, and often make for excellent fodder to take enemy attention away from you.

I played on Normal difficulty initially and felt challenged enough, but I could probably go higher in my next playthrough. Playing with friends in campaign I would definite up the difficulty to compensate, as 3 competent players would eviscerate.

All in all: Buy this game if you like Warhammer 40k. Buy this game if you like good action campaigns and fun multiplayer. Buy this game on sale if you like good campaigns and multiplayer is hit or miss for you. There is PvE MP too so take that into consideration.

Before I get into this, i just wanna preference that if you enjoyed the first game, you will without a doubt, love this as its an upgrade on basically every front. AND that this is an Early Access, so it is expected to have many bugs, this is what they are designed for so they can detect these bugs and potentially fix them before the full game is shipped off, i feel that some people dont understand that so i feel the need to state it.

-----------------------------------------THE GOOD-----------------------------------------
As far as 40k games go, this is by far, the most faithful to the universe. its story, the combat, the environment, all fantastic and about as faithful as any current 40k game is going to get. The story, whilst it is short, which isn't a bad thing in the slightest, is fantastic, every moment feels like you're in a cinematic even when you're not, and when you are in one, they're some of the best cinematics I have seen as of late, you really get to know the characters and see them develop through-out. You may also see some people talk about how you need to know the lore of 40K to understand the story, however this is not the case, as many of the thing are explained to you, and anything that you maybe think you need a little bit more clarity on are just a quick search away and i can confirm this due to many people i know who are not into warhammer as much as I am found it perfectly fine to understand.(as a side note, as much as i love to play on the hardest difficulty on a lot of games, i whole heartedly recommend u play it on normal or veteran until the AI gets fixed, or you find some friends to play with, because some of the later moments seem almost impossible to do, even after trying multiple different strategies multiple times)

The combat feels so fluid and blends together beautifully between each shot and strike and the sound design of the guns in this game, they make every gun feel weighty and powerful, something that i found was lacking in Space marine 1, which i can set aside since the game is 13 years old now, at times it may feel like u should've parried an attack or dodged it, however the indicators for such attacks can be a bit questionable, some of the attacks will come to you really quickly, whereas other will be much slower. only advice i can give is to parry or dodge when the attack actually hits you and not when you see the indicator

The environments..they are, absolutely amazing, as someone who is heavily into environments, these scenes that saber interactive have produced are just breathtaking. Other than darktide, you are not going to see the grand scale of the 40k universe, and i'd even go on to say you would have trouble grasping it in darktide, with SM2, you can see the absolute scale of these scenes, from the vast jungles, to the sprawling hive cities, they've truly captured the beauty within 40k

-----------------------------------------THE BAD-----------------------------------------
I think it goes without saying, no matter what the game is, its going to have some bad sides to it, literally no game is perfect, its impossible to please everyone and its not a bad thing to say that, but some of SM2's issues are issues for everyone and i believe they should be addressed.

The FPS, now this is a huge issue for some people, especially those on weaker machines, but the FPS in SM2 is bad, especially when the swarms upon swarms of tyranids begin to rush your location, i will easily drop to 20-30 fps in times like this, thankfully however i can deal with it, however some people I know will not be able to and it might ruin the experience for them, and if this is the case, i highly recommend waiting until it is fixed, speaking of which, i believe that the devs are aware of this issue and are working on a patch for some time in the future, hopefully the day 1 patch.

The AI. my god the AI is as dumb as a ton of bricks, aside from reviving you when you go down or using their abilities, they are in all essence useless at anything else, they cant kill or anything, which is a very big part of this game obviously and it feels like you do all of the heavy lifting, which is why i recommend that you do no play on angels of death difficulty for the moment until they hopefully get an upgrade because as stated, it is almost impossible in some sections.

Now, in terms of the PVP, I have yet to properly play it, but from what I've heard it is a great experience, I do however have 1 issue with it, that being that the traitor astartes get far far far less customisation options when compared to their loyalist cousins, Now i do understand the reasoning for this, they have very little ways in which they can be changed, but it would've been nice to be able to change the design of the helmets and pauldrons and even the chest pieces, because in alot of artistic renditions, they very clearly have different designs that could've been used, especially the death guard, they have so many designs to pick from, yet we're stuck with the basic death guard who shows very little signs of corruption from papa nurgle. It would also allow us to play as the thousand sons, as they are absent from the choices due to being purely psykers/librarians which is not a playable class, atleast for the time being.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As a parting note, if you're an avid 40k fan who wants to see the universe represented in a faithful way, this is definitely the game for you, it has everything you could want out of the game and more on the way.

After finishing the campaign and co-op campaign, i can say this:

This is the definitive Space Marine game. There is no other game that evokes the feeling of being a Space Marine, genetically altered to be perfection and death incarnate, to be an Angel of the Emperor.

It's also so lore-accurate. Every enemy you encounter you can just look up and get genuine lore for. I have Death Watch Mark of the Xenos book, and every Tyranid I encountered has an entry in it (Although I do with that a trygon, tyrant guard, or prime warrior made an appearance. They'd make good bosses.)

The melee combat is so visceral, and it took me a bit to get used to using guns as an accessory to it. Once you get the practice, you can become an instrument of divine wrath, the Emperor's will manifest.

The final missions are also just peak warhammer. I won't say anything about those as I don't want to spoil it. But they're so grand and awesome, I yelled with joy (I'm not even exaggerating here) when I recognized some units.

I love this game. This was worth the money I spent to play it early. If you're looking for a good Warhammer game? This is it. IF you want a universal jumping off point for 40k? This is it. If you want to feel like a badass killing hostile aliens? This. Is. It.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is an exhilarating return to the iconic action of the original, blending the intense power of a Space Marine with refined gameplay mechanics that modern gamers expect. Right from the start, Space Marine 2 grabs your attention with its stunning visuals, capturing the grimdark beauty of the Warhammer 40K universe with jaw-dropping environments and impressively detailed character models. The attention to lore is impeccable, allowing both die-hard 40K fans and newcomers to immerse themselves in the epic, galaxy-spanning conflict.

The combat system shines, offering visceral, weighty melee and ranged combat that feels empowering. The ability to seamlessly switch between weapons, chainswords, and bolters adds a satisfying rhythm to the combat flow, allowing for creative and brutal takedowns. The new additions to the arsenal give players even more destructive options, and the larger scale battles against swarms of enemies are adrenaline-pumping.

Character progression is also a standout, allowing players to feel the growth of their Space Marine as they unlock new abilities and gear. The narrative is engaging, pulling players into the ruthless world of the Imperium, where the stakes couldn't be higher, and no battle is fought without sacrifice.

What sets Space Marine 2 apart is its ability to balance large-scale battles with intimate, close-quarters combat. Whether you're taking down hordes of Tyranids or engaging in epic one-on-one duels, the game delivers a perfect blend of chaos and strategy.

Overall, Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 successfully builds on its predecessor while injecting enough innovation and polish to feel fresh. It's a must-play for Warhammer 40K fans and action game enthusiasts alike, offering a brutal, thrilling ride through the grimdark future.

I wasn't sure when I started playing, it felt a bit clunky and I struggled with the parry system etc. There's definitely a learning curve to this game but once you crack it, it's fantastic. The online PvE and PvP systems are really good; different classes create team synergies that work really well and make you feel like you have a specific role to play within the squad.

There are some issues - matchmaking can take a while, and loading takes ages but it's worth it for the visuals. Bot squad mates are actually morons, they have near infinite health but rarely attack anything and have no appreciation for the many 'protect X' objectives - this is only really a problem if you're playing campaign on veteran or higher.

My main gripe is that you can only have one of each class per 3-man squad, but the matchmaking will throw you in with random people so you end up not being able to start a game because 2 or more people are the same class. This happens half the time, meaning one of you has to change class or leave. This is really annoying when you're on high level operations and only have one class levelled up enough to be able to take it on.

All that aside, it's a solid game. Expect a challenge that rewards you.

As an esteemed member of the Adeptus Astartes (or as I like to call myself, "The Emperor's Last Hope"), I dove into Warhammer 40K: Space Marine with the enthusiasm of a Tech-Priest at a servo-skull convention. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint!

Graphics? More glorious than a Golden Throne selfie! The colors pop like a Chaos Space Marine at a paintball match.

Gameplay? Satisfying enough to make my Power Fist tingle! Nothing like smashing Tyranids into paste while shouting, "FOR THE EMPEROR!" to really get the blood pumping. (But seriously, I should probably tone down the yelling; the neighbors are starting to complain...)

Story? It’s about as deep as a puddle on a T'au world, but who cares? I’m here to turn Xenos into sludge and take names! I mean, let's be real: every plot twist just means more enemies to obliterate.

Multiplayer? Oh, the sweet joy of fragging my friends while they scream, "STOP USING THAT POWER FIST!" Sorry, bro! It’s the only way to ensure the Emperor's will is done.

Fun Factor? Off the charts! I laughed so hard my helmet nearly came off. I even tried to do the Space Marine walk in real life. Spoiler: I tripped over my cat.

Overall, if you want to experience the grim darkness of the far future with a side of hilarity and a dash of over-the-top violence, grab this game. Just remember: in the grim darkness of the 41st millennium, there is only war... and memes.

Pro Tip: Always carry a spare bolt gun. You never know when you'll need to shoot a heretic or your buddy during a heated debate about who’s the best Primarch.

Got several more hours into this beast, a quick update;

The Good;

- Visuals are fantastic
- Lore is pretty much 100% spot on
- Runs buttery smooth on a half decent pc setup
- Co-op operations feels like this is where the heart of the game is. A lot more fun when you have a full squad of human folks with you.
- Thunder Hammer
- Boss fights are actually pretty fun, much improved over the weird QTE mess that they were back in SM1

The 'I'm still not too sure about this';

- Melee combat STILL feels off; clunky, slow, laggy and feels unresponsive more than half the time.
- Parrying is still wildly inconsistent and windows for them can be very tiny and next to impossible to execute if you're already in an attack chain or getting swarmed and stunlocked by gaunts.
- Bolters sound and feel the best they've ever been in a 40k game but ranged combat as a whole still feels weak and needs to get buffed.
- Even though playing with friends IS a better experience, that's honestly on your friends and not the game.
- The customization grind is very slow, and you get no exp for doing the campaign; operations and PVP only.

The Bad;

- Healing still feels wrong; in the OG you go into melee and rip & tear to get your health back with executions, in this one you get your health back via the Bloodborne rally system and armour via executions; issue is that you will be swamped 9/10 and what health you get back is instantly gone making. You HAVE to chain the pistol one tap gimmick to keep your armour up in the thick of it which gets tedious quickly.
- Ranged enemies still strip your armour and health super fast and with insane precision. Especially them venom cannon warriors.
- Zonethropes are TINY. WHY YOU SO SMALL???
- Ai team mates are useless in the campaign but weirdly more competent in the operations if you happen to have an empty slot.
- QTE enemies still feel like a cheap death.
- Solo play still feels miserable; a.i. will focus on you only and ignore your a.i. team mates. If you have other humans with you it does split the aggro which is really weird.

I feel if you got a good amount of 40k buddies this'll serve you well for a bit, but playing solo will most likely be a worse off experience.

With no spoilers, my review of Space Marine 2's story is summed up as thus:

The perfect sequel to the first game.


It has some flaws currently, but all of these are outweighed by the gameplay and story.

Chief among them SO FAR:

-Co Op does not support private lobbies YET
-Co Op is limited to 3 players (If they double it or at least don't intervene in modding then this will make the game even more popular)
-Assorted nitpicks about particular weapons (IE certain heavy attacks not staggering enemies out of unblockable attacks is infuriating in some cases)
-Certain difficulty scaling elements feel excessive or fall more into the Frustrating camp than challenging camp
-Coop squads can only have one of any class, which while i understand is going to make more people unhappy than happy
- THAT MASSIVE TEASE in the main that left me with the most blue of ultra smurf balls!

But like I said, those are all nitpicks. Overall I give this game a 9/10 with a 10/10 for the story.


I was also EXTREMELY happy to see that GW's recent infestation by slaaneshi cultists has had effectively 0 impact on the game's story.

A game with awesome visuals that stays true to the lore of 40k. I only want to talk about the cons.

The veteran diffculty mode which is the default mode, is scaled for coop multiplayer. Doing it alone is doable but an annoying experience.

Was misled into thinking this was gonna be a casual shooting gallery but its a totally stressful experience on single player. A mission required me for example to use a flame thrower to drive away fodder enemies but there are tanky flying mobs that will shoot at you at the same time. Add to that there will be heavily armored mobs also attacking you. The AI in this barely do anything and so youre left having to multitask your ass off.

Some other proof that the difficulty is scaled for coop is that ranged mobs do sooo much damage and also very tanky. Clearly you need a teammate that has to focus those.

Thumbs down for now but I will keep playing at this difficulty because iam a total badass.


EDIT: I found out that the campaign is not very long and it does get easier later on in singleplayer. What I've said above don't feel like an issue anymore which is why i'm changing it to thumbs up. Also thumbs up because I also want them to make more 40k games like this in the future.

That being said I still believe there are some weird design choices that they've made with this game and something about it feels incomplete. Making this game is a step in the right direction but they need to do better.

Finally a good Warhammer game.

I recommend this for the feeling of the universe of 40k and because so many other people are having fun. I deeply, deeply hate the combat 95% of the time.

This game nails the feeling of W40k and being a Space Marine. You feel heavy but can dodge around, the swings of a chainsword feel meaty, and the bolters are incredible. The environments are baroque and huge and, usually, covered in blood and ichor and on fire. Seriously, the world-building and general feel of the game is A+ 150%.
The sound effects and music are also A+. Maybe more than that... the voice acting is excellent, of course, but every weapon sounds perfect, the chunk of a door opening is perfect, etc. Love every second of it.

The jump pack could be the entire game and I would love it.

The graphics options are barebones. Needs more granularity, and even with upscaling disabled (probably? hard to tell the way the two AA and upscaling options are described) everything is vaguely fuzzy... which is too bad because the details are awesome, right down to the stamping on bolter shells, the wear and tear on a command console, the burning candle on a servo skulls head.

Anyway, I hate the combat. To be clear, this is a skill issue. I'm old and I've destroyed my brain (don't do drugs).
I hate quick time events, and I'm bad at them... and the combat in this game is all QTE's.
You dodge the red ones, you block the blue ones. But you also block the non-telegraphed attacks, and when you do that just right you can then click to fire and get some armor back. Then you click to swing your chainsword, and maybe start a combo, or maybe you get tagged by the 1000 fodder that are surrounding you, or maybe you randomly spin to hit them and the big guy hits you... and everything staggers you, so then you spend a bunch of time lurching uncontrollably around trying to hit the right button at the right time.

Basically, you spend every combat watching for a small crosshair icon on an individual Tyranid so you can click to fire and keep your armor up, and hopefully get them to the point where you can press E to execute. The rest of combat is listening for the chime of an unblockable attack. In big fights, the chiming is constant so my chances to actually attack are few and far between. There's a fight early on with a Ripper swarm and two Zoanthropes, and the chiming was so constant I literally couldn't left click or I'd be hit with something horrible.

I don't play Dark Souls for a reason... but having said that the fights I like most are the boss fights with big honking enemies... it's still just a QTE, but you don't have lethal distractions like fodder jumping on your back and somehow staggering you for 4 seconds.

The armor system seems neat at first, but it's just a layer over your health bar that recovers in chunks... and gets taken away so fast that I don't see the point. Does it prevent stagger? Doesn't seem like it, although I'm so bad at blocking that I probably just never have any armor nodes.

The first game was simple, sure, but straightforward and efficient. Shoot a bit until you're in range, then swing that chainsword, and execute for health restore. In this game, you can restore a bit of armor with the dumb stagger/gunshot thing, or a bit more with an execution.
But I'm too dumb to hit any of the buttons at the right time, so I just spend my time dodging and blocking and hoping the trash AI companions will actually shoot things if they aren't caught on a crate or door frame.

I switched to easy, but then combat is boring... and it's still just a big continuous QTE.

I'll play through every bit of content, of course, because the story is rad and the companion characters are fun, unlike that whiny ♥♥♥♥♥ Leandros from the first one. The Ultramarines are lame, but the developers are continuing the story and that's great.

There are bugs with overlapping dialog (on my system anyway), but otherwise I'll totally free of the challenges some other folks are having.

Some tips for new players

- This is a team game without co-ordination you will die yes you're strong but swarms can and will melt your health bar so don't rush in like cod and then disconnect because you died

- Stop hoarding loot especially if you're a melee class theirs no reason for you to take loot from the heavy such as Ammo the heavy cannot use a melee weapon so by taking the ammo from him you've effectively made him useless.

- Prep your gear before hand (tired of waiting 60 seconds to go to a mission because you decided to spent ages customising plus it saves time) so do it before hand or leave matchmaking to do it

- Executions give you armour so while cool they offer you that armour that could save you plus while doing so you cannot take damage so it's a win win

- only 1 class per mission so make sure none of your friends have the class you want eyed up

- Requisition is the currency used and can be used to upgrade and buy new cosmetics so ideally only buy 1 set as it can be a pain to grind and only 990 can be held so spend it before doing another mission

- This is 40K and for those unaware Space Marines have 3 hearts which has translated to 3 lives after which you will die and respawn so try to spend it wisely and move as a unit

- Servitors are found by looking around each mission and will offer you a skill point only one of you needs to activate it and you should all get a skill point

But most importantly have fun

Space Marine 2 is bringing back the same iconic protagonist, Captain Titus, but this time he’s a Primaris Space Marine, which is even more exciting. The scope looks grander, with epic battles against Tyranids—the perfect enemies for fast-paced, swarm-based action. I can already imagine the chaotic battles, the intense gore, and that satisfying weight behind every attack.

From a visual and gameplay standpoint, everything looks bigger and better. The environments appear more detailed, the combat seems even smoother and more brutal, and I’m especially eager to see how they’ve updated the lore and narrative. The cinematic trailers and early gameplay footage show a real commitment to honoring the 40K universe while also evolving the game.

What really has me hooked, though, is the potential for co-op multiplayer. Fighting alongside friends as a squad of Space Marines, facing insurmountable odds together—it's going to be glorious. Space Marine 2 has the potential to take everything I loved about the first game and crank it up to a new level.

In short, I love everything about the Space Marine 2 concept—the lore, the gameplay, the atmosphere—it’s shaping up to be a perfect continuation of the original's legacy.

Title: An Unforgettable Galactic Triumph – Space Marine 2 Takes the Crown!

From the very first moment I launched into Space Marine 2, it was clear that this game is a masterclass in delivering high-octane, immersive action. Building on the success of its predecessor, this sequel elevates the Warhammer 40,000 universe to new heights, and I can’t recommend it highly enough!

The graphics are nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in the environments and character designs is remarkable, making each battle feel like a cinematic experience. The grim, dark atmosphere of the Warhammer 40K universe is perfectly captured, drawing players into a world where every corner teems with intensity and epic scale.

Gameplay is where Space Marine 2 truly shines. The combat mechanics are incredibly polished, offering a seamless blend of strategic depth and adrenaline-pumping action. The new and improved weapons and abilities give players a variety of ways to approach each encounter, whether you’re a fan of heavy firepower or tactical melee strikes. The sense of power and impact when commanding your Space Marine is incredibly satisfying, making every battle feel both exhilarating and monumental.

The story is engaging and well-crafted, with a narrative that pulls you deeper into the lore of the Warhammer 40K universe. The characters are well-developed, and the voice acting is top-notch, adding depth to the already compelling storyline. The plot twists and dramatic moments keep you on the edge of your seat, ensuring that the campaign is as captivating as it is action-packed.

Multiplayer is also a standout feature, with a range of modes that cater to both competitive and cooperative play. The variety of maps and the balance of gameplay make it easy to find something that suits your style, while the community feels vibrant and welcoming.

Overall, Space Marine 2 is a triumph that every fan of the genre and the Warhammer 40K universe should experience. It combines stunning visuals, fluid gameplay, and a gripping story into a package that is as enjoyable as it is epic. Whether you’re a long-time fan or new to the series, this game is a must-play. Get ready to don your power armor and dive into one of the most exhilarating experiences in gaming today!

I have waited for this game longer then i want to admit. Im a 40k freak and therefore it is kind hard to stay "objective" while leaving a review. However, i will try...
From the get go what really pulled me in is the atmosphere, lore and the story. While there is not hours upon hours of that... the things that were there, are great...
The visuals are on another level, this is all i ever wanted for a WH40k game. Last achieved with the Deathwing game everything else has fallen short on the promise to deliver...
Yes, Necromunda and Darktide are "interesting", something was always missing.
Here... not so much... i feel like im in this world with all its brutal harshness and grotesque beauty.
The story made sense.. like 95% of the time and was interesting especially if you have played the first game. No worries you dont have to play the first one to be able to follow. But it would make more sense.

On the mechanical side of the game, this is not really my game... and by that i mean im to old to really be able to follow all the fast paced action. I try and die more often then i would like to admit, but yet i have not given up. Most interactions make sense including the inputs. The animations and the movements seem plausible and flow very nice. All in all a good game which i really enjoy to play, if im good at it or not...

One of the bad things, which has been brought up quite often is the missing for widescreen support... YET. The developer promised to get this fixed.. lets see.

All in all i had no bugs that stopped me from playing or irritated me during my playtime. In fact i would say it is one of the few examples now days that were released in a not desolated state.
Yes there seem to be bugs for several people... but i have not encountered any.

Never forget to double check, how many people are playing the game and how many reviews it got from players. It puts it very well in perspective. :)

I had the impression it was shorter than the first game, but when I checked, it took me 3 hours longer to beat this one. I think that's because the orks had a lot of personality. The tyranid just...run up and die. They squeal a lot. It's not as cool as I hoped.

Warhammer 40k: Space Marine 2 is an incredibly fun and immersive experience. The action-packed game-play and brutal combat make you feel truly powerful. The visuals and atmosphere are also top-notch, drawing you right into the gritty, war-torn future of the 40k setting.

However, the inability to use a fully-customized class in the story-mode/campaign can be frustrating, as you're locked into what the game assigns. I really enjoy playing Bulwark, so this restriction limits player choice and flexibility, which would have added a great deal of replayability, outside of the 6 currently available co-op "operations". Additionally, the AI of your allies when playing solo is noticeably weak. They're often more of a hindrance than a help, lacking the tactical awareness needed to support your efforts effectively, becoming more of a personal "revive bot" than anything else. Despite these issues, the overall experience is still a blast, with intense battles and satisfying game-play that I can foresee myself playing for awhile to come.

All and all, this is a very solid game. Is it game of the year? Probably not. But, this is one of my FAVORITE releases this year.

As a long-time Warhammer 40k fan, Space Marine 2 delivers everything I could have hoped for and more! Whether you're a veteran of the franchise or a newcomer to the grimdark future, this game is an absolute blast to play.

What I Loved:

🔥 Combat: The combat is fast, brutal, and gloriously satisfying. Every swing of your Thunder Hammer feels impactful, and the fluid combat mechanics make you feel like an unstoppable force of nature. The melee and ranged combat balance is spot-on, allowing you to switch between the two seamlessly depending on the chaos around you.

🎮 Controls and Movement: Movement is smooth and precise, with the agility you’d expect from an enhanced Ultramarine. The jetpack sections take things to another level—literally! Jumping into the fray from above is exhilarating.

🌌 Atmosphere and Visuals: The grimdark future of the 41st millennium is faithfully represented here. From the towering gothic architecture to the menacing presence of the Tyranid hordes, the atmosphere immerses you in the brutal and unforgiving universe of Warhammer 40k.

👹 Enemies: Facing off against Tyranids is both terrifying and thrilling. Their relentless swarming attacks keep you on your toes, and they look fantastic with excellent creature design. You feel like you’re battling an overwhelming force, yet every kill is immensely rewarding.

🎭 Story and Lore: The narrative captures the essence of Warhammer 40k perfectly. The voice acting, especially for Titus and his battle-brothers, brings out the stoic intensity of the Space Marines. While the lore is deep, newcomers can still enjoy the core storyline without feeling lost.

Minor Gripes:

If I had to nitpick, some missions could feel a bit repetitive in design, but the sheer fun of combat more than makes up for it. Also, I would love to see even more enemy variety in future expansions or updates.

Overall Verdict:

If you're a fan of Warhammer 40k or action-packed third-person shooters, Space Marine 2 is a must-play. It’s a glorious power fantasy that makes you feel like a true champion of humanity. Between the epic combat, stunning visuals, and faithful dedication to the source material, this game is a home run. The Emperor would be proud!

Let me tell you, "Space Marine 2" is the Warhammer 40k game we've all been dreaming of while chanting "For the Emperor!" in the shower. We're discussing a game that grabs you by the Power Armor and doesn't let go. I’m giving this bad boy a solid 8.5 to 9 out of 10, and here’s why it’s set the new standard for all Warhammer 40k games.

First off, the gameplay. If you thought Titus was a beast in the first game, he’s come back beefier and even more ridiculously heroic than ever. This time around, he’s rocking an even bigger gun and an even more righteous zeal to purge every alien that dares exist in his vicinity. Combat is a glorious ballet of bolter fire, chainsword cleaving, and the kind of over-the-top violence that makes Mortal Kombat look like a tea party. The fluidity of the combat mechanics makes every swing and shot feel weighty, like you're genuinely punching through hordes of Tyranids and heretics with a literal ton of ceramite-covered rage. Dont get me started on the classes. Each class feels good (however some feel better than others) and I love the progression for each type of class and weapon. It brings you back every time to catch that "carrot".

Let’s talk visuals. "Space Marine 2" looks chef's kiss gorgeous. My god there were multiple times me and my mates had to stop and just soak in the world. Saber truly captures the size of the world and how (even though we are hella tall) small we are in this grand universe. The environments are more Warhammer than the actual Warhammer lore—yes, somehow they found a way. Gothic cathedrals that reach the sky, shattered hive cities, and endless fields of carnage are painted with a level of detail that makes you feel like you’re right there on the front lines, choking on the smoke of burning heretics and inhaling the incense of Imperial piety.

Now, let's get into the narrative. Unlike other Warhammer 40k games, where plotlines are often an afterthought stapled together with grimdark tropes, "Space Marine 2" actually gives us a story that's engaging and, dare I say, coherent. The plot doesn't just serve as a backdrop to the carnage; it makes you care about the carnage. The game delivers on those big cinematic moments, and Titus' journey feels like it has stakes beyond just his survival—though don’t get me wrong, there's plenty of "If it bleeds, we can chainsword it!" action to go around.

But the true shining beacon here, the reason why "Space Marine 2" has set the new standard for Warhammer 40k games, is that it understands what makes Warhammer 40k special: the vibe. This isn't just a game for people who like Warhammer—this is a game for people who have ever thought, “I’d like to be the angriest man in the galaxy, preferably while wielding a gun that sounds like the angry growl of a cornered chainsaw.” It captures the sheer absurdity and grandiosity of the Warhammer 40k universe better than anything before it, and that's saying something in a franchise where the stakes are always, quite literally, the fate of the universe. I honestly believe this is what Darktide should've and could've been. But since they dropped the ball so hard nice to see someone who came in and just blew me away. I've enjoyed every second of this game and I am only hoping and praying that we continue to see live support for many many years.

Sure, it's not perfect. There are a few bugs here and there like the occasional Tyranid stuck T-posing in the background like it's auditioning for a sci-fi musical, or you're somehow flying thorugh the air, or even better you somehow ended dying on an evelaytor and then proceeded with the entire map laying on the ground without touching anything. But when you’re tearing through enemies as a Space Marine, who has time to care about a few rough edges?

So, is "Space Marine 2" perfect? No. But is it a blast of a game that raises the bar for what a Warhammer 40k title can be? Absolutely. If you're a fan of the 40k universe or just love some good old-fashioned over-the-top action, this game should be on your radar.

Now go, brave battle brother, and purge those xenos scum. The Emperor protects—but a solid 8.5-9/10 game experience certainly doesn't hurt either.

Warhammer 40K: Space Marine 2 – A Triumph of Tactical Warfare and Epic Storytelling

Warhammer 40K: Space Marine 2 is nothing short of a masterful triumph in the realm of action-packed shooters and immersive storytelling. Building upon the solid foundation of its predecessor, this sequel amplifies everything fans loved while introducing exciting new elements that elevate the experience to new heights.

Visuals and Atmosphere: From the moment you dive into the game, it’s clear that Space Marine 2 is a visual feast. The grimdark world of the Warhammer 40K universe has never looked better. The intricate details of the environments, from the desolate battlefields to the labyrinthine interiors of war-torn structures, are rendered with stunning clarity. The atmospheric effects, such as the smoke of battle and the flickering lights of warzones, add layers of realism that immerse you deeply into the dark and gritty world of the Imperium.

Gameplay and Mechanics: The gameplay is where Space Marine 2 truly shines. The combat mechanics have been refined to perfection, offering a blend of visceral melee and strategic ranged combat. The power of the Space Marine’s weapons and abilities feels both awe-inspiring and satisfying. The improvements in the fluidity of combat, combined with the introduction of new abilities and a more dynamic enemy AI, ensure that battles remain thrilling and engaging from start to finish.

Story and Character Development: The narrative in Space Marine 2 is a testament to the strength of Warhammer 40K’s lore. The story delves deeper into the grim fate of the galaxy, presenting a narrative that is both epic and personal. The character development is rich, and the protagonist’s journey is both heroic and fraught with sacrifice. The voice acting and dialogue are top-notch, delivering a storyline that is as emotionally resonant as it is action-packed.

Multiplayer and Replayability: The multiplayer experience has been significantly enhanced, offering a range of modes that cater to both casual players and competitive gamers. The cooperative missions are particularly noteworthy, allowing you to team up with friends to tackle the horde of enemies in strategic and satisfying ways. Additionally, the game’s replayability is bolstered by its extensive customization options and multiple difficulty levels, ensuring that players have ample reasons to return to the fray.

Overall Experience: Warhammer 40K: Space Marine 2 is a stellar addition to the Warhammer franchise. It successfully balances intense, strategic combat with a compelling narrative and breathtaking visuals. Whether you’re a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer eager to experience the chaos of the 41st millennium, this game offers an exhilarating journey that is not to be missed.

I want to say firstly, this is the ONLY game I've ever played where I went with the in game suggested difficulty setting, and died in the tutorial. I personally believe there are some balancing issues, but you could just as easily read this and think "skill issue" so I'll move on from the difficulty, but I feel as if advertising Veteran (the third out of four difficulties) as the way the game is meant to be played, may dissuade new players, especially those who may not have anyone real to fill their squad.

On to the game issues, and let me preface this by saying aside from the tutorial, all of my game time was with a friend in co-op, him on ps5 and me on PC. With that in mind the number of times we had game breaking connection issues was, unfortunately, very high. It would say he'd join my lobby successfully and then it would stick him in an eternal loading screen and he'd have to restart the game to try again. Same thing happened with me trying to join him on multiple occasions with the only solution to be, restart and try again. The final straw for me was about halfway through a mission, an elevator took us into a loading screen and when I loaded in, my buddy was stuck in the infinite load again and could not rejoin the mission even after several attempts and troubleshooting.

I personally had a lot of audio issues, where all of the audio would cut out or seem to skip every now and again, noticing it most frequently when there was a lot going on, but even at the start of the second (first real) mission while I was just standing at the start of the level the audio was skipping. I also experienced weird character animation hiccups (for lack of a better word). I would sometimes notice an enemy, or myself start an attack animation, and then hang in that first frame for a few moments until it would then skip forward and complete the ending of the animation. It's a funky issue that I've never experienced. Maybe it's graphically related, but I'm getting a pretty steady 60 frames (which is what I cap everything at) on medium to high graphic settings. So I wouldn't think it would have to do with that, but who knows. (really, if anyone knows please share)

TLDR: This game is a lot of fun when it works properly but me and my co-op buddy experienced a ton of connection issues that prevented us from playing together, and even ruined an entire mission.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Why you should buy this game:

- Fun, satisfying, gory gameplay.

- This game is actually masculine, unlike most of the crap that has comes out of the gaming industry lately (think Dustborn and Condord).

- Amazing graphics and art direction. This game has serious style.

- Campaign AND Mutliplayer (has both PvP and PvE modes), just like how games used to be. Horde mode also coming soon.

- NO PRIDE FLAGS, NO WOKE DIALOGUE, NO FORCED "DIVERSITY": ABSOLUTELY ZERO WOKE TRASH (unlike Call of Duty). That way, you can actually be immersed in the game instead of being reminded every 5 seconds about the real world's societal problems. The funny part is, the main trio of the game is a white guy, a black guy, and an asian guy, but people are still crying about this game not being diverse enough. You can never please these people, so luckily this game doesn't try. This game is what REAL diversity looks like, where it is actual diversity without being cringe and forced (another good example would be Sergeant Major Johnson from Halo). Even though Games Wokeshop has been pandering to these people lately by changing the Warhammer lore, none of that crap made it past the devs into this game.

While it's not absolutely perfect, this game is a shining example of what games should be. It's immersive, it's got a lot of content, and it's just plain old fun; something that a lot of games recently don't know how to be. It is very much a golden era Xbox 360 game released in the modern day. If you don't know if you want to buy it just look up a gameplay video and if it makes you go "Hell yea!" then get it, you'll have a blast. I also recommend playing through or at least watching a story recap of the first Space Marine game, since this one continues the story of the original. It would also benefit you to research some of the Warhammer 40k lore since it will help you understand/appreciate the game more. Overall this game is a SOLID 8/10 and I'm glad to see the shift in gaming lately toward more games like this.

Difficulty seems inconsistent and doesn't feel good (on Veteran, the games stated intended difficulty), its either a fun time fulfilling the power fantasy of a Space Marine or it's just crushingly difficult/annoying, with most of that time being spent in the latter. Even on the easiest difficulty of the co-op PvE, same experience with my friends that are long time shooter players.

Some enemy combos during missions feel cripplingly annoying. Barb wire energy spam along with locust swarm knock downs while green fog to make it so you can't see anything more than 5 feet in front of you? Or what about swarm knock downs with flying energy blasts that also knock you down, to pinball you around? All the while getting swarmed by basic melee guys. Or gun enemies shooting you in revolutionary war style firing lines from behind long waves of enemies and elites.

For me personally its just been pushing through waves of annoyance to get to the cool set pieces or brief moments of feeling like a one man army Space Marine.

Maybe it's me? Maybe it's poorly balanced? Maybe its both? I'll play more and see if my view changes or, fingers crossed, they update the game with some difficulty adjustments.

edit: lowered the difficulty to normal, and it was a much better experience. Normal felt like easy in terms of how difficult it was but at least I wasn't getting frustrated with the game as much any longer. Changed my review to positive after finishing the campaign. If you had any of the same feelings as I had above, then lower the difficulty and its a better experience (albeit one that is much too easy).

After playing a bit more, I wanted to add a few more things to my review -

Control set up is not great for PC. I was hoping for control similar to Darktide / Vermintide (or Helldivers 2). Not even close. I had watched several reviews and many comparisons were made to Darktide, this seems to have been regarding the co-op and the aesthetic of the game, however (not control set up). UPDATE: So, I decided to go ahead and finish the game despite sub-par performance. It's a grand spectacle, and there's a lot to enjoy. However, the game doesn't really change much at all from the opening hours to the final ones. The first game is similar, but that was also 13 years ago. The production value is insane here, so there's something to be said for that, but I really wish there was a hair more depth to the game. As it stands, it's a good sequel, but it still feels like a game from a decade past.

The performance doesn't get any better. With a 4090, my performance is the same on highest or lowest settings. At 4k, the game eventually settles around 60fps max, with LOTS of time spent in the 30s and 20s. It's just the nature of the game. It's not impressive, not by a long shot, and it's one of my major qualms with the game still. Multiplayer is pretty much a nonstop sub-60 fps fest, but it is what it is. The PvE is good fun and challenging.

In the end, I'll update my review to positive, but only because I think the overall experience is a positive one. The performance sucks, and there's not a lot of innovation here. If this was Joe Action Game, it'd be little disappointing, but as such a fan of the original game and the WH40k universe, I can't help but support and be a little biased.

ORIGINAL

The first game is one of my all-time favorite games and, aside from Rogue Trader now, my favorite WH40k game. This game, from the beginning and what little I've played, has surpassed expectations and seems like it could be the sequel we've all been waiting for.

However, even with a 4090 on lowest settings, the performance seems very disappointing (80fps at best, 45fps at worst). They've confirmed DLSS3 support coming, which likely means Frame Gen is coming, and it seems like this game needs it bad.

I hate to wait, but I'm going to have to. Cannot recommend this game in it's current state as getting 60fps consistently at 4k even with aggressive upscaling isn't possible. However, I'm hopeful for updates. As soon as Frame Gen comes to the game or we see some significant performance optimizations, I'm back in a heartbeat.

I purchased this game on a whim to play with friends, without watching the trailer, and with only seeing a few minutes of gameplay.

Initially i was impressed by the graphics, sound design, and the visceral combat. I don't know if ripping Tyranids and heretics apart will ever get old.

However, the campaign, while relatively brief, was nothing short of a masterpiece. Most co-op campaigns use well-tested tropes and techniques that we've all seen dozens of times at this point (if you're a fan of co-op games, anyway). Space Marine 2's campaign felt pretty standard at first, but i was pleasantly surprised to find a plethora of original ideas, practically all of them i won't share for the sake of spoilers.

As the campaign was reaching its end, i kept thinking to myself "My GOD this is good", and after every moment where i got that feeling, the next moment somehow one upped what i had just experienced, reaching a roaring crescendo towards the end. When the story was over, I felt satisfied, despite it only taking ~10hrs.

This story will leave you with memorable moments, in addition to incredible spectacle, and bad ass combat. This is easily one of if not the best co-op stories i have ever played, and i will certainly be running the campaign again on harder difficulties.

In the 15 hours i've played so far, the only bugs i've experienced were sound and camera related. I did one "Operation" (PvE co-op) where it sounded like my space marine was in a fishbowl during the entire mission, which i fixed by restarting the game after the mission ended. I've also had my third person perspective get a little wild during executions a few times, but it always resolved itself after a few seconds.

All in all, i don't regret paying the full price for this title. Worth every dollar already and i expect to be playing it regularly for quite a while.

Firstly, I can't tell you whether you should or not should buy this game. That is for you to decide on your own. All I will do is give my opinion. WARNING - THIS POST WILL CONTAIN SOME SPOILERS.

This is not a review that is heavily pro or heavily negative but in the middle. "bUt yOu rEcoMmEndEd iT" - yes, because its positives are that its designed to primarily serve one community and that is the 40k one; but those new to this universe not so much, but I digress....

PROS:
- If you're a 40k fan, especially one who played the first game and loved it (key word - "loved"), then this will not disappoint you in terms of its aesthetics, campaign and options to update your armour during multiplayer (eternal war) and operations mode.

- From what I can recall, compared to the first game, this one has more classes with a higher level of customisation.

- Learning the controls is easy, whatever the class and combinations are intuitive and flow mostly OK.

- Learning the levelling up system is also easy.

- If you want the exact same look at feel (just more polished) as the last game, then you will like this.

CONS:
- The game feels like it's designed as a bull run to me (especially during operations). It seems too narrow and although it's designed very similar to the first game to keep you on task, it has a flat and one dimensional look to it. Most genres of games, have moved on as tastes have expanded. It would have been so much better to have had the world expanded more given that you're a 8ft tall Primaris Astartes, running around in tank armour.

- Movement.... As stated above, you're an 8ft tall super soldier...but you can't climb over ANYTHING that isn't a set of steps or a designated pathway, nor do any form of 'parkour', nor use any ladders, you can't climb on any walls or jump AT ALL. The movement hasn't moved on at all past the first game. You can turn around, slow walk, walk, run and forward roll... To me this is just unacceptable now and the design team dropped the ball with the movement/physics. It wouldn't even be outside the lore to have the Astartes do any of the above - they'd be pretty useless marines if they couldn't do any of that, and this falls into the issue with the bull run look of the game. Nothing has moved on in this manner since 2011, and I found that a real let down. Even 343 got that right with Halo Infinite, and that's saying something given how much people have hated 343(!) But Space Marine 2 is well below standard.

- Combat. The entire system seems designed around getting you get up close ("bEcAuSe tHaTs wHaT aStArTeS dO") so you can engage in a combat cinematic over and over again. This is not inherently bad, it's just not everything you want to do at every moment. Because of this felt need to get up close, the projectile weapons are a let down. They don't have anywhere near the impact that they should (even from a lore aspect!), and given you're fighting mass wave attacks of enemies (no matter what enemy faction), you're let down by the stopping power of your weapons. The lack of ammunition is also a problem when you can't even carry more than 200rds on you, despite the fact you're fighting enemies who's entire combat style is predicated on mass wave attacks to overwhelm you. This leads me onto the Melee/CQB weapons... These are fun, but nowhere near as effective as they should be. Again, you have to fight mass wave attacks and whilst it initially appears that you've just cut through a dozen nids in one blow, the reality is that you need to repeat that blow at least once more (combat knives take longer) to get the job done. With heavier units you need to slash through them many more times using your power sword or bash them in more with your warhammer. It just feels very deflated and ineffective and unfaithful to the lore from which this is all derived.

- Locked classes. This is a massive let down. So what if four of us want to run into a mission as Bulwark's or Heavies? The devs dropped the ball with this one also and this should be a thing of the past. People want to get together and game in their play style. They shouldn't be forced to choose one or the other.

So, it's over to you now. But in my experience, if I knew what I knew now, prior to purchase, I'd wait until its on sale and then if you really don't like it, you won't feel as let down. Unfortunately, this game hasn't moved on as far as I hoped it would have since 2011. Its fun, but when that fun is limited by game physics and play styles that are from over ten years ago, the fun can get a little dull and underwhelming. I have only put 'yes' to recommending this game if you're a real 40k fan who 'just has to have this'. If you are new to this game and 40k in general, think again before buying as you may end up quite disappointed.

It's a qualified recommend from me. I've been having a blast with it, it's the 40k vermintide I wanted from Darktide and never got. It's got some rough spots currently. A lot of crashes at startup, or trying to load things, though the good news is the crashes don't seem to happen mid gameplay. If you launch a game successfully you're not gonna crash during it. You might crash loading OUT of it, but it's never affected progress or rewards for me. Balancing seems a little off for higher difficulties, but I also see a lot of people playing the game poorly. (You can regen armor through finishers, parries, and shooting the little red target reticules! stop skipping the animations and dying as a result of it!) I expect most if not all of these issues will be ironed out in the coming month or so, and some of the server stresses atm are likely just from it being the new hot game. But these are all important in the "need it now, can deal with that" vs "eugh ok maybe I wait for a month/sale" balance.

I will say, several times during the campaign, myself and the people i was playing with had absolute jaw dropping moments of "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥", or "wait, look over there". It's pretty in a "next gen" kind of way I've not felt in maaaaany years.

One of the better 40k games in recent years.
The graphics are insane, the movement and animations really give the feeling of playing a 8 foot super soldier. The combat is fun, hitting a perfect parry following up with a gunstrike never gets old. The finishers are gory and glorious. The voice acting is very well done.
It has a good campaign (co-op with 2 others), some decent PvE (Operations) and PvP.

However, the gameplay loop is what you'll be doing most, if you don't mesh with it, you'll unlikely enjoy it. If you find it addicting, you'll be hooked like I am.

My only real downside is the lack of content. Campaign can be finished in 11 hours or less, and has no achievement for playing on the hardest difficulty setting.
PvE (Operations) only has 6 maps with little variation between difficulties.
PvP only has a mere 3 maps, with 3 game modes and has it's own set of issues.

An Epic account is needed for online. Only PvE & Campaign are crossplatform. PvP is not.

Hopefully, more content gets added and other issues get resolved. But as a fan of the Warhammer 40k universe and super soldiers, I'd say it's worth it.

Story is your basic simple plot shooter experience with cool moments of hype, 8-10h for me and some friends. PvE is very barebones (3 maps with 3 modes) but is surprisingly fun with very quick sub 10m matches. The best part about this game by far is the customisation options, you can really make a space marine to call your own (RIP on chaos customisation though). All in all, if you love the feel of 40k this is a no brainer buy imo but from a pure gameplay standpoint I can see why someone would not like this, not a game for everyone.

If you are a Warhammer fan, just buy it already.

But for those who wants more convincing:
DISCLAIMER: This is a hybrid hack and slash + 3rd person shooter. You will run out of bullets so learn the melee combos.

-Single player
I bought in with the expectation for a good single player game and it sure is an extremely pretty looking game.
The story is a concentrated testosterone serious to the bone hero who is fighting against all sorts of evil and the atmosphere of the environment strongly immerse you onto how grim the situation is being the last bastion of mankind.
Though it only takes me about 10 hrs to complete the campaign, it is definitely not an easy game and dying is inevitable especially for those who do not posses the tactical awareness and reflex to avoid damage from quick time events.
The game force you to not rely on your guns as the shear volume of enemies thrown at you challenge you to consider using your ammunition strategically as melee combat is inevitable, and at the same time running in blindly with a sword is also a guaranteed death sentence. Focus on environmental hazards like explosive barrel and the likes to take out swarms and remember to use you grenades and you will find success especially on the higher difficulty settings.
Your AI companion are just walking emotional support characters as they don't seem to do much against enemies and their only purpose is the draw enemies attention away from you and revive you when ever you go down.
I personally have not try this feature but it seems that you can invite friends to join you in your single player campaign and I do hope that would spread the work load of killing, making it more enjoyable to progress.


There is Co-op and Competitive mode.
I have yet try competitive mode as i am not profoundly interested in that aspect, however the co-op game play currently still contain game breaking bugs which could prevents you from loading into a game. This occurs randomly (every other game). The Dev's seems to be aware of it and has pledge to fix it in the up and coming patch, thus I'l hold them to it and update my review when i see it fix.

There are a good amount of classes, variation and upgrades for the multiplayer mode that I can foresee giving the game much longevity. The Co-op mode is much more enjoyable than the campaign due to the fact that actual player are contributing to the fight, sharing the burden of the onslaught. Teamwork is still important as a singled out player can be easily dispatched by a swarm.

All in all, a very solid game.

Could have used more execution animations too, it becomes really obvious that there's only a couple after the first few missions.
That being said there's a lot of replayability in the PvE content due to how fun the combat is. The "not Tyranid" missions suck because the whole combat system just doesn't feel as good against more standard enemies, thankfully they're only 2.5 out of the 6 maps.
Oh and you get to play dress up with your Space Marines which is tip-top.

A simple and fun game that feels like it came out of the Xbox 360 era in terms of what it offers. You get a solid campaign, a fun co-op mode with some replay-ability and a decent albeit unbalanced multiplayer experience without any obtrusive microtransactions.

Space Marine 2 will likely only get better with time, especially once they introduce the horde mode which seems what much of the game was designed for.

My biggest complaint about the game though is its difficulty/balancing. The game in itself is not hard in most scenarios, but having played through the story on the hardest mode and sunk a few hours into multiplayer I think there are some things that need major tweaking.

For starters, the Armour/health system is awful. Armor is weak and you get melted by the 20-30 by gunners mixed into a crowd of swarms. The difficulty is artificial at best and is only made worse by how tanky enemies are. On Angel of Death (The Hardest difficulty) some enemies can take a literal 120 rounds of a heavy bolt gun depending on the range. That is 3 full magazines of ammo which is almost your entire ammo reserve. And these aren't even bosses, these are just common enemies that you fight over and over. It leads to so many fights being such a slog and because of the sheer amount of ranged units mixed in with melee units mixed in with specials that just constantly AoE you, you are forced to sit behind cover near ammo just whittling enemies down.

The game feels like it wants you to engage in more melee combat, but melee combat doesn't refill your health like it did in the first game so you are constantly out of health and armour as the only way to restore it is through stimpaks which seem to barely exist and refill very little health or Titus special tactic which takes like 10 minutes to recharge. I think if you restored health from melee combat the game would make more sense but for the moment its just frustrating because you will either get shot or jumped on from enemies that are off screen that you have no idea are there and this just repeats for the entire game. Some missions are especially frustrating as you are forced to defend objects while 40 enemies will be jumping on you preventing you from moving and slowly taking damage, all the while you are being shot at and explosions from other specials go off around you. Sometimes it feels like you don't even have time to shoot and you are forced to make the choice of lose 90% of your health or take the objective.

Multiplayer doesn't have the issue as health and armour will restore on their own over time and it is quick. But multiplayer definitely needs some balancing. Some classes are simply just way better than others and because you are limited to only 2 players per team using a single class, someone has to take the lesser class. Vanguard especially is broken as they can grapple you and in a 1v1 situation, it is a guaranteed loss for you unless you have team mates backing you up that can kill the attacker while he is stuck pulling towards you.

Overall, the game is solid and I do highly recommend it for what it offers, but there is definitely lots of improvements that can be made. There is so many little issues that seem to add up that can make the experience frustrating at times but they are fixable.

I do recommend the game, but... with some caveats.

Are you a Warhammer 40k fan? Get it.
Are you an arcade shooter fan that wants to smash some stuff in a very satisfying way, but doesn't care about the challenge? Get it.
Do you want to experience the 40k world in all its glory? Definitely get it.
Played the Space Marine 1 and want to finish the story, sure. Get it.
The hype around it is justified, because we finally get a good 40K game.

Now, let's talk about the ACTUAL game.

The world building is incredible. Attention to detail and the lore is out of this world. Everything looks and feels like someone hearing about 40k for the first time might imagine it. It is beyond beautiful. Art direction is mind blowing.
Graphics are incredible, VFX is impactful and animations are weighty and very well done overall.
Whoever figured out the optimization is a dev god and nothing less. Besides LODs, I see a lot of smart use of video/sprite particles that imitate 3D objects that add to the swarm combined with 3D models. It is so smartly done that I was just dumbfounded by how intelligent these devs are. This game runs WAY BETTER than it is supposed to.
Narratively the game is pretty solid. A good continuation of the story from the SM1 with a lot of explanations of what happened and why it happened. It paints a very bleak story open to discussion and puts Titus as one of my favorite game characters. His devotion and lack of ego is actually quite refreshing. Dropping one faction you were fighting mid campaign to fight the other is a bit clumsy, but so was SM1. Oh well.
When it comes to my solo campaign NPC teammates - I am torn. I grew to like them at the end, but for space marines, they act like petulant children and tend to piss me off. I like that they have some banter, but sometimes the way they behave is very unsoldierly like. It is like having two toddlers around at times...
In SM1, when Leandros reaches his boiling point (don't worry, spoiler free), he is passionate. Otherwise, there is a professional coldness to everyone's demeanor which is very befitting the Astartes.
Voice acting is so so SO good! Characters actually come to life with the level of acting and I appreciate all the effort that went into it.
Sound and music is also very solid. I don't remember any songs sticking out, but hey, I have the Mechanicus soundtrack for that.
Talking about Mechanicus, I love how they speak in their binary gawking. Super cool.

Level design is serviceable. It is mostly fine, but due to the combat requiring items and ammo, you will look around for resources only to end up at a dead end making you trot all the way back. It can get annoying, but it is okay.

Tyranids are a cool enemy narratively and thematically, but now we get into the weakest element for me personally, which is ironically the combat.
The way the combat is built is around tactical and precise shooting, with timed parry mechanics that regenerate your armor and health that is immediately depleted. The depleted health is reduced quickly so you have to get aggressive in order to replenish it, before it permanently drops. It can only be recovered by stims (which you will be chasing around constantly therefore level design can get annoying). Here is the kicker - Tyranids are nasty bug like aliens that have a weird body build. This means it is hard to read their moves when they telegraph an attack that you NEED to parry. The game throws a UX solution at you - blue notification overlay means PARRY, red notification means DODGE. The thing is - some tyranids attack right away when the blue flashes, some delay, some combo the move. The UI overlay distracts me from the actual moves. I finished the campaign on the Veteran difficulty and I can say that the game is so easy when you get to the Chaos section that Tyranids feel like the true enemy. Chaos are humanoid so reading them is much much more simple than the bugs.
The combat always feels a tiny bit off. You have moments where it is a power fantasy and you are just murdering. The other times, I am cheesing the game by staying out of enemy sight and picking them off. Even worse, I am dodging more than in a soulslike. What happens when you add a dodge roll, but no stamina on increased difficulty? You get bullet sponge bosses, aggressive attacks and you, a super soldier in tank armor dodge rolling like you're playing Elden Ring.

Friendly NPCs are useless in a fight. Difficulty is pretty much broken. As I mentioned, Veteran difficulty is me finishing it solo and using NPCs to rez me. Bosses are bullet sponges. All AI targets YOU. It can get very frustrating and I turned off the game a few times because of these moments.
I am doing operations now and it gets better with people, but doesn't every game?
Multiplayer is a lot of fun, but again, there is an issue with the parry system - I spent this whole time learning perfect parry and, logically, the PVP doesn't have it.
I am not a fan of a game teaching me a mechanic I have to rely on heavily with it being completely gone from the PVP.

So, I might get crucified for this, but I am not a huge fan of the combat. I want to do more operations and PvP, just because I want to unlock stuff, but I wouldn't replay it. I think it is a bit lukewarm. Sometimes the input felt like it was lagging and I am not sure if it is 100%. I know that it certainly felt this way because some moves - you are lightning fast. Others, you are sluggish and heavy.

Conclusion - for the true 40K fan and for the 40Kurious people out there that like arcade games.

SM2 - in its current state Brings you three prongs of content: First, a curated and well-written campaign, with 3 player coop (with unique interactions when played in such a manner, which was a nice touch). The two characters your "battle-brothers" play in said coop are fully written into the story whether they're piloted by the computer or your mates, and are not just jobbers who spectate the main characters' tasks. Being someone into the warhammer universe, I was presently aware of a lot of the story aspects - however friends of mine who are not in the scene at all also enjoyed the story and plot provided.

Secondly, Operations. There are missions performed by side characters, also written into the story, representing different "classes" which each have full progression trees; with additional progression for your weapons independant of the classes (meaning if a class shares a weapon, you progress it for all classes that use said weapon). I found the way these were associated with the story very interesting, made "yourDude" feel impactful and cool. Difficulty rides on your level as well as your skill, you can't just jump to the top difficulty and complete everything on its hardest and call it a day, you gotta work for it, which I prefer as it feels like myDude is actually progressing.

Finally, PvP. In its current state, its decently balanced and simple in all the right ways. Melee can be a bit of a miss, but besides from that it's a fantastic experience and what I have sunk the most hours in thus far. The classes are the same as those you play in Operations - and the visual customisation carries across - but the loadouts differ, a promising prospect indicating that PvP will be balanced in isolation, a thing which lots of PvE/PvP games don't like to do for some reason. I see a lot of people complain that they can't beat X, or that Y is too strong, and 99% of the time i've seen that - its because they're not using the thing that definitely helps counters said strong thing. 3 (with more to come) game modes keeps things varied, though everyone i've met has their favourite they primarily queue into, and three maps (also with more to come) - whilst small in number - I feel are incredibly well designed and thought-out from a gameplay perspective, making me look forward to the additional ones coming.

We know both operations and pvp are going to be recieving ongoing content patches, we'll be getting a survival game mode, and more as the game lives - none of which will be paywalled. The only paid DLC will be cosmetic, like the good old days.

Games like this, and Wukong, are great examples of AAA titles releasing in complete packages. Rife with content, stable and performing well (my rig isn't fantastic, rocking a 2060 gpu) was a lovely surprise. at £55 quid I think this is a great retail release, and the sequel the first deserved and more; bringing awesome visuals and mechanics alike.

I don't normally recommend games, but considering the state of release of Space Marine 2 against other recent competitors on the market, this is a really solid product. For the same price as other big titles you get a masterfully paced, story driven, three player coop campaign that requires no previous knowledge of Warhammer 40k to be invested in. A working multiplayer PvE mode that has a scalable difficulty for when you progress. A functional PvP mode with quick action rounds and a fairly balanced feel (I have found that this does suffer with server issues during busy times, requiring you quit to menu).

This is however, still a brand new game with its own issues. Over a week into this game I have completed all the Operations (PvE missions) at least once on normal difficulty and played on all the PvP maps with all game modes. I still have yet to try my hand at every class and I am not even close to unlocking everything 56 hours in, but ultimately, I have already seen all of what the current state of the game has to offer. Nothing has felt like a grind thanks mostly to the combat system, which is so simple and gratifying that I grin a little bit whenever I run out of bullets and it's time for close quarters.

Scratching the hack and slash, brutal shoulder to shoulder coop and challenging tactical fighting itches all at once, I will recommend the base version of the game without dlc or season pass for now (as this is all cosmetics that wont mean much to new people!). Thank you Saber Interactive for modern graphics in a classic feeling game!

I really felt like the best way to prove my loyalty to the Emperor was when I performed a low-sweep on a Tyranid Warrior's leg with my Chainsword, and then spun around to saw its body in half.

So I've now beaten the campaign in co-op with one friend and also played every PvE mission at the first difficulty level. I'm unsure if I'll touch the PvP mode yet as that doesn't really interest me.

But after trying the PvE missions at higher difficulty to unlock more stuff, my enjoyment in the game dwindled fast. I have been playing the Heavy Class and using the Heavy Bolter because I love using miniguns like that, and all was going well until I hit level 8 and joined a friend on the 3rd difficulty setting which gave me a warning that the minimum level is 10.

I didn't think 2 levels would really make that much of a difference but I quickly found my gun not doing nearly as much damage as it had been before and the enemies hit a lot harder and there is much fewer items and healing heals less.

Looking up in the discussions on the game, it seems that people recommend using the Melta gun as a Heavy, but I would prefer to stick with my Bolter. It seems the enemies become more bullet sponges at higher difficulty rather than adopting more advanced tactics for the player to deal with, which is very disappointing. Too many games nowadays go for the bloated HP route rather than adding more complex gameplay to up the difficulty.

It also doesn't help that the PvE mode only consists of 6 missions as of writing, and 5 of those missions are tied to the campaign that gradually unlock once you reach a certain point, that gives you a glimpse at a different viewpoint playing as different marines in a mission that happens alongside some of the campaign ones.

Which is cool, but the linear missions can get boring pretty fast. I might continue playing them to fully unlock everything for the Heavy, but I doubt I'll stick around to do another or I may even give up entirely before even doing that.

I wish they had a more procedurally generated mission structure that took place on several planets and would switch up the missions to create an illusion of you being marines going on infinite missions.

I think the lack of a Horde Mode which is extremely popular and that it won't be coming until later in 2025 will end up killing this game's current high player-base. The current PvE is just too linear.

The campaign was absolutely amazing though, I love every single minute of it. I've seen some people complain that it's too short, but I would argue that the campaign was at a fairly decent length. Most Call of Duty campaigns are like 4-5 hours long, this ended up being over 12 hours for me, and that's not including the additional hours I spent taking a break from the campaign to do the unlocked PvE missions as they came.

I wish the campaign was longer though because it was so awesome being a Space Marine and destroying. It felt so satisfying. That's probably why I'm not enjoying the higher difficulties of PvE currently, because I find myself constantly rolling away from enemies and feeling like a paper doll rather than a genetically altered super soldier.

I hope they release an expansion with another campaign, I would gladly pay more money for that for sure.
