So 80 Hours in this game features 3 distinct parts.


TLDR: game looks and sounds great, very true to source material

campaign story is decent but nothing to write home about. great spectical but obviously parts were cut from it. maybe not enough time, still good fun, specially in coop.

PVE mode 3 player coop in style of darktide, L4F etc, has a lot of meat to sink your teeth into, customisation, leveling etc.

outside of PVP the gameplay is a 3rd person shooter where you can often run out of ammo but that where melee comes in. this has a whole melee system with attack combos, blocking parrying, doging in it. kind of like the lastes god of war games. if you take damage you lose armor which regenerates after 30 seconds or you can execute enemies to get some back. when out or armor you loose health which you can get back by doing damage a short time after taking it. like in bloodbourne. if you miss that short mindow there are me packs that restore some health and some classes can get health back r hel other with it.

so now you run around and 20 small enemies + a handfull elites leading them show up. you shoot and melee the hell out of them taking damage, regenerating armour by executing which also give you i-frames. blocking, doging parrying etc. with enough pratice it becomes a dance of death. which can be really fun when you get into "the flowstate" of the combat.

a single player campaign:
playable with up to 3 players in coop. this is the main story. features no progression or leveling or armor customisation. the story is and plot is ok. nothing fancy but servicable. in terms of looks and sound its great though. bombastic and warhammer as hell. depending on your difficulty you will play this for about 8-10 hours. good for one playthough but thats it. there are a lot of shooters that deliver a better story. but the spectacle is here.

adjacent to the campaign is the operations mode:

you play 3 marines can choose from 6 diffent classes featuring unique skills and skill trees ofthen even unique weapons. you play 3 player coop missions kind of like darktide, left 4 dead etc. with a director that keeps thing fresh and sets up enemy spawns etc.

this mode features full leveling of weapons and classes with skill trees with 4 difficulty levels. this is where i spend 90% of my playtime. leveling different classes and their weapons earning ingame currency to buy their gear and customize their armor look from the 9 loyalist legions + a plethora of 1st and second founding astartes chapters. armor visual customization looks really good. in this mode i have arnound 60-70 hours and have maxed 4 of the 6 classes but often just a handfull of their available weapons.


next is the 6vs6 pvp modes, it is disconnected from the other modes in terms of progression and although you have the same classes some skills are slightly different and you only unlock weapon loadouts & cosmetics. there are no skilltrees or weapon skill trees. you also earn ingamemoney you can use in the operations mode to unlock new cosmetics and weapons.

BOTTOM LINE UP FRONT
- Excellent game with high production values. Well done to the developers and I am happy to support them
- Highly recommended time sink if you want mindless fun for an hour or so, or want to take a break from your other main games
- Extremely smooth, addictive gameplay. Consistent 60FPS on ULTRA settings
- Beautifully executed game package - while campaign is short, there's plenty of options in PVE and PvP
- Not necessarily worth the $89.95 for the 8 or so hour campaign with only 3 planet locations with 6 maps in total, however the production values is what makes one of the best games I've played in recent times
- The parry system does not feel quite right, it's very clunky and you take damage anyway almost making parries useless in some scenarios
- The in-game animations during some mandatory actions where you take damage can annoy some players
- The game's linear style similar to old school games like Ghost Recon Future Soldier may put off some players. The game's insane attention to detail and mechanics prove not all action games don't have to be "open world" and the linear style does serve the game well

OVERALL 9/10 HIGHLY RECOMMEND even if you're not a Warhammer fan

GRAPHICS (9/10)
Pros
- Fluid and nothing short of stunning
- No noticeable lag with so many things on screen
- Set pieces are stunning and accurately captures the dark world of the 40K series

Cons
- Some off the distant set pieces or flying Nids flicker sometimes but it is not readily noticeable

SOUND (10/10)
Pros
- I've got a Bose sound bar and subwoofer and feeling the thud and crack of every weapon is insane. Whoever was in charge of sound needs a raise

Cons
- Nil

GAMEPLAY (9/10)
Pros
- Fast, fluid and responsive
- Movement is precise and you can feel the weight of the armour with every step and finishing kill animation

Cons
- You take damage during mandatory action animations. Hopefully the developer can balance this as your health and armour gets stripped very quickly no matter what difficulty you are playing
- The parry system and melee are clunky - it doesn't feel as smooth as games like Ghost of Tsushima, which has a similar parry system with the blue (heavy attacks, can be parried) and red indicators (special heavy attacks, can't be parried)

LONGEVITY (6/10)
Pros
- The game has some random spawning in Ops maps, which vary the game somewhat, but you can generally predict where enemies will spawn
- If you have friends to play with it's extremely fun and addictive
- The developers released a roadmap for 2024/2025 which looks to add more maps, weapons and content. If these remain a free update to the base game and separate from paid DLC cosmetic content then this is a welcome change from other game developers which block certain base game content and functionality behind a paywall. THIS IS HOW IT SHOULD BE!

Cons
- The Ops (PVE) can get repetitive and boring for the number of maps available
- There is a significant delay sometimes when waiting at the launch bay. Not sure there is a bug, but it definitely occurs when someone leaves or joins your squad
- PvP seems a bit unbalanced and not as engaging as PVE

MY COMPUTER SPECS
- Intel I5 13500K
- Nvidia 4070Ti 12GB VRAM
- 80GB DDR4 RAM
- Samsung 4K TV (60FPS)

In-game settings all on ULTRA preset

As a long-time Warhammer 40,000 fan, this game is a masterpiece at launch.

Pros
- The storyline takes place on several planets, with the Imperium dealing against a Tyranid splinter fleet. Not too overwhelming as an actual fleet but still a threat regardless lorewise.
- The story focuses on Titus's continued storyline and redemption, with the general character and storyline development being solid writing.
- The details of not just the character design but the armor, weapon, and layout is amazing, incredible work to their visual and graphics team. Throughout the campaign and operations, just take a moment to take in the view.
- Some of the weapon designs are feel lackluster, but others are so satisfying to use, this is both a pro and con.
- The class system seems iffy at first, and I've only played about 2 classes so far, both are decent, but as far as I know the builds are quite solid with varying types of gameplay per-class.
- Operations are a good way to provide an alternative viewpoint to the campaign, with different characters and quite a satisfying amount of customizability

Cons
- The loading times and connecting times to multiplayer can be abysmal, disabling crossplay seems to have fixed it for me, but I've read that it doesn't always work for others.
- The campaign is short, each mission is lengthy and satisfying, but I still hope they manage to expand on the mission in future updates and expansions.
- You do occasionally come across dodgy team members on matchmaking, with dodgy tactics, but you can always launch solo operations with AI instead, and most times you should be getting good players.
- The weapon designs' cons section would be related to some weapons feeling lackluster, they refined how it works compared to the first game, and it does indeed have weight, but it hasn't achieved that sweet spot yet. For example, Auto Bolt Rifles, Heavy Bolt Rifles, and just plain Bolt Rifles don't feel that much different, when they should.
- My only gripe on the class system is how some of the weapon loadout restrictions can be quite iffy and too restrictive. For example bulwarks not having a heavy bolt pistol, tactical can't use a combat knife or only restricted to a bolt pistol.

Overall the game is amazing, a definite must buy experience for any warhammer 40k fans. And to elaborate on why there are no female space marines, it's because their gene seed used in stabilizing their implants are coded to only male zygotes, this was done potentially to control the space marine population and not have them replace humanity completely. Also please read up on Adepta Sororitas and the Anathema Psykana, literal female Adeptus Astartes and Adeptus Custodes equivalents.

If you have an adequate GPU, none of the settings really make a difference if you are CPU bottlenecked. The link below has some good baseline settings. If you have an older cpu, like my 9900k, I suggest setting the render resolution to dynamic and target 60 fps. Then make sure you set the frame limit to 60 fps or it will try to overshoot the target and will look blurry. Check out this persons guide video. Man, I was not expecting this to be this good. Never played the first game or the tabletop versionn, went in blind on the recommendation of a friend with refined taste.

Epic. Bleak. Bad ass. I went in thinking this was going to be just another "dude-bro hell yeah brother" game. I wasn't wrong but it does it so well, I was never bored by it. The story and the environments were so epic. Great writing and voice acting, and some excellent sound design.

The combat has some surprising death. Again, I thought it was going to be shoot-y chainsaw sword swing swing. I wasn't wrong, but there's more to it. Combos, regain shields on execution, parry for cinematic headshot opening, and more. I started and finished on the Veteran difficulty. I felt like I really won every fight and was often left hoping I could make it alive through the next one.

My feedback:
I really like the campaign, operations, and how those are tied together. However, I found myself wanting to just do the operations because I wanted to customize and level up, and I was disappointed that the campaign didn't contribute to any sort of progression in operations. I really wanted to level up and get gear for operations, and I was really feeling not working toward that while I was playing the campaign.

The season pass really doesn't feel like a good value right now. You get access to some colors and emblems, but then you have to grind for currency to unlock them, and that currency is also used to level up your weapons. Progression also feels really slow in operations.

I was a little surprised at the lack of visual customization. There's some colors and emblems like I mentioned, and then just a couple of helmets, slight variation on other armor pieces, and small adornments that you can add. I saw an NPC space marine with a leather cape that would be cool to have. More helmets, cool armor pieces, and weapon skins would be welcome.

Lastly, being able to just create a character for operations would be nice. I know you can't pull a character creation system out of thin air, though.

Overall, great game, glad I spent $60 on it.

It's not quite the original, which is funny because the original is a fairly middling game elevated only by the fact you get to play a smash captain, but it's still a good time. This game trades the balanced, linear campaign and mix of gunplay and melee for a hub based mission framework and a more intricate melee system, at the expense of pacing and the shooting. The shooting is serviceable but the different varieties of bolt rifle are fairly underwhelming, as are the melta weapons. The only standout guns are the snipers for their big headshot damage and the plasma weapons for being able to deal effective damage with charged shots. This is a game you play to get in the thick of things. The operations are fun little bite sized chunks that were probably taken out of the main campaign, but are fun nonetheless. The PvP mode is excellent, if a bit desync-y.

FOR THE EMPEROR!!! What a truly fantastic sequel! If you loved the first one (I know I sure did!) your going to love Space marine 2 because it just gets better and better. The campaign is just epic & from the moment I stepped into the boots of Demerian Titus once again, I just couldn't get enough.

The combat is absolutely brutal in all the best ways. Whether you're hacking & slashing your way through hordes of Tyranids with a Chainsword or a Power Sword or mowing them down at range with Bolters, I mean, It doesn't matter because it is just incredibly satisfying either way and pulling off those savage executions, It just never gets old, EVER!.

I don't think it will be any surprise, but the game's visuals are a massive leap forward compared to the first game. The environments are immersive & highly detailed & they really do capture the grimdark essence of the 40K universe. Whether you’re fighting in the cityscapes of Avarax or alien-infested swamps of Kadaku, it all looks stunning and immersive.

In Conclusion, If you’re a fan of Warhammer 40K or if you just love third-person action games, Space Marine 2 is an absolute must-play. It’s everything you could ever want from a sequel and then some.

Game improvements i'm hoping for (INCLUDES SOME SPOILERS):

Class Locking - One class per team in PVE should be taken out as even though 3 tacticals would be powerful, i dont think it would be better than the current tac, sniper, and heavy combo as long as you cant stack abilities from the same class i.e. auspex scan 3 times at once.

Weapon buffs - a few weapons like the melta and bolter w/ grenade launcher feel really good but many bolter type weapons don't hit with the correct power. I get that the glitch where you're able to heal more than your contested health needs to be taken out (which would nerf the AOE weapons slightly), but other than that I feel that most weapons could use at least a small buff (especially melee). Melee weapons are pretty mid with most being used sparsely when you don't have/need ammo.

More GOOD Operation Variety - Many of the operations (specifically ones involving chaos) have gimmics that make them less fun. More missions that end with cool bosses or large set pieces where we are joined by multiple friendly vehicles would be preferred over hitting color combos to kill a helldrake.

With all this being said, the game is still awesome and a definite buy!!!

The tyranids are really good enemies and provide a lot of good challenge. It seems to me at least on the lower difficulties that i have completed that the thousand sons are actually easier to bring down ? I'm not sure if this is the effect of access to better weapons near the same time that they become a antagonist or if they are just weaker on whole. i like the general idea of the parry system and i really feel great when im in the zone, the main problem i see is it is awfully hit or miss, there are times where the timing seems perfect and in fact it triggers perfect parry passives, but you still get staggered and take damage afterwards. I like that they force you in PvE to mix in your pistol gun-play into melee and you feel genuinely in danger when you run out of ammo on your sidearm on a melee class. Its a great tough punishing game that keeps you white knuckle and enjoying the action the whole playtime.

The main gripes i have are as follows:
A little fast and loose with the lore, although a location like "the immaterium" "can" look similar to your current physical location there is generally a reflection of the emotions experienced and most of the immaterium is basically roiling psychic radiation that would kill you instantly, a little better explaination of that last segment like that the changer of ways was keeping it habitable for the sorcerer and Marneus, but its most likely Tzeentch would have instead just betrayed his sorcerer for the opportunity to kill Calgar and not helped.

The weapons don't fit: If you are a big 40k fan the weapons are gonna feel off what you expect and the only one i feel is fair for that is for the thunder hammer to act the way it does because thats what it acted like in SM1. generally in Warhammer you are always trading something for something else when accessing weapons on the same tier. if you look at actual wh40k properties on the scale of swarm to heavily armored targets it should look like this:
Chainsword -> power sword -> Power Axe(offensive)/mace(Defensive) -> thunder hammer -> Power Fist
what seems to happen in the game is that the chainsword is weak, the power sword feels like an objectively better upgrade especially in the heavy wreath mode, the powerfist has more AOE and the thunderhammer has the most aoe .... Thankfully unlike other titles in the Genre that beef balanced weapon options the firearms you can equip generally cover your weaknesses or allow you to excel at specific targets. the best way i can describe it is that there isn't a "melee weapon made for elites +" the chainsword is bad at almost every encounter, the power sword has more aoe than the chainsword as well as more damage and penetration. The thunder hammer trades some speed for even better AoE but it drops off as a single target killer, the power fist seems to be a midrange between the sword and thunder hammer, it provides a cone like striking area and good penetration and damage (well rounded?) if you are having trouble with elite enemies transition to plasma pistol or incinerator and weave in charged shots while fighting elites, it does the job the power fist should.

The "block" trait outside its interaction with the Bulwark seems like an objectively worse trait and so far has never been worth the trade off of losing parry.

Assault needs more mobility in Co-op PvE

Power sword and plasma pistol should probably be accessible by all classes that have a main melee weapon (Not devastator/Heavy)

Chainsword needs some kind of buff when fighting non armored enemies to make it the minion mulching monster it should be.

The ravener, the lictor and the whip tyranid's red reveals do not accurately represent the window you have to dodge in all three can also very easily animation lock you on a single missed parry and basically take off 80% health or more, without you being able to evade, block or parry after getting hit once, you just take the next 3-4 hits with no agency (Not talking about the quick time events).
Single player is good but short. Worth the full price if you plan to do PVE or PVP.

100% recommend the campaign. but if you are looking for PVE coop experience or PVP, there is no rush. They need to fix the server issues first. Wait to see in Oct 2024 if you are unsure now in September.

a 5/10 game that got overhyped by the ANTI-WOKES to an 8/10, possibly a 6.5/10 in it's current state with gameplay adjustments to make the frustrating mechanics lessened. people saying this feels like a 2010's shooter are so right for the wrong reasons LOL.

campaign is nice junkfood, has nice 40k shlock but is fairly short. not a whole lot of variety but it gets the job done and is pretty fun. played on angel of death and didn't have too much trouble getting through it.

operations are a decent coop mode that do not have enough content. fairly satisfying PVE combat backed by a frustrating health/armor system and a satisfying but boring parrying/execution system that doesn't work that well with a cooperative experience. the progression system takes forever but has no meaningful branching, build variety, or decision making other than picking the best weapon class (Melta ofc) and perks. ranged weapons are way better than melee at everything (sustaining health, damage output, avoiding boring combat systems, etc.), the most obvious example being the ass-ault class in PVE which has a gimped jump pack and underwhelming damage compared to the other classes (the other melee focused class such as bulwark have other abilities that make up for it). people touting the customization options are on mega copium, it's pretty much recoloring and barely any armor variety at the end game. matchmaking is absolutely terrible. a lot of the other issues that people have with operations (low ammo, ranged damage) get completely nullified with class perks/upgrades; the higher difficulties are tailored more for class upgrades/perks rather than skill (seems completely backwards). difficulties just make enemies spongier rather than more abundant or aggressive or faster (boriiiinggggg). overall operations at first glance a deep coop experience but when you dig into it progression is extremely shallow/boring, there is one 'right' way to do combat (melta/ranged spam or learn how to parry and gun strike to sustain), and very low mission variety.

Review for PvE/Campaign:
As always this team nailed the storyline, despite it being somewhat short and leaves in a insane cliffhanger. It's worth buy imo to support the devs. Same thing with the PvE, the PvE aspect of this game called "Operations" delves into the side story of the other Ultramarines that assist Titus in the campaign against the Xenos and how they helped you during the main campaign. That's pretty cool, you get to learn what they encounter to complete the mission, it is apart of the campaign as side missions. Also the scenery is mesmerizing!

Despite a short story and 6 missions to play in Operations, the devs are going to continue this marvelous story.
9/10
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review for PvP: This games pvp felt like a game that was made by EA and unfinished. It does have it's aspects of an old school pvp shooter but the clunkiness and the awful hit reg. would have you question yourself is this a "Skill Issue" or "Does my PC and/or Internet blow".

Well no it's not a skill issue unless you have tracking issues/poor reflexes to land shots on your target. No, even a good player that comes from a handful of shooters such as myself and friends. We came to conclusion that this game has awful hit scanning, shots won't register majority of the time and the sniper reticles do not match your shots, both moving and standing still.

The PvP in this game can be good with better optimizations and registry, even getting a headshot with a sniper is unrewarding with how inconsistent it is, you're better off playing a Heavy or the Melee Classes to play this game.

4/10 - You're better off waiting for the patches to clear up the cesspool PvP has become. I see why people praise the PvE of this game, because PvP is extemely wonky.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

I will still recommend this game for the PvE and Campaign but for PvP, a definitive F no.
Saber, fix your games pvp otherwise, just leave it as it is a colossal failure and no hopes for improvement.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 is a product of a former decade. It is filled with the same energy as Gear of War, the Bungie Halo Games, and the original Space Marine title for which this succeeds.

Non-stop high impact action, coupled with top-notch voice-acting (even slipping the storied voice of Johnathon Keeble into the background cast) and a unified vision with Games-Workshop lends this title to being pure in purpose, and devoid of the usual political confluence with D.E.I. (Sweet Baby, Inc., etc.) consulting firms that takes a good idea, and turns it into a bad one.

No, Space Marine 2 is nothing but a testosterone-filled epic that will run you roughly 8-12 hours of gameplay in the Campaign alone, followed by dozens of hours of multiplayer content to unlock and pimp out your Space Marine in your favorite Chapter (or Legion's) colors. My only complaint is that the servers are a little unstable at the moment for multiplayer, though disabling Crossplay improves this stability remarkedly, and that there is not a lot of content to work with. However, there is a year-one roadmap by the developers and an actively engaged development community.

This is one of the best games I have ever played. I am now a 40K Convert.

-The campaign Is genius and a masterwork of craftsmanship.
-The Operations(PvE) are incredible and tie into the main story. Allowing you to parallel the efforts of the campaign from the other side of the battlefield. I enjoyed progressing this with a battle-brother.
-The Eternal War(PvP) has to be the worst thing I have ever played.

If you want really cool gear for 1 character play 30 or so missions. If you want that same gear but quicker play pvp; as games go quicker. But you need victories to get the gear. Here's where it all falls apart. In 40 matches I've seen victory only twice and others who have played since launch have never known victory. Could this be a skill issue? Ya probably, but when discussing this with more pvp inclined friends the consensus is "Just get on a good team".

In PvP there is no MMR or rating of any kind that can be seen. You are always placed on a random team that needs you when queuing up. Teams are not shuffled before matches and you will always remain on your team and your lobby between games. The trick is to Queue Solo (winning teams never have the space for squads). Get on a team with several higher level players (of which have all the more powerful weapons unlocked due to their levels) and then never leave that team and steam roll every match. This is a cascading effect as each player that joins the losing team will inevitably leave and a new player will join.

When playing with friends one of us is often kicked from the group in between matches. This causes some sort of bug where they are no longer able to be invited to our group. This will force a restart on that players client as they will no longer be able to join any game mode or group. If this happens to be your leader for the group the current lobby you are in will become as we call it "Corrupted". All players will need to fully restart their client. For one of our friends this is a death knell to game time as his game takes 15 to 20 minutes to boot up.

Eternal War is fun don't get me wrong. Getting a triple kill on a flank as heavy; supported by the tank class will always be a favorite memory of mine. I will still play it and join my friends in glorious combat for the Emperor. But I will be watching the patch notes every day praying for a change.

-Group lobbies by level 1-5, 6-10, 11-15 and so on
-Boost loss rewards with extra Exp and Money so we can keep up with the winners
-Shuffle groups between matches

TL;DR - This game is amazing and I highly recommend it for the campaign and operations alone but the PvP is structured so that you will not see any victories unless you are king of strategy or just really lucky.

Cons:

Space Marine 2's greatest problem lies within it's lack of content. Which, although disappointing, is a good problem to have. This game only brings a sense of wanting more.

The campaign is simple to follow story wise and it's level design is fairly linear with enough minor garden paths to explore to give you sense of scale.

The game excels majorly in it's spectacle. Everything you do is painted with a backdrop of a planet under siege, a city fallen to an invasion or the mysteries of the warp. This game seeps 40k. If you want to imagine you are the front cover of a codex, then this game will provide.

The "feel" of the game is meaty. You KNOW you are an angel of death, mowing down xenos or bursting fleshy heads with your bolter. There is nothing more satisfying that finishing off an enemy with an execute or a well timed gun strike.

The coop content outside of the campaign is lacking which could create some cause for concern regarding longevity. I found myself rotating between 6 of the same maps over and over and while each encounter on these maps can vary, the lack of variety backdrop or objective wise can get a little tedious.

Despite that, there are currently 6 definitive classes to choose from and I find the limitation of 1 class per mission to be adequate especially given there are more classes than there are players to take to these missions. However, there is a clear meta given how shallow the playstyle of melee classes feel compared to their range counterparts.

I have not played as much pvp compared to pve but as with most pvp games, the emphasis on meta gaming is much stronger there and can easily sway either way whenever those metas and balancing occurs so I won't comment further.

When I first played this game it had its issues for sure. Crashing, bugs affecting the parry and aiming and it was super laggy. After the first update however the game was overall way better. Like most games it struggled at the very beginning.

Campaign: Now that I have put roughly 30 hours into this game (usually when I start to lose interest in story games) I find myself still excited to open up this game. The story overall feels good and not so rushed. (I have no prior knowledge of lore or other games) The characters and enemies are fun and refreshing. I have now played the full campaign 3 separate times with a few different buddies and still find myself enjoying each play through. I love the need for some sort of specific load out depending on what enemy you're facing.

Operations: I love the ops game mode. As I found out very quickly that playing only the heavy option may not be good for every operation. I like that every op has a different difficulty (Which actually seems to mean something in this game) and that the replay value is insane. It's refreshing that I can choose either co-op or single player for the ops.

Multiplayer: The multiplayer option is fun. There are people that definitely have way to much time on their hands (Like most games now adays) If there is a skill based matched making function in this game, it does not work very well. I consistently find myself going up against someone who is 5-10 levels higher than me. I have played roughly around 40 matches and have only won twice. I will say that all of the guns feel balanced depending on class that you play. For example, if I have a sniper and someone else has a sniper it comes down to who is the better shot.

Overall: Overall I love this game and see myself playing it for the foreseeable future. Highly recommend for anyone who just wants to hack and slash.

Campaign: Great
PVP: NOPE
PVE: MIXED

Story: Decent
Graphics: Great
UI: :Adequate
Stability: Mixed
Gameplay: Inefficient
Price (60): Maybe worth
Price (90): Not Worth
Price (100): Laughable

I'll start with the good.

So the campaign is well balanced and fun. It's about 12-15 hours depending on your mileage. The bigger issues show up when you get to the PVE. This is because the gameplay during the campaign is heavily curated to the story and does not rely on any timers/horde type mechanics to create difficulty. I very much feel this is the best version of the game, and provides a great experience for what the game can be. I thoroughly enjoyed this, and you can invite others to join you in this campaign, it is not required to be solo, once you get back to the lobby. If this is what you are here for, stick with the $60 version as there is no real customization options for your marines in the campaign.

PVP? I can't say much about that, I've seen it, not really interested in it. Looks fairly unbalanced with only a few classes actually being worth playing. Assault might actually be worth playing in this mode.

PVE? OH BOY... So here we go. This is the mode where the prior campaign balance dies. When you play difficulties Easy to Average you can actually see sections that highlight just how fun this game CAN be. However, from Average to Ruthless, there are increasingly more opportunities for you to see how much this game CAN'T work.

First, the parry system is not a bad idea, when one on one, handling an elite, a boss or even a random special unit like a lictor, the game can feel incredible. Parry this attack, reply with a gunshot, perfect dodge another, and heavy attack back, pushing back the smaller foes and staggering the elite. The execution ending the fight in a glorious spew of limbs and viscera. Unfortunately, if you take this same scenario and add the normal 6-8 extra elites with the hordes of tiny Xenos running around, you get to see how much it doesn't work. You parry one elite while another attacks just a half second after and you will parry one, and get hit by the second as you can't get both parries to work. Then you get hit by the unblockable attack from another one with a whip, get staggered by the gun shots from the one in the distance as you hold for a heavy attack to try to clear room. Now you have no armor, half hp, a full bar of white hp (reclaimable), and still a buttload of enemies trying to murder you. So you do your best sonic the hedgehog rolling around while attempting to clear an opening, and deal with the elites. Eventually you manage to either survive or more likely go down and get rez'ed (if emperor is willing) by one of the incompetent AI.

Issues with combat? The repose gun shot, needs I FRAMES! It feels like crap to get a perfect parry that you can't get off because you are being staggered to death by a 8 elites. The gunshot has a literal animation zoom that decreases your surrounding awareness to other attacks, making it impossible to defend when taking advantage of this mechanic. Also, if you are actively engaging in a parry with one enemy, the devs should not force you to complete the first parry animation before being able to perform a second, because of this, the group will interrupt that animation set, as you can't parry twice in a row in the quick succession. Now imagine this whole time, for any of these issues, that you are being pelted with rounds that both strip your armor, create barbs on the ground that deal damage, slow you, and prevent you from being able to see when the buildup is too great. Not to mention the swarm of enemies that do and can surround you while you are fighting, that will continue to shred your armor and hp, while you try to parry, and fire back. Trying to get a shot off from within a horde to stop ranged enemies is a death sentence. The game cannot handle the imbalance of events such as lowering the bombs and hordes being generated during the event. The special type enemies like the lictor or Zoanthropes, are fairly balanced as individual enemies go and work. However, it's about the timing or some of these spawns that can just End your run, such as if you get two Zoanthropes passing a shield back and forth while being a mostly melee character. Which the game is encouraging you to do, because you HAVE to get executions off to keep or get back your armor. The armor gets shredded so quickly you feel more like a tin can marine than one that is wearing 1.5k kilograms of a thick hardened ceramic plating.


When playing with others, sometimes the issues of being curb stomped lessen, because the enemy AI will actively ignore the other AI teammates you have. Sometimes having entire swarms just trying to kill the only players in the group. It is absurd that it is far more efficient to sonic the hedgehog your way through a level than to stop and fight the enemies. A space marine should feel powerful, and they don't. They feel heavy, they feel like they can hit, but they certainly can't take one. With how few Astartes exist, this makes me think it's because they keep wearing the best in paper mâché.

Anyways, I really like this game, and I haven't even touched on the crap ammo amounts at higher difficulties. This is likely to encourage the melee, but you can't do this, because of the amount of enemies and the previously mentioned issues I mentioned with melee combat.

The game has great bones, and is extremely fun when it works, but when it doesn't. It is PAINFULLY bad. HD2 is not in a great place, but the devs might turn that around here... still It is not a HD2 killer, and was supposed to be a different kind of game. I didn't think I would feel as squishy as a HD though as a Space Marine.

Currently I recommend the game, but If they can't figure out how to prioritize the mass combat, it won't even keep up with games like Darktide of Vermintide 2 soon.

As for stability, the game spins up extreme resources and hangs up when it is closing. I have to force close it every time. I have never had it successfully close.

Let's be clear, the game is absolutely not perfect especially in terms of overall balancing, netcode, and actual clear explanation of most mechanics. It's also a spectacular experience that doesn't play like anything else, putting you in an amazing rush even with its jank. TL;DR, the game does a lot of things right, but nothing *perfect* which can make it feel dragged down or missed potential, trying to cover a wide umbrella of modes instead of focusing.

This game differs from Space Marine in that you no longer gain health on executions, instead mostly gaining armor (acts as a Halo shield) or whatever perks your co op class has. It also bites the bullet and makes your character invincible, instead of before where you could very much still die doing any of them. This ends up creating weird problems in the harder parts of the game. In Space Marine 1, you spent a lot of time poking out in a cover shooter without a cover system and quickly eating bullets and dying. In this game, you want to constantly be up in the fray to regain armor to live even one more hit, but you'll have so many indicators and so many attacks to try blocking that you're going to eat a ton of unnecessary damage and likely die anyways if you're even thinking about using your non-heavy melee attacks.

The game is split into three modes: Campaign, Operations (Co-Op focused missions), and Eternal War (PvP).

Campaign is relatively short clocking in around 7 hours on normal assuming you're new to it. It has plenty of warhammer wanking and a good continuation of Titus's story with some new marine chemistry, but it gets a bit grating hearing their almost high-school drama tier dialogue until the final couple missions. There's a point halfway through where they just sound like kids arguing over nothing rather than war torn marines. The levels are still pretty standard defeat the waves until you can go on like the first game, but there's a few times where the objectives change and they're easily the worst parts gameplay wise because despite making an enemy system where you reaaally want to get out of the way of certain attacks, you have plenty of "hold down this one area" objectives which are basically death traps. The environments and sheer number of enemies is gorgeous though, something I think can't be matched for the foreseeable future. However, you'll notice that a lot of the changes to the gameplay (notably the weapon selection) is greatly neutered for the sake of the added join in Co-Op, which can make it feel more stale than it should because you'll just grab the Las Fusil or Melta Gun every single time you have it. The AI partners never change their weapons and they're incredibly stupid, sometimes barely firing at minor grunts. If they're trying to melee they act at the speed of a nursing home patient. It's genuinely shocking how long enemies take to kill in the campaign solo, and then you jump online and see the same enemies melt when actual sentient beings are firing at them.

Co-Op is the meat of the game, and probably where most people are reporting their issues with the gameplay overall.
A lot of the problem comes from the overall grind of levels for every co-op class. A lot of them just... feel awful without getting perks first. A couple of examples are Tactical and Sniper not seeming like much, but becoming the kingpins of the game once they're at a very high level after a lot of hours of playing them like garbage. Many of the classes are way more limited in weapon selection than they should, I see no reason everyone can't use the plasma pistol for example. Levels are long for how often you're expected to replay them, reaching about 20 minutes on average with a competent team but can go up to 30 or 40 depending. Unlike say, Helldivers, there's very little you can do to make it quicker due to the missions being tied to story so you usually have more than a few "wait for x to happen" moments. Progression is also unclear because the items needed to unlock new weapons called Armory Data is a completely random spawn. Weapons require so many kills to progress which is a huge problem with the extra terrible starter tier guns or the sniper rifles with low capacity. This is made worse by some weapons actually being insane at max level but feel so awful at base that you would never figure it out, like the Tactical's basic Bolt Rifle at max tier can reload several grenades in its grenade launcher and match damage with some of the hardest hitting weapons in the game... but you have to get there with the worst gun in the game before it gets to that point. Almost everything is like this, which is probably why you'll have a huge disparity between how much 200 hour players love the game and how much that people who only wanted the campaign will really not like the experience. It really should've had a starter lineup of perks to define the playstyle of the classes instead of needing to unlock all of them over the course of 20 hours each.

I bring up all of these negatives because I think the game feels incredible when you're blasting and slashing through a horde of enemies and knowing that you're good enough to get out of situations that are killing most players in the game. It keeps you on the backfoot almost every turn at high difficulty until you fully master the role you have. Sniper goes from being just that job to kill big enemies, to being the best class to take objectives and heal allies with its invisibility along with restoring ammo for a weapon that kills the most obnoxious enemies in the game at any range in a couple of shots. The absolute storm of blood as you're trying to save your friends from three dogpiles is a blast.

PvP is still something I have to get used to after spending almost all the time on operations, but from the 20 or so games I've played of it, it is hilariously unbalanced and for now its fun because of that, but later I can see it being really bad once people acclimate to just grouping up and death balling on enemy spawn zones. Annoyingly, this mode *also* has a separate progression, which is going to make the disparity between people with starter weapons and people with the bolt carbine and melta gun way worse as more people get on. Some classes also kinda just function differently. Vanguard with its grapple gun can now also grapple somewhat freely to most walls, and Assault with its Jump Pack can have 3 charges like the campaign. This scratches the head over why Assault feels so gimped in Operations where it has half the jump height and less charges for no reason.

The overall matching system is pretty dreadful. You have to guess whether or not you're joining matches because there's no kind of browser and you're leaving everything to chance on pressing the queue button, which sometimes breaks and doesn't even actually launch you. The after-game is similar to Helldivers where you're sent back to the hub area after a mission, which gets really annoying because most people will just leave to freely customize their stuff after leveling up and the resulting loading screens get so long and take up all of your time. If even this aspect gets touched up I would have a much more positive review.

Space Marine 2 reaches for a lot of things and it's still an incredibly fun and unique experience, but not everyone is going to love the confusing combat at first and I still can't fathom people saying SM1's cover shooting was somehow balanced better. The grind is atrocious for how cool the missions are to go through for your first times and for how fun the classes feel at high level. PvP is similar to the old days where it felt kinda tacked on. Other than that, I can at the very least say its a hell of a game even with so many rough eurojank edges. It's refreshing to have a game that doesn't just tell me to keep coming back daily and if you're sick of the co op, you can just say you're sick of the co op.

a phenomenal game for people that like to get knocked around a bit, learn, and master a challenging game with rewarding unpredictability. it's darktide combined with elden ring and doom eternal, with a thick layer of delightful lore and gore.

the "operations" mode is the beautiful core experience. 3 player coop to survive traversing a map with various objectives and waves of attack. the darktide / left4dead experience we all know and love, a wide variety of enemy types across 2 factions, surprise boss fights randomly overlapping huge waves of enemies for disastrous effect. each class has a 1 to 25 level crawl but after level 10 you have a full talent build. weapons are leveled or instantly mastered at a cheap cost.

the campaign's real cool but not worth the price alone. the PVP mode is nice to have, and works better than you'd expect, but it feels a bit tacked on and probably won't be the selling point for people. i wish they'd lean into the satire and comic flaws of the empire a bit more, personally, but it's bad for marketing.

early tips:
- tiers of difficulty are relative to your level and item strength, so just know you'll get stronger as you go and it'll start to feel a bit more fair. particularly when leaning into certain talents.
- google a discord for the game. you rely on players a lot and if you're 2 people it is bugged to matchmake a third. you can drop a "join code 6digits, class1/class2 reserved" statement in a channel and instantly get a strong player or two to join in 2 seconds.
- attack to heal HP bar, avoid staggers that prevent doing so.
- there are three parry styles for melee weapons: block, balanced, fencing. know what they are and test.
- remember to stretch and bring a towel for the sweat.

Finally, after all these years a good game. A game that is not trash. A game that lives up to every expectation and more. Too many AAA games are being released in a trash state and are buggy incomplete messes. Not Space Marine 2. Space Marine 2 is everything a game should be. This will be many peoples first warhammer game and it will leave a good impression. The only thing I could be happier with is having all the custom options be included in the game and not DLC. That is my only complaint, everything else is wonderful.

Space Marine 2 reminds me of great shooters from the 2000s and the early twenty-teens. Games like early Call of Duty's, Kill Zone, Halo, and Gears of War. Shooters that had the just the right amount of action and variety to be very enjoyable for their run time. As well as having stories that range from good to great. I would like to call attention to the mention of "their run time." This to me is a very key part of this. Space Marine 2, and the games I mentioned that it reminds me of, are all relatively short games when comparing them to a lot of modern day games. Which have run times that call well exceed fifty hours. While long run times are not necessarily a bad thing. I have found that shorter games have their place. Especially for people who do not have the time to finish a hundred plus hour epic anymore. I also believe that if Space Marine 2 was any longer then its ten to fifteen hour runtime it would start to become monotonous. It ends right as the enemy variety and mechanics are coming to the end of their ability to engage me. Perfectly timed!

However, that isn't to say once you finish the ten to fifteen hour main campaign that you uninstall this game and not think about it for two years until you think it may be fun to go back and experience it before the sequel comes out. It also comes shipped with both a Co-op PvE mode and a 5v5 PvP mode. Which again, reminds me of the fully fleshed out games of the past. These two modes offer quite a bit of variety and are pretty dang fun.

The PvE mode has you following a secondary group of space marines that run different missions that Titus (The main character) orders to have done during the main campaign. Which is a cool concept for these PvE missions. These missions follow a formula similar to that of Darktide's gameplay. You march to an objective taking out large groups of enemies and the occasional elite enemy or boss, then complete that objective. It works in Darktide and it works here! However, I would not think of the PvE mode as a Darktide clone, but it has the same type of "feel". Which is again a good thing if you like the tide games. I will say however, there are, at the time of writing this review, only six of these missions and the objective variety and enemy variety due become kind of stale after a few hours of gameplay. But I would assume this is going to get some post launch support that will address these issues. At least I would hope....looking at you FatShark. Overall the PvE mode is a good way to extend your time with the game. Especially, if you have a couple of friends to help you purge the filthy xenos.

Now the PvP mode I believe is the weakest part of this game. That's not to say it's bad. But I will say parts of this game are good or even great, While I would classify the PvP as, serviceable. It's a fairly standard 5v5 arena style third-person shooter with the game modes that you have come to expect out of the base rotation from the likes of Call of Duty. It has the same class structure as the Operations mode, were you have to level up each class to get access to it's other weapons and cosmetics. Again, very standard stuff here. What I feel is the most rough part of the PvP, is that some of the classes just feel way to good, or I guess you could take the stance that the other classes feel bad. I assume this will also receive some post launch balance. But even still I feel this games strong suits are in the PvE modes and will always be.

To finish this up, I think Space Marine 2 is an excellent game that is well worth your money. It's a return to what feels like games from the past, fully fleshed out experiences that don't prattle on for way too long and while anecdotal, I did not experience any noticeable bugs while playing. So if you enjoy the 40k universe, would like to purge xenos a heretics alike as an angel of death in service to the holy emperor of man kind, and would like to support the idea that all games should release like this, pick it up!

Having delved deeply into Space Marine 2, it’s safe to say this game is a triumphant return to the Warhammer 40K universe, bringing with it everything that made the original great while enhancing the experience with stunning graphics, brutal combat, and an intense sense of scale.

From the first moment I dropped into the game, the sheer weight and power of being a Space Marine is palpable. Playing as a hulking warrior of the Imperium, the action is visceral, with every bolt round, chainsword swing, and explosive encounter delivering a brutal, tactile punch. The combat mechanics shine, maintaining that perfect blend of ranged and melee combat that keeps the adrenaline flowing. Whether I’m mowing down hordes of Tyranids with a bolter or hacking them apart with a power sword, every encounter feels cinematic and intense.

The enemies themselves—primarily the Tyranid horde—are terrifyingly relentless. The AI is smart, and their swarm tactics push me to adapt constantly. It creates an atmosphere where every battle feels like a desperate stand for survival, much like the lore of the Warhammer universe demands. The game's environments are vast and beautifully designed, evoking the grimdark aesthetic of the 41st millennium, with gothic architecture towering over battle-ravaged landscapes.

One of the best aspects of Space Marine 2 is how it captures the essence of Warhammer 40K’s lore. Whether you're familiar with the universe or not, the game immerses you in the brutal world of eternal war. The voice acting, music, and sound design are exceptional, making every battle feel like a holy crusade in the name of the Emperor. As a fan of Warhammer 40K, the little lore touches—the chants, the prayers, and the fanatical zeal—are a delight.

Space Marine 2 nails the feeling of being a relentless superhuman warrior in one of the most dangerous universes ever created. For both veterans of the Warhammer franchise and newcomers alike, this game is a must-play. It’s not just a game—it’s an immersive experience where you are the Emperor’s might, purging heretics and xenos alike. For the Emperor!

So. This is a review for the SP Story. I haven't touched anything else yet.

So, the game is good. Actually, it's great. The story is awesome, to the degree that I could not put down the game nearly. And I have issues with playing the same game for too long, in case I get bored and just don't open the game again.
But this game changed that. Quickly.

Voice Acting.
It was good, really good. Nothing extreme, but very Warhammer.

Facial Animations.
This is important to me, I enjoy seeing the emotions of those that I play as and with, it helps me get immersed in the story. And this was well done. But, one can only get some emotional expressions when it comes to Astartes.

Graphics.
Jfc. The Graphics are bonkers good. Even on Medium/High settings. I tried it on low as well and no matter what, the game looks incredible.

Story.
The story is Solid. Almost feels like 2 storylines at times. With Tyranids in one and the other with the Traitors. But it merges soon enough and the game becomes a great addition to the WH40K universe and for those that already loved the universe, the story will make you happy.

But.
The story is way too short for it's price.
The PvE extra content is only 6 missions as well.
I can see myself continue to play this solo when they fix the bots. Just grinding the operations to upgrade my classes. But I haven't touched that yet.

I dearly hope they add more to the Operations part of the game. Especially for the price.

But, I still recommend this for those that are unsure.

The Good: The game itself is so fun. It might look hack and slashy on the surface but the combat is nuanced and compelling and keeps you on the edge of your seat. It's wonderful to finally have a fast paced game that lets you play a space marine. I genuinely love this, and I wish so badly the multiplayer actually functioned properly.

The Bad: The connectivity. Good lord it is stone-age levels of terrible. I have yet to play a single game of multiplayer where I didn't disconnect in the victory screen, if not when trying to find teammates or mid-mission. And the disconnect on the victory screen wouldn't be so bad IF you got to keep your progression. If it disconnects at the wrong moment, or if you do anything in offline mode, your progress is gone. No exp for your character. And god help you if you purchased any cosmetics or upgrades, because not only will you not have those the next time you log in the in game currency you spent will still be gone. It's like your astartes got their power armor pocket picked. Many cosmetics also require you to win a certain number of games to unlock, BUT if you disconnect in the victory screen that counter doesn't go up. I've got a level 10 character who hasn't unlocked any of those cosmetics because every round disconnects.

The only way to reconnect is by restarting the game entirely. Doesn't matter at what point it loses connection. It claims you can reconnect from the title screen but that has not worked once.

Frankly, I enjoy this game, quite a bit too. It reminds me of Helldivers 2 during its peak, but there are some issues that are honestly just a deal breaker for me.

(Note: I've only played a single operation, and a little bit of the campaign. I'll update this as opinions come up/change)
1. WTF is the combat. It feels like a horrid mix of Helldivers minus the stratagems, and Darksouls. It doesn't feel right, and it just feels clunky rather than awesome, which is what I should feel when I'm a SPACE MARINE.
2. On the topic of being a space marine, WHY AM I SO FREAKING WEAK??? I feel like no matter what I do, I never have enough "health" (if you can even call it that), and my armor always just gets melted. I know this could be called a skill issue, and it probably is, but I'm on normal difficulty, I'm not trying for a crazy hard experience, I just want to play the game, rather than have my bot teammate (who actually almost never dies, because only like 2-6 enemies actually target him) revive me every 30 seconds because my health gets melted in 5 inches thick of armor.
3. I don't like the movement very much. This is honestly a simple fix, the walking feels not right, I don't know how to explain it, but in-lore they move at 40mph (according to Reddit, take that with a grain of salt) but it feels like I'm moving slower than an NPC in a CoD campaign, furthermore the movement is just not reactive. To see what I mean you really have to look at some clips or play the game, but it just doesn't feel .
4. Why are my guns so weak? The bolt/plasma/melta guns are MASSIVE, so why does it take me 2 or more shots to neutralize a small or weaker enemy on normal difficulty? I honestly feel like this could be fixed with some balancing to make your guns feel strong, like they should be.

Overall, I don't really see a place for this game. It feels like its trying to live up to the "Helldivers 2 but better" but also like a Soulslike? With some simple balancing, and the ability to regen health outside of Medicae Stimms, which feel really rare when I'm constantly hovering at low health, would do wonders for this game. Until then? Wait for it to go on sale.

The bossfights in the Single Player campaign were often confusing to me and rather overtuned or just a bullet sponge event.
Most campaigns have a couple big fights - and they are impressive with the sheer number of enemies - but they also have very long passages of walking and using elevators. There is a lot of stalling.

If you are a 40k fan I guess this carries the game to a 10/10. I think it's a decently crafted game. The gory finishers are fun, the weapons work - however it's also lacking in a lot of areas. Most range weapons are very much the same. To me there rarely was a "flow" state in which the game felt "cool" for minutes at a time. You either have your flow interrupted because you can't get an execute to refill your armor and you die or because the battle is over and its time for 2 elevators and 3 hallways.
The only innovative thing is the amount of enemies you have. The only unique thing about this shooter is the setting an the over the top visuals. The graphics overall are pretty impressive though a HD texture pack might be nice.

Multiplayer:
I only dabbled a little in the story missions which seem to be almost on par with the campaign - just no cutscenes. And I did some PVP.
Overall there are too many load screens in multiplayer. I don't know the technical side to this but I feel like I have to do 10 loadscreens to finally join a game. 4 at least. In PVP the graphics are heavily tuned down. HEAVILY.
The PVP surprisingly played quite nice and not unbalanced - but it's not really my cup of tea.
In the story missions it's quite easy to get lost or get confused what your team should do. But with a little improvement - and even as is - it can be a very fun mode to play with friends. With randoms it's not really that great.


Bugs:
I crashed a couple times during the campaign. Couldn't really tell what the issue was - game just froze at some points. Otherwise the game is pretty polished, the textures will load low res and then high res which reduced stutter to a minimum. The multiplayer servers were a little buggy at times.

Overall:
I can't really see this game being shooter of the century, I think there are other shooters that are better. But the multiplayer was more fun than Helldivers II for me - so that is a plus.
It definitely is a good game and if the developers keep developing it, then it has a lot more gametime than 10 hours of campaign.

Fun game with one of the best depictions of WH40K you'll see. Tells a better story than a lot of Hollywood movies. Fun overall gameplay but the game has some serious balance issues when you get out of campaign and into the pve operations. There's also some major matchmaking issues right now that will hopefully get better with time. Also the audio for gunshots and marine footsteps could do with being more "meaty". Let's get some bass, yall (overall sound design is great though).

Biggest problem for me is the balancing, where 2-3 classes and 1-2 guns (starts with "m" and ends with "elta") being VASTLY superior to any other choice with how the mechanics work for getting back health/armor. If you read this Saber, DO NOT make the same mistake that a lot of pve devs make and just nerf the viable things into the ground. Look at WHY everyone is using them (namely the survivability that they provide), and buff other things to make them viable as well. Do NOT nerf the melta into the ground right now because it will drive players away. General tip, every class needs ways of getting health back that isn't med packs. I honestly think that was a bad design choice, we should be constantly losing/getting health back in this game. But for a lot of the classes, you just do the "losing health" part.

Also game could just use more legs. The meat of this game for pve players like me is the operations and only having 6 missions is a detriment. The enemies are procedural so there is replay value but you can only do the same 6 missions so many times. There's also a lot of people just farming the first mission because it's the easiest. Tyranid and Chaos forces should be more balanced for that reason (everyone is going to farm the missions with the tyranids if they're objectively easier to fight for several reason e.g. Chaos Marines rarely melee, meaning they can rarely be parried, removing TWO of your most powerful tools in the combat flow, parries and gun strikes). Also the roadmap only shows ONE more map in the next year or more. I've already gotten 40-50 hours of fun outta these missions so it's been worth it for me but possibly not for others.

Overall great game but it's clear that they haven't ever balanced a pve coop game before because there's a lot of problems baked into the mechanics of the game that will never go away (but can hopefully be improved with time). That said, the gameplay itself is fun enough that a lot of people won't care and will still get a lot of fun outta this game. Would just be more fun if the game was better balanced and had a bit more content. 7/10 right now, 8.5/10 when they get the multiplayer issues more sorted, and 9.5/10 if they can somehow find some way to balance classes/weapons more (godspeed on that).

Loving it, 10/10. Best so far imo!

Campaign (Solo/Co-op): Good, enjoyable story. Great service to the lore. Titus is awesome. Dreadnoughts look amazing!

Operations (PvE): Fun, cooperative mayhem fighting across 6 missions (more to come).

Eternal War (PvP): N/A. Not played enough of this mode to really say.

Customisation: Outstanding! So many chapters in currently, including the Ultramarines DLC. If I had one thing to add, would be custom emblems, though I've seen enough games including them to know that can also go the wrong way.

Gameplay: Really visceral. Highly enjoyable. Feel like a Space Marine from Warhammer 40k. The combat loop has been great and I have enjoyed every encounter so, Operations has by far been the mode I have enjoyed the most outside of the Campaign.

Inconvenience: Eternal War and Operations both offer restrictions for team composition. While Eternal War (PvP) has a limit of 2 of the same class per match, Operations restricts you to 1 of each class (3-playters, 6 classes).

The frustrating thing is down to matchmaking on Operations not really engaging with the class you have selected and sometimes you join an in progress game on a difficulty you can do with your primary class, but someone else has taken it, now you are forced to run either a Lv 1 class you've never used, or back out and try again.

For Eternal War (PvP), I have found myself been able to select any class when I play, except on a couple of occasions when two players have chosen it, but this seems very uncommon, at least in the games I have played.

Overall recommend this game to any fans of the Warhammer universe, and action gamers will find the combat very fun and hopefully find more about this expansive universe.

Got this mainly for the PvP, well made with room to grow.

So far I have encountered quite a few bugs, mostly with the cosmetics customization:
- Custom armor sets / cosmetics lost on exit and have to be redone.
- Some cosmetics combinations causing the game to crash upon exiting armor edit menu.
- Exiting the game sometimes causes it to get stuck and require ALT+F4 to close.
- "Lost connection" while in the ship and have to reconnect.

None are game-breaking and hopefully will be fixed in time.

Will be nice to get more PvP/PvE maps in the future (as per roadmap) as well as possibility to edit the armor and weapons of Chaos Marines for PvP (not just color).

Regarding PvP, the following should be addressed:

- Ability to report AFK / griefing / cheating players
- More balancing & specialization of classes, e.g. Assault gets + % melee dmg, Sniper + % movespeed, etc.
- Ability to remap specific buttons (playing with controller is a challenge)
- Melee should have more impact, interrupt or slow.

Glory for the Emperor! This game a souls-like third person shooter version of what the old Call of Duty AAA releases used to be. A simple and plot heavy campaign, with variation and co-op/multiplayer play. The game is stunningly beautiful on max settings. if you can figure out parrying, blocking and dodging, the game is pretty straightforward. Don't sleep on the power of sniper rifles compared to other guns.

For both someone new or seasoned in 40k lore this game has so much to offer with how respectfully it handles the setting. As someone well versed in the lore of this universe it brings me great joy to see every little detail handled with immense care and precision. As for the gameplay, I heavily reccomend this game if you're looking for the kind of experience provided by games like Vermintide 2 and Darktide. Melee combat is precise and requires a methodical approach, baiting out attacks in order to perform parries and granting occasional moments of respite from the swarm in order to execute a stronger foe with amazingly brutal animations that I have yet to get tired of.

I've mainly played the operations and pvp modes as the Bulwark, a melee focused class which I've found to be a great frontline fighter in both modes. His lack of a primary weapon for ranged combat is a weakness I haven't felt much, as secondary weapons in this game are still very effective and vital for the game's melee combat loop. Teamwork also makes the Bulwark a frighteningly powerful fighter, acting as a one way barrier in pvp, blocking bullets, light melee attacks, and some grenades with his thunder shield. His banner ability restores armor to teammates in an area around it, which also restores your entire health bar with rally health in operations, meaning you and your team can use a well timed banner and execution to heal back to full health.

I want to be honest up front and admit I'm a moderate Warhammer 40k fan; I've played a couple of the other games and read 4 or 5 of the books, but I don't feel my bias is too much to ruin my review.

The gameplay is exciting, the controls are easy to learn, the scale of the battles is impressive, the environments and structures make you feel like you're in a massive and dark world, and the combat is brutal and shocking in a good way. It feels a little similar to God of war games in several ways and thats a good thing.

The best part of the game is the visuals, particularly how many enemies you see on screen. You truly feel like you walk into the middle of huge battles and I love it. You also have a choice of several weapons which change how you play in certain ways, for example, a power sword is more powerful than a chain sword but the chain sword swings in a wider arc to hit multiple enemies more effectively.

The only downside I can really see for the game is the fact that if you are new to Warhammer 40k then you won't know the lore of this universe which is awesome. Also, I recommend playing the first game first for the story to make more sense. I actually think the story in these games are pretty good for the type of games they are, but in this type of universe don't expect a heartfelt drama or anything. Overall I think its a good game and one of the best this year so far

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 Review: A Dance of War and Glory

In the grim darkness of the far future, where hope is a whispered memory and the galaxy drowns in perpetual war, there stands the warrior: an embodiment of humanity's last, unwavering bastion. Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 plunges you headfirst into this brutal universe, offering an exhilarating, visceral experience that reverberates through every pulse-pounding moment.

The World: Drenched in War
From the very first moment you set foot on the war-ravaged planets of the Imperium, Space Marine 2 offers an awe-inspiring vision of the Warhammer 40K universe. The environments are a dystopian symphony of iron, ruin, and death. Gigantic Gothic structures loom like silent witnesses to centuries of unending warfare, while distant explosions paint the sky a fiery orange. You don’t merely observe this world; you feel it in every clash of bolter fire and the thunderous impact of your chainsword cleaving through alien flesh.

The sense of scale here is monumental. This universe is so much larger than you, yet you march through it as one of the Emperor’s mightiest—an Adeptus Astartes. The art direction captures this perfectly: everything feels vast, overwhelming, as though the galaxy itself is folding under the weight of endless war. But you—clad in your mighty power armor—are its answer. Every corner of the battlefield feels alive, not only with the constant clash of battle but also with the oppressive atmosphere of hopelessness, which you, as a Space Marine, push back against with every swing of your blade.

Gameplay: A Symphony of Brutality
Where Space Marine 2 truly excels is in its fluid, bone-crunching combat. The gameplay is a refined art form, a violent ballet where every swing of the chainsword, every blast of the bolter, and every stomping charge into enemy hordes feels precise and devastating. There’s an elegance to the brutality; you're not just fighting—you’re executing a deadly dance of destruction.

The satisfying feedback loop of combining ranged and melee combat is nothing short of masterful. As a Space Marine, you seamlessly shift between mowing down swarms of enemies with your bolter to crushing them in savage close-quarters combat. The sound of your chainsword roaring to life as it rips through Tyranid hordes is a mechanical growl of death. Each kill feels personal, earned, and necessary, giving you a primal satisfaction only a game in this universe could deliver.

The sheer variety of enemies, from the chittering Tyranid monstrosities to hulking boss encounters, ensures that combat remains dynamic and engaging. The tactical depth, enhanced by a rich set of abilities and weapons, offers freedom in how you approach each skirmish. Do you wade into the fray, slaughtering enemies in a berserker fury, or do you hang back and rain down bolter rounds with terrifying precision? The game leaves the power in your hands, as any true Space Marine should wield it.

Narrative: For the Emperor!
The story of Space Marine 2 strikes at the heart of what makes the Warhammer 40K universe so enthralling. It's not a tale of simple good versus evil, but rather a reflection of the constant struggle for survival in a galaxy where even hope itself is a luxury. As Lieutenant Titus, you stand as a bulwark against the endless tide of alien invaders, your duty not just a responsibility but a sacred oath.

The weight of that duty is palpable throughout the campaign. Every decision feels like it carries the burden of the Emperor’s will, and the voice acting and dialogue add gravitas to the characters and their grim determination. The moments of triumph, when you finally stand victorious after a harrowing battle, are as fleeting as they are glorious. Yet, in those moments, you feel the righteous fury of the Imperium driving you onward, deeper into the heart of war.

The Soundtrack: War's Anthem
The music in Space Marine 2 is nothing short of a war hymn. It swells and crashes with the same ferocity as the battles you're fighting. The orchestral score lifts every moment to a crescendo of tension and victory, the perfect accompaniment to the violent, relentless nature of the game. Each clash of steel, each bolt fired, feels augmented by the grand, sweeping melodies, reminding you constantly of the epic scale of the conflict you are embroiled in.

The Visuals: Power, Purity, and Destruction
Visually, the game is a feast for fans of the Warhammer 40K universe. The hulking power armor of the Adeptus Astartes is rendered with such loving detail that you feel the weight of every step your character takes. The battle damage, the weathered, grimy look of your armor after endless fights—it’s all a testament to the unyielding strength of the Emperor’s chosen warriors. Environments, from shattered cities to alien-infested wastelands, are designed to not only challenge you but also immerse you in the chaos of galactic warfare. The sheer variety and detail are breathtaking.

Even the Tyranids, your relentless foe, are given meticulous attention. Their insectoid forms, swarming in their numbers, strike fear and disgust, as they should. Facing down hundreds of them makes every victory feel that much more heroic. The game pulls no punches in delivering spectacle—whether it's a massive battle scene or the quiet, eerie moments before the storm, everything feels grand.

Player Experience: The Glory and Grit of War
For a fan of the Warhammer 40,000 universe, Space Marine 2 feels like a gift. It’s everything you could want in a 40K experience: epic in scale, brutal in execution, and relentless in its pacing. But even for newcomers, the game offers a finely tuned, adrenaline-pumping third-person shooter that’s as accessible as it is satisfying.

The only criticism that may arise is that the game rarely lets you breathe. It's a non-stop barrage of battle, and while that’s part of its charm, it can feel exhausting for those who might crave a bit more variety in pacing. But for those who came here for war, this is exactly the experience they’ve dreamed of.

Final Verdict: 9.7/10
Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 doesn’t just live up to the legend of the Adeptus Astartes; it honors it with every roar of bolter fire and every clash of chainsword against alien flesh. This is not a game for the faint of heart—it’s for those who revel in war, who take joy in standing against impossible odds and emerging victorious.

With its breathtaking combat, immersive world-building, and deep reverence for the source material, Space Marine 2 is an exhilarating and near-perfect dive into one of the most iconic universes in gaming. For the Emperor!

Just amazing! A straight to the point action/shooter like the first game, but with today's visuals. No BS, no shannanigans, just a great, authentic, brutal and beautifull experience throughout. Was very affraid that with all the drama and the delays it would just be another AAA mess as is the custom these days, but, incredibily, it actually delievers!

Doesn't shake up the formula too much. Combat is fun but a little repetitive. However the best thing about this game is the fan service. Customisation is incredible, classes feel very lore appropriate and distinct, and the campaign had some of the most epic moments i've played in a long time.

This is a good game. Nothing more, nothing less.

Things I liked:
-Combat (A third person shooter, hack n slash hybrid. Love it)
-Environments (This game is stunning)
-Sound design (You feel heavy and your weapons sound very nice)
-Fashion (I might have spend a bit too much on customization
-Story (I really enjoyed the main campaign

Things I disliked:
-Music is boring (Compared to other 40k titles)
-Progression is terribly long
-Little to no replayability (Replaying the same mission over and over is not fun)
-Difficulty is a little boring. (Enemies get more health for some reason)

I would have loved to see a replayable activity on launch. A PVE activity that did not involve the same mission over and over is always welcome. I saw that a Horde mode was comming in 2025. But I think it would have been better if they launched with it. This game + a COD zombies type horde mode would be amazing.

The set pieces and armor are true to the over the top, bigger than life world of Warhammer 40k and are truly crafted by a team that meticulously respects the source material they're working with.

The space marines feel clunky and hits are weighty, meaty strikes that turn xenos into meat carpets for the Emperor's gloriously chosen to walk upon. Weapons, for the most part, feel strong, and as with the heavy bolter, have a chunkiness to the firing that is satisfying while holding back a large horde.

Introducing a parry mechanic is a welcome addition to a 40k horde shooter, adding some technical variety to what is usually just a block and swing playstyle. Not to mention how well timed dodges can be rewarded with a follow up headshot.

However, something about the classes feels wanting. I don't find the level of variety that I did in Dark Tide between choosing a psyker, or say, the veteran class and a couple of the classes feel wanting in general. Looking at the Bulwark and Assault marines specifically.

In all, the game is fun and it is what it is, a 40k horde shooter that satisfies that power fantasy itch to be one of the glorious Emperor's chosen to assert humanity's stake in the grim dark future.
