As someone who enjoys 40k & The fantasy series, this game hits most of if not all the right bars.

Story: The story isn't on the same level as God of War: Ragnarok, Halo trilogy, or the older call of duty games. It is short, if you skip the operations in between each mission. However I say it's pretty damn good for a 40k game.

Graphics: The scenery is gorgeous, surprisingly a bit optimized, although like most games now days you need to have a solid pc to experience them. With a 3070ti & A Ryzen 9 5950X, I've played on the highest graphics settings with 60+ fps. The best of it is definitely the scenery & cinematics, which are grand and epic in proportions.

Gameplay: The gameplay is fun, and the mechanics that exist in the game have a bit of difficulty to them but in due time you can learn and master them. I went from the tutorial mission giving me some difficulty in getting my butt kicked although not dying, to being able to never lose a singular health point, since you can regain armor relatively easy. My general experience is playing the game on the 2nd hardest difficulty.

Multiplayer: On pve side operations is harder than the story with some classes over others, Assault feeling like the weakest due to restricting the jump pack movement which isn't consistent to the campaign or pvp, to the rest having extremely fun experience and high survivability like the Bulwark. I haven't touched pvp too much, but its alright, it's not like 40k Eternal crusade (RIP), and the time to kill feels faster than that game which isn't bad. However the elephant in the room is that cheaters do exist. Yes the game has only been out for 6 days officially + 4 from early access. The cheaters are able to do the following: Shoot through walls, have sight of everyone, able to switch teams somehow and have many more abilities yet to be seen but from what I heard they can do a lot.. But it was only 1 out of a lot of matches have yet to see another.

: This unfortunately isn't the strongest quality of the game, a lot of effort was put into the campaign and that is definitely shown, 6 operations, 5 of which are tied to the story and 1 being side content. Each operation takes about 20 minutes to complete, varies based on difficulty and whether you are alone or not. Mostly your grind is leveling the different classes, which levels do not carry between Operations & Eternal war what does carry is Cosmetics & money. I've found Eternal war to be better at getting cosmetics & money as operations is much slower and rewards you different through armoury data for weapon upgrades all in all it needs more improvement and additions. Luckily there's a roadmap that already features new weapons for later, maps, operations & even classes.

All in all the game is very good and I recommend for newcomers to 40k or long standing story lore Librarians, the future of the game is unknown however the popularity of the game will show whether Focus Entertainment & Saber Interactive would wanna add to the game after Season 4 or end up working on a new title. 9/10.

It's a game that really has all the signs to be a great game but and if I could I'd probably give this game an 'average' rating. Most of my issues come from the really odd choice of making this game play more like dark souls then space marine or really any other third person shooter.

The game was clearly not all that thoroughly tested as the incredibly chunkiness of the controls is a infuriating issue. Parry indicators are present but are super inconsistent and the timing for them is all over the place such as the Ravener having the indicator at the start of the wind up but the animation being so long the parry ends before it attacks and you get hit anyways or the fodder who just auto jump into your parry attack the moment you hit the button.

It doesn't help that this game seems horribly animation driven in every aspect as animations are locked the moment they start meaning you will often get hit trying to perform certain attacks because the game will prevent you from canceling it with a dodge. Damage is so violently overtuned that the little ♥♥♥♥♥ are vastly more lethal then the actual majors who are themselves only lethal en-masse which becomes real common and having a squad of warriors or rubricae spawn up my ass doesn't exactly lead to fun when every engagement ends with me rolling 36 times, and spamming melee in the hopes something becomes executable and even then that will only heal armor and not health for some reason and a lot of the time it's just safer to shoot the enemy more then try and get close for an execution unless there one of the last people around.

I don't think I need to explain the issues with always online, the game seemingly balanced for coop single player be damned, and the AI being 'special' while 95% of the enemy is focused solely on you and are hyper aggressive to an almost oppressive level. Executions not stunning targets around you and melee having very little crowd control. Almost every enemy locking you into animations or staggering you with some form of special attack.

Regardless of all this ♥♥♥♥, I still like the game. I just hope they go about some changes so the game doesn't just feel like a tedious slog to even play and this is on the lowest difficulties. Higher difficulties just sound like an abject pain that really isn't worth the effort save for being forced to due to the armory progression system that I fundamentally hate on requiring higher difficulty to progress.

It's an average game with a lot of weird changes from the first that just make the game far less enjoyable and more tedious to play. Fun in coop if about as annoying to play, Maybe they might change or fix some stuff later but I probably wont be playing much more of this game outside of my friends wanting me to.

Also, let me rebind controller controls, thank you.

I will be updating my review upon completion of the campaign and this is more or less a first impressions on a little bit of everything of the title.

Space Marine 1 stands as a relic of the past in which it was championed by a beloved critic and a niche community he called home and for many PC gamers that became the smallest inkling into a world they have never been approached with. Warhammer 40k has inspired countless pieces of media as it was inspired by its own and purely off the visuals and branding, we see constant inspirations of this world through games like Halo and Starcraft. But for countless years, we have yet to have a sequel that takes the player truly into the boots of their star cast... and here we are once again, Welcome.

Plot: to the uninitiated, you play as Titus a Space Marine of the Ultramarines chapter, one of countless Adeptus Astartes who are made of the genetic material of several sons of the late Emperor of Mankind. He serves as a truly rare sight to the common man and along with his Battle Brothers have earned the prestige and status as "Angels of Death". Humanity faces countless threats such as the dreaded Hivemind of ever-evolving aliens, the fungal barbaric Orks, the elusive Eldar, the united and mechanized Tau, the ancient undying Necrons, and their own traitorous brothers who fell into the hands of demonic Chaos gods.
During his adventures against the Orks, he was tainted by the energy of Chaos and serves penance by order of the Inquistion, a shadowy authoritative agency that serves almost as the status quo in the power vacuum of the late Emperor.
It is in this penance he finds himself facing the Tyranids and is given a twisted chance of fate, to be reborn as the latest developement of the Imperium of Man's technological doctrine to become a "Primaris" Space Marine. Bigger, badder, and with new armor, weapons, and strategies by the order of the Ultramarine's Primarch Roboute Guilliman, who has stepped forward, awakened from death, prepared to allow humanity to rise once again as a power in the 41st millenia.

But has your new augmentations rid you of your curse and how will your brothers react as your dirty past comes to haunt you once more?

Gameplay: Much like Space Marine 1, you are given a remarkable sense of control over Titus or any Space Marine you control during your cooperative or PVP modes. Your left mouse button will control any firearm you have and your right mouse button (depending on presses and holds) will execute combos. These combos paired with a decent parry and dodge system will allow your Space Marine to deal with tougher opponents, wound them to perform an execution or gunshot combo which will heal any grey-bar health and fill your armor meter.
During your journey across space you will use this as the foundation to hold, escort, and solve minor puzzles as you face waves, boss fights, or other players in a narrative that ties any and ALL content together in the canon of the universe.

Sound: embrace the audio that may not be revolutionary, but sings the bloody song of a world far beyond our own. Each of your guns fires a rocket propelled loaded projectile or energy from a 10ft tall human wearing essentially ceramic armor, and you FEEL these truth in every trigger pull, every chainsaw rev, and every crackle of energy from hammers, jetpacks, and more.

Voice acting: be fully aware that the Ultramarines are the prime "standard" of the emotional and physical display of the Imperium of Man's finest. While they may seem rather dull with their zealotry to brotherhood and their doctrine and ethics book "the Codex Astartes", every actor fits nicely into the mythos of a world dictated by minature figures. Plenty of them may not be A-List actors but they surely know the topic enough to not phone it in.

Optimization: as for writing several issues are both on the radar of fans as well as the developer. I have suffered no crashes upon patches but a really hit-and-miss connection to servers to play with friends and randoms. This is the most critical problem for a game that looks drop-dead-gorgeous- even with the lowest of low settings. CPU usage is high across some rigs and again the developers are active, aware, and frankly obligated considering 2 million people bought this niche title.

Coop and Multiplayer.
You can enjoy the campaign cooperatively as Titus is held by two of his peers as well as a secondary story that plays very much like Splinter Cell Conviction where you ARGUABLY have a story just as good as the campaign, but in the context of a faster paced and more difficult multiplayer setting. These fit the campaign proper and despite the non-canon nature of using your personal customized marines, they still fit the necessities of the plot.
Even the multiplayer has a place in the story where you face head to head across three game modes with other players.
The only issue with the multiplayer, at this time, is some minor balances, the connectivity, and frankly ZERO customization from the Heretic Astartes, but brownie points are given for at least the creativity of fitting several chapters as your player character.

Across ALL modes you will unlock weapons, cosmetics, and find lore in all of your transactions in-game.

Monetization: as of right now you only need to pay a minor DLC which is intended to give players extra colors, decals, and designs inspired by the secondary chapters of the Ultramarines. In other words, the Ultramarines have their own "cousins" of sorts, all with their own backstory and popularity, and you pay for those armor presets. There is no pay-to-win mechanics and frankly not every player needs to purchase anything beyond JUST the title to enjoy the game.

Nitpicks: there is admittedly no means to glory kill to regenerate health on higher difficulties, which sort of works backward to the gameplay pace and design. The heretic astartes got not love in the multiplayer and frankly your first enemies are the most interesting in the campaign.

Roadmap: the community does have a looseform roadmap displayed on social media that aims to add more classes, more coop missions, and expansions to the multiplayer for the longterm. This IS the future of Warhammer 40k titles save for Darktide that has a weird spot in the market right now. The future looks very bright as the success of this title, paired with the necessity to do justice to the frontcharacters are important to the brand... this isn't Darktide which is niche within itself.

Final verdict (first impressions)
Just buy it, my fingers hurt typing all of this but I do so because I have faith in this title far more than I have with other bug stomping games of this year. My only SIGNIFICANT FAULT of the game is the lack of an FOV slider because this game was in memory of the beautiful man we call John "Totalbiscuit" Bain and even then that's more out of humor than something damning.
Saber has done an incredible job at making a game that can rightfully surpass the necessities of Eternal Crusade and be the new standard of a marketable 40k title while sticking true to the source material with just enough fanservice and breadcrumbs for everyone to enjoy. I sincerely hope you join us in the fight.

Considering I like classes I don't expect, said "WOW" multiple times as a novice of the universe (trust me, this is LIGHT compared to what others know), and the joy I have of this... it's worth every penny in a market that nickles and dimes the average consumer.

You can paint, play, and enjoy Space Marines in THIS GAME for $60 MSRP and not even have to walk into a brick and mortar game store... that's a steal on its own and theres plenty of people in the community who will happily play with you beyond your adventures here in other titles... that's the BEAUTY of this.

Thanks for reading Brothers, the Emperor protects.

TL;DR Action hack-and-slash with good story, characters and voice acting. Amazing graphics and art direction. Good violent gameplay. And ok, separate, more replayable gamemodes like pve missions and pvp.
I recommend this game to anyone already interested in Warhammer. Else, it is 7/10, with optimization, pacing (loadscreens and cutscenes), connectivity, and, balance issues. With fun, but, underbaked pve and pvp modes.

--

Space Marine 2 is an action hack-and-slash story (and later pve, pvp) game, set in the grand and 'grimdark' Warhammer 40k universe, that follows the protagonist Titus from the first game. And whilst there are nods to the first, it is not a requirement to play the game, nor understand its characters or story.

Your avatar is as a Space Marine (or Astartes as lore-nerds like me would correct), a manufactured warrior class of humanity: Genetically modified, mentally conditioned, cybernetic, and religiously zealous post-humans, clad and armed in equipment more befitting a tank than man. And your job as one is to stop the invasion of the Tyranids: Unending waves of beasts from beyond the galaxy, controlled by a hivemind that can only feel HUNGER. They have arrived to devour, and their gluttony demands entire worlds.

As you rip and tear through the alien the nuance of characters, story, and narrative will slowly progress, leading to question about both, your so called allies, and the true happenings behind the alien invasion, all the while introduced to new ways to kill and maim through weapon choices and more challenging foes, although the gameplay loop remains relatively similar, and gorey throughout. Whilst set to the backdrop of fantastical Warhammer 40k settings that truly make even the superhuman soldiers you play as, feel small and inadequate.

Boss battles that will be thrown your way are going to be rather tough (veteran difficulty: one dev's intended to be the difficulty to play the game through), and once defeated for the first time, you're expected to fight them regularly at a later point... Baring especially special boss fights which, from an art-direction standpoint are genuinely amazing and rememberable, and I will not be spoiling them for you here.

Whilst in the main story you battle as the protagonist Titus, he, as a lieutenant, sends squads of other space marines on separate, but just as important to the game story, missions. These you can play through the 'Operations' coop pve mode, where you choose a loudout through class types, and through successful completions upgrade your equipment and perks to be able to handle harder difficulties of missions, and most importantly, customize your marine to look as rad as possible, or just paint them hot pink.

This mode plays nearly exactly as the main story does, and since there are only (currently) 6 missions available, of which, some are inherently harder than others, and you will need to complete MANY to fully progress ONE class to the point of being able to handle harder difficulties, this mode ends up unreasonably grindy, especially since each mission will take 30-50 mins. This also has the unintended consequence of both, having to 'main' a class (only use one for the time being) so you can have any sense of progression, and have to use un-fun tactics to speedrun through missions, since xp and currency is solely tied to mission completion, whether you killed 1 or 1000 aliens, matters nothing. This is very much an area the developers need to refine.

Speaking of refining: The PvP mode 'Eternal War', is extremely halfbaked. You play as space marines either on the Loyalist side, or the Traitor side, withe each operations class. It has just the right amount of raw content (maps, gamemodes, hints, progression, character customization, voice acting, graphics/ui) to be in a 'passable' state: It feels more like an alpha, as the balance is off, there is no traitor customization, no stats screen, no explanation of what the gamemodes are, only 3 maps and 3 gamemodes, and melee being very rudimentary, and yet, it is fun despite all of that. So as a gamemode to play infrequently, it is welcomed, but needs far more love and care put into it than the developers currently have, as if this gamemode was made as a separate game, it would rightfully flop.

And speaking of flops: The game, and it's sales, do very much ride on the fact that this game is set in the Warhammer 40k universe, a universe the fans-of (like me) will pretty much consume regardless of quality nor nutrition, and if this game, the exact same as it is now launched, but was not set in this setting, it would not have achieved even a tenth of its success. Which is very notable, as if one is not interested in the setting, or actively dislikes it, selling you this product is going to be far tougher than for a fan, and as such, as much as I do 'recommend' this product, it very much has it's strengths, and it's weaknesses. It is far from a necessary video game experience to consume, and at a later point the game might have improved drastically, and be sold on sale...

As such, a 7/10 overall rating is fitting, as whilst I would put the story mode itself higher, other modes, ones which demand more gameplay time from you, are in a worse position than it. Hence, the overall experience of this game will be dragged down by them and the (currently) inherent flaws of the game.

Simply put: This game is extraordinary. Not only is it visually stunning and highly immersive, it is a game made for the target audience through and through. Loved every minute and can't wait for more after 9 hrs of play.

The story is rich, the characters are well done, and the atmosphere is palpable throughout the campaign. More than anything else though: Space Marine 2 is a game that makes me feel like I was heard. The game stays true to the core of 40k and incorporates much of the existing lore into an amazing rendition of that world.

The combat system takes some getting used to but it is akin to Helldivers and Gears of War blended with a somewhat "Souls-like" play style. Dodging, timed strikes and blocks, run gunning, and simply brute force are all options. Different combat strategies are rewarded differently with different enemy types and I enjoyed the challenge. On Veteran difficulty you absolutely have to be more careful and consider what enemies you are fighting our else you will get absolutely mogged. The combat is addictive and exactly what I think of when I read a 40k book. The flashlights are also fairly lore accurate which is awesome haha.

I highly recommend this game:

Pros:
-Fantastic landscape and world design. Highly rich environments with stunning visuals and details
-Plays fantastic. The combat system works great with minimal bugs and the game appropriately rewards strategy
-True to the lore and ties in nicely with the original game
-Very palpable passion in the writing and development. This game was made for true 40k fans and new fans alike. It leaves you excited to play again.
-Great PvP and PvE coop options

Cons:
-Audio bugs for me have been most common. Muffled audio randomly after cutscenes or death is my most frequent bug but even then are not persistent and resolved with rebooting the game.
-I wish the campaign was a smidge longer. I got a solid 8hrs out of my first playthrough on veteran, and I stopped to look at things and explore the NPCs conversations as I went. This is somewhat made-up for in the coop mission mode.
-Some of the enemies are serious bullet sponges and when playing solo campaign the enemies tend to target you far more than your NPC allies. Normally this would be ok, but when cooping the enemies target everybody in a more balanced way and that did make the missions more enjoyable simply because the mobs don't drown you in harass on top of tougher enemies.

There are also some obvious areas where the game can be expanded, and I really look forward to it.

I have not yet played the PvP heavily but in the brief time I did try it I enjoyed it.

THE BOTTOM LINE: If you are a 40k fan this game is worth every penny of full price. If you are a Helldivers/Gears of War/Halo fan you will probably love it too, and this game makes a decent into to 40k but you will have to google some things (Such as Space Marine structuring and who the Emperor is, but don't worry YouTube is rich in lore vids).

28 hours on record, the campaign is NOT 6-7 hours. It's a fun campaign that captures all of the feel of WH40K. If you are a Warhammer fan then you should definitely pick this up.

i9 Intel 12900 32 gigs of ram, SSD and a 3070, all on high settings. I stay away from AMD because I tried a pc with it once and it gave me constant blue screens. Anyway, during my full playtime never once crashed, no graphical issues , no overheating, only had a slowdown twice during a heavy battle scene and that lasted 2 seconds. Never got a constant disconnect, or an endless loop of anything. I read the reviews from others and honestly it's a hardware problem and not the game. People don't want to believe it could be something on their end so they will just blame it on the game.

Gameplay is very fun but this is a game about timing. There is a parry system but in being truthful, it was not explained that you CAN parry all melee attacks (not the orange ones) without the color notifier. Also the game will punish you for button mashing, as I said it's a lot about timing. If you are firing your bolter recklessly then you won't have the time to parry in time. The game could be viewed as a dance of sorts, don't get greedy and be aware and ready to always block, parry or dodge.

Is the game perfect? No game is, but they did a great job with this one. It SHOULD have launched with horde mode, and I also think you should be able to customize the face of your marine even if just using in game presets. I also think it would be amazing to add another enemy faction (Necrons, Aeldari, more chaos legions) in the game but it's early and who knows what the future holds. All paid Dlc is just cosmetics which is good too.

I played PvP and PvE, both are fine but a little shallow, I'm hoping they flesh it out more in the future. All in all it's great and a game I'm glad I purchased. The longevity of the game NEEDS Horde mode asap while waiting on the other things the devs have planned on the roadmap.

As someone who has NEVER touched the 40K games, I am BEYOND impressed with what I have played. The campaign may be only 6 missions. But it is an immersive experience you won't forget. Take your time in this, it is well worth every bit of your attention.

My view:
Story 10/10: Titus and Co are top tier VA's and have amazing chemistry in this story. Even if there is (like previously mentioned) only 6 missions. It is like watching a movie and being in the universe yourself as an actual Space Marine!

Operations: The game has separate, 3 man operations that take place as the separate squads doing tasks in Titus' storyline. Here you select Classes and their desired loadouts as well. While I may point out and not necessarily agree with the class locking, I believe in some portions it is to get everyone playing a different class to freshen up the player experience.
Playing and succeeding in these operations provide you with the "currency" (or points more accurately speaking) to buy better gear/better perks for you and your team. And also unlock decals/paints to TRULY ADORN THE EMPEROR'S WILL

PVP: PVP is a 6v6 format with their respective modes. There is still a class selection with this and this also provides a challenging experience against other players in the lobby!

Misc notes: There are no micro-transactions in this game. There is no "shop" or anything of the sort. You can earn almost everything in game via the operations and pvp.
The only exception is the Season Pass ($40) you can purchase that is a one time buy. It provides you with the rest of the cosmetics you can earn in Operations. And in continuing "Seasons" that is laid out by the devs, there will be exclusive gear/content available to you if you have the pass. There will be content for everyone regardless. But a little more for the eager ones willing to make the one-time buy

TLDR; FOR THE EMPEROR!!!

WHY IS THE POWER CREEP SO BAD?

You have the trailer showing titus rip through hormagaunts and termagaunts in single hits / bullets yet in game it takes a strength level 13 sword 3 full swings to kill 1.

It feels sometimes like i have instead become a guardsman who discovered an abandoned suit of power armour and started flailing my arms about. If i had any suggestions to the devs its to maybe more accurately portray the strength of these tyranids. Wanna make the level harder? Just add more enemies to the base operation and increase the probability of an extremis level enemy spawning. I want to feel like a marine, not a grunt guardsman who has nothing but a rifle and his lost hopes and dreams.

However when we look away from that i must say that the game is good and once these kinks are worked out it will be flawless.

It's very good. It pays respect to the last entry, in the series. You feel like a space marine, and the bolters are perfect. The game play loop is pretty simple, but very fun. The game is well paced, and unlike the first entry doesn't wait till the end to change up the enemy types. The only down side is it's short. Really really short. I think if they would have side tracked Titus like make him do more death watch mission's, or maybe give him more exploration/ fetch quest's. The Main campaign is well appointed though but still only 10 hours. I didn't get into a team mission so I can't comment on that aspect of the game. I would have liked it if I could have changed/ customize Titus just to make him look like hes my space marine. The cinematic's were good, I would have liked to seen Bobby G show up, but Calgar was good to. If your a fan of WarHammer it's a must get. If you do not like GW you will wonder how it turned out so well O.O.... Get ready Brother's tons of heretics to purge.
P.S they could have added more to make the game longer. Examples... Titus could have done a another mission in the death watch. We could have played as the dreadnaught. We could have done out missions as titus and his team, then play the parallel mission as the other team after or during. We could have had a section where we were the hive mind directing then forces around. It feels like there was enough content to make the game at least 40 hours but it just got cut and stream lined...

It has it's pros and cons but overall I'm having a lot of fun with it.

PvE right now has some connectivity, crossplay and server-side problems but I think anyone who has played a Saber game previously probably understands that was coming. They've never really had a game kick off as big as this and are probably a bit overwhelmed. They're constantly working on it though so we can't really complain. I have also noticed it can be quite difficult to time parries and dodged right when the ping is a bit higher (playing with friends from other continents) so that can be pretty frustrating.

PvP has a lot of problems but I also feel, after having played a bit of it, that it's just a tacked on game mode and not something that any real investment was placed into. There's a number of pretty seriously balancing problems and I'm not sure there is a way to fix them all without ruining the PvE experience or entirely segregating the two game mode (not sure if this is possible with how the game is designed).

SPOILERS AHEAD...

Captain Lieutenant Demetrian Titus returns to my personal GOTY. If I was to sum up this game in short, it would be- that it reminds me of an Xbox 360 game. In every possible good sense. You have three modes. Campaign, PVE, and PVP, that's it. Almost no microtransactions. The game just works. No glaring optimization issues. It's just an all around solid game. But I'll get into the meat of the review now:

The Emperor Decides Our Fate, Gadriel

Saber Interactive picked up what Relic put down and turned the dial to 11. They expound on literally everything, while also making it extremely easy for somebody who knows nothing about 40k to understand. Titus' arc from the end of Space Marine 1 to the beginning of Space Marine 2 is amazing and lovely to someone who understands 40k lore (and especially to someone who cough mains Deathwatch cough). It is however, somewhat reminiscent of Space Marine 1, for good and bad. Orks Tyranids invade an important Imperial planet, they spend most of the campaign fighting them, go deeper and realize there is the same an artifact that is being hunted by Bloodletters the Thousand Sons, who end up being the real enemy all along. In terms of story, it should probably have been a bit different, but in terms of gameplay continuity, it makes sense, and expands the overall 40k lore because it is now official canon. However, the characters contained within the story are simply excellent and even tie into the miniatures directly, such as the new Captain of 2nd Company, whose mini you can literally buy off Games Workshop. Gadriel and Chairon, for being brand new side characters in a sea of lore, held up really well and successfully gave two individual and human arcs to two superhuman soldiers. Titus himself is ascending to a legendary figure status within the lore and is probably going to be the face of 40k to the masses.
Everything about this game has been pretty amazing so far.

All in all a good Game. Could be better, but quite good. I've only played Solo-Singleplayer so far.

Lorewise the Game is on Point. Multiple Moments where i was pleasantly surprised on how well Sabre followed 40K Lore. There are also a few nice Nods in the Direction of Dawn of War which were appreciated, showing that they did their homework very well.

Gameplay is what you expect. Hack and Slash, go through door, Shoot and Slash, go up the elevator, hack and slash while activating your power. The Weapon-choice is a bit bland in my opinion. Apart from a few heavy-weapons it's either Bolter that shoots fast, bolter that shoots slow, sniper-bolter. Plasma-Pistol and Plasma-Gun trivialize later bigger enemies a bit too much maybe. You can hunt for Data-Slates and sometimes you find Areas beside the main path that reward you with Weapons you can have 1-2 Missions earlier then the armory would grant them or Health-Pickups. Not enough to enourage secret-hunting, nor necessary. You'll start to look where the compass guides you, and try to go the other path for a little advantage maybe.
Heavy Weapons feel different and thus interesting, but you only pick them up and have them until they run out of ammo without a refill (Except for the Flamer). Not enough time to experiment and enjoy them to the fullest sadly.
Melee is better then in SM1. The parry-system feels rewarding, giving you a very much needed defensive tool that enables badassery right afterwards. The weapon-choices however are also not the most varied. Apart from Thunderhammer, everything kinda feels and fights the same.
The NPC Companions are passable. While they often leave Enemies stunned (most likely for you to regain shield) and forgett about finishing them off, they also sometimes don't prioritize important targets. You as the player have most often 2 jobs to fullfill on your own, which is stressfull. However, while sometimes they are not of much help, they never get in the way or need to be babysitted, which was a big relief.

The Game looks good. Cinematic visuals, Enemy design, you look and feel like a true space-marine, especially when fighting next to guardsmen. Doing overly violent and crazy stuff is part of the charm of the series and appreciated.
Also nice that i could play it on medium with my 8 year old rig, the optimization seems to be allright.

The Story itself is rather weak. While i am sure that people who are not deep into 40K Lore can enjoy this, Knowledge about the setting makes the experiance a lot better. Even better if you've also played the first game, otherwise you'll have a lot of "What's going on? What is this? Who is it? What's a Primarch?" moments. But even for those who have played the previous game, the very important question which lead to most of the events of the first game are talked about, but not resolved. Also, somehow, "Palpatine" is alive, undoing a lot of what we fought for in the first game. That plot-point is really weak and never explained to satisfaction which is a bit lazy. The Rest of the story you can forsee for a mile away. Especially if you've played the first game, because it's basically the same but a little weaker. Which is not good, as SM1 allready had a weak story.

The Characters are okay to good. Titus had a good chunk of character-development, torn between talking about his past and following orders, while dodging suspicion. It was also a very good choice to include the later antagonists, especially the deity they follow is perfect for making Titus question himself and his comrades constantly. It must be a tight corsett to write a Space-Marine Main-Protagonist while squeezing at least some relatable human emotions into it, without destroying the Angel of Death, that put's duty above else.
His two Companions try to establish banter between them, but it kinda falls a bit short. But that's okay, we're space Marines after all, the human side should be a bit clunky and underdeveloped. They have their moments and feel alive enough for me to accept them. The Rest of the Cast is rather flat however, one-dimensional and sufficing in their role, nothing more.

All in all, i would recommend. It's not groundbreaking, but a fun time to be sure.

Speedy review with good and bad (pain) points

Pros
+ Great combat system that feels meaty and powerful with excellent finishers that change with melee weapons.
+ Reasonable campaign length (9-10 hours) with a decent and engaging story.
+ In addition to the story there is a PvE operations (6 maps with more coming with seasonal content for free) and PvP eternal war mode. The operations link to the story well being an alternate squad mission objective.
+ Great and massive amount of enemies on screen thanks to the swarm system as per World War Z.

Cons
- The game has a varying number of issues and needs a lot of bug fixes. I get the waiting room bug for both story and eternal war game modes 99.9% of the time.

It is the 41st Millennium. For more than a hundred centuries The Emperor has sat immobile on the Golden Throne of Earth. He is the Master of Mankind by the will of the gods, and master of a million worlds by the might of his inexhaustible armies. He is a rotting carcass writhing invisibly with power from the Dark Age of Technology. He is the Carrion Lord of the Imperium for whom a thousand souls are sacrificed every day, so that he may never truly die.

Yet even in his deathless state, the Emperor continues his eternal vigilance. Mighty battlefleets cross the daemon-infested miasma of the Warp, the only route between distant stars, their way lit by the Astronomican, the psychic manifestation of the Emperor's will. Vast armies give battle in his name on uncounted worlds. Greatest amongst his soldiers are the Adeptus Astartes, the Space Marines, bio-engineered super-warriors. Their comrades in arms are legion: the Imperial Guard and countless planetary defence forces, the ever vigilant Inquisition and the tech-priests of the Adeptus Mechanicus to name only a few. But for all their multitudes, they are barely enough to hold off the ever-present threat from aliens, heretics, mutants - and worse.

To be a man in such times is to be one amongst untold billions. It is to live in the cruelest and most bloody regime imaginable. These are the tales of those times. Forget the power of technology and science, for so much has been forgotten, never to be re-learned. Forget the promise of progress and understanding, for in the grim dark future there is only war. There is no peace amongst the stars, only an eternity of carnage and slaughter, and the laughter of thirsting gods.

For 40k fans, this game is a must-buy. If you're not a 40k fan, it's still a great game, and is likely to get you interested in the wider 40k universe.

Played on an MSI GE75 Raider with an RTX 2080 Super (Mobile) GPU and an Intel 10th gen i9-10980HK CPU. Game ran smoothly on high settings, albeit a little hot, averaging 88-90c while using the laptop's turboboost feature for its fans. When turboboost was turned off, it averaged 93c. For some reason the game runs hottest for me while in the armoury's customization screen. I didn't keep track of FPS but didn't notice any stutters.

Pro's:
-The story campaign is great.
-The PVE Operations are a great co-op experience.
-PVP is surprisingly fun.

Con:
-The story campaign is a bit short.
-There is only 6 PVE Operations, and increasing difficulty only increases the enemies health and their damage toward you, it does NOT increase the amount of enemies you fight. A BIG miss.
-PVP is 3 basic modes which all utilize the same 3 simple maps.
-Overall, the game feels under-cooked. What is here is mostly great, it just simply needs more of everything, as well as a revamp of the PVE difficulty modes.

Final thoughts: Based on the developer roadmap and comments, it looks like they have a lot more content planned for this game, which will be vital if they want this game to continue with a healthy player-base.
Regardless, if you plan on playing more than just the story campaign, this game is definitely worth a buy.

**Space Marine 2 Review**

Space Marine 2 delivers fast-paced, brutal combat that’s a joy to play. The smooth switch between guns and melee feels great, and every hit has satisfying impact. It’s an adrenaline rush, especially in large-scale battles, with crisp visuals and chaotic action.

While the story takes a backseat and combat can feel a bit repetitive, the core gameplay shines. If you’re looking for an intense, action-packed shooter, this one’s a solid choice.

The multiplayer experience is where the game really extends its lifespan. PvE co-op lets you team up with friends to take on waves of enemies, testing your squad coordination against increasingly tougher challenges. It’s perfect for those who love the horde-style survival gameplay with intense, non-stop action. On the PvP side, the game offers competitive modes where you can clash with other players in team-based combat. Here, mastering both ranged and melee mechanics becomes essential, and the skill ceiling feels rewarding for players who want to dominate.

Both PvE and PvP are well-crafted, ensuring plenty of replayability and giving the game lasting appeal for players who thrive in online multiplayer environments.

**Final Score: 8.5/10**

It's a late 2000s era over-the-shoulder shooter with the quicktime events streamlined into dodging and parrying. It's not a deep story but it's fun to listen to. Gameplay is satisfying, scale and set-dressing are marvelous, game feels like a complete experience that didn't overstay its welcome. If you're a fan of the setting or liked playing either Uncharted or Gears of War back in High School then this game is for you.

Overall love the game there are just a few issues in my opinion with the parry/dodge system (like hitting parry and it feeling like it doesn't parry some times and when aiming down sights which the default is middle mouse you can't parry, dodge or melee when you need to unless you hit the middle mouse again to get out of it which is dumb). Also at the moment if you try and switch gamemodes (go into PvE or PvP) it will put you into matchmaking which is annoying af when you're just trying to look at stuff (customization, skills, loadouts, etc.). You have to quickly cancel matchmaking before it can send you into a match.

Campaign is amazing but a little short, I hope we get some campaign dlc added in the future.

PvE I feel is unbalanced. There are 4 difficulties: Minimal, Average, Substantial and Ruthless. I have only beaten Minimal (which is easy and pretty fun but seems to have gotten harder) and Average (kinda hard but doable) difficulties. I believe I played Substantial once which was impossible due to it spawning basically a special enemy (basically a mini boss but it doesn't have a visible health bar) that is very hard to fight on it's own and a mini-boss (with a visible health bar) (this has also happened on Average difficulty but we were able to handle it). The biggest issue is a certain level of item you can only get on the higher difficulties that you need in order to level up your weapons which is armory data. You need 1 Master-Crafted, 1 Artificer and 1 Relic for every weapon in the game. Basically when you level up a weapon it hits a roadblock that you need the armory data to unlock then you can get more powerful versions of the weapon.

PvP is generally annoying in my opinion. There are 3 game modes: Seize Ground (Domination where there are 3 static flags that need to be captured for points over time. Basically wherever you spawn you get the closest flag, the better team gets the middle flag and you keep swapping spawns stealing the outer flags). Capture and Control (Hardpoint where there is an area that moves around the map after a certain amount of time where players stand in order to get points or if both teams are present no one gets points. Annoying when no one plays the objective or when you keep getting put on low level/skill teams constantly.... the only mode I play because I'm decent but can't get kills and stay alive at the same time). Finally Annihilation (Team Deathmatch kill enemy players to get points.... never played because I can rarely get a positive Kill/Death ratio).

The biggest thing there are 6 classes (for now, they plan on apparently adding more in the future), to get all the cosmetics for each class you need 40 wins either in PvE or PvP matches (so overall 240 wins). PvE matches are kinda long and can get repetitive since there are only 6 and you might not like to replay some missions (1 in particular has an objective you need to move by standing by it then when necessary press buttons to rotate it and some people don't know what they are doing making it very annoying). While with PvP you are stuck with trying to find teams that can win and having to stay in lobbies with those winning teams (I tend to cancel matchmaking if I end up in a lobby with more than 1 level 10+ on the enemy team and more than 1 level 5 or under on my team. There have been some good low level players, there had been some bad high level players but overall I don't like getting stuck in matches where we lose 50 or less.... including 0 to 200 or being always like 20 points behind the enemy dragging out a losing battle forever).

This game is a faithful representation of the Warhammer franchise. Is it perfect? NO. But that's ok. It's certainly a step in the right direction for Warhammer as a whole. Pros

1. Great story and writing through the campaign and operations.

2. Amazing back ground buildings and model details that capture the Warhammer 40k universe to its core.

3. Graphics are Superb and highly detailed.

4. Gameplay feels responsive and fluid. Very well done.

Cons

1. Game is not alt tab friendly and crashes game, atleast in my experience.

2. Game sometimes times out at certain points and disconnects you randomly. To be fair it's probably from server traffic overloads with player connecting to server since the game is new.

3. Needs more game modes and customization options at this point but, the game has more game mode types and enemies in development with a road map to show what the devs are working on with a timeline.

4. Armour feels like tissue paper and may need to be reworked a bit or give health back with armour on executions like in the first space marine game. Only getting armour back isn't fun when it doesn't even feel like armour when playing campaign or operations. I feel the first space marine game had a great system for staying in the fight and making it more fun and enjoyable in combat. It would make campaign and operations more fun and enjoyable but, leave the armour and health system alone for the Eternal Crusade pvp mode as it is as I think it is well balanced for pvp and needs no rework.

Other than the few Cons the game is great and I think it is game of the year material.

The best description I've heard for this game is that "it's like playing Bloodborne in a mosh pit." Space Marine 2 is pulling ideas from all over the place so of course it decided to meld the swarm-based enemies of the original game with Soulborne-style melee mechanics that require timing and finesse. As much as I find good parry mechanics satisfying, paying attention to an enemy's attacks becomes a bit of a chore when approximately 50,000 clones of the same bugger are simultaneously trying to claw their way into my butt hole. So I wouldn't say Space Marine 2 offers a refined experience, however I would say that it is a perfect popcorn game. Big, serious men talk about honor and duty while wearing armor that looks designed by a second grader with half a pack of crayons. Plot that's both convoluted and simplistic. Combat that's a few zip codes away from balanced but at least is too chaotic to get samey. Performance at first was worrisome- I experience pop-ups galore and the camera decided to take periodic coffee breaks while I was taking on a boss that looked like a cockroach with mantis blades and a bad attitude. This has gotten mostly better, although the jank now might approach Bethesda-levels of entertaining, like when I stood for 30 seconds watching one of my squad mates stand in a corner hopping up and down like he was doing the pee-pee dance.

Steam Deck performance: Will start, and is actually manageable when the game is in tight corridors, but as soon as it opens up to sky boxes and swarms becomes very prone to crashing. If you manage to get it running with no problems for more than 30 minutes remember to thank the Emperor.

I just finished the game and I'm absolutely blown away. This game is everything I could ever wish from a Warhammer game. If you are a fan of linear shooters or action games in general, this game is a must-play. It's bloody, brutal and violent, full of spectacle and badass moments, where you feel like an absolute god of the battlefield.

The combat takes a while to get used to, but once you do, oh boi does it feel good to skewer and rip the Xenos open with the power of your fists alone or with the help of an iconic chainsword. The weight of the Space Marines is so perfectly conveyed, you can feel every step, every shot, every punch and the power it carries. The enemies are varied and force you to play around them differently based on their type and abilities, adding quite a nice tactical aspect into the combat.

The environments are insanely detailed, the atmosphere is absolutely breathtaking at times, the views are staggering. Graphic wise, this game is a feast for your eyes. It's honestly amazing how faithful the game is to it's source material and how well it managed to recreate the Warhammer universe and it's vibe to the smallest detail. Especially the armors and the different chapter designs and decals *chefs kiss*, the amount of customization you can do with this is amazing.

Apart from the visuals I think the sound design also deserves a big heads-up. Not only environmental and character / weapon sounds, but also music and at times stunning voice acting really helped to sell the situations and the characters.

Content wise, I'd say the campaign was well paced, with good variety and long enough to be fullfilling without overstaying its welcome and becoming stale. Coop works really well, your friends can basically join you at any point of any mission, so it's quite seemless. Multiplayer also seems to be quite fun from a little bit I've tried so far.

If I had to list some gripes I have with the game, it would be:
- slight problems with optimization here and there, where we couldn't load in the middle of a mission
- story might be quite confusing for people who haven't played the 1st one or don't know any Warhammer lore
- enemies in the 2nd half get a little bit repetitive after a while

In the end this is exactly my type of jam. I freaking love this. Absolutely phenomenal, fun, run and gun, balls to the walls story full of spectacle, explosions, gunfire, xenos blood and unbreakable brotherhood. 8/10 would server the Emperor again. FOR THE EMPEROR!

As a middle aged male, I am the target audience. Game play is better then it looked on reviews. Good fun, challenging on higher difficulties. AI team mates kind of suck but they are good enough to revive me to get me back into battle so it's not the worst.

Initial Thoughts -

Campaign - Short and somewhat mediocre. With the fantastic stories of 40k, having a re-run of Space Marine 1 story arc was not it. Pacing is all over the place but with some fun moments here and there. Seeing Tyranids is very nice to see however small they may be compared to the stories presented in the novels and books, Hardware limitations be damned. Overall a solemn 6.5/10.

However.... the gameplay, is very fun and satisfying. Strong sound design with the Bolter weaponry aswell as the meaty slams of the hammer and energy power up from the power sword makes for some great presentation and weight. Parrying is a bit of an issue as the philosophy of relying on color'd reactions is not always reliable as looking at what your parrying by the animation of the enemy. This gives a false sense of reaction timing at times which leads to some somewhat irritating encounters.

The aesthetic and world building is unmatched only slightly above what was the champion - Darktide. In a Galaxy filled to the brim of wars that are constant and brutal, this gives the best sense of it. Hive cities are truly gargantuan and the Jungle/Rural landscapes that seperate the Factory/Church feel give a very welcome feel.

Operations are super solid with some interesting class choices that at times feel somewhat lack luster. The 6 missions you do are great... but drag on as you play them on and on and on and on. The customization is prolly my favorite part of Op as it gives me the Table top feel of painting my own miniatures. Sally and Death Guard enjoyer here!

PvP is prolly the most 2010 3rd person fps I've felt in a long time. Imagine Gears of War but with the classes of Op, and then put those two formula's into Deathmatch or King of the Hill. Pretty much self explanatory. with only 3 maps tho makes for underwhelming amount of content.

Overall I'm happy for this game as I personally did not have many technical issues. This game however is clearly unfinished and was pushed to make date and time. I love the polish that is in the game and overall its very fun!

It needs more content to provide that full price tag.

If you are a 40k fanatic you will have already gotten the game like I have.

If you are considering getting this game, understand that what is offered is fun but will last you only so long before it may become meh for you.

My recommendation is either get it right now for those who understand what they want out of this game, Big men in Power Armor Killing alien and xenos alike and enjoying it or wait and see what content is added to the game in the coming months.

Consider the Road map and may the Emperor guide you to Great Games as always!

Absolute must play for anyone interested in 40k, no question. Even if you're not, if you've ever enjoyed games like Helldivers, Doom, or Gears of War, you'll likely love this too. Play the original Space Marine from 2011 while you're at it, still holds up very well and you'll get a lot more out of the sequel if you play it first.

All this game needs right now is more maps for PvP, more game modes for PvP, armor customization for Heretic Astartes, and, above all else, an option to play the PvP mode with a cross-platform party. Right now the game refuses to let you enter the PvP mode with anyone playing on another platform for "balance" reasons, but you are still randomly matched with players from all platforms anyway so it's a completely pointless restriction that does not actually prevent crossplay from happening, it only prevents you from playing with your friends across platforms. At the very least, it should be an option to opt into completely unrestricted PvP where anyone can party up and be matched with anyone regardless of platform or balance concerns.

If those issues are addressed soon enough, Space Marine 2 will be a damn near perfect 40k experience.

The moment to moment gameplay is excellent. The story is great (the actions of certain characters don't make any sense, but hey that's typical in 40k). Sound design is excellent.

HOWEVER:

1. The 6 missions in the co-op pve mode wear thin quickly. There is a ton of customization and progression across 6 different characters (which is AWESOME) but there is simply not enough here to reach level 25 without content getting extremely repetitive. If you continue increasing the difficulty as you level up, one levelup occurs every 1-2 missions. There are 6 total missions. That means 50 victories to max level. So to max out ONE class, you would end up playing each mission EIGHT TIMES (if you spread it out evenly).

2. The operations mode at higher difficulties are very unbalanced and break all immersion. It's very challenging for the wrong reasons. Small fodder shred through ceramite power armor and sponge up multiple bolter shots (this applies even if your character is the recommended level for substantial/ruthless difficulty).

3. The campaign ends with a cliffhanger/sequel bait. Again. Hopefully we won't have to wait another 11 years for the next one!

All in all, a GOOD game worth your time/money. Definitely better than the first. However, don't go into it expecting a Dan Abnett novel in video game form. 40k video games have yet to hit their stride.

By the Emperor's grace and the will of the Omnissiah, I have traversed the battlefield of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2, and as a loyal servant of the Imperium, I offer my review from the trenches of battle. Let it be known that this game, forged in the crucible of our most hallowed lore, stands as a testament to our unyielding might.

From the outset, the game immerses you in the grimdark reality of the 41st millennium. The weight of the Power Armour, the unyielding resolve of the Emperor’s finest, and the relentless tide of xenos and heretics have been captured with a level of fidelity that befits the legacy of the Adeptus Astartes.

The environments are a reverent homage to the desolate war-torn worlds we are accustomed to. The visuals are a masterful depiction of ruin and decay, as though the very rubble of forgotten bastions and the smog of burning hive cities have been rendered with an artist's touch. The power and majesty of our Chapter's armor is showcased in all its splendor, each detail reflecting the sacredness of our wargear and the grim determination etched into our souls.

The combat in Space Marine 2 is a symphony of brutality and precision. The melee mechanics have been honed to a razor’s edge, allowing us to cleave through foes with righteous fury. The bolter’s roar is as satisfying as ever, and the newly enhanced weaponry feels as though it has been forged in the fires of Mars itself. The enemies you face are varied and numerous, from the grotesque horrors of the Tyranids to the cunning schemes of the heretic, each demanding a different strategy and relentless perseverance.

The narrative is a grim reminder of the eternal struggle we endure. The story unfolds with the gravitas fitting of our Imperium's eternal crusade. It does not shy away from the stark realities of war, the sacrifices made, or the unyielding will required to endure. The voice acting and script serve as a rallying cry for those who heed the Emperor's call, and the sense of camaraderie and duty is palpable.

For those who thrive in the crucible of war, Space Marine 2 offers a range of challenges that would make even the most seasoned veteran break a sweat. The difficulty settings ensure that even the most battle-hardened of us will find ourselves tested, with every victory a testament to our skill and dedication.

Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2 stands as a worthy continuation of our storied legacy. It honors the tradition of our Chapter and the Imperium, offering a battle experience that is both exhilarating and true to our grimdark universe. To the Emperor’s chosen, this game is not merely a pastime; it is a call to arms, a celebration of our eternal vigilance, and a reminder of the darkness we fight against. For those who seek to wield the power of the Astartes and defend the Imperium with valor, this game is a beacon of our indomitable spirit.

In the name of the Emperor, I commend this title to those who walk the path of the warrior. Remember, brothers and sisters, to play with honor, and may our enemies tremble at our might.

- A Humble Space Marine

Although I personally didn't like it (and refunded it), I can still recommend this game. It's an extremely solid experience, no doubt. Space Marine 2 does a great job of being a simple, yet dumb fun power-fantasy shooter to play with friends. With adjustments in the settings, the game runs fine and it's easy to drop in and join your friends.

However, I will say Space Marine 2 has a variety problem. Now, admittedly, I'm not familiar with the Warhammer Universe at all, so maybe I have the untrained eye to notice certain things... but to me, nearly all the enemies fight/look the same and the guns you use feel/look the same. Although there is some enemies/guns that are unique, every arena and fight seems to be the same, outside of three/four exceptions. The combat is also very simplistic, as your arsenal/movement is: one pistol, one rifle, 3 grenades, a melee, and a roll (and a jetpack if you pick a class that has it).

Again, it's still a good game, but I think that catch is, at least for me, is the 59.99 USD price tag; it doesn't feel like I'm getting a whole lot for the price. Although I did not finish the campaign, it seems like it's only 10 hours long (judging from word of mouth). The PvE mode seems a little unbaked, as there's only 6 missions that play very similarly. The PvP is actually quite fun, but there's only 3 maps.

So, just to conclude: good game, just not worth 60 dollars for what it currently offers in my opinion. However, if you are on the fence, I'd wait for a Steam sale as this game is definitely worth getting with a reduced price tag.

hands down my favorite 40K game sofar
the story was short, but incredibly hype (even if the end somewhat deviates from the lore, but it was sick, so i wasn't bothered by it)
the pve is basically the same as the campaign gameplay wise, just with your own custom spacemarine
the combat is responsive, the guns feel weighty like bolt weapons should, the different melee weapons cover all the types between fast, medium and slow and my god the executions, they really never get old
but the gamemode i did not expect to be enjoying the most has been pvp, sure there's only 3 gamemodes and 3 maps (there are more gamemodes coming according to the roadmap and i do hope that they start adding more maps aswell), but there's just something about it that i can't put my finger on. i'm not usually a pvp enjoyer especially with shooters, but this one feels different.

some things i would like to see added/changed in the future:
-at the very least heretic customisation
if it were up to me, the heretic classes would not be restricted to a class per chapter and i assume because of how it is now is why emperors children and thousand sons are missing (maybe one day we'll get 2 more classes and see those chapters added) i do know full chapter representation per heretic chapter is no small ask
-the currency to unlock perks in pve should not be the same as the currency you use to unlock customisation options (while i don't like the idea of currency bloat, i like having to choose progression over fashion less)
-the matchmaking in both pve and pvp is kinda bad atm
in pve your squad of 3 needs 3 unique classes and when starting a mission the game asks you what class you want to play, so i don't understand why the game will continuously match you with people playing the same class which ends in either a staredown until someone caves and switches to a different class or you leave the lobby to look for a new one
in pvp it's not about who you're getting matched with, but the fact that after a match you stay in the lobby and immediately start the countdown for a new match unless you're quick enough to leave the lobby to not go straight into the next match. at first i didn't think much of it until i wanted to swap game modes after a match, but the timer which is usually roughly 60 seconds now started at like 5 seconds once i loaded into the hub (fun fact: at 4 or 5 seconds you can no longer leave the lobby) so you're essentially forced to either play another match or alt f4/quit out of the match after it starts (which i've seen happen and ended in us playing 4v6)
if you do end up able to quit the lobby and start matchmaking for a different game mode, sometimes the matchmaking will just die and you have to return to the main menu and load in again

despite its current issues, i do really really enjoy this game
it is incredibly fun, aside from the one rule of cool moment at the end of the campaign, it is incredibly faithful to the source material and there is so much potential for future content, i can't wait to see what everything on the road map turns out to be
if you're a fan of warhammer, this game is absolutely for you

So, I played this since release, main story (solo) and operations (PvE). Here is why I liked it:

GAMEPLAY. In both modes it feels like a slasher-shooter, and it's quite satisfying to do both. On higher difficulties tactics becomes quite important, now your team has to pick certain types of weapons. Bots are stupid, they do two things good - they kinda shoot and they rush to revive you, so for higher difficulties you are better off with other players. I am yet to see how the game looks like in coop (main story, operations will be called PvE) when you play anyone but Titus (sorry for spoiler but it isn't a spoiler, he is even on a banner in Steam). But for now, lets talk weapons. I was looking forward to try power fist in the story mode but sadly it's absent, and since the discovery of power sword I can't play anything else, I like it too much. As for the guns, Titus isn't limited by any class and can use just any weapon, pick yours, I liked Bolter Rifle (with grenade launcher, when possible) and a heavy bolter pistol. Speaking of which, I am very disappointed that it's absent from most of the classes in PvE, I would expect someone like Bulwark who doesn't have a ranged rifle to be able to access it but no :( Guns do feel different, and I especially like how they sound and just annihilate anything small. Enemies have a variety and are very well gradually introduced, though closer to end of a main story it kinda exhausts, and outside of unique bosses for PvE there aren't any new enemies that you can encounter several times per level.

GRAPHICS. Note: played this game on QHD 60 fps quite stable on 1080 Ti + 1950X Threadripper. The amount of details in this is crazy. Every mission you get a scene where there is a lot of units in a distance running/fighting, and if the background is Imperial you get this Gothic cathedrals, high spires and everything, it looks amazing. Also nothing beats an actual swarm of Tyranids running towards you, you understand that no matter how many bullets you sink into them, it is the question of when you would have to go in melee. And customization, oh my lord. Though the interface is a bit clumsy, you can get a feel of it. You can actually change parts of costume and their coloring, guess next step would be attaching new components and custom emblems, it's not there yet. I am quite happy running as Salamander/Raven Guard in PvE.

BUGS: I encountered only minor bugs and one disconnection while I was AFK. I got Tassets (yes, I googled it) flying and clippling though arms in a cutscene and a game for a bit, I think restart fixed that. Then I got two times when characters were lagging behind on the elevator, one time that was in PvE. And rather recent, I seem to have a delay to the victory music after each PvE mission which gets progressively worse the more I play. Either that happened due to a long session or something else - I don't know, will come back if fixed now.

SOUND. Music hits in the moment, but sadly I don't think I would like to hear it outside of the game. It works inside the game though. Sound design is just amazing! You hear the heavy footsteps of Space Marine, their jumps, bolters firing sounds like a heavy weapon, slashing sounds good too. It just clicks. I have to admit, in a heat of battle it can be quite hard to understand some characters over the vox filter and you don't quite have time to read the subtitles but other than that it is very solid.

OPERATIONS (PvE). Even though they are designed as main campaign rather corridor-like, it doesn't make them bad. There is still quite a lot happening and these levels aren't used in main campaign, variety allows you to take a break of some missions to enjoy other ones. Replay value is good, stuff on the map is placed differently (aside from datapads, a.k.a. audio logs) but the levels are premade, after few runs you would memorize them. The classes have quite some customisation, both for cosmetics and for weapons. You get character perks, you get weapon perks, you get weapon rarity which allows to change their cosmetics too. My issue with this is locking 1 class for 1 player. Had to stare as someone joined into my lobby to pick the same class as me and then wait for them to stand in armory for 5 minutes, didn't got enough votes to kick (me and 1 other player were standing in the launch area at this point). So, please remove this, I know that having 3 bulwarks sounds stupid yet I want to be able to try it. If balance is your concern, add this to private lobbies only so that you can only do that on purpose.

STORY. You don't need to know anything about the universe or the previous game, the game does explanation very well. Read quite some criticism on this point but I liked it. I know a bit about Warhammer 40K lore so, to me it was enjoyable and understandable, I quite liked how the story was done. Yes, it may seems as generic battle brothers saving the world, but in this Universe for Space Marines that's everyday, sometimes many times a day. Spoiler alert!!! Feel free to finish on this. I liked how your squadmates grow with Titus, first trying to get to know him, later throwing out words like "The Codex Astartes does not support this type of action... But I am looking forward to it". Quite a pun to previous game, especially hours or days after he suggested to reanimate ancient ship that's wrecked and send it ramming xenos structure, Imperial Navy approves. Okay this is getting long - so two more things that I noticed and liked. First is that PvE missions have a story, with 5 of them going parallel to the main storyline! And it's not like some simple tasks: go kill an enemy general to disorient them, blow up an fuel field and cook enemy swarm that was going after main target or get to that ship wreck and reanimate it! The immense scale of Warhammer 40K goes even into them. Oh, by the way, the levels for PvE missions are unique, not the same as in main story. And the last bit, the story bit. I was shell shocked when I realized that Tzeench's followers first killed Archmagos, then allowed us to retrieve his pupil (they were trying to get him too, but that's like a win-win for them. If they succeeded than they would get his knowledge, if not) so that we would send him to the power source to the planet where it can be used and then tricking Magos to turn it on himself! And then launch a full-scale invasion on it, catching Imperium off-guard. Honestly, if not for Titus and his squad's unorthodox tactics that battle would have been lost for the Imperium. So I think writers did very well on that part, shows how terrifying Tzeench can be with his intrigues.

This is Warhammer 40,000.

Furthermore, there is an annoying matter of having to unlock colors in multiplayer to customize your character in multiplayer - though they do thankfully give you enough currency at the start to at least pick a chapter you like as a start.

Also dear developers, please let us have the old Aquila or Beakie helmets.
Looks and feels beautiful, and very loyal to the IP without being overwhelming, so should appeal to veteran 40k fans and newcomers alike.

As a fan of anything warhammer, this is it.

For the environment : The attention to details is amazing and beyond this world. The way they did battlefields is amazing with the hordes of tyrannids rushing to devour their prey. Even going in corridors or small players you can look around and see a story being told through was looks like last stands, lost fights and such. Even walking into adeptus mechanicus areas, you can see the grim dark flowing through through one of these servitor lining up the wall to control the air conditioner.

For the lore : Good attention to details, all the units seems like a living model from the board game. All the loyalists factions act like they should be in the lore and it's amazing that not much has been modified to fit in the ''modern audience'' . Only thing I wish was for Pink horrors to show up. Would it not be amazing to have them separate into blue horrors if you don't execute them fast enough?

For the game overall : The gameplay is amazing, I like the parry system and it always feel like you're STRUGGLING to survive any encounter. It can get really high intensity and you have to use the proper gun/tools sometimes to survive. My only complaints is that I wish the imperial guards AI would be better. If you look at them mid fight they will just stand there doing nothing ( I wish they would go behind cover or even flee if the hormagaunts are approching. ) .

I Wish there was more horrific ends to the humans as the lore is pretty crazy regarding the weapons of the termagaunts : they can shoot some short of high velocity beetles called fleshborers. Their short lives are simply to dig through armor and dig inside their victim causing the most damage. Would have been crazy to see stuff like this like in The Mummy movie ( the beetle going to the brain scene )

Also wish there was more variations of the finishers, they really lack diversity compared to games like doom eternal.

Final comments :

Really glad these developer kept the game highly respectful to the lore and the WH40K universe. The characters are masculine, no woke messaging and it's just about completing the missions and winning the war.

The duo of marines with Titus are not 1 dimentionals and critique properly Titus when needed. But it's not long winded conversations : They state a question or a comment, the other argues back or answers, then after a quick settling they focus back to their mission ( no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ).

The campaign is the only real reason to buy this game. It's good, and it's short. The mechanics and feel are not exactly my cup of tea, but it IS good, it feels responsive, and it works on my Linux setup.

BTW learn to parry. You can parry anytime, even during an attack animation. Do it vs everything but ranged attacks, and you won't die.

The PvP is broken. You'll die of frustration from a thousand cuts. :
- You can't chat until you've spawned. You can't chat with the enemy. You can't emote either.
-
- You must die to change class. Get it? You'll be owned by any premades who get to decide who does what.
- There's no balance at all. ALL games I've played were teams of newbies vs teams of people that quadruple them in levels.
- And there is no player shuffling, so you'll either leave the match, or play again with the same skill disparity. Get bored or get owned.

EDIT: Should've talked about The Feel. You don't feel like a big, chunky, genetically engineered human being that weights a ton and a half. You feel like a normal person, and the actually human infantry feel like hobbits with guns.

Ever played For Honor? For all its flaws, the feeling of WEIGHT it gives the player is a master's touch. Every attack has incredible consequences, and every attack is FELT by both players. It has inertia, it has weight, it makes you feel powerful.

Space Marine won't give you that feeling. You'll be flailing a sword around like it was made of paper. You'll be able to cancel most attacks into a guard stance, as if your character didn't have anything in his hands. You don't have the feeling of inertia that a 1.5 ton boi should have. Instead, you'll flail.

I crave to feel the weight of my actions. Highlander, anybody? Chop chop.

The narrative is shorter than Space Marine 1 (6 missions vs 18. The 6 missions in Operations just give different perspectives of the same narrative through other people). However, it -is- still a very fun and engaging story. By the final mission, my friends and I were looking around and talking about the implications of what we see and we were all like "This is -BAD-, we gotta stop this!"

The main story is fun in multiplayer, and feels like it was designed with it in mind, but it's still good fun in single player as I've tested it, and the AI companions are more than capable of holding their own. Operations mode is multi-player only, and those levels actually feel better designed likely because they're meant to be played with randoms.

The PVP feels good some of the time, but the third-person perspective can lead to some silly situations, like losing engagements where the enemy comes out from behind the left side of a wall, and can see you first, but you can't see him because of the camera placement. That, and snipers are scoped-in with a first-person perspective so they don't have that problem. I hope the kinks are worked out there, but lets be honest here: no one wanted this game for the PvP!

But while we're on the topic... You can play as Chaos in PvP only. But there's no armor customization options, only re-colors. That sucks tremendously.

ALSO, THIS GAME IS VERY BEEFY. OLD LAPTOPS AND COMPUTERS WILL STRUGGLE!! My Nvidia 1070Ti can play on low preset with ~50 FPS. Sometimes lagging during real-time cutscenes or effects-heavy events. Not often enough to disrupt play or become frustrating, though.

The Campaign and Operations portions are really fun and challenging. The combat can take some getting used to, but after a mission or two you've got it pretty good. If you do decide to play Operations, I'd highly recommend finding some buddies to play with, as the AI is pretty brain dead for the most part.

As for the PvP, I'm sure it would be fun if I ever got to play more than 2 seconds of anything but staring at a death screen. There is a huge issue of the other team just being able to sit inside of your spawn and spawn camp you. Playing any game mode but the TDM mode is good, but I would avoid the TDM like a jar of mayo with a condom at the bottom.

I wish that the customization was a little bit more in depth as well, as I typically play Salamanders (who have onyx black skin) or Carcharodons (Who have grey, shark like skin) but your Astartes skin tone is locked to whatever class you're playing. I also wish that Chaos was customizable past just the colors.

Overall, I recommend, but avoid TDM like you would avoid a Florida man on bath salts.

We have before us, the greatest hoard shooter in years.

After GW sh!tting the bed for many years, Sabre Interactive has graced us with the Bloodiest, Manliest, Xenos-killin'ist shooter since Gears of war on the xbox 360.
Every swing of your blessed chainsword feels like it has the weight and gravitas that it deserves for being something wielded by a 9ft tall superman. Every round of the holy bolter chimes in the chorus of metal jet bullets fired into some poor bastards skull. Every execution, a glorious spray of blood and viscera as your space marine dismembers the foul creature with his bare hands.

Combat is a tense dance of evading enemy projectiles, parrying larger enemies for a counter hit and perfect rolling away from deadly attacks. Armour and grey-health are restored upon melee or pistol execution so it often becomes a frantic search for a dying xenos to eviscerate while dodging the entire hoard. When you're not running for dear life, you are cutting through hoards of the enemies with blade and hammer turning the smallest of the brood into red mist so you can focus your attention of the bigger xenos that are casting psykic spells or throwing bombs at you.

Alongside a well made Single/(coop) campaign, there is also (coop) Spec ops missions and pvp deathmatch.

This game was very clearly made by a talented team that love and respect the source materiual. Every cut-scene is a love letter to warhammer 40k and its grand legacy (that shall not be tainted by the traitorous scum within!). Meanwhile the gameplay itself hold lasting weight and competency, showing that these guys simply know how to make a good old fashioned: Damn fun game.

Game runs well on pc. Gtx 2080ti / i7-9700kf / Debian 12 / Proton 9.
After rebinding parry to my mouse thumb button the default pc controlls were pretty good as well. I wouldn't want to aim with anything other than a mouse and using the RMB to melee clicks after a few hours.

Conclusions: Suffer no Herasy and fight for the Imperium brothers!
