As a 40k fan, I was thrilled to dive back into the grimdark universe with Warhammer 40k Space Marines 2. The game delivers an exhilarating blend of brutal combat and rich lore that will resonate deeply with franchise fans. Here’s a breakdown of my experience:

Gameplay & Mechanics:
The core of Warhammer 40k: Space Marines lies in its intense, fast-paced combat. Playing as a Space Marine, you get to wield various heavy weaponry and unleash devastating attacks on hordes of enemies. The gameplay remains engaging throughout, satisfyingly balancing shooting, melee combat, and tactical decision-making. However, one aspect I felt was missing was a cover system. In a universe where strategic positioning is crucial, having the ability to take cover would have added an extra layer of depth to the combat.

Story & Atmosphere:
The narrative is a standout feature. The story is compelling, capturing the essence of the Warhammer 40k universe with its dark, epic tone. The plot draws you into the conflict and keeps you invested in the fate of the Space Marines. Fans of the lore will appreciate the attention to detail and how the story immerses you in the grim realities of the 41st millennium.

Technical Aspects:
I did encounter a few minor bugs along the way, which occasionally detracted from the overall experience. While these were generally not game-breaking, they were noticeable and could impact immersion. Additionally, the absence of achievements for completing Veteran mode was a letdown. For a game that celebrates its challenging gameplay, having achievements tied to higher difficulty levels would have been a rewarding incentive for players looking to test their skills.

Overall:
Despite a few flaws, Warhammer 40k: Space Marines is a fantastic addition to the franchise. It captures the essence of the Warhammer universe with its gripping story and thrilling combat, even if it could benefit from some quality-of-life improvements. For fans of Warhammer 40k, this game is a must-play, offering a satisfying blend of lore and action. If you overlook the minor bugs and the lack of a cover system, you’re in for a solid and enjoyable experience.
The game feels very fun, and even if your not into the 40k lore, the story will be simple to understand and easy to follow. Good introductions to mechanics and overall a great game.

TLDR: The art, animation and sound teams carry this game.

It's weird that I'm 80 hours in and haven't already written a review for this game.

Almost all of my time has been in operations, the game's PvE multiplayer mode. With that as context:

1. The matchmaking is atrocious. Problems range from very long load times between sections (loading from your ship to someone else's ship requires reloading all of the assets from that map, even though it's exactly the same map?) to matchmaking simply not working at all. Frequently you get silently taken out of the matchmaking queue and the game stops even trying to match you with people. You have to quit to the main menu and load back in to fix that.

On top of all of that, the game limits Operations to one of each class, but the matchmaking doesn't account for that limitation. It will indiscriminately dump you in matches where someone already has the class you have selected

2. Combat is gorgeous, visceral and crunchy. It's also horrendously designed.

To get a perfect parry, you have to parry at the start of an attack. To get a perfect dodge, you dodge at the end of an attack. Not a huge deal, but very unintuitive.

The upgrade system for weapons is super pointless. It's your normal babby's first game design stat inflation system. You get more powerful, your enemies get tougher, the equivalence stays more or less the same.

I would've much preferred a system where enemies and weapons were just what they were, unlocks were cosmetics only, and higher difficulties required managing larger groups of enemies. As it is, the upgrade system is an unbalanced stat nightmare and enemies on higher difficulties are extremely bullet-spongy.

Speaking of, the iconic bolt weapons feel terrible. They look at sound amazing (with the exception of the bolt pistol. It sounds like a 9mm), but it takes entire of bolt rounds to kill medium sized enemies. I understand why this is the case from a game-play perspective (they want to encourage melee), but it just feels bad. I would prefer a system where enemies are less spongy and more plentiful.

Fighting Thousand Sons is an exercise in absolute frustration. This game is at it's best when you're mixing melee with ranged, dodging and parrying. It's cinematic.

Thousand Sons, as an enemy faction, is completely anathema to that. Tzaangors are unrealistically tanky and shielded gors will just sit and eat bolter rounds all day. Rather than engaging in glorious melee, if you do try to close on a Rubric Marine, they'll shoot you the entire way in and when you finally get to them, they'll teleport away.

So you're forced to engage in ranged battles in a game that doesn't really have sufficient tools for that. You're too fragile to just stand there and tank incoming fire, but there's usually no cover available. Enemies don't spawn in from any specific direction: they usually just appear all around you. The end result of all of this is your team taking fire from all directions, unable to meaningfully close on enemies to force a melee engagement, all the while being harassed by hordes of invincible Tzaangors. It's a miserable slog.

The biggest complaint I have about combat is to do with horde management; namely, that there isn't any. You're constantly surrounded by smaller enemies and they attack constantly from all sides and each attack takes off a full segment of armor. Space Marines are made of paper in this game. You have extreme tunnel vision from the very narrow and unadjustable default field of view, so you simply cannot see what is around you. Hordes of gaunts should be a nuisance: an appetizer for the main course of larger, stronger enemies, but that's not at all how things actually play out. Five or six medium sized Tyranids is an engaging and dynamic fight, but a horde of little gaunts will chew right through you with no issues.

3. Balance in general is not great. Some classes (the bulwark, for example) are extremely overpowered, while others (assault, specifically) is broken to the point of being non-functional. The melta is so much more effective than other ranged weapons that no one uses anything else. The thunder hammer looks and sounds incredible, but it hits like a wet noodle. It's just a mess.

I'm giving this a thumbs up because I waited a decade for a sequel to Space Marine and the fact that it HAS a mode like Operations is excellent. But the actual implementation leaves a lot to be desired.

As someone who has never engaged in any way with Warhammer 40k content before playing this game, I can definitely say that I only barely understand what's going on. With that said, some of my Warhammer-savvy friends have expressed a great deal of appreciation for the lore accuracy and finer detail of many aspects of the game, and I'm happy to take their word for it. Gameplay wise, this title, as one of my friends put it, "plays like an Xbox 360 game in all of the best ways". He is completely correct in this assertion, based on my experience thus far.

Space Marine 2 presents you with a wider variety of gameplay mechanics than you could ever expect from a conventional shooter, and each of them proves to be well made and thoroughly balanced. None of these mechanics overstay their welcome (though the story begins to drag on towards the climax), and most of them can be experienced much more readily in the non-campaign modes of the game. While the story is somewhat shorter-ended, the detail in every mission and the number of supplementary missions (operations) more than make up for it. There's a lot of replayability here, based on difficulty and loadout, as well as just developing your own skill level.

My predominant complaint is that, in the cooperative mode of the story, the loot density does not seem to have been accurately adjusted to sustain three separate player characters. Healing items in particular are extremely few and far between - which may force you to throw away the Space Marine power fantasy for a brief time in favor of just actually trying to stay alive long enough to see the next section of the level.

Space marine 2 is an amazing game, you feel huge, the guns feel great and the finishers are amazing, but it isn't without its flaws, after completing the campaign and multi-player missions here are my only complaints
1. Healing - Healing is absolutely stupid, you can only heal through stims or damaging enemy's after you've been hit, sounds great in theory but if you get swarmed by little enemy's and someone shooting at you, you just end up at low health for a long time until you find a stim that barely heals you at that, and on top of that armor takes around 30 seconds to naturally regenerate, the health problems NEED to be addressed.

2. Enemy spawning - Spawn locations for enemy's are atrocious, you will complete a wave of enemy's just to end up having a bunch spawn behind you with no heads up; I've died multiple times to heavy units in later levels that spawn directly behind me while we are moving areas

3. Repetitive content - not really a complaint but the PVE multiplayer is extremely repetitive, and the levels are also very linear, would be nice to see new levels added in the future and make them a bit more open

4. Unlock system - The cosmetic unlock system uses the same currency for unlocking perks and weapons, so you end up having to choose between unlocking new weapons or the high priced armor colors and decals

Again, don't get me wrong I'm loving this game but these are some overbearing problems I've found in my play time that i cannot ignore

Basically SM1 with a fresh shiny paint-job and some of the most gorgeous environmental work you've seen in your life. If you liked the first, you'll 100% enjoy this.

Campaign: Short (6-9 hours max), sweet, and highly cinematic. Decent enough storyline for a 40k game, voice acting is superb. No complaints here really. Feels like they're set up for a broad range of potential, very exciting DLC's (not in a bad way).

Operations: very fun with friends, extremely replayable, feels they just need to add more, same as Darktide on release. You *can* play campaign missions with friends as well obviously, but you won't get online cosmetic/perk unlocks doing this. It's a little annoying there's no private lobby option, but that's on the roadmap to be added very soon anyways.

PVP: Probably the "weakest" part of the game right now, feels a little tacked on and barebones. However it is exceedingly fun in a very 2012-ish vibe. Pretty fast matches, no SBMM meaning you're not constantly against sweats, team retainment between matches. They could honestly add just like 6 or so more maps and a few more game-types for variety (why is there no 3v3 option?) and I'd be pretty happy.

Performance: in my experience (3080 + 5800X3D at 4K so granted not a weak system) this is one of the smoothest releases I've seen in a long time, which is very impressive for such a beautiful game. I genuinely don't think I've noticed any frame-drops even when all heresy is breaking loose, and after the hotfix for CPU utilisation my PC wasn't turning into a space-heater either. Servers can definitely be a little janky, more noticeable when playing with friends across the pond or via crossplay, but I'm hopeful this will stabilise as they correct for the number of people playing.
Simply amazing, true to the lore and just a great game that makes a lot of fun. Solo or with friends doesn't really matter. I hope the future brings more such games.

Warhammer II is an absolute gem!

The attention to detail is incredible, and it really honors the Warhammer lore in a way that is easy to appreciate.
The storyline is super engaging, and the animations bring the world to life in a way that just feels right. Plus, the soundtrack? It’s absolutely epic!

Everything about the game—from the assets to the code stability—shows that the team put a lot of love and effort into it. You can tell there’s some fantastic skill and teamwork behind the scenes.

The base campaign is a blast, though I definitely wouldn’t have complained if it were a bit more to it (isn’t that always the case with great games?).

Also, the Operations system was a brilliant decision. It’s an MMO-style LFG and instance system where you can drop in and play a mission that progresses weapon, class skills. I very rarely write reviews, but this game really warrants a shout out. It certainly is worth purchase price.

The long term possible plans for this game are pretty wide open, dlc for more base campaigns, new operations maps. Adding the remaining races and classes from WH40K.

I envision a DLC to where the Astartes are putting down the orc hoards led by Gorgutz with new operations maps. Dakka Dakka!

There are some things, might be a skill issue who knows - the lack of 'healing' since its only in the form of pickups and their 'bloodborne aggression' mechanic (you take hit, you get white bar - deal damage, regain some of that health back.) Likewise, it would be nice to have some achievement unlockables, such as completing the game on certain difficulties, or having distinct achievement unlockables, like completing the game on the highest difficulty, or not going down once the entire game etc.

Overall, very good - i hope they expand on this game like Vermintide, i.e. adding onto one game overtime so it becomes a complete package, rather than segmenting it into another game, as like Darktide/Vermintide/Dawn of War, this is one of those warhammer games that aren't just a cashgrab using the warhammer title - its actually good!

Singleplayer: Everything a 40K Fan can hope for! Delivers exactly what the very first trailer promised!!

Multiplayer: A tedious grind with lackluster operations and way too few maps.

Game is well optimised, even my old machine can run it with decent graphics.

A friend recommended a series to me some time ago, but I didn’t pay much attention until the release of Space Marine 2. After playing it, I found it to be a great game with excellent gameplay, which led me to explore the 40k universe more deeply.

Currently I feel like I had a better time with Saber Interactive's other game, World War Z, but this game has the WH 40K advantage to it, which should help it sustain itself longer than WWZ.

The environment design, as far as Warhammer 40K environments go, is nothing short of amazing.
Movement and combat feels good and weighty, as it should be with space marines - think WWZ but with space marines.
Music is unremarkable - even Darktide had more memorable ambient and battle music.

As with any game, it is only as good as its control interface(s).
The default keyboard & mouse control scheme feels awkward, and ultimately feels like it should've spent more time in the oven.
To be fair, yes, the newer mechanics in this game are new to these developers, but not to other games in existence that have had the same range of actions too, but mapped them to fewer, more concise controls (melee, ADS, shooting, sprinting, dodging, blocking/dodging, abilities).
There is also a dedicated 'sprint' key in this game, which feels redundant since they could've just made a 'walk' key and have everyone sprint all the time instead - like I said all this could've been resolved if they gave it more time to cook, maybe had a few more rounds of quality user testing and feedback, etc.

Mechanics like parrying/blocking could have also been explained better, especially since they can change with weapon upgrades/perks, which could also use better explanation in-game.

The perfect parry window doesn't feel intuitive - it works similar to dark souls where you need to begin the parry earlier and you get punished if you're late, but the saving grace is this game instead forgives you for late parries by turning the parry into a block (that still blocks all damage).
Parries in this game are unlike in Sekiro where your parries are best initiated right at the point of impact/taking damage.

Progression - just like World War Z, the one turn off I have in both games is the amount of grinding you have to do to unlock the better variants of your weapons, skills and equipment. World War Z had the same progression design and at some point they released a bundle of their game with a lot of the equipment already unlocked with extra (progression) currency to boot, probably in hopes of sustaining their dying game. So I imagine this game will have the same bundle released eventually, so if you don't want to grind, I suggest you wait for that to be released and buy that instead.

There are also dumb issues with key rebinding in this game where, for example, if you wanted to rebind the 'E' to 'F', and 'E' was mapped to 2 actions, the game would block you from binding the second one to 'F'.

Rating 8/10

--(Review)--
The game offers a unique combat experience and high replay ability, the campaign and multiplayer are very immersive and cinematic and the classes and content offered offers a large variety and all have good progression paths and variance in ways to play them, on the surface you may see 6 classes, but each has multiple ways to play them and the combination of them on a team makes repeated game play consistently engaging.

For players wanting to only play the story, know that it is relatively short for the price with an average 8 hour play time although the quality of the story and the way the lore is respected and utilized in unique ways made the story very interesting and was a great jumping off point for my friends just starting war hammer, allowing them to ask many questions about the lore and and explore a wide variety of it.

For Multiplayer PVP players I would recommend that you wait, the PVP is very fun and feels fair and balanced, i've seen every class get top of the leaderboard at least once, but the main issue is a lack of maps, which for $60 isn't enough if this is all you plan to play.

Overall it seems the main focus was put into the multiplayer PVE and this created a very satisfying and fun multiplayer experience that has it's unique takes on combat and gun play that make trying different play styles very rewarding without forcing you using push tactics. The campaign holds it's value and the PVP is a fun change of pace, and for $60 if you plan on playing all of this content it feels very complete and is a great package of content that seems to be already planned to be expanded upon.

--(Key Points)--
-Unique and Engaging Combat System
-Cinematic and Diverse Set Pieces and Maps
-Very Lore Friendly and great starting point to learn about universe
-Engaging Multiplayer and Heavy Replay ability
-AI Director has a similar feel to the tide games in the good ways

--(Key Negative Points)--
-Shorter Campaign
-Not enough Multiplayer PVP Map Diversity
-Objectives in PVE maps do not have enough variance when replaying same mission
-Technical issues but I did not see them, I recommend you read reviews that touch on that better to get a fuller picture

Really makes you feel like a space marine.

This game feels like a love letter to Warhammer 40,000.
From the moment you start, you really do feel like a Space Marine.
The combat is brutal and satisfying, with melee attacks feeling visceral and weighty.
The sound effects and music capture the atmosphere of the 41st millennium absolutely.

The game is challenging, especially on the highest difficulty setting.
Shooting is effective but often you'll find yourself surrounded by hordes of enemies, making melee combat a necessity. Engaging in close-quarters battles is exhilarating, as you smash through ranks of foes with ruthless efficiency.
The visuals are stunning, immersing you in the grim darkness of the 41st millennium. Every texture, model and animation fits the feeling of the game.

While the single-player campaign (can be played in co-op) offers variety and a good story, it's the multiplayer modes that truly shine. Operations provides a robust co-op experience, letting you team up with other players to tackle challenging scenarios. Endless War mode is a PvP experience that feels different with each of the classes.

As you level up, you unlock new abilities, acquire better weapons and armor, and alter your appearance. The armor customization is particularly impressive, with dozens of options to personalize your look.

Overall, this game is a must-play for any fan of Warhammer 40,000. It delivers on its promise of an authentic, immersive 40K experience, with plenty of challenges and replay value to keep you engaged.

Next off the weapons and gameplay, ranged is moreso a supplement to melee, but melee is amazing, being able to go from absolutely mauling a swarm of tyranids, to then parrying a warrior and getting a gun kill on it, it all flows into itself so well. The weapons themselves are all distinct enough to be worthy of being different, from fire rate and magazine increases to being a literal flame shotgun.

Finally, the multiplayer, this is the weakest part of the game, but it is still good, so, there's a lot of connection issues currently, not as bad as Helldivers 2, but still some minor bugs, such as getting stuck in the battle barge when a player is connecting and you start the mission. Overall, this game is a 9/10, if they add more co-op and PVP missions, itll be an easy 10/10

Absolutely love the Campaign, as an original Space Marine player from 2012. Combat is satisfying, range of weapons hits the spot. It is going to take me a while to become proficient at melee and learn the attack patterns of all the new opponents.
Online (PvE) is also satisfying so far. There is a nice levelling system for your equipment and lots of customisation available for people like myself that prefer to see the Black Templars Chapter. Some people criticise a lack of ammo and dying too much, but that's the reality of the 40k universe even as a Space Marine. Everything is out to get you and even a regular Tyranid can do some damage to a regular Space Marine. Even if you are a longer ranged Sniper you need to sometimes get your hands dirty with your Combat Knife.
There is still a lot about this game I am discovering and even if I give up after another 15 hours of gameplay I think it was worth it to see this second instalment of Space Marine. Also keep in mind that the original Space Marine game didn't have Exterminatus on release (my favourite game mode), so there could be some chances of additional missions, game modes and other new content on the horizon for this game.
Also, if you're joining a game of PvE, don't expect other players to be able to hear your microphone. By default the volume of the weaponry you're using is going to drown out whatever the hell you're saying. Don't get upset with players who don't seem to be listening to what you're saying, they probably can't hear you over the sounds of the brutal executions and bolter explosions... LOL
Haven't tested PvP but not really interested in it unless there are unique unlocks. Wasn't a fan of the original Space Marine locking some perks behind PvP content, thus far this doesn't look to be the case with this game. 10/10

Genuinely loving this game so far. I enjoyed the first game, and this is even better, controls feel nice, graphically beautiful, and have only ran into a couple of bugs since launch (which is rare nowadays lol). All-in-all, VERY good game off of launch, which is more credit than I can give to most games in this day and age.

I personally love this game when it works. When this game works it's amazing and love every second of it.

Campaign: Game play is fun and addicting and I love how much more in depth the mechanics are compared to the first. The story is far better than the first as well, I love the characters far more. TItus is so much better than the first game and it hooks you right away. I've been playing the campaign co op and it's how it should be played. We've been playing it on Angel of Death difficulty (the hardest difficulty) and honestly I feel the game is to easy. The tutorial was the hardest part of the campaign trying to learn the mechanics and by yourself it felt like the odds were against you. After that the game is basically smooth and pretty easy which kinda disappointed me. Yes we died but it made sense but it didn't feel hard at all. Most bosses we beat on the first try and I didn't feel that I felt challenged which I would like. I haven't beat the campaign fully yet and I'll get to why. So far though the game is amazing and awesome and in my opinion worth the buy for the campaign alone.

Operations: I've only played one match of operations because they're other space marines stories along side the main campaign and it's exactly what I wanted. The game caters to your play style and gives you the options to play 6 different classes and I enjoy the insane customization for your space marine. In the first mission they did reuse some areas of the base campaign but very little most of the areas is new and I'm glad. So far I'm excited to keep going on it.

PVP: Now this is insanely lacking, I really enjoy the multiplayer and I love the maps and how the gameplay transitions to multiplayer. Now for the negatives on this the maps are seriously lacking. 3 MAPS? How do we only have 3 MAPS? The argument is "their focus is PVE" if that's the case don't add multiplayer, 3 maps and only two are memorable then only 3 game modes? It's ridiculous that this game is severally lacking when we could've had so much more stuff within the game that other games had because none of the modes are unique, It's TDM, Domination, and Hardpoint, that's it. I would like to see maybe a game mode where we play the tyranids against 6 Space Marines similar to Gears of War's Beast mode, better maps, balancing on health since I feel like grenades are overpowered, I've thrown it at two enemies who are full health and kills them instantly and they're two different classes with different armor protections. Snipers are inconsistent in multiplayer and really don't feel the best. Progression for weapons in my opinion is pretty slow and with only 3 modes and 3 maps it's going to get boring fast. Thankfully there's a good amount of weapons. My biggest issue though is that the Chaos marines don't have much customization. Most classes have a few weapons and you can't customize any of them, you can't even customize the armor sets and it feels very tacked on. I'm very disappointed and this needs severe changes if not this isn't gonna last like COD's DMZ mode, potential but didn't have the same effort put in. Another issue is constant disconnecting from servers on Sabers end. Just today (9/13/2024) I went in to play pvp and it took me 15min of trying to fix the game to connect just to play 1 game and then loading into the 2nd my game freezes and crashes probably for the 20-30th time owning this game.

Lastly the cons and there's big cons to this game. For the price point and handful delays we shouldn't be getting a buggy mess with so many bugs it makes me want to refund the game. I'm running a RTX 3060 and a Ryzen 5 5600X running mostly High and medium settings, at 1080p and a 165HZ monitor and I've had massive issues. The game is downloaded on a 2T SSD specifically a Samsung-970 EVO Gen 3x4 NVMe and my game crashes every time I play. I will open up the game and instant freeze sometimes taking up to 10min to unfreeze itself. Sometimes it freezes so long I have to click the power button on my PC to turn it off. I thought I was a handful of people but I guess a lot of people playing the game has the same issue. This isn't one game mode it's every game mode I play. Crossplay makes the game bug out causing my friends on the Series X or PS5 have issues joining or having to reset due to them stuck on loading. I probably have the freeze issue happen 3-9 times a day and it is the most infuriating thing of all time. I want to play the game I enjoy it but this makes me feel that the game should be $30. Not $60 or $75 for console with tax. I am a consumer and expect the product to work well at least. This age of games is frustrating having to deal with delay after delay and the game to come out so buggy. If you don't want you immersion to be sucked out so often I would wait til they fix these issues. They have a lot of things to fix and I wouldn't have mind another delay but with a Beta to know the bugs when more people are playing for an extended amount of time because it feels they weren't ready for this launch.

Also add crossplay to PVP I just want to play with my friends who aren't fortunate enough to have PC's the game isn't a twitch shooter like COD it's not an Esports type of game, it's a fun pvp just let me play with my friends and meet new people who might be on a different console. That's how friendships are made and you shouldn't be limiting players from playing with their friends. Cheaters is always going to be an issue and yes I bet there is going to be sweaty people but there's always gonna be those people so just open the flood gate for cross play and allow a toggle button. You did it for console so just add it for everyone please.

I do think this game is amazing but the bugs are massively the biggest issue and need to be fixed ASAP, I don't care if content is delayed. Expecting a game to work should be the standard not the outlier. PVP issues need to also be fixed and it's embarrassing the state it's in. PVE is the only good state about the game but you'll get the whole experience of maps and game modes of PVP within 2-3hrs of playing. I would give this game 9/10 or 10/10 for how fun it is and is a strong contender for game of the year for me along side Black Myth, but right now the game is in a 6/10 range due to how mad the bugs make me. I spend more time fixing bugs than playing the game. my review is conflicting I'm sorry I love this game it's love hate relationship but tired of bugs being the norm of games now.

The more repeatable part of the game is the pve operations and right now there are only 6, but the gameplay is so fun I could (and do) just play even one of them over and over again. More specifically the combat flows really well and the multiple ways you can deal with the enemies keeps combat from getting stale. The space marines feel powerful and like any single enemy would be trivial while the game overall is still challenging. I would highly recommend this game if you like the general style of the combat. Additionally if you are a 40k fan, especially a space marine fan, this game is fantastic. My biggest army in the table top is space marines and this game is extra cool because of my interest in the ip so if you like 40k you will enjoy the game more than the average person. Lastly I don't have strong feelings about the pvp. In my opinion what makes this game great is the pve system and a lot of that is inherently different and lost in pvp. Thats not to say pvp isn't fun but it doesn't have most of what, in my opinion, makes this game really good. A lot of people play the pvp and i assume enjoy it. Overall really great game, especially for 40k fans

This game absolutely needed to happen and it was an unexpected surprise for myself

Space Marine (1) was a fantastic romp as a Space Marine and for a while I believe was the only Third Person WH40K game. I absolutely loved it and it was the game aside from DoW that cemented my love for 40K

And thank the Man Emperor this exists. I went into it blind and I left thoroughly satisfied. Like a Tech Priest and a toaster, or Rogal Dorn and good quality wooden furniture.

Lets break it down. My likes and dislikes about the game.

- This game is very pretty to look at and the effects and shadows are some of the best I'd seen in a game for a while. It is, however, somewhat dull and grey sometimes. It maybe my lighting settings, so do take this as a grain of salt

-I love the soundtrack. It's orchestral and epic. What you expect as a Ultramarine. I imagine there are far more fitting soundtracks for other legions, this one works.

-The sound design is on point, I cannot really think of any real issues. I appreciate the clunky noises, although I think Boltgun did a better job at emulating the weight of Astartes power armour

-Even the voice work is really damn good. Clive Standen does a great job as Titus, even if the absence of Mark Strong can be felt. I appreciate the VA work for Gadriel and Chairon, they were powerful secondaries whom I hope to see in a solo campaign expansion in the future, as we never see the early days of a Primaris Marine

-The Operations mode is a welcome addition to the game, as it expands the campaigns plot and makes for fun replayability. I enjoy being able to mix it up with different customisation and classes, I also enjoy the randomness of it as well. I am also fond of the fact that it contributes to cosmetics and offers more reward than PvP and it seems to be the mode most encouraged to indulge in. I do hope in the future we get something similar to the Chaos Rising portion of Space Marine 1 for this game, as it would be nice to have Traitor Legions in the mix with unique classes and abilities in a PvE environment

-I, for one, feel like the combat is very much a combination of the Arkham games, with a dash of DS1 and Force Unleashed. The executions add a fun twist and I like that Beat Em Up aspect with the melee weapons in this game, even if I don't use them a lot of the time. The gunplay also feels good but I wish it felt punchier and weightier overall.

-The story also feels like it hits the right beats and makes sense, but it also still leaves some lingering questions which warrants an expansion or a sequel. It was also nice that the guard was also featured being a Guardsman guy myself.

-Despite my praise of the visuals, there is no excuse for some of the pre launch/advanced access and the day 1 optimisation. There are people who cannot properly play the game at all in some cases and some of the effects, even with high end rigs, will tank your frames. Even if you set it lower, you will feel the particle effects almost turn your PC into molten slag

-The controls need to be fine tuned before you even start the game, it feels odd some of the keybinds, though this is a minor point

-The constant network issues. I cannot stress this enough, it is frustrating to deal with. It is especially frustrating when your friends cannot do PvE.

-There are some major bugs and glitches that need sorting still, especially pertaining to transitioning to the loading screen on PvE or even Co-op Campaign at times. We are also waiting for Ultrawide and that should've been standard for a game of this visual calibre in my opinion.

-Although I have some reservations and criticisms about the PvP, I will say this: Chaos needs to have some customisation options like the Loyalists, especially with the wide array of Firstborn aesthetics. Hell, I'd like some Firstborn callbacks for the Loyalists, although lore wise, it seems Mark X armour supposedly beats out the OG Mark VII and Mark VIII Errant armour in a lot of ways


My biggest issue is in fact the PvP. I cannot stress this enough: It needs to bake longer.
I will elaborate: It felt like it needed more time cooking or at least a beta to figure out the balancing issues. So far, it feels absolutely useless to melee anything that is lighter than a Bulwark or Heavy class, in fact, melee seems to not penalise the other classes at all, there is no staggering and you can just hip fire to counter. I also feel that it should take notes from TF2 and mix the teams up after each round to make it fair, rather than keep the same squad. It feels like this should've been opened up post launch instead of Horde Mode


To sum up, I recommend this game to a casual fan and 40K fans alike. It is one of this years best games, although, I would wait a little while longer until some of the major bugs are fixed or remedied, especially around the point we get private PvE lobbies and Horde mode.

After further research I figured out my crashing problem. This could help you if you're using a 13th or 14th Gen Core i9 or i7 CPU, the root cause of these issues isn't fully clear, since it could be related to high default power and current limits that some motherboards may use.

Proceed to your motherboard's setting for CPU Configuration, locate Long Duration Power Limit (Package if Asus Board) should be set to 243 by default it's set to auto, do the same for Short Duration Power Limit (Package if Asus Board).
Finally, CPU Current Limit should be set to 307, & save exit.

Current Specs:
13th Gen i9-13900K
Nvidia GeForce RTX 4090
32GB Ram DDR5 overclocking @ 7000mhz

Just as an fyi, I'm running this game at 4k, and on a SSD at Ultra Settings.
Hope this helps, and purge this heresy!!!
